Title: Patient Presentation – Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Mr. John Thompson  a 63-year old Caucasian male  has presented with a suspected case of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). His primary complaints involve pain and swelling in his right calf which he noticed four days ago. The patient describes the pain as being constant and getting worse when standing. He also noticed redness and warmth over the painful area.  He is an electrician by trade and spends many hours per day on his feet. He is a nonsmoker and mentions that he does not engage in regular physical activity aside from his demanding job. He admits to moderate alcohol consumption  averaging around 10-15 units per week.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  for which he takes bisoprolol 5mg daily. He also had an appendectomy at age 12 and a hernia repair at age 40. His mother had a history of a stroke  and his father died from a heart attack at age 75.  He denies any recent travel or periods of prolonged immobility and states he doesn't have any history of blood clot disorders in his family. He admits to situational stress but denies generalized anxiety or depressive symptoms.   This combination of prolonged periods of standing  moderate alcohol consumption  and a history of hypertension are potential risk factors contributing to Mr. Thompson's presentation. His age  gender  and hereditary factors (i.e.  family history of cardiovascular events) may also play a role in his risk for DVT.  Given the patient's presentation and past medical history  a thorough evaluation is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other potential causes of his symptoms. If confirmed  initiating appropriate treatment for DVT including anti-coagulation therapy  lifestyle changes  and possible referral to a specialist will be the next steps.

Title: Patient Presentation - Deep Vein Thrombosis  Introduction: Today  we have a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a case presentation of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient is a non-smoker and moderate drinker  employed as a long-distance truck driver. His lifestyle is generally sedentary with minimal physical activity. He carries a diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus which is under control with Metformin. Additionally  he lives with moderate hypertension  managed with a combination of beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and regular monitoring.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of pain and swelling in his left lower leg. He further reported a mild rise in body temperature over the past couple of days but did not measure it. The pain escalated over the previous three days  leaving him in a state of discomfort and limitation of movement.  Family History: His family history includes his father dying at the age of 68 due to myocardial infarction and a sister currently living with systemic lupus erythematosus. Moreover  his maternal grandmother had a known history of deep vein thrombosis.  Clinical Examination: Upon physical examination  the patient’s left leg was noticeably swollen and red  particularly in the calf area. A positive Homan’s sign was observed. The remaining systemic examination revealed no abnormalities.  Investigations: Preliminary blood work revealed a slightly elevated D-dimer level. An ultrasound of the leg confirmed a thrombus in the left posterior tibial vein  thus determining the diagnosis as Deep Vein Thrombosis.  Risk factors: Given the sedentary nature of his job  a history of systemic hypercoagulable conditions in the family  his age  and the presence of comorbidities such as diabetes and hypertension  this patient has multiple risk factors for developing DVT.  Plan for Management: We immediately start him on a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)  in accordance with standard DVT treatment protocol. We will also encourage him to elevate his leg regularly  wear compression stockings  and maintain regular movement to facilitate circulation. Long term anticoagulation therapy will be initiated. Lifestyle modifications and frequent follow-ups will be encouraged to monitor for improvements and potential complications.  In Conclusion: In conclusion  our patient is a 58-year-old male with numerous risk factors for DVT  including his lifestyle  personal medical history  and family history. With timely diagnosis and appropriate management  we aim to alleviate his current symptoms and prevent severe complications such as a pulmonary embolism.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Demographic Information: Our patient is Mrs. Susan Thompson  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  retired high school teacher  residing in Springfield  Illinois. Mrs. Thompson is non-smoker and non-alcoholic. She lives with her husband and engages in routine domestic activities with limited physical exhortation. She reports being on a balanced diet and has no known food allergies. She has a body mass index (BMI) of 31  which classifies her as obese.  Presenting Complaint: Mrs. Thompson presented to the outpatient department complaining of a swollen  warm  and painful left lower limb which had been gradually worsening over past week. The pain is more detectable when she stands or walks. She denied any history of injury to the leg. On further inquiry  she complained of occasional left-sided chest discomfort that resolved spontaneously.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Thompson has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both conditions managed well with medication. She was diagnosed with hypothyroidism 10 years ago  and is currently taking Levothyroxine. She also had a minor myocardial infraction 4 years ago  from which she reports a complete recovery. She has not had any surgical interventions. From the report  it is noted that Mrs. Thompson had a long flight journey a week before her symptoms started.  Family and Social History: There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases; her father had a stroke at the age of 72 and one of her elder brothers is on medication for coronary artery disease. Mrs. Thompson used to be a passive smoker as her husband smoked but he quit 2 years ago.   Examination: On physical examination  the left lower limb was visibly swollen with a slight increase in local temperature. There was tenderness on deep palpation. The overlying skin was not showing any discoloration or inflammation. Pulses were palpable and symmetrical  no altered sensation was detected in the lower limb.   Investigations: Considering the clinical history and examination findings  she was investigated for deep vein thrombosis. An Ultrasound Doppler of her left lower limb was done  confirming a blood clot in the deep veins of the leg. Initial at-rest echocardiogram was normal. Blood tests showed slightly raised D-dimer levels  but normal complete blood count  kidney function and liver function tests.  Given this presentation and her recent long-distance travel  a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis was made. Further management strategies will be discussed in a multidisciplinary team.

Patient Presentation:  Demographics:   Our patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who resides in an assisted living facility in Miami  Florida. She is a retired school teacher  a widowed with two children. The patient is a lifelong non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol. Past Medical History:  She has a documented history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with medications. The patient had bilateral total knee replacement surgery eight years ago due to osteoarthritis  after which she developed a right-sided deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Medications:   She takes Metformin 1000 mg twice daily for type 2 diabetes  Lisinopril 10 mg daily for hypertension  and Warfarin 5 mg daily for DVT prevention. She also occasionally uses Paracetamol for joint pains.  Family History:  The patient's family history includes hypertension in her late father  and her mother had type 2 diabetes. Her elder brother also had a deep vein thrombosis after undergoing hip replacement surgery.  Social History:  The patient retired five years ago and is now living in an assisted living facility. She leads a mostly sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity. She has a healthy diet consisting of foods low in salt and sugar. She does not use alcohol or tobacco and has no reported drug allergies.  In summary  this patient has multiple risk factors for DVT including her age  earlier DVT  sedentary lifestyle  and prior knee surgeries. Therefore  further investigation is warranted to confirm the suspected diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:   ""I would like to present a 60-year-old Caucasian male patient named Mr. John Smith. He hails from Boston  Massachusetts and is a retired attorney. He lives with his wife and has three adult children. He is a non-smoker but admits to drinking alcohol moderately.  Mr. Smith came into the clinic concerned about a persisting pain and swelling in his right leg  especially in the calf area. In the past week  the symptoms have been amplified  accompanied by a slight fever and a warm touch over the area. Upon examination  the leg displays a red and somewhat bluish discoloration.   His past medical history indicates chronic hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both conditions controlled with medication - Losartan and Atorvastatin  respectively. He also underwent a total knee replacement surgery 5 months ago on his right knee  following which he reported being less physically active than usual due to recovery.   There is no family history of clotting disorders. However  he did mention that his father suffered from late-onset Type 2 diabetes.   Mr. Smith's symptoms suggest the possibility of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  possibly due to his recent knee surgery and a decrease in physical activity. Further diagnostic tests  including D-dimer Test  Duplex Ultrasound  or Venography  will be required to confirm the diagnosis.""   Our team's immediate plan for Mr. Smith includes a prompt assessment of his DVT risk and possible initiation of anticoagulant medication  pending his diagnostic test outcomes. We will also need to educate him on measures to manage these symptoms  including elevating the leg and using compression stockings. His case could benefit from a multidisciplinary approach  with involvement from the primary care provider  vascular surgeon  and a physical therapist in future treatment decisions.

Presentation of Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Demographics: Patient: Mr. John Doe Age:    60 Years Sex:    Male Race:   Caucasian Occupation: Retired Army Officer Home Address: 250 Main Street  Seattle  Washington  WA98101  Presenting Symptom: Mr. John Doe is presenting with a 3-day history of swelling  pain  and slight discoloration (reddening) in the left lower leg.  Medical History: Mr. Doe has a known history of hypertension which has been controlled with medication for the past 10 years. 5 years ago  the patient had undergone a total right hip replacement surgery following a fall.   Family History: His father died of a stroke at age 75  and his mother died of heart disease at age 80. There is no known family history of blood clotting disorders.  Social History: He does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. He is a social drinker  consuming around 2-3 glasses of wine per week. Based on the information supplied  he is physically active with regular walking and light exercises as part of his daily routine.  Additional Information: Mr. Doe recently travelled overseas requiring prolonged immobilization during the flight which potentially indicates the trigger for venous thromboembolism.   Current Medications: Lisinopril for hypertension. He is not on any blood thinners at the time of this visit.  Physical Exam Findings: Lower left leg is swollen  warm to touch and red. The circumference of the left calf is 3cm greater than the right. Notable pain on dorsiflexion of the left foot (positive Homan's sign). No ulcers or varicosities are visible.  Given Mr. Doe's medical history of hypertension  recent prolonged immobilization  family history of stroke and current presenting symptoms  the likelihood of deep vein thrombosis is a significant concern and will need to be immediately evaluated with a Doppler ultrasound. If confirmed  anti-coagulation therapy should be initiated.

Presentation Title: A Case of Deep Vein Thrombosis   Slide 1: Patient Introduction Our patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian male by the name of Mr. Brown  currently residing in Houston  Texas. He works as a software programmer and lives a majority sedentary lifestyle. He is a former smoker and has a family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Slide 2: Medical Background Mr. Brown has a past medical history notable for obesity  with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 33. He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus eight years ago and Hypertension five years ago. He has been managing these conditions with oral medication. However  his compliance with the prescribed medication and therapeutic lifestyle changes has been mediocre. Previous hospital admissions include an appendectomy twenty years ago. He does not have any known allergies.  Slide 3: Current Presentation Mr. Brown presented himself in the emergency room due to increasing pain and swelling in his left leg  which has been persistent over the past week. He also reported a recent prolonged period of sitting due to a software project deadline. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or any other systemic symptoms.  Slide 4: Clinical Examination A physical examination revealed a warm  erythematous  and swollen left calf. His vitals were stable but his blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/95 mmHg. His cardiovascular examination was normal  with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The rest of his examination was unremarkable.  Slide 5: Diagnosis and Management Given the clinical presentation and risk factors  a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) was suspected. After an ultrasound confirmed the presence of DVT  Mr. Brown was started on anticoagulants. A patient education session was conducted to improve his medication compliance and lifestyle changes. He will also receive therapy to manage his weight  diabetes  and hypertension to reduce the risk of recurrence of DVT in the future.  Slide 6: Takeaway  Mr. Brown’s case emphasizes the pivotal role of lifestyle modification and vigilant management of chronic diseases  like diabetes and hypertension  in preventing complications such as DVT. It also shed light on the importance of early recognition and management of such conditions to thwart life-threatening situations.   Slide 7: References & Acknowledgement  We thank the team of doctors and nurses who provided care for Mr. Brown. We also extend our thanks to Mr. Brown for allowing his case to be shared for educational purposes.

Patient Presentation:  I would like to introduce Mr. Robert Smith  a 65-year old Caucasian male with a primary complaint of swelling and pain in his right lower extremity. His symptoms started approximately 2 days ago and have been progressively worsening. Along with this  he also mentions that there is noticeable warmth and redness in the same area.  Before this  Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  both of which are well managed with medications. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years back but had a 30-year history of half-a-pack cigarettes a day. He is not a known case of any hematological disorders  though he does express that he has been leading a sedentary lifestyle  especially since his retirement 5 years ago.   A month back  Mr. Smith had undergone an orthopedic surgery for a total hip replacement after a fall he had at his home  resultantly leading to restricted movements post-op. He neglects any history of similar symptoms in the past or any family history of blood clotting disorders.   There is no history of chest pain  shortness of breath  or hemoptysis. His medications include Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for his diabetes. He also reported occasional use of OTC Ibuprofen for arthritis pain.   Initial physical examination findings show the right calf circumference to be significantly larger than the left  with a tenderness along the line of the deep venous system. His vital signs were stable with a blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg  heart rate of 82 bpm  temperature at 98.7°F  and with an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air.  Given his recent surgery  the nature of the symptoms  and his mostly sedentary lifestyle  there is a high suspicion of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Further diagnostic tests including a D-dimer assay and venous Doppler ultrasonography of the lower limb will be conducted for confirmation.  Additionally  an assessment for pulmonary embolism will also be considered due to the potential risk in a DVT patient. For immediate medical plan  we are considering starting anticoagulation therapy.

Slide 1: Introduction Our patient for today's presentation is a 68-year-old male of Caucasian descent named Mr. Smith who presented with deep vein thrombosis.  Slide 2: History of Present Illness Mr. Smith has a progressive history of experiencing unusual leg pain and swelling in his right calf over the past 72 hours. The pain was initially intermittent and mild  but has progressively become more constant and severe. He also reported increased warmness of his right calf and notable redness.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Mr. Smith is a retired coal miner who has been previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension. He suffered a mild stroke four years ago. His medications include Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Simvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  Slide 4: Social History  Mr. Smith is a former smoker  he quit 10 years ago after smoking a packet a day for 40 years. He is a moderate alcohol drinker  consuming average of one to two glasses of wine daily. He lives with his wife and leads a somewhat sedentary lifestyle.   Slide 5: Familial History  His family history includes a father who died of a heart attack at age 73  and a mother who died at 80 with unspecified dementia. His younger brother had a Pulmonary Embolism at the age of 66.  Slide 6: Assessment  Based on his symptoms  history of prolonged inactivity  familial history  and his past medical history – specifically his age  history of stroke and hyperlipidemia is at high-risk for deep vein thrombosis.  Slide 7: Summary In summary  Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old man with a significant history predisposing him to deep vein thrombosis and higher-risk prognosis due to his history of cardiovascular diseases. The recent development of constant and severe leg pain along with swelling in his right calf suggests complications  possibly a deep vein thrombosis.  Next steps would involve laboratory investigations  ultrasound  and if confirmed  appropriate treatment involving anticoagulants  lifestyle changes  and possibly thrombectomy to prevent further complications such as pulmonary embolism. Further patient and caregiver education about disease management and prevention will also be a crucial step.

Title: Presentation of a Case of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Introduction: We bring to you a case of a 68-year-old Caucasian female patient presenting symptoms indicative of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Contextual Identification: The patient  Mrs. Bonnie Thompson  resides in Augusta  Georgia  living an independent and mostly sedentary lifestyle. She is retired  widowed  and has two children. Mrs. Thompson was a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  and has a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Thompson has a recorded history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes  all of which have been managed with medications for the past 15 years. She also has a history of obesity. Five years ago she underwent a total hip replacement due to osteoarthritis. Notably  she has previously denied any history of strokes  myocardial infarctions  or blood clotting disorders.  Present Illness: The patient presented to the ER with primary complaints of increasing pain  redness  and swelling in her right lower leg  which she first noticed 3 days ago. She also mentioned a feeling of warmth over the swollen area of her leg and slight shortness of breath. However  she denied any chest pain  palpitations  or blackout. On examination  her right calf was found to be swollen and tender.  Lifestyle Factors: Mrs. Thompson's daily routine majorly involves reading  knitting  and watching TV. Although she has a mild level of physical activity  including a habit of taking short walks around her neighborhood daily  she follows an unhealthy diet which consists largely of processed and fried foods.  Possible Diagnosis and Future Steps: Considering her symptoms  past medical history  and lifestyle  we suspect a possible Deep Vein Thrombosis in the right lower limb  which may put her at risk for pulmonary embolism due to her shortness of breath. We would consider immediate ultrasound assessment for confirmation of the DVT and evaluate for pulmonary embolism while starting her on anticoagulation. It is also important to review her current medications  lifestyle  dietary habits  and diabetes management.   Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of considering Deep Vein Thrombosis in elderly patients presenting symptoms of leg pain  redness  and swelling  especially in the presence of risk factors such as previous surgeries  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  hypertension  diabetes  and family history of cardiovascular diseases. Treatment interventions  lifestyle modification  and diet counseling will be significant in managing Mrs. Thompson's condition.

Title: Case Presentation on Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:  Mr. Robert Davis  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  who resides in Houston  TX  had been working as an accountant for the past 30 years. He practices sedentary lifestyle  admitting to lack of exercise and a diet high in fats and sugars. He is 5 ft. 11 in.  weighs 240 lbs (BMI 33.5)  and a regular smoker for 20 years. He currently lives with his wife and two children.  Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Davis presented to the hospital with complaints of warmth  edema  erythema  and tenderness in the left calf for the past 2 days. When asked about any recent injuries  the patient denied  but admitted to experiencing early sign of discomfort in the leg a fortnight ago but didn't seek medical attention.  Past Medical History:  He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago which is inadequately controlled with metformin. His most recent HbA1c was 8.2%. He also has Hypertension for 12 years and on Lisinopril  now controlled (BP  140/85). Patient has a history of Pulmonary Embolism 5 years ago  secondary to DVT from prolonged immobilization following a road traffic accident. Patient has a family history of coagulation disorders - mother had DVT; brother with Factor V Leiden mutation. Patient had an appendectomy at the age of 22.   The combination of his personal medical history  family history  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  and nicotine dependence appears to have culminated into his current condition of Deep Vein Thrombosis.  Physical Examination:  The physical examination revealed the left lower limb to be swollen  warm to touch and presented a deep reddish coloration and edema when compared to the right lower limb. No findings were noted from the other systems.  Conclusion: A diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis is suspected based on patient's history and examination. Prompt diagnostic assessment to confirm our presumptive diagnosis is mandatory  optimizing his management approaches from simple lifestyle interventions  anticoagulation  to invasive procedures  all aimed at preventing a fatal Pulmonary Embolism.

Patient Presentation: Mrs. Julia Roberts  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department today complaining of severe pain in her right calf which started approximately 4 days ago.   Demographics: Mrs. Roberts lives in a suburban area of Nebraska  United States with her husband. She is a retired nurse and currently a homemaker. She has a history of 40 pack-years of smoking but quit smoking around ten years ago. Mrs. Roberts drinks alcohol occasionally and is not known to use any illicit drugs. She has a body mass index of 31  suggesting that she is clinically obese.   Past Medical History: Mrs. Roberts has a significant medical history that includes type 2 diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidaemia  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She was hospitalized twice  once in 1995 for an appendectomy  and more recently  in 2018 for an episode of pneumonia. She has never had any clot or thrombosis-related conditions in the past.   Her medications include Metformin 1000mg twice a day for her diabetes  Losartan 25 mg once a day for hypertension  and Advair (fluticasone and salmeterol) diskus as needed for her COPD. In addition  she has been routinely taking a low-dose aspirin as recommended by her primary care physician.   Family History: Mrs. Roberts has a positive family history of cardiovascular disease. Her father died from a stroke at age 76 and her mother had Coronary Artery Disease.   Summary: Mrs. Roberts' clinical presentation and hypercoagulable condition places her at an increased risk for deep vein thrombosis  which seems to be the most likely diagnosis given her acute onset calf pain. Further medical evaluation is recommended to confirm the diagnosis and outline appropriate treatment measures.

Patient Presentation:  Today we are discussing the case of Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting with a classic case of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  He is a retired school teacher  a non-smoker with moderate alcohol consumption  who lives with his wife in suburban Chicago. His primary language is English  and he is of Irish-Scottish ancestry. He is fairly active with regular involvement in community clubs and walking his dog.  His past medical history is significant. He has been managed for hypertension for the last 15 years  and Type II diabetes for 10 years. He also has a history of prostate cancer for which he underwent successful surgical treatment 5 years ago.  Mr. Smith reported that he recently underwent a hip replacement surgery about three weeks ago. Since then  he has been primarily sedentary  spending most of his time sitting or lying down  which may have contributed to his current condition.  Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Smith was brought to the ER complaining of pain  swelling  warmth  and redness in his left calf  which has progressively worsened over the past week. He reported no chest pain or dyspnea.   Vitals upon presentation:   BP: 140/80 mmHg Pulse: 80 bpm Temperature: 98.8°F  Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute   The given symptoms along with the recent orthopedic surgery and sedentary lifestyle suggested a possible DVT.   Further investigation is necessary for a definitive diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.    In conclusion  Mr. Smith's case underscores the importance of post-operative mobility and the risk factors associated with prolonged immobility leading to conditions like DVT.

Title: Patient Case Presentation – Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: The patient is Mr. John Doe  a 56-year-old Caucasian male  currently working as an accountant in a multi-national corporation. History of Present Illness: The patient's symptoms began a week ago  starting with mild discomfort that has progressively worsened. Mr. Doe admits to being largely sedentary at his desk job  with few opportunities for physical activity. His condition has started to affect his mobility and daily life tasks.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a past history of hypertension  which he manages with medication and occasional visits to his healthcare provider. He had a myocardial infarction five years ago  with successful angioplasty performed. The patient is also obese  with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31. He has been working from home due to COVID-19 restrictions  which has significantly reduced his physical activity.  Review of Systems: Negative  except as mentioned in the HPI.  Summary: Taken together  the clinical manifestations such as persistent pain in the left lower leg  leg swelling  tenderness  coupled with the risk factors of prolonged immobility  hypertension  past history of cardiovascular disease  and obesity  render a presumptive diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Further diagnostic procedures  including Doppler Ultrasound  D-dimer blood test  and possibly venography  will be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:   Our patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith  who has been presented to the emergency department with symptoms of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Mr. Smith's demographic details are as follows:  - Age: 62 - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired engineer - Residence: Urban  nonsmoker  drinks alcohol occasionally - Marital status: Married with 2 grown children  In terms of past medical history  Mr. Smith has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with medications for the last 5 years. He also underwent an arthroscopic knee surgery six weeks ago.   There is a history of on and off pain in the right leg for about a month now. Mr. Smith informs the pain to have escalated in the past two days leading him to urgent care with the inability to walk without severe discomfort.   In addition to the direct relation to his symptoms  it’s worth noting that his father died from stroke and his mother passed away because of heart failure. This familial tendency for cardiovascular disease places Mr. Smith into a higher-risk category for Deep Vein Thrombosis. Title: Clinical Presentation of a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: Mrs. Lauren Baines  a 73-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher  currently living alone. She presents with complaints of swelling  pain  and warmth over her left lower leg that has been progressively worsening over the past several days.   Past Medical History: Mrs. Baines has a significant past medical history that includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus—all of which are under reasonable control via medications. She underwent a total knee replacement surgery in her right knee six years ago. She is a nonsmoker but reports occasional alcohol use. Her father had a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and her mother suffered a stroke in her older age. Patient recalls being declared positive for Factor V Leiden mutation  an inherited disorder that predisposes to hypercoagulability  about a decade ago.  Current Medications: She takes Metformin (500 mg twice daily)  Lisinopril (5 mg once daily)  and Atorvastatin (20 mg once daily at night). She does not take any regular antiplatelet or anticoagulant medication.  Clinical Examination: Upon physical examination  her left calf appears swollen and erythematous  approximately 3 cm larger in circumference compared to the right one. On palpation  the entire left lower limb is warmer than the right and she complains of tenderness along the deep venous distribution. Her vital signs are stable.  Although formal diagnostic confirmation is yet to be done via Doppler ultrasound scans  these findings are highly suggestive of DVT  in a high-risk patient with numerous predisposing factors such as age  hereditary causes  recent immobility  past hospitalizations  and surgeries  etc.  Plan: She was admitted for further investigation and management. Anticoagulant medications have been initiated immediately in view of her symptoms and the high probability of DVT. A consult was sent to a vascular surgeon  and if confirmed  she may require long-term anticoagulation therapy. Further management would be decided based on her diagnostic tests results and the specialist's recommendations. Her other chronic conditions will be managed accordingly and a complete medication review will be conducted. A multi-disciplinary team approach will be adopted for overall care and to prevent any possible complications.

Title: A Clinical Presentation of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Profile: Patient: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired school teacher Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with the chief complaint of persistent pain and swelling in the left lower extremity noticed since the past one week. The pain is described as aching and increases when standing or walking. He also notices warmth and redness over the area.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 10 years  controlled on Metformin. He was previously diagnosed with hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  managed by Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively. He underwent a knee replacement surgery on his right leg 3 years ago due to osteoarthritis. John is a former smoker but quit 15 years ago. It is necessary to start appropriate management immediately due to the risk of potential life-threatening complications of a possible pulmonary embolism.

[Slide 8: Lessons Learned] ""This case reminds us of the importance of considering deep vein thrombosis in patients presenting with unilateral leg pain  especially those with risk factors such as sedentary lifestyle  history of cardiovascular disease  and a family history of venous thromboembolism.""

Patient's Presentation:   Name: Jane Smith Age: 52 years old Gender: Female Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Office worker Insurance: Private insurance Source of Report: Self-referred  Presenting Complaint:  The patient  a 52-year-old Caucasian woman named Jane Smith  presented to the clinic with swelling  warmth  and redness on her left leg along with moderate to severe pain. The pain was characterized as a constant  dull ache that seems to escalate when she walks or moves her leg. Additionally  she reported feelings of tenderness in the inflamed region.   Past Medical History:  A thorough examination of her medical history indicated that she had been previously diagnosed with obesity and hypertension. She also sustained fractures in her left leg from a vehicular accident five years ago which required her to be immobile for a considerable amount of time in a cast. She revealed that she is also a smoker  smoking around a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 26 years. However  she was not aware of any personal or familial history of coagulation disorders or any other significant systemic diseases.  Lifestyle & Family History:  Jane leads a sedentary lifestyle due to her office work  spending most of her day sitting at her desk. She has a family history of heart disease  with her father passing away from a myocardial infarction in his early sixties and her mother currently living with congestive heart failure.  Clinical Assessment & Conclusion:  Upon assessment  the symptoms along with the patient’s medical history and lifestyle pointed towards a potential case of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). D-dimer test was ordered to check for clot degradation and Doppler ultrasound was scheduled for visual confirmation of the thrombus. The patient was advised about the severity of her condition and the importance of immediate treatment was emphasized. Management plan was drawn up promptly  considering the severity of the condition and potential further complications like Pulmonary Embolism.

Title: Case Presentation - Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: Name: Mrs. Jane Smith. Age: 68 years Sex: Female Address: 3212 Oak Street  Syracuse  NY  Presenting Condition: Mrs. Smith presents with symptomatic deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She complained of persistent  throbbing pain in her left lower leg  with notable swelling. The leg is warm to the touch and has a reddish discoloration. On examination  the Homan's sign is positive – pain in the calf upon dorsiflexion of her foot and knee at 90-degree flexion.   Past Medical History: Mrs. Smith has a significant past history involving various conditions.  1. Cardiovascular: Hypertension (diagnosed 8 years ago) - Maintained on Lisinopril. 2. Endocrine: Type II Diabetes Mellitus (diagnosed 12 years ago) - Well controlled with Metformin and diet regulation. 3. Orthopedic: She suffered a fracture of the right femur 6 months ago and remained mainly immobile in the recovery period. 4. Gastrointestinal: She undergone a cholecystectomy 3 years ago due to gall bladder stones. 5. Smoking: She is a former smoker and quit 15 years ago.  Personal and Social History: Mrs. Smith is a retired school teacher. She lives with her husband and has two children living out of state. She drinks alcohol occasionally and does not have any known drug allergies. Mrs. Smith lives a sedentary lifestyle  which became increasingly inactive following her femur fracture. She had limited physical therapy and has a family history of DVT  with her mother experiencing it at a comparable age.  Risk Assessment: Given her age  extended periods of immobility  a positive family history  and chronic conditions like hypertension and diabetes  Mrs. Smith is at a high risk for the development of DVT. Furthermore  her recent orthopedic history  involving a significant period of immobilization  has likely been contributing factors in DVT development.  In conclusion  Mrs. Smith's presentation  coupled with her personal and medical history  underscore deep vein thrombosis. Immediate initiation of appropriate treatment and lifestyle modifications are recommended for stabilization and secondary prophylaxis.

Patient Presentation  Introduction: We are discussing a case of a 68-year-old Caucasian female who is currently under evaluation for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Demographics: Patient lives in a suburban area and is a retired school teacher. She is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol socially  and exercises moderately. Her family history has been significant for cardiovascular disease  with both parents having succumbed to heart-related disorders.  Presenting Problem: The patient came in complaining of increased swelling  tenderness  pain  and warmness in the right lower extremities  which she noticed a few days ago. The pain is exacerbated on walking and standing. She mentions no recent long-distance travel  surgeries  or injuries.  Medical History: The patient has a known medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes  both of which are well-controlled with medications. A detailed medication history reveals daily administration of Metformin and Lisinopril. The patient has been compliant with her medications and follows a recommended diabetic diet plan.   She had a hysterectomy 20 years ago due to uterine fibroids and a motor vehicle accident in her teens resulted in a fractured tibia  which was treated with internal fixation.  Evaluation: On physical examination  her lower right leg is noticeably swollen  warm to touch  and shows signs of erythema. The patient winces when the calf muscle is squeezed  indicating pain. Initial ultrasound investigation has shown positive signs of clot formation in the deep veins of the right leg.   Summary: This patient's age  personal health history  and the symptomatic presentation are all highly suggestive of deep vein thrombosis. Further analysis is required to confirm this and plan the appropriate treatment strategy to prevent potential complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male named John Doe. He presents today with an acutely swollen  warm  and painful left calf. He states that he noticed the swelling about two days ago and has been feeling generally unwell with intermittent low-grade fevers.   His past medical history includes hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a recent hip replacement surgery on the same side about three weeks ago. The patient admits to a sedentary lifestyle and long periods of immobility post-surgery  as he lives alone and hasn’t been getting out much. Social history reveals that he is an ex-smoker  having quit 15 years ago  and drinks alcohol occasionally. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases with his father dying from a myocardial infarction in his late 60s. Mr. Doe does not have any known allergies.   His current home medications include ramipril for hypertension and rosuvastatin for hypercholesterolemia. Recently  he was on post-operative prophylactic low molecular weight heparin  which stopped a week ago.   On examination  his left calf is significantly swollen and tender along the deep venous route with noticeable erythema. On palpation  the left calf is considerably warmer than the right  there is a palpable cord feeing in the calf region consistent with a superficial vein becoming hard and tender. He had a positive Homan's sign.  Given the patient's surgery history  symptoms  and physical exam  there is a high clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left lower extremity  which is concerning due to the risk of pulmonary embolism. Immediate diagnostic studies  specifically a venous Doppler ultrasound  has been ordered to confirm the diagnosis. An intervention plan will be initiated based on the findings.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Demographics:  Patient is Mr. John Doe  a 58-year-old Caucasian male. He works as an corporate attorney and is a smoker for approximately 20 years  consuming a pack of cigarettes per day. His alcohol use is moderate  and body mass index (BMI) is 30  which classifies him as obese. Mr. Doe lives alone after his divorce five years ago. He has no consistent exercise regimen and frequently reports prolonged periods of immobility due to the nature of his job.   Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Doe reports an acute onset of pain and swelling in his left lower leg  which he initially dismissed as muscular cramp. However  the pain has been worsening over the past 24 hours  which led him to seek medical care. He further reports experiencing a feeling of warmth over the swollen area  and noticed that the skin is slightly discolored (red).  Past Medical History: Review of Mr. Doe's medical record reveals he has hypertension which he has been managing for last 10 years with lisinopril. Moreover  he was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus three years ago which is being managed by oral hypoglycemics. His last HbA1c three months ago was 7.8%. Unfortunately his compliance with his medications has been questionable due to his hectic work schedule. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 62 and his elder sister had a DVT following a long-haul flight 5 years ago.   Clinical Status: Mr. Doe appeared distressed due to pain  however his vital signs were stable. On physical examination  his left lower leg was markedly swollen  warm and erythematous. He displayed a positive Homan's sign. Initial ultrasound confirmed the presence of a thrombosis in the left popliteal vein  and D-dimer was significantly elevated  thus confirming the diagnosis of DVT.   Treatment:  Treatment was initiated promptly with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)  and patient was referred to a vascular surgeon for further evaluation and possible thrombectomy. Patient education was also conducted with regards to the importance of medication compliance  lifestyle modifications  and deep vein thrombosis disease management.  Prognosis:  The prognosis is uncertain due to his chronic medical conditions and lifestyle  but with proper adherence to treatment and lifestyle modifications  risk of recurrence and complications can be significantly reduced. Early detection and intervention have improved his chance of recovery significantly.

Title: Clinical Presentation of a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Profile: The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian female named Mrs. Jane Doe. She is a retired school teacher residing in New York City with her spouse. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. She maintains a healthy diet and performs a moderate level of physical activity regularly.   Past Medical History: Mrs. Doe has a history of medical conditions including Hypertension (HTN) and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM). She was diagnosed with these conditions 10 years ago and has been managing them through lifestyle interventions and medication. She takes Lisinopril (10mg daily) for HTN and Metformin (500mg twice daily) for T2DM. Additionally  she is overweight with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 28. There is no relevant family history of any genetic/coagulopathy disorders.  Current Presentation: Mrs. Doe reported to the emergency department complaining about a subtly progressive pain in her left leg that began five days prior. The pain was dull  continuous but non-radiating. She also noted that her left leg appeared swollen and slightly warmer to touch than her right leg. No discoloration was observed.   She further reported not having any recent history of prolonged immobility  surgical operations  major traumas  or long-haul air travel. She denies any chest pain  cough  shortness of breath  or abdominal pain.   Examinations and Investigations: Upon clinical examination  her left calf showed signs of swelling  tenderness  warmth  and erythema. Vital signs were within normal ranges. A Doppler Ultrasound was performed that confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the left femoral vein  hence establishing the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Conclusion: Together with the clinical presentation and the results of the diagnostic tests  Mrs. Doe was diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis. The present episode of DVT could likely be triggered by her existing HTN  T2DM  and obesity. She would need anticoagulation therapy and close monitoring in the hospital to prevent potential complications like pulmonary embolism. Further investigations would also be required to rule out any malignancies as they could be a hidden trigger for the DVT.   Early recognition  appropriate diagnostic investigations  and prompt treatment are key to managing DVT effectively in such patients. This case emphasizes the importance of strong differential diagnostic skills and individualized care approach to manage such patients effectively.

Title: Patient Presentation - Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Identity: Mr. Arthur Greene  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired bank clerk and resident of New York City  reported to the emergency department on the 2nd of July with symptoms suggestive of deep vein thrombosis.  Demographics and Social History:  Mr. Greene lives with his wife and they have two adult children. He is a non-smoker  non-alcoholic with no known drug allergies. He has a sedentary lifestyle and has a BMI of 28. Mr. Greene's dietary habits lean towards the excessive consumption of red meat and high-fat processed foods.   Presenting Concern:  The patient complained of persistent pain  swelling and redness in his right lower leg which he initially attributed to arthritis flares but became concerned when these symptoms persisted for over a week  accompanied by localized warmth and slight fever.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Greene has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type II diabetes  all of which have been reasonably well-controlled with medications. He has had two episodes of ischemic stroke in the past 5 years. The patient also underwent an orthopedic surgery after a hip fracture 2 months ago. He has been on bed rest since then due to postoperative complications.   Family History:  Mr. Greene's father died of myocardial infarction while his mother had a history of varicose veins. His elder brother also suffers from coronary artery disease  suggesting a possible genetic predisposition to cardiovascular diseases.   Conclusion: Mr. Greene's age  static lifestyle  obesity  recent surgery and extended bed rest  coupled with his existing chronic conditions (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes) all put him at an increased risk for deep vein thrombosis. His persistent leg symptoms   feverishness and family history also strongly suggest a diagnosis of DVT but further diagnostic tests like ultrasound and D-dimer tests are required to confirm this diagnosis. In the meantime  immediate therapeutic action is needed to prevent possible serious complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis: A Clinical Case Review  Patient’s Details: Name: Mr. Michael Johnson Age: 55 years Gender: Male Occupation: Office Clerk Ethnicity: Caucasian Residential Location: Chicago  IL  USA   Present Complaint: Mr. Johnson consults today regarding episode of progressive swelling  pain  and warmth in the left lower limb that he's been experiencing for the past three days  which has begun to cause walking difficulties due to severity of discomfort. He has a history of hypertension and peripheral artery disease (PAD) and takes aspirin and lisinopril daily for these conditions. His father had a history of deep vein thrombosis. He leads a sedentary lifestyle due to the nature of his desk-bound job and moderate obesity  with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31.  Medication: 1. Aspirin 75mg- Once daily in the morning 2. Lisinopril 10mg- Once daily at night  Allergies:  Mr. Johnson reports no known drug allergies.  Examination: Upon physical exam  the left calf is noted to be 3cm larger in circumference compared to the right one  which is warm and tender to touch. There are no visible skin changes or ulcerations.   Investigation: Investigations will comprise of a Doppler ultrasound to confirm the presence of DVT and blood tests for coagulation profile.  Impression: Mr. Johnson presents with symptoms suggestive of deep vein thrombosis  which is supported by his risk factors that include prolonged immobilization  personal and family history of vascular disease  and smoking habit.  Follow Up and Recommendations: The patient has been advised to quit smoking and suggested lifestyle changes towards a more active routine  weight loss  and healthier diet. If DVT is confirmed  anticoagulant therapy initiation will also be considered. Referral to a vascular specialist may be required. Regular follow-up visits will monitor progress and adjust therapy as needed.

Patient Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Demographic Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named John Doe. He is of British descent  was born and lives in Manchester  UK. He is married  has two adult children and is a retired accountant. He currently smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and has smoked regularly for 45 years. The patient reports his alcohol intake as moderate and denies illicit drug use. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 29.5 kg/m2 which indicates he is overweight. The patient was referred to the Phlebology clinic by his Primary Care Provider.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a known history of hypertension  well-controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily)  and Type 2 diabetes  managed with metformin (500mg BID). His familial history is significant for cardiovascular diseases - both his father and elder brother deceased due to myocardial infarction. He has had one previous episode of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) five years back.   Recent Hospitalization: Mr. Doe was recently hospitalized for 10 days following a left total knee arthroplasty. During the period of immobilization post-surgery  he was given list-protocol prophylactic low molecular weight heparin.  Current Presentation: Mr. Doe has presented with a several-day history of increased swelling and discomfort in the left lower extremity  which is the same side of his recent knee surgery. He described the pain as a “continuous cramp” that does not improve with rest or over-the-counter pain medication. He also reported slight shortness of breath. Consequently  a clinical concern was raised for possible Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  The physical examination revealed a swollen and somewhat erythematous left leg. His vital signs at the clinic included a blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  a pulse of 78 beats/min  respiratory rate was 16 breaths/min  and the SpO2 was at 96%. A venous Doppler ultrasound has been ordered to confirm the diagnosis of DVT. He has been admitted for further evaluation and treatment as he could be at high risk due to his past medical history.

Patient Presentation:  We are presenting case of a 57-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. X  with a primary complaint of unilateral leg swelling and pain. Mr. X is a non-smoker  occasional alcohol consumer and does not report any illicit substance use. He lives independently and works as a truck driver  often sitting for extended periods.  Past Medical History: Mr. X's past medical history is significant for obesity (BMI 31)  controlled hypertension (on Lisinopril 10mg daily)  and type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin 500mg twice a day. He had uncomplicated gallbladder surgery five years ago. His family history indicates a father who died of a myocardial infarction at age 62 and a maternal aunt with a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). On social history  he has low physical activity level besides his work. He has no known drug allergies.   Upon examination  we observed that the patient’s right calf was significantly swollen  warm  and tender to touch. The condition had been gradually worsening over the past week  compelling him to seek medical assistance. He also mentioned shortness of breath that developed in the last 2 days.   Based on the clinical presentation  history of prolonged immobilization due to his occupation  and familial history of DVT  a preliminary diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis was made.  This case warrants urgent diagnostic confirmation and management due to the risk of pulmonary embolism  particularly given the recent development of shortness of breath. To confirm a diagnosis  a Duplex ultrasound is planned. Advice on immediate lifestyle modifications to reduce obesity and enhance activity levels  as well as potential anticoagulation therapy depending on the imaging results  are currently being deliberated.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Anthony Thompson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who has presented to the clinic today with a one-week history of progressive  unilateral leg swelling and pain in the calf muscle of his right leg. He has described his pain as cramp-like in nature  which worsens upon standing and walking but reduces upon resting and leg elevation. There is also noticeable warmth over the site and discoloration.   Mr. Thompson is a retired construction worker and has been living independently since his wife passed away two years ago. He is a father of two adult children. He has a 60-pack year smoking history  having quit ten years ago. He neither drinks alcohol nor uses illicit drugs.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he is on Amlodipine 5mg once daily and Type 2 diabetes mellitus which is managed on Metformin 500mg twice daily and dietary modifications. He also underwent a total knee replacement surgery of his right knee 15 years ago.   Family history is notable for coronary artery disease in his father  who passed away from a myocardial infarction in his early seventies. His mother had a stroke in her late seventies.   He is not known to have any allergies. He has not been on any recent long-haul flights or undergone recent surgeries but does generally lead quite a sedentary lifestyle.  Considering his clinical evaluation and risk factors such as old age  sedentary lifestyle  and history of knee replacement surgery  a presumptive diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) has been made. Further investigations  including D-dimer test  duplex ultrasound  or venography  will need to be pursued for confirmation.  The proposed plan would be to start anticoagulant therapy as early as possible once the diagnosis of DVT is established  to prevent any life-threatening complications such as a pulmonary embolism. A referral to a vascular surgeon or hematology specialist may be contemplated. Dietary consultation and supervised exercise programs will also be arranged for better management of his conditions.   Education about the risk factors for developing DVT and its signs and symptoms would be offered to the patient and his family members. This would aid in early recognition and prompt treatment  thus reducing healthcare costs and potential morbidity.

Patient Presentation:  We have a 54-year-old Caucasian male patient named Mr. Mark Johnson presenting with symptoms indicative of deep vein thrombosis. Slide 1: Patient Overview  The patient is a 68-year-old African American male named Mr. Johnson  who currently resides in Baltimore  MD. He is a retired construction worker  had been a heavy smoker for more than 40 years  and has a sedentary lifestyle.  Slide 2: Main Complaint  Mr. Johnson came to our clinic presenting with severe calf pain and swelling on his right leg  which he noticed worsened over the past week. He described his pain as a constant  dull ache worsened with walking.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and previous myocardial infarction about 5 years ago. Medications include metformin for diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and simvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He also has a family history of vascular disorders and stroke.   Slide 4: Clinical Presentation  Physical examination revealed a noticeably swollen  red  and warm right lower extremity. His vitals were stable  but he exhibited positive Homan’s sign (pain in calf or popliteal region with abrupt dorsiflexion of the foot).   Slide 5: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Given his symptomatology and risk factors  Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with suspected deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He underwent an ultrasound of his lower extremities  which was confirmatory for DVT.   Slide 6: Management   Outpatient treatment was initiated with therapeutic anticoagulation using low-molecular-weight heparin and warfarin. Consideration for thrombolytic therapy should be made given the extensive DVT. Furthermore  Mr. Johnson was encouraged to increase daily physical activities  smoking cessation  and maintain a healthy diet to manage his underlying conditions better. He was also advised on the importance of adherence to his medications.   Slide 7: Follow-Up and Monitoring  Regular follow-ups and monitoring  including blood tests (PT  INR) to adjust warfarin dosage and monitor therapeutic levels and repeat ultrasounds to track the resolution of the DVT  were scheduled. Additionally  the importance of early detection of signs of complication  such as chest pain or breathlessness  which may suggest pulmonary embolism  was emphasized.   Mr. Johnson's case underscores the critical role of risk factor management in preventing deep vein thrombosis and highlights the significant impact that lifestyle modifications can make on disease outcomes.

**Case Presentation**  Today  we're discussing a 58-year-old African American female presenting with unexplained pain and swelling in her left leg.   *Patient Details:*   Name: Mrs. Jane Doe   Age: 58   Gender: Female   Race: African American   Occupation: Retired School Teacher    *Chief Complaint:*   Onset of unexplained  localized pain and swelling in the left lower extremity  suggesting potential DVT.  *History of Present Illness:*   Mrs Doe observed the increased swelling and pain in her left leg two days ago. The leg pain seemed to be more intense when she was standing or walking. There is no history of trauma or injury to her leg. She reported mild discomfort and warmth over the area. No previous similar episodes in the past. No symptoms of sudden shortness of breath  chest pain  lightheadedness  or fainting.  *Past Medical History:*    Long history of Type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. She underwent a hysterectomy 20 years ago. Previous smoker  who quit 10 years ago. No history of thromboembolism  clotting disorders  or malignancy. Mrs. Doe is also overweight with a BMI of 32.  *Medications:*   Taking Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  *Allergies:*   No known drug allergies.  *Review of Systems:*   Nothing significant from other systems.  *Family History:*   Her mother had a history of deep vein thrombosis and her father had a history of stroke. Her older brother also has diabetes and hypertension.  *Physical Exam:*   Upon physical examination  the patient appeared in mild distress. Her left calf was notably swollen and erythematous. The left calf was also approximately 3 cm larger in circumference than the right. It was warmer to touch compared to the corresponding area on the right leg.  Based on the clinical history and physical exam findings  the differential diagnosis should consider deep vein thrombosis as the main cause. This indication is based on her clinical presentation coupled with the constellations of risk factors including a family history of DVT  obesity  hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. Venous Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremity would be recommended for further investigation and confirmation.

Slide 1: Introduction  Today  we are discussing the case of Mrs. Mary Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  currently a non-smoker  with a BMI of 32.6  who presented with complaints of pain and swelling in her right lower extremity.   Slide 2: Past Medical History  Mrs. Smith has a significant past medical history including type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  all of which have been managed with medication  as prescribed. She also underwent hip replacement surgery on her right side  three weeks ago.  Slide 3: Current Presentation  Post-surgical  Mrs. Smith had been primarily non-ambulatory and upon presentation  reported a dull ache in her right calf that had increased over the past several days. The leg was significantly swollen  erythematous  and warm to the touch. She also reported unexplained shortness of breath  particularly post-exertion  which began around the same time as the leg pain.   Slide 4: Risk Factors  Assessing her risk factors  we see several high-risk elements. She has recent orthopedic surgery  prolonged immobility  obesity  and advanced age. All these factors increase her risk for hypercoagulability and could potentially lead to deep vein thrombosis.   Slide 5: Diagnosis & Recommendations  Based on her symptoms  clinical presentation  and risk profile we strongly suspect deep vein thrombosis. Further investigations include a D-Dimer test and possibly a Doppler ultrasound of the affected extremity to confirm the diagnosis. We recommend initiation of Anticoagulation therapy as per the protocol  pending test results  consider inferior vena cava filter placement and encourage early ambulation. Additionally  patient education on the importance of medication compliance  outpatient follow-up  and immediate reporting of any changes in symptoms should also be prioritized.   Slide 6: Conclusions  This case highlights the importance of vigilance in post-surgical patients  particularly those who are immobilized and have multiple risk factors for hypercoagulability and deep vein thrombosis. Early detection and treatment of DVT are crucial to prevent severe complications  such as pulmonary embolism.

Slide 1: Introduction The patient is Mrs. Eleanor Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian female with an onset of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She is a retired teacher who lives in Jonesboro  Arkansas  with her husband. She is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol.  Slide 2: Presenting Symptoms Eleanor presented with a 4-day history of increasing left calf pain and swelling. She reported feeling warmth over the affected area. There is no history of trauma or injury. She also noted a recent reduction in her mobility due to occasional shortness of breath. No chest pain or palpitation was observed.  Slide 3: Relevant Medical History Eleanor has a known history of hypertension  which is well controlled with medication (ramipril 10 mg daily). She underwent a total left hip replacement 5 years ago for osteoarthritis with no complications. Furthermore  a year ago  she was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus  which is managed with metformin. There were no previous reported instances or family history of thromboembolic diseases.  Slide 4: Recent Medical Interventions  Approximately 2 weeks ago  Eleanor traveled on a long (>5 hours) flight after visiting her daughter  during which she remained seated most of the time. During her visit  she was mostly sedentary due to the cold weather.  Slide 5: Assessment  Physical examination showed a mildly distressed patient due to pain. Her left leg was swollen and tender along the line of the femoral vein  and there was mild erythema. Her vital signs were within normal limits.  Slide 6: Preliminary Diagnosis & Next Steps Suspicion of deep vein thrombosis is high due to her clinical presentation and risk factors  which include her age  recent prolonged travel  and history of reduced mobility. Confirmation of diagnosis and further management will require investigation tests  including a D-dimer test and potentially an ultrasound of the affected leg.

Subject: Presentation of Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Introduction: Mr. Henry  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a week-long history of increasing left calf pain  redness  and swelling. His medical history indicates known risk factors for DVT  including recent knee replacement surgery six weeks prior  history of smoking and obesity.  Demographic Information: Sex: Male Age: 58 years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Computer Engineer Marital Status: Married  Clinical Features: The patient describes the pain being 7 out of 10  continuous in nature  localized mainly to the left calf area. He states it mildly improves with rest and drastically exacerbates with walking. Accompanying symptoms include mild shortness of breath on exertion  warm skin over the affected area  and increased calf circumference compared to the right leg. Mr. Henry denies any significant changes in the chest pain  coughing up blood  dizziness  or fainting.  Medical History: Mr. Henry has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both well-controlled with medication. He had his left knee replaced six weeks earlier and completed a total of two weeks of postoperative prophylaxis with enoxaparin. He has a 30 pack-year history of smoking and Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31  indicating Grade I obesity. He denies any history of previous blood clots  stroke  or known malignancies. He also denies any family history of clotting disorders.   Current Medication: 1. Lisinopril for hypertension  2. Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  Risk Factors: His sedentary lifestyle  recent surgery  obesity  and smoking create a significant risk profile for DVT.   That concludes a brief overview of Mr. Henry's presentation. The next step requires detailed physical examination  blood work  and imaging (like a Doppler Ultrasound) for definitive diagnosis and commencement of appropriate anti-coagulant therapy. Early identification and correct treatment are critical to prevent life-threatening complications like Pulmonary Embolism.

Title: Case Presentation of a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis   I. Demographics   The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named John who currently lives in Boston  Massachusetts. He is a retired office worker and is a widower with three adult children. John is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol moderately. He reports a sedentary lifestyle due to his retirement  though he tries to take walks three days per week.   II. History of Present Illness  John presents with a 3-day history of progressive pain and swelling in his right left calf. He has noted redness and warmth over the area  with skin that's tender to touch. Pain intensity increases when he tries to walk or flex his ankle.   III. Past Medical History  John's medical history consists of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been treated for the last 8 years with Metformin and Atorvastatin. Additionally  he underwent a total right hip replacement two weeks ago due to severe osteoarthritis. He experienced an uncomplicated postoperative period and was discharged with anticoagulant prophylaxis  but he inadvertently discontinued the anticoagulant medication shortly after discharge.   IV. Family History   There is a notable family history of cardiovascular disease  with his paternal grandfather and his father both passing away from heart attacks. There is no family history of blood clotting disorders.  V. Social History  John’s social history revealed that he lives alone. His children visit him weekly  and he has a part-time caregiver. He has no history of substance abuse.  VI. Review of Systems   John's review of systems is positive for discomfort in the calf  increased sensation of warmth in the right lower leg  and difficulty in walking. Other systems review is otherwise unremarkable.  Thanks for your attention  and I look forward to discussing the probable diagnosis  differential diagnoses  and management plan for John's case.

Patient Presentation:  The patient  Mr. Thomas Blake  is a 65-year-old Caucasian male recently retired from his sedentary corporate job. Mr. Blake  a resident of New York  NY  presents with symptoms suggesting deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He has been experiencing mild swelling  pain  and tenderness in his left calf for the past few days. Upon physical examination  that area shows minor redness and warmth. The pain increases when he flexes his foot. However  he does not have any chest pain  palpitation  or breathing difficulty.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Blake is a smoker with a 40 pack-year history  with his BMI categorized as overweight (BMI of 28). He also has hypertension for the last 10 years  which is currently controlled by daily diovan and hydrochlorothiazide administration. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago  which is managed by metformin and lifestyle modifications.  He does not have any history of major surgeries and has never experienced any clotting disorders or strokes in the past. Two years ago  he underwent a total knee replacement due to osteoarthritis  without any post-operative complications reported.  Family history revealed that his father and older brother were both diagnosed and treated for DVT  and his mother died due to a stroke.  Conclusion:  Given Mr. Blake's age  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  smoking habit  hypertension  diabetes  family history  and his symptoms mentioned above  he is at high risk for deep vein thrombosis. Further diagnostic procedures like ultrasound or D-dimer tests are required to confirm the current hypothesis.   Upon confirmation of DVT  appropriate treatment – which may involve anticoagulants and lifestyle modifications – would be initiated. Given his underlying conditions  regular follow-up with his primary care physician  cardiologist  and endocrinologist would be recommended. It is important to educate the patient about DVT and the importance of early recognition of symptoms to prevent complications like pulmonary embolism.

Presentation  Patient Information: Mr. John Deer  a 64-year-old Caucasian male  presents with signs and symptoms consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Presenting Issue: Mr. Deer reports recent significant discomfort  swelling  and slight discoloration primarily in his left calf over the past week. He also mentions that he had flu-like symptoms  including general fatigue and low-grade fevers for the past 5-6 days. He denies any trauma or injury to the area.  Demographics: Mr. Deer is a retired plumber  is married with two adult children  and lives in a suburban community. He is a non-smoker but admits to moderate alcohol consumption. He enjoys gardening but has no other regular physical activity.   Medical History: His medical history includes hypertension (HTN) that has been controlled with medication (Lisinopril) over the last 5 years. He also had a minor heart attack seven years ago  for which he underwent angioplasty and was prescribed daily aspirin. He reports occasional bouts of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Given the potential for DVT  his family history becomes of immediate relevance: his mother had a pulmonary embolism at 70 years old  and two siblings have been previously diagnosed with DVT.  Review of Systems: The patient denies chest pain  shortness of breath  palpitations  or syncopal episodes. He also denies abdominal pain  nausea  vomiting  changes in bowel or bladder function. There's no report of changes in sleep patterns  vision or hearing problems  or severe headaches. He denies any significant weight loss or gain.  Physical Examination: Mr. Deer had elevated blood pressure reading of 150/95 mmHg  and his other vitals were within normal limits. The left calf appeared to be swollen  warm  and visibly redder compared to the right.  Observations: The primary concern is that Mr. Deer's signs  symptoms  and medical family history increase his risk of developing DVT. Further diagnostic testing  including an ultrasound of the lower extremity and necessary blood tests  should be carried out to confirm the diagnosis. He should be instructed regarding the signs of embolic events and be started on appropriate anticoagulant therapy pending the results of diagnostic tests.  Patient Education: Mr. Deer needs to be informed about the seriousness of his condition and the importance of adhering to his treatment regimen. He should be advised to reduce alcohol consumption and to engage in regular physical activity like walking. Regular follow-ups will be crucial to monitor his condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

Title: Patient Presentation - Deep Vein Thrombosis  Introduction:  I am presenting Mr. George Hamilton  a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a fresh diagnosis of Right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Demographics: Mr. Hamilton is retired  previously worked as a truck driver  is married  living with his wife in the urban residence of Brooklyn  NY. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol moderately.   Presenting Complaint: Patient's chief complaints were of sudden onset of swelling and pain in the right leg examined 2 days ago and the superficial veins of his leg were slightly more visible than usual. He acknowledged having had some shortness of breath over the last day.  Past Medical History: Mr. Hamilton has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  which are managed with medications (Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension). In addition  he experiences occasional atrial fibrillation  which he attributes to his lifestyle and manages with beta-blocker Metoprolol. He had a past DVT in the same leg around five years ago. His only surgical history is of an inguinal hernia repair 10 years ago.  Family History: His father died at the age of 72 due to myocardial infarction  while his mother is still alive and suffers from osteoarthritis. He has two siblings  both of whom are living and well without any serious illnesses.  Risk Factors: Mr. Hamilton's risk factors for DVT include his profession (long-hour sitting)  previous history of DVT  history of atrial fibrillation placing him at high risk for embolic events  hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and his age.  Summary: Given his symptoms  past history  and detailed examination findings  Mr. Hamilton was diagnosed with a new episode of deep-vein thrombosis in the right lower leg and is being started on anticoagulant therapy with warfarin and heparin bridge. The team will also arrange for his lower-extremity Doppler Ultrasound and echocardiogram to check for possible pulmonary emboli.  In the future  he will need further vascular assessment and attempts should be made to optimize his diabetic control and anticoagulation to prevent further episodes or complications stemming from DVT.

Title: Case Presentation of Deep Vein Thrombosis  I. Demographic Information:   Patients Name: Mr. Johnson  Age: 62 years old  Gender: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired librarian   II. Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Johnson presented with a 3-day history of sudden onset  intense pain in his left lower leg which is swollen  warm to touch  and notably discolored (red). Mr. Johnson reported no preceding trauma  recent immobilization  travel  or surgical procedures.  III. Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson's past medical history is significant  which includes:  1. Cardiovascular: Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with hypertension 7 years back and has been consistent on his antihypertensive medication.   2. Respiratory: He had a moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease diagnosed about five years ago from his 40-year history of smoking  although he quit smoking 3 years ago.    3. Gastrointestinal: He also has a diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease for the past decade and is on regular proton pump inhibitors.  4. Current Medications: His current medications include amlodipine 10mg daily for hypertension  tiotropium inhaler for COPD  and omeprazole 20mg daily for GERD.  Mr. Johnson is also sedentary  has a BMI of 29 (overweight)  and follows a high-fat and high-sodium diet. He has no known drug allergies.  IV. Family History:   Mr. Johnson's father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and his mother died from what was apparently a stroke at 74 years old. His older sister  aged 70  is currently being treated for type 2 diabetes.  Given the findings of leg swelling  pain  warmth  redness  and the patient’s significant medical history  the preliminary diagnosis is Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). We recommend immediate diagnostic testing by Doppler ultrasound to confirm the presence of DVT and initiate treatment as needed.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Demographic Information: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  who currently resides in Asheville  North Carolina. He is married  a non-smoker  and has a moderate consumption of alcohol. His weight is about 180 lbs  and he is 6'1"" in height. The patient's Body Mass Index (BMI) indicates that he is on the border of an overweight and normal weight class.  Presenting Issue: Mr. X visited the clinic while complaining of an uncomfortable sensation in his left leg for around one week. Upon examination  the leg was found to be noticeably swollen and warm to the touch. There is mild redness and tenderness along the path of the inner thigh. The patient stated that the discomfort is moderate at rest but increases upon walking. Mr. X revealed that he did not sustain any recent injuries nor was involved in any physically demanding activities that could potentially lead to muscle strain.   Past Medical History: Mr. X's past medical history reveals that he is hypertensive and has been on medication for the last 10 years. His high cholesterol level also required him to take omega-3 supplements. He is pre-diabetic but managing through dietary changes and increased physical activity.   Additionally  Mr. X had a right hip replacement surgery five years ago due to chronic arthritis and was immobilized for a considerable period feeding to his sedentary lifestyle. Besides  Mr. X had a history of deep vein thrombosis in his right leg  nearly three years back which was resolved through anticoagulant therapy.
