His familial medical history indicates that his mother suffered from deep vein thrombosis and passed away at the age of 75 from pulmonary embolism  while his father survived two myocardial infarctions before dying at 81 due to congestive heart failure.  These symptoms and past medical history suggest that Mr. X has a moderate to high risk of deep vein thrombosis recurrence  which may be the reason behind his current complaints. More tests such as a D-dimer blood test  duplex ultrasound  or in severe cases  a venogram should be undertaken to confirm the diagnosis. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with anticoagulants can help prevent life-threatening complications like a pulmonary embolism.  Professional consult from a vascular specialist is advised for Mr. X's case due to his past medical history.

Title: A Case of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Presenter: Dr. [Your Name]  Patient Profile: Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. J. He is a retired construction worker  a lifetime non-smoker and moderate alcohol consumer. He is slightly overweight with a BMI of 29. He hails from suburban Houston  Texas and lives with his wife.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. J presented with a three-day history of pain  redness  and increasing swelling in his right lower leg. He also reported slight fever  feelings of warmth in the area  and mild fatigue.  Past Medical History: Mr. J has a notable past medical history of type II diabetes for which he is on an oral hypoglycemic agent  hypertension controlled with an ACE inhibitor  and hyperlipidemia managed with a statin. His surgical history includes an appendectomy more than 30 years ago. He was hospitalized five years ago for a fracture of his right wrist  sustained in a fall. His family history was significant for cardiovascular disease  with his father suffering a myocardial infarction at age 54.  Investigations: His physical examination revealed unilateral swelling of his right leg with warmth and erythema consistent with possible Deep Vein Thrombosis.   The initial diagnostic workup included a CBC  electrolyte levels  coagulation profile  and D-dimer which came back high  suggestive of thrombosis. A confirmatory ultrasound was done  which located the thrombus in the popliteal vein.  An ECG was conducted  which did not show abnormal findings.  Management & Plan: Mr. J was admitted to the hospital. He was started on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) after blood tests confirmed the diagnosis. After the initial treatment  warfarin therapy was initiated for long term anticoagulation. Patient education was conducted on lifestyle modifications and prophylaxis measures.   Summary: This case represents an incidence of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 68-year-old man with a significant past medical history. It underscores the importance of prompt diagnosis and initiation of anticoagulation therapy in managing DVT. Risk factor management and patient education for potential lifestyle changes are being looked into.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 58-years old  Gender: Male Ethnicity: African-American  Occupation: Office Worker  Residence: Urban   The patient is a relatively sedentary office worker  a former smoker with a thirty-pack year history who quit ten years back and drinks alcohol socially. He is overweight with a BMI of 30 and has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus for which he takes Metformin and Lisinopril. He has a familial history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  with his father having had the condition in late adulthood and his sister in her early 40s.   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith presents with a 3-day history of increasing pain  warmth  redness  and swelling in the calf of his right leg following a 6-hour non-stop flight. There's no prior history of trauma or injury. He reports some associated mild shortness of breath  especially on exertion  but no chest pain  syncope  cough  or hemoptysis. The patient denies fever  recent surgeries  or bed rest for a prolonged period.   Assessment:  On examination  his right calf is considerably swollen  warmer than the surrounding area  erythematous with a tender palpable cord. The Homans' sign is positive on right leg. His vital signs are within normal limits  except for the blood pressure which is slightly elevated at 145/90 mmHg.   Our provisional diagnosis based on the clinical history and physical examination findings is right calf deep vein thrombosis. This is a serious condition  as DVT can result in potentially life-threatening pulmonary embolism.   Plan:  We will proceed with further investigations including Doppler Ultrasound of the leg. Blood investigations  ECG  and Chest x-ray may be considered  given his mild symptoms of breathlessness. Initiation of anticoagulant therapy with low-molecular weight heparin or direct oral anticoagulants might be considered subject to final diagnosis. Regular follow-ups and monitoring are critical. Lifestyle changes are recommended including weight loss  regular exercise  and hydration. Patient education about recognition of pulmonary embolism symptoms is essential.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department with a 2-day history of swelling  pain  and redness in his right lower leg. He noted that the pain started gradually and has been getting increasingly worse. The swelling is localized to his calf and is accompanied by a warmth sensation.  The patient denies any history of trauma to the leg  recent surgeries  or long-distance travel. Moreover  he denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or hemoptysis. Mr. Smith is a retired truck driver and has a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He used to smoke a pack of cigarettes a day for 30 years  but quit around ten years ago. Mr. Smith admits to occasional alcohol use and denies any illicit drug use.  His home medications include Metformin  Losartan and Atorvastatin. He denies any known drug allergies. Family history is significant for a cousin who had a ""blood clot in the lung.""  On physical examination  his vital signs are within normal limits except for an elevated blood pressure of 145/90. His right lower extremity is notable for its slight warmth  non-pitting edema  and tenderness to palpation in the calf region. There is also slight erythema noted. Pulmonary  cardiovascular  and abdominal examinations are normal.   Due to high clinical suspicion  a Doppler ultrasound was performed which confirmed the presence of a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in the right popliteal vein.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Paul Nowak  a 56-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of smoking and obesity  presents to the clinic complaining of acute onset pain in his left calf that has been progressively worsening over the last three days. The pain is associated with swelling and redness. Mr. Nowak also complains of a feeling of ""heaviness"" in his left leg. The areas surrounding the pain are warm to the touch. There’s no associated chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. Additionally  he states that he recently had a knee replacement surgery  two weeks prior to the onset of these symptoms and he has been mostly sedentary during his recovery period. He denies any history of previous venous thromboembolic events  malignancy or bleeding disorders. He does not have a family history of clotting disorders and he is not currently on any hormone therapy.

Patient Information:   A 67-year-old Caucasian male named John Doe presents at the emergency department. He is married  has two children and is retired from a desk job.  Chief Complaint:   Mr. Doe describes observing swelling and redness in his right lower leg for the past 2 days  associated with a dull aching pain. He has no reported injury to the leg or history of any recent trauma. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or any cosmetic surgery recently.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe was diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 50  and he also has a history of hyperlipidemia and type 2 diabetes  for which he is on regular Metformin and a statin. He suffers from obesity (BMI: 33)  and his lifestyle is sedentary. His family history reveals that his mother had a stroke at the age of 75 and his father died from a heart attack. Furthermore  a sedentary lifestyle was maintained due to the recent COVID-19 pandemic where he was forced to self-isolate. He also reports that he recently took a long-haul flight (12 hours) back from Australia two weeks ago.  Medication:  He is currently taking Metformin 500 mg twice daily  Atorvastatin 20 mg once daily  and Lisinopril 10 mg once daily.  Social History:  Former tobacco smoker - quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially.  Examination:  On examination  his right calf appears swollen  warm to touch  and red. The circumference notably appears larger than the left calf  and there's a positive Homan's sign.  Impression:   Based on the clinical history and examination  the presentation is suggestive of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Further investigations like D-Dimer testing or an ultrasound/Doppler study of the leg veins are warranted. Mr. Doe's chronic health conditions  prolonged immobilization  long flight  and family history of cardiovascular disease increase his risk for DVT.

Patient Information: A 64-year-old Caucasian female named Mrs. Smith.  Chief Complaint: Mrs. Smith is presenting with a three-day history of gradually increasing pain and swelling in her right leg. Over the past 24 hours  the pain has localized to her right calf area  which is now warm to touch.  Present Illness: The patient reports that she recently took a 12-hour flight back from a vacation in Europe  during which she was seated the majority of the time. She claims that her situation worsened after the flight  causing difficulty in moving her leg for her daily activities.  Medical History: Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes  for which she is taking Metformin and Lisinopril. She quit smoking 1 year ago after a 30 pack-year history. No previous episodes of venous thromboembolism.  Family History: She reports a family history of blood clots  as her mother experienced a deep vein thrombosis at the age of 70.  Social History: The patient is a retired school teacher  living with her husband. She does not consume alcohol and quit smoking last year.  Review of Systems: Positive for calf pain  leg swelling  and warmth over her right calf. Negative for chest pain  shortness of breath  recent surgery  or trauma. No change in appetite or weight loss. No headaches or any other symptoms are reported.  Physical Examination: The patient’s right lower leg appeared slightly swollen and erythematous as compared to the left. Palpation of the right calf muscle elicited pain. No calf tenderness or edema was found in the left leg. The rest of the physical exam  including cardiovascular and respiratory  was unremarkable. Pulses are equal in both the legs.  Assessment: The symptoms  combined with her recent long-haul travel and family history  suggest highly of deep vein thrombosis.  Plan: To confirm the diagnosis  Ultrasound Doppler of the lower limb venous system was suggested to the patient. She is advised to avoid standing for long periods  elevate her legs when sitting and walking to improve blood flow in the legs. Initiation of anticoagulant therapy will be considered based on the ultrasound results.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian female with a body mass index (BMI) of 28  presenting with a 3-day history of increasing left calf pain and swelling. She describes the pain as a constant  dull ache  rated 6 out of 10  slightly relieved by rest and elevated positioning  but exacerbated by walking or standing. The left leg appears red and slightly warmer than the right on examination  and is approximately 3cm larger in circumference. She denies any recent trauma or surgeries but  upon further questioning  admits to recent long-haul travel.   In terms of medical history  the patient has a history hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are well-controlled on Lisinopril 20mg daily and Atorvastatin 40mg daily respectively. No known allergies to any medication. Family history is significant for heart disease in her mother who passed away at the age of 75. No history of previous blood clots  but not tested for thrombophilia disorders. The patient is a nonsmoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. She lives on her own and is generally active  walking her dog every day. She has been less active in the last 3 days due to pain.  Given the patient's symptoms  history of recent travel  and background risk factors including age and obesity  a presumptive diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is considered.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of a persistent pain and swelling in his left lower leg  which began gradually three days ago. He describes the pain as a constant  aching sensation  rating it as a 7 out of 10 in intensity. He denies any trauma  insect bites  or recent travel. However  he mentions a prolonged period of immobility due to a recent 10-hr long-distance road trip.   The patient has a known history of obesity (BMI: 30)  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia; and recently had a total knee replacement surgery on the same side two months ago. He is currently on Losartan and Atorvastatin  with no known allergies. He quit smoking five years ago  occasionally consumes alcohol  and denies any illicit drug use. His family history is significant for his mother having a pulmonary embolism at the age of 60.   No previous ultrasound or imaging of the leg has been done. His vital signs on presentation are within normal ranges  with a blood pressure of 140/85  heart rate of 78 beats per minute  and respiration rate of 15 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination  the left lower limb looks swollen and is warm to touch compared to the right. No erythema or skin changes have been noticed. There is a tenderness along the distribution of the left calf muscles. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Simmons  a Caucasian male aged 62  presented to the clinic today with symptoms indicative of a deep vein thrombosis. Mr. Simmons is a long-haul truck driver by occupation  who spends most of his hours sitting  and a current smoker with a 30 pack-year history. He has a past medical history of hypertension which he's been managing for the past five years. He also disclosed that he recently underwent a hip replacement surgery 2 weeks prior and has been largely sedentary in his recovery. He has been having shortness of breath  chest pain  and an apparent swelling in his left leg from the knee down. He described the swelling to be painful with a warm sensation and has observed some redness and tenderness  but the symptoms have persisted for a couple of days. He denies fever or any recent trauma to the affected limb. He reports no known drug allergies. He lives alone  and his family history includes his father  who suffered a stroke at the age of 70.

A 48-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with a complaint of swelling  warmth  and a dull ache in his left lower leg that has been gradually worsening over the last three days. He notes occasional shortness of breath  especially while climbing stairs. However  he denies any chest pain  cough  or hemoptysis.  The patient is a truck driver by profession and mentions recent on-road durations of over 6 hours without stopping. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol in moderation. He is obese with a BMI of 34.   His past medical history includes a few cases of chronic lower back pain  hypertension controlled with amlodipine  and a previous peptic ulcer disease episode three years ago. He has no recorded history of malignancy  clotting disorders  recent surgeries  or long-term immobility.   He shares a family history of deep vein thrombosis (his father was diagnosed in his late 60s).   Examination findings indicate swelling  warmth  and tenderness on palpation of the left calf muscle. The right leg appears normal. His vital signs are stable  with a blood pressure of 138/90 mmHg  heart rate of 86 bpm  and oxygen saturation of 97% while breathing air in room.   The physician suspects deep vein thrombosis and plans to initiate further diagnostic work-up such as duplex ultrasonography.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. A is a 66-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and sedentary lifestyle who presents with a 4-day history of increased pain and swelling on his left leg. He reports that the pain is constant and increases with movement. He notes no trauma to the area  no other site of pain or swelling  fever  recent travels  or history of similar occurrences. He reports having been sitting at his home office most of the days since the COVID-19 pandemic began due to his work-from-home setup. His medication list includes lisinopril for hypertension and simvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He occasionally consumes alcohol but does not smoke or use illicit drugs. His family history reveals his mother had deep vein thrombosis in her later years. Examination reveals a noticeably swollen  warm  and tender left calf.  Given his medical history  recent increase in sedentary behavior  family history  and presenting symptoms  the differential diagnosis includes deep vein thrombosis. He is advised to undergo venous Doppler ultrasound scanning for confirmation.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department complaining of increasing swelling and pain in his right lower leg for the past four days. The pain is aching in nature  non-radiating  and exacerbated by movement or walking. He also mentions experiencing mild shortness of breath upon exertion over the past 48 hours.   Mr. Doe works as a long-haul truck driver and spends prolonged periods without significant movement. He has a 20-year history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day. His past medical history is significant for past episodes of superficial thrombophlebitis in his right lower extremity and hypertension which is managed by lifestyle modifications. His mother also suffered from recurrent DVTs and underwent anticoagulation therapy.    He denies any history of surgery  malignancies  recent prolonged travel or immobilization  trauma  fever  or bleeding disorders. He also negates any chest pain  cough  hemoptysis  or other systemic symptoms.   On physical examination  his right calf appears swollen  warm and erythematous  with a +2 pitting edema. A palpable cord is also noted along the course of his calf veins. His vital signs are within normal range  except for a slightly elevated blood pressure of 145/90mmHg.   The clinical picture  coupled with Mr. Doe's substantial risk factors indicate a high possibility of deep vein thrombosis. Further investigations including duplex ultrasonography and D-dimer blood tests  along with a management plan will be discussed.

Patient Presentation:   A 50-year-old Caucasian female patient presents to the emergency department with a history of increasing discomfort and swelling in the lower left leg for the past 5 days. She describes the pain as dull and constant  rating it as 6/10 on the pain scale  and it aggravates upon walking. The patient also reports a recent long-duration flight about one week ago.   Demographic Information: The patient lives in suburban Connecticut with her husband and works as an accountant. She denies any smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use. She is slightly overweight (BMI - 27) and carries a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus being managed with oral hypoglycemic agents.  Past Medical History:   The patient's medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 7 years ago and well-controlled with Metformin. She also has a history of hypothyroidism  for which she takes Levothyroxine. The patient underwent a cholecystectomy procedure five years ago. No history of any cardiovascular disease  stroke  or other thromboembolic events. Her family history is significant for coronary artery disease in her father. She does not recall any family history of DVT or other clotting disorders.   During the current visit  the patient was noted to have left calf swelling with discoloration. She denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  or other systemic symptoms suggesting pulmonary embolism. The patient is worried about her symptoms as they have been progressively worsening. A D-dimer test was ordered with subsequent ultrasound depending on the result due to her high risk for DVT.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male  who presents to the Emergency Department with complaints of acute left leg swelling  warmth  and discomfort which have been gradually worsening over the past 24 hours. No history of trauma or injury to the leg is reported. The patient works as a software engineer and spends most of his day sitting at his desk.  Demographics:  Mr. Davis lives in the suburbs of Chicago with his wife and two grown-up children  both of whom do not reside with them. He is a non-smoker but acknowledges that he drinks beer two to three times a week. He has a BMI of 32  indicating obesity.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Davis was diagnosed with Type-II diabetes approximately eight years ago and has been compliant with his metformin medication and maintains a routine check-up every three months. He also has a history of hypertension  which is being managed through a combination of antihypertensive agents (lisinopril and amlodipine). Additionally  he had a myocardial infarction two years ago that was managed by angioplasty and stenting  and since then  he is on low-dose aspirin therapy.  In the past  he was also diagnosed with a minor pulmonary embolism managed with warfarin  but he discontinued his medications after six months against medical advice. Family history is significant for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his mother and maternal grandmother. He does not recall any instances of cancer in the family. His last travel was a 12-hour flight for a business trip  about a week ago.  Clinical Notes:  The patient's left lower extremity appears markedly swollen and erythematous compared to the right one. It is also significantly warmer to touch  and palpation reveals tenderness in the calf muscles. Both superficial and deep palpation elicit significant pain. The patient's vital signs are stable  but his heart rate is slightly elevated at 110 bpm.

A 57-year-old Caucasian male presents with complaints of tenderness  pain  and swelling in his left lower leg that has gradually worsened over the past week. The pain increases when standing or moving and mildly alleviates when he elevates the leg. He describes the pain as dull and constantly throbbing. Upon inspection  the left lower limb is slightly warmer and visibly swollen compared to the right one. Patient denies any shortness of breath  chest pain  or recent injury to the affected limb.   He has a 10-year history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  for which he takes Metformin. He smokes about a half pack of cigarettes a day and consumes alcohol socially. His occupation involves prolonged periods of immobility as he is an interstate truck driver. The patient has no known allergies. His mother died at age 72 due to a pulmonary embolism. He has no history of surgeries or blood clotting disorders.   Upon initial assessment  these symptoms appear indicative of deep vein thrombosis. Further diagnostic tests  potentially including an ultrasound and/or D-dimer  would help confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Profile: Sex: Male Age: 64 years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Truck driver (sedentary job)  Chief Complaint:  ""Left leg has been sore and a bit swollen for the past three days.""  History of Present Illness: Patient reports a gradual onset of aching pain in his left calf three days ago  which has progressively worsened. The patient has noticed a slight swelling and redness in the same area  and the pain intensifies with ambulation. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or calf pain in the right leg. No recent history of trauma or injury to the legs.  Past Medical History: - Diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes 10 years ago  moderately controlled with metformin and insulin. - Hypertension diagnosed 7 years ago  controlled with lisinopril. - History of smoking (1 pack/day for the last 30 years). - Occasional alcohol use. - No reported allergies. - No previous history of blood clots  thrombophlebitis  stroke  or heart disease.  Social History: Patient lives alone. He’s a long-distance truck driver which involves extended periods of immobility.   Family History: Father had coronary artery disease. Mother had hypertension.  Physical Examination: General: Alert  oriented  in no acute distress. Vitals: BP 140/90 mmHg  HR 80 bpm  RR 16/min  Temp 98.5°F  SpO2 98% on room air. Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm  no murmurs. Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. Extremities: Left calf moderately swollen  erythematous  warm to the touch. Positive Homans sign. Right leg appears normal.   Preliminary Assessment: 64-year-old man with risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  smoker  sedentary job) presenting with unilateral leg pain and swelling  suggestive of deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:   A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the office with complaints of progressive left leg pain and swelling for the past three to four days. It is severe in intensity and increases with elongation. The patient denies any injury to the leg. He says the pain diminishes slightly with rest but increases upon standing for long periods. His leg also appears slightly discolored.  He has past medical history of hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril  type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with Metformin. He quit smoking five years ago after a 40-year history of 1 pack per day.     He recently had a long flight from New York to Tokyo a week ago  on a business trip. He reports he was seated for most of the 15 hours duration of the flight.  On observational inspection  the left leg is notably swollen compared with the right one  with a slight erythematous discoloration. The patient expresses pain on palpation of the area.  This constellation of symptoms and the recent history of long travel suggest possible deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Joseph Brown is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents today with a 2-day history of unilateral  right-sided leg pain and swelling. The patient reports the pain is worse when he stands and walks  rating it 7/10 on the pain scale and somewhat relieved while resting. He further reports mild shortness of breath while walking which he initially attributed to his age. He denies any recent trauma or injury to the affected leg.  He has a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity with a BMI of 32  and a myocardial infarction 5 years ago. He is currently receiving metoprolol and lisinopril for hypertension  and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. During a recent hospitalization for pneumonia about 4 weeks ago  he developed a pulmonary embolism for which he completed a 3-week course of anticoagulation with rivaroxaban.   He used to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day but quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally. His social history is significant for sedentary lifestyle due to his retirement.   Mr. Brown's father had a history of recurrent DVTs and PE  and his older brother had a stroke at the age of 60. His vitals on presentation are stable except for a slightly elevated resting heart rate of 95 bpm. His right lower extremity is edematous  warm to touch  erythematous and tender along the path of the deep veins.  Assessment: The patient's presentation prompts an evaluation for a suspected deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Given the history of recent thromboembolism  a D-dimer test and venous duplex ultrasound is to be done to confirm the potential diagnosis of DVT.

Patient Presentation:  A 55-year-old male  KYC analyst by profession  presents with a 2-day history of pain  swelling  and slight redness in the right lower leg. He reports the pain as a constant  heavy ache  rating it as a 7 on a scale of 10 and states that it becomes worse when he tries to flex his foot. He also mentions an increase in the leg's temperature over the past 24 hours. The patient denies any recent trauma to the leg and also denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or hemoptysis.  His past medical history is notable for hypertension controlled with losartan and type 2 diabetes well controlled with metformin. He also reveals that he recently went through a period of prolonged immobility due to an international flight and subsequent busy working hours.  His family history includes a mother who had a pulmonary embolism in her late sixties. He denies smoking  illicit drug use  and excessive alcohol intake. He reports minimal physical activity due to desk job commitment.   On examination  the patient's right calf is swollen with a circumference 3cm larger than the left calf  warm to the touch and erythematous. Upon dorsiflexion of the right foot  he reports calf pain (Homans' sign).  Given the patient's congratulation risk factors  prolonged immobility  recent long-haul flight  and physical findings  the differential diagnosis is consistent with a high probability of deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  presents to the ER with a two-day history of unilateral lower extremity swelling and discomfort. He complains of a sensation of tightness and localized pain in his left calf which has been progressively worsening. He denies any recent trauma  surgeries  or long plane flights.   The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which are under control with medication. He was a 30-pack year smoker but quit 10 years ago. Patient admits to a sedentary lifestyle and reveals that he does not participate in regular physical activity. His mother had a history of a blood clot in her leg in her late 60s. His vital signs on arrival are: BP 135/85 mmHG  heart rate 90 beats/minute  respiratory rate 16 breaths/minute  and temperature 98.5°F.   Upon physical examination  the left leg appears swollen and marginally erythematous as compared to the right leg. Palpable cord is felt along the major venous pathway of the left calf. No palpable pulses could be determined in the left leg due to venous engorgement but distal pulses were present on Doppler. No other significant findings were seen in the examination.   Diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is considered due to this presentation. Further investigations are planned to confirm the diagnosis  including a d-Dimer test and a Doppler ultrasound of the lower limb veins.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old caucasian female presents to the emergency department with severe left calf pain and swelling. The pain started approximately 4 days ago and has gradually worsened. It is unrelieved by over-the-counter NSAIDs and is greatly exacerbated with ambulation. She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or any other systemic symptoms. She hadn't suffered any falls or injuries recently.  Her past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension  for which she takes daily medications. She is a retired school teacher and does not smoke  drinks alcohol occasionally  and no substance abuse.  She has a familial history of venous thromboembolism  with both her father and younger sister having encountered DVT previously. She recently traveled from a trip overseas  which involved a long duration of immobility (approximately 10-hour flight).  She has no known allergies. On exam  her left lower extremity is swollen with a circumference greater than the right leg  warm to the touch  and she exhibits a positive Homan's sign. No evidence of trauma or skin changes are noted. Her cardiovascular  respiratory  abdominal and neurological systems are all within normal limits.  Given her history and clinical presentation  a high index of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was established. Other differential diagnoses include cellulitis  post-thrombotic syndrome  and ruptured Baker's cyst among others. Further diagnostic testing  such as a D-dimer test and ultrasound  was ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 66-year-old African American female presents at the ER with complaints of right lower leg pain and progressive swelling over the past 5 days. The patient denies trauma or injury to the area but admits to long periods of immobility due to her recent 9-hour drive to visit her daughter. She describes the pain as aching and constant  rated at a 7/10 on the pain scale  which is slightly relieved with elevation but aggravated by walking.  She also noticed some warmth and redness but no discharge or wounds. No associated fever  chills  shortness of breath  chest pain  or other systemic symptoms. She denies any issues in the contralateral leg.  The patient has a pertinent past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and rheumatoid arthritis for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide  atorvastatin  and methotrexate respectively. She also took oral contraceptive pills earlier but stopped 1 year ago. Non-smoker and occasional alcohol drinker  she also has a family history of myocardial infarction in her father.  Given her profile and clinical presentation  the potential for deep vein thrombosis is high in consideration.

Patient Presentation  Mrs. G is a 67-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of gradually worsening pain and swelling in her left leg. She states the pain is aching  concentrated in her lower calf  worsens with movement  and mildly alleviates with rest. She denies any known trauma or injury to the leg. Moreover  she mentions having prolonged periods of sitting  as she recently traveled on a 14-hour long-haul flight for a family visit. She denies experiencing fevers or chills but admits to mild shortness of breath on exertion  which she initially associated with her known condition of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD).  Her past medical history is significant for COPD  hypertension  and previous DVT on her right leg two years ago for which she received anticoagulant therapy. She also had a knee replacement surgery approximately 7 years ago. The patient is a former heavy smoker and quit smoking 5 years ago. She is currently taking atenolol and an inhaler for her COPD.  Family history reveals her father had experienced multiple deep vein thrombosis  and her mother suffered from stroke at the age of 72. The patient shows concern and anxiety regarding symptoms similar to her previous DVT experience and immediate family history.   Upon examination  the left calf is visibly swollen  warm  and erythematous. Mrs. G's vitals are BP 134/80 mmHg  pulse 95  respirations 19  and an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith is a 64-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic complaining of increasing pain and swelling in his left lower leg that has developed over the past 3 days. He describes the pain as a dull ache  rating it 6/10 on the pain scale. The swelling is localized to the calf and does not extend to the foot or the thigh.  Mr. Smith recently underwent a total hip replacement about a month ago  and has been mostly sedentary since then. He states he has been compliant with his medications  including prophylactic low molecular weight heparin but stopped 5 days ago. He has no known allergies. He has no history of smoking  and his alcohol use is limited to occasional social drinking.   His past medical history is significant for obesity (BMI 30)  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus but denies any personal or family history of blood clots or any genetic thrombophilic conditions.   On examination  his vital signs are stable. His left calf appears erythematous  edematous  and is warm to the touch compared to the right leg. He has a palpable cord  tenderness on calf compression and a positive Homan's sign. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Given his clinical presentation  recent immobilization following surgery  and risk factors including obesity  hypertension and Diabetes  a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is suspected. His symptoms have worsened while off heparin  raising a significant concern for DVT. The patient was sent for diagnostic imaging and blood tests to further evaluate this concern.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. E  presents in the emergency room complaining of increasing pain  redness  and swelling in his right lower leg which he has noticed over the course of the past three days. He describes the pain as dull aching  7/10 on the pain scale  which gets worse with mobility and alleviates slightly during rest. He denies any significant trauma  however  he recently returned from a 14-hour flight  two days back.   Mr. E has a significant past medical history of type 2 diabetes for 15 years and hypertension for 10 years. He was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years ago. His current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history but quit 5 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally. He denies any known allergies. No history of previous similar episodes or any family history of coagulation disorders. He has been quite sedentary over the past couple of months due to the nature of his job as a computer analyst. There were no associated symptoms such as chest pain  shortness of breath  lightheadedness  or fainting episodes. His father had a stroke at the age of 72. He lives alone and is independent with his activities of daily living.   Based on his presentation and past medical history  Deep Vein Thrombosis is being considered. Further diagnostic imaging and blood tests including a D-dimer are planned.

Patient Information: A 56-year-old African American female presents to the emergency department reporting sudden onset of pain and swelling in her left lower leg  that started yesterday evening. She rates her pain at 7/10 on the pain scale. She states she had a similar occurrence in her right leg about 5 years ago  which was diagnosed as a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and managed accordingly.  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of DVT as stated  for which she was placed on warfarin but was non-compliant with medication use. She also has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus which is fairly controlled with Metformin. She is a former smoker  quitted about 2 years ago. She has a family history of a sister with a recurrent venous thromboembolism  implying a possible genetic predisposition.  Review of Systems: No relevant findings at the moment.  Current Medication: Metformin  Social History: The patient is a retired schoolteacher  lives alone  and is relatively sedentary. Denies alcohol use and quit smoking two years ago.  Physical Examination: On examination  the left calf is swollen  erythematous  and tender to palpation. There is pitting edema  but no signs of ulceration or infarction. A positive Homan's sign is noted. She is afebrile  and her vitals are within normal ranges. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.   This presentation is most consistent with an acute DVT. Doppler ultrasound of the left lower extremity is warranted to confirm the diagnosis and consider the need for anticoagulation therapy.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old African American male presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of swelling  warmth  and pain in his right calf. The pain is 6/10 in intensity  it worsens with movement  and partially relieves at rest. He also reports a slight increase in shortness of breath over the past 48 hours. There's no history of trauma or injury to the affected limb.   He has a past medical history of uncontrolled Type II Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and had undergone a right total knee arthroplasty 6 months back. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Aspirin. He is an ex-smoker and abstains from alcohol. Family history reveals his father had a Pulmonary Embolism at the age of 70.   On examination  there's a noticeable swelling of the right calf with mild tenderness and increased warmth as compared to the contra-lateral side. There are no visible varicosities or changes in skin color. Active dorsiflexion of the right foot induces pain in his calf (positive Homan's sign). His vitals are stable  but respiratory rate is 22 breaths/min.   Considering his past medical history  his recent orthopedic surgery  his symptoms and the physical examination findings  he seems to be at high risk for a Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Further investigations with a Venous Doppler and D-Dimer are recommended.

Patient Presentation:  A 52-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of acute onset of severe pain and swelling in his left leg. He describes the pain as persistent  with a throbbing sensation and rates its severity as 8/10. He has no history of trauma  recent surgery or prolonged travel. He has noticed that his left leg appears to be more swollen than the right one  and states that the symptoms have progressively worsened over the past 3-4 days. He denies any chest pain or shortness of breath.  On questioning  the patient admits to being a 20-pack-year smoker and is on treatment for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and low-dose aspirin. He denies any other significant medical conditions or surgical history.   The patient is a lawyer by profession and leads a sedentary lifestyle  mainly sitting for long hours in his office. He resides with his wife  has two adult children and is a social alcohol drinker. Family history reveals that his mother suffered from deep vein thrombosis following a hip replacement surgery. He has no known drug allergies.

Patient Information: The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male who works as a long-haul truck driver. He presents today complaining of a reddened  swollen  warm and painful left calf.  Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus which is managed by Metformin and Insulin. He has a history of hypertension controlled with Lisinopril. The patient has a 40 pack-year smoking history and admits to frequent and heavy alcohol use. There is a family history of myocardial infarction; his father died from a heart attack at 62 years old.   Current Medications: Metformin  Insulin  Lisinopril  Review of Systems: Reveals an intermittent cough  shortness of breath  intermittent chest discomfort  worsening fatigue  unexplained weight loss and night sweats. Denies fever  chills  palpitations  dizziness  syncope  abdominal pain  nausea or vomiting.  Physical Exam: Vital Signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left lower extremity reveals a swollen  warm  erythematous  and tender calf as compared to the right. There is a positive Homan's sign on the left. No superficial vein distension or tenderness. Respiratory exam reveals normal breath sounds bilaterally. Cardiovascular exam reveals normal S1 and S2 heart sounds without murmurs  rubs  or gallops.  Given the long periods of immobility due to his job  the patient’s clinical presentation points to a possible deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Further diagnostic tests such as a Doppler ultrasound of the left lower extremity will be necessary to confirm this diagnosis. His respiratory symptoms are worrisome for possible Pulmonary Embolism (PE). Therefore  appropriate diagnostic measures such as D-Dimer and possibly CT-Angiogram should be considered if suspicions for PE are high enough.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old retired male truck driver  presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of unilateral swelling  redness  warmth  and discomfort in his right lower leg. Mr. Doe also reports occasional chest pain and shortness of breath that started around the same time his leg symptoms began. He denies any recent trauma or injuries to his legs.   Mr. Doe has a past medical history significant for morbid obesity  type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  which have been well-controlled with metformin and lisinopril respectively. His surgical history includes a cholecystectomy 10 years ago. He quit smoking ten years ago but has a 30 pack-year history. He denies any history of similar episodes or any known family history of hypercoagulable conditions. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and recently completed a cross-country driving trip that had him sitting for extended periods. He denies usage of alcohol or illicit drugs. He is currently on no anticoagulants or antiplatelet agents.   On physical examination  his right lower leg appears edematous  erythematous  and is warm to touch  as compared to the contralateral side. Homans' sign (pain in calf or behind the knee when the foot is flexed upwards) is positive. The rest of his physical examination  including cardiovascular and respiratory  is within normal limits.   Given his presentation and risk factors  a deep vein thrombosis is suspected and appropriate diagnostic studies are planned.

Patient Presentation:  A 64-year-old Caucasian woman arrives at the clinic presenting with unilateral swelling  redness  and pain in her left lower extremity. The pain has been progressively worsening over the course of three days. She denies fever  chest pain or shortness of breath.   Demographic Details:  The patient is a retired schoolteacher  lives with her husband of 40 years  and has two adult children. She's a non-smoker but is overweight with a BMI of 31. She drinks alcohol socially but denies any illicit drug use. She travelled by plane two weeks ago stating a 10-hour flight  but has had no injuries  recent surgeries  or long periods of immobilisation.  Relevant Past Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both controlled with medication. She also has a family history of deep vein thrombosis; her mother and one of her sisters both had occurrences in their 50s. The patient is currently on metformin  lisinopril  aspirin and a statin.   She was diagnosed with mild varicose veins 10 years ago but opted not to have surgery as they were not causing significant symptoms.   The patient is post-menopausal and took hormone replacement therapy for hot flashes for five years after her menopause onset.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Richard Lawson is a 63-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department with a progressively swelling right leg that started two days ago. The patient also complains of reoccurring moderate-to-severe pain in the same leg. There are no visible signs of trauma or infection  but the patient's right calf is warm to touch and feels firm.  Richard is an architect by profession and leads a sedentary lifestyle due to the nature of his work  often traveling long distances. He admits to a history of smoking for 20 years but quit five years ago. Richard is moderately obese  with a BMI of 32 kg/m2. He has a two-year history of hypertension and takes a daily dose of amlodipine but occasionally misses doses. He underwent a total hip replacement surgery on the right side three weeks ago.   His family's medical history is significant  both his father and mother had coronary artery disease. His father also had a history of deep vein thrombosis. His maternal grandfather had a stroke.   Richard doesn't seem short of breath and denies chest pain  palpitations  or lightheadedness. He  however  expresses concern about the swelling and pain severity in his right leg not improving with rest and over-the-counter pain relievers.   Richard's clinical presentation and history raise suspicions of deep vein thrombosis  assessing him for the same would be advisable.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired physical education teacher who presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of increasing right calf pain and swelling. The pain is aching  constant  and increases with foot movement. The swelling is noticeable and localized to the calf area. He denies any associated fever  chest pain  dizziness  or shortness of breath.  Upon questioning  Mr. Johnson reports that he had a total hip replacement surgery approximately 2 weeks ago. He then traveled for 8 hours by car with few breaks for leg motion. He is adherent to medication instruction but admits that he has been less compliant with the physical therapy exercises that were prescribed postoperatively.  His past medical history is notable for hypertension and obesity. Current medications include atorvastatin  lisinopril  and acetaminophen as needed for pain. Family history reveals a father with pulmonary embolism but no known inherited thrombophilias. He denies smoking  illicit drug use or alcohol use.  On examination  his vital signs are stable. His right calf is swollen  erythematous  warm to touch  and tender  compared to the left. His Homans' sign is positive. The remainder of his exam  including a cardiorespiratory exam  is within normal limits.   Given his recent surgery  prolonged immobility  symptoms  and physical exam findings  he was treated with suspicion for deep vein thrombosis. Plans were made to confirm the diagnosis with a Doppler ultrasound study.

Subjective:  Mr. Carl Douglas  a 64-year-old Caucasian male  presents with complaints of a warm  swollen  and tender right lower leg that started two days ago. The pain is progressively getting worse  making it increasingly difficult for him to walk. He describes the pain as ""throbbing"" and rates it 8 out of 10 on the pain scale. The patient denies any trauma  fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath. He states he was on a long-haul flight from the United Kingdom to the United States five days ago.   Past medical history reveals he is a regular smoker (30 pack years) and was on treatment for stage II colorectal cancer three years ago. He also has hypertension  which is well controlled with Lisinopril 20 mg daily. He underwent colorectal cancer surgery post-diagnosis but hasn't been on chemotherapy or radiotherapy. He doesn't have any known allergies and denies any family history of similar complaints or clotting disorders.  Objective:  On physical examination  his vitals are as follows: Blood Pressure: 130/80 mmHg  Pulse: 89 bpm  Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths/minute  Temperature: 98.6 F  O2 Saturation: 98% on room air. Right lower extremity is swollen and visibly reddened compared to the left leg. There is tenderness on palpation and increased warmth. Peripheral pulses in the right leg are present but slightly weaker compared to the left. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Assessment:  Suspected deep vein thrombosis of the right lower extremity  especially given the risk factors of the patient including recent long-haul flight and history of cancer.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents with an increasingly painful  warm  and swollen right lower leg. He reports that the pain is getting progressively worse over the last few days and it's not relieved with over the counter pain relievers. He is a former smoker and admits to a sedentary lifestyle due to his current job as a truck driver. Past medical history reveals that he had a recent hip-replacement surgery about 2 weeks ago. His family history includes his father having had a stroke at an old age.  The patient denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or recent travel. He does not have any history of cancer or clotting disorders. His regular medications include aspirin for primary prevention of cardiovascular diseases and acetaminophen for arthritis. No known drug allergies. On physical exam  right lower leg is observed to be slightly larger  red  and tender upon palpation as compared to the left lower leg.  These symptoms suggest possible deep vein thrombosis  which will require further diagnostic testing  including a Doppler ultrasound  to confirm.

Patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker  presenting with acute-onset  unilateral swelling  and discomfort in his left lower extremity. The pain is described as a dull ache  constant  7/10  exacerbated when walking or standing. He notes the affected leg appears redder and feels warmer than the other. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or recent trauma to the area.   The patient has a significant past medical history of Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and obesity. His current medications include Metformin  Ramipril  and Amlodipine. He underwent a total knee replacement two years ago with uneventful recovery. He recently had an international air travel about 2 weeks ago. Family history includes a brother with a history of deep vein thrombosis. He admits being relatively inactive at his desk job  exercising infrequently. His vitals upon examination are BP 142/90 mmHg  pulse 88/min  temp 98.6°F  respirations 18/min  and oxygen saturation 98% on room air.   There is no history of bleeding disorders in the family. He takes occasional over-the-counter ibuprofen for joint pain and admits to drinking alcohol socially. He denies illicit drug use. On examination  there is swelling and warmth over the left calf with a positive Homan's sign. His recent laboratory investigations including complete blood count  liver  and kidney function tests were found within normal limits. His current BMI is 32  positioning him in the obese category.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Laura Thompson is a 68-year-old Caucasian woman who presents to the clinic with a two-day history of progressive swelling  redness  and pain in her left lower leg. She describes the pain as a consistent  dull ache  scoring it a 7 out of 10 on the pain scale. She denies experiencing any trauma to the area  but has noticed a palpable  warm lump.  She has a history of type II diabetes and hypertension  both of which are controlled by medication. She underwent total knee replacement surgery on the same side approximately six weeks ago and completed a short course of physical therapy subsequently. She confirms adherence to her medications but admits to a negative lifestyle with prolonged periods of immobility due to her remote work-from-home setup. Additionally  she mentions recent long-haul travel two weeks ago.  There are no allergies  she is an ex-smoker  and she consumes alcohol sporadically. There is no family history of similar issues or known genetic disorders  but her mother passed away due to stroke. She is widowed and lives alone  but her daughter lives nearby and visits frequently.   Review of systems is negative for chest pain  shortness of breath  and neurologic symptoms. However  she admits to generalized fatigue over the past few days and poor appetite. There are no associated symptoms in the right leg. Rest of the medical  surgical  family history  and review of systems are unremarkable.   Considering her presenting symptoms and risk factors such as recent surgery  physical inactivity  and long-haul travels  the possibility of deep vein thrombosis is being taken into account. The patient is visibly anxious about her condition.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old male  presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of progressive  unilateral swelling  and pain in his right lower limb associated with a low-grade fever. The pain is severe in intensity and aggravated on movement or standing. Mr. Smith is a known smoker with a 40 pack-year history and has been relatively sedentary since his retirement 5 years ago from a desk job. He denies any history of trauma to the lower extremities  and recent long-haul travel or surgeries.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and he was recently diagnosed with stage 3 chronic kidney disease. His daily medications include Amlodipine  Atorvastatin  and Lisinopril. He denies any known drug allergies. Mr. Smith's family history is remarkable for a sister with a history of pulmonary embolism. On examination  the right leg appeared swollen  erythematous with palpable warmth compared to the left one  suggesting potential deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male truck driver presents with sudden onset of pain and swelling in his left lower leg that started three days ago. He describes the pain as a ""deep ache"" and rates it as a 6 on a scale of 1 to 10. The pain is constant and increases with walking. He also reports mild shortness of breath.  Past Medical History:  Past medical history is significant for hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril 10mg daily  and hyperlipidemia  managed with Atorvastatin 20mg daily. He has no history of surgery or prior venous thromboembolism. The patient had a long history of smoking but quit ten years ago. He consumes alcohol moderately and denies any illicit drug use.   Family history is notable for a sister who had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 60. The patient is overweight with a BMI of 28 and has a sedentary lifestyle. His job involves long periods of sitting. He denies recent long travels.  He is up-to-date with his immunizations and receives regular health check-ups. His last complete blood count and lipid profile were within normal limits five months ago.

A 47-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a 48-hour history of right calf swelling and pain which has progressively worsened. The patient also reports mild shortness of breath and light-headedness. He denies trauma or injury to the leg.   The patient is slightly overweight with a BMI of 27. He has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both controlled with metformin and lisinopril  respectively. He is a former smoker who quit 5 years ago but admits to drinking 1-2 glasses of wine nightly.   He has a job requiring prolonged sitting and recently completed a long road trip. There is no family history of clotting disorders. His vitals on presentation are stable with a mild tachycardia noted. Physical examination reveals a visibly swollen  erythematous right calf  which is tender to touch. The patient expresses pain during dorsiflexion of the right foot - a positive Homan's sign.  These findings coupled with a positive D-dimer test subsequently led to a Doppler-ultrasound which confirmed a deep vein thrombosis in the right popliteal vein.

A 78-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. Carter  presents to the ER with a complaint of intense pain and swelling in her left leg for 2 days. The pain is described as a constant dull ache that becomes sharp upon movement and is localized over the calf muscle area. The swollen leg appears reddish-blue. On probing  she reports no known injuries to the leg and no recent long-distance travels or surgeries.  Mrs. Carter lives alone and has a 40 pack-year history of cigarette smoking. She has a past medical history significant for hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril  and Hyperlipidemia  managed with Atorvastatin. She had a transient ischemic attack 5 years ago with no residual deficits. She takes Aspirin 81 mg daily.   On examination  the left calf is found to be notably larger than the right  it is tender  warm to touch  and has a positive Homans' sign (calf pain during foot dorsiflexion). There are no visible signs of injury or skin infections around the calf area. Her blood pressure is well controlled at 130/80mmHg  her pulse rate is 86 bpm  and her respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute.   She has a BMI (Body Mass Index) of 30 and exhibits a slight shortness of breath on exertion but admits she is not regularly active. She also denies palpitations  chest pain and other systemic symptoms. The rest of the review of systems is largely negative. Lab tests including a D-Dimer are ordered  and a potential Doppler ultrasound is being considered based on laboratory findings  to confirm the clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presenting with unilateral left leg pain and swelling that has persisted over the past four days. The patient has a past medical history significant for Type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both controlled with medications  and had a hip replacement surgery 1 month ago. He is an ex-smoker  quit 10 years ago  and admits to moderate alcohol consumption.  He reports a sedentary lifestyle since his surgery and has noticed an increase in tenderness and warmth over the calf region along with a noticeable swelling in his left leg. No associated chest pain  shortness of breath or hemoptysis is experienced. No history of trauma or insect bite. Patient has no known allergies. No family history of bleeding or clotting disorders.  He is currently on Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and low-dose Aspirin. His last INR was within normal limits. He has a BMI of 29 kg/m2  signifying overweight. No recent history of travel or prolonged immobilization.   On physical examination  the left leg is noticeably swollen with a positive Homan's sign and there is tenderness along the path of the deep veins of the leg. No signs of skin breakdown  ulcers  or visible varicosities. No palpable cords or evidence of superficial thrombophlebitis. Cardiovascular  respiratory and abdominal examinations are unremarkable.   Given the patient's recent hip replacement surgery  sedentary lifestyle  and symptoms  we suspect deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Information: Mr. Jones  a 64-year-old Caucasian male  employed as a truck driver  presents to the clinic with complaints of swelling  warmth  redness and pain in the left lower leg  which has been progressively increasing over the last few days.  History of Present Illness: The patient has noticed a dull  aching pain in his left calf which has worsened in intensity over the past 3 days. He reports no history of trauma or injuries to the leg. There is no observed shortness of breath or chest pain. The patient returned from a cross-country driving trip  spending long hours seated over a 4-day period  just prior to onset of symptoms. No recent surgeries or hospitalizations reported.   Past Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension managed with lisinopril  hyperlipidemia controlled with simvastatin  and type II diabetes mellitus managed with metformin. There is no known history of any hematologic conditions or malignancies.   Family History: Mother had a pulmonary embolism at age 78 and died of a stroke at age 82. Father died at 72 from a myocardial infarction.   Recent Medication History: Adherent with prescribed medication regimen  denies use of any OTC or herbal agents.   Social History: Moderate smoker with a 40-pack-year history. No recreational drug use. Drinks alcohol socially  approximately 1-2 times per month. Lives at home with wife. Works as a long-haul truck driver  spending many hours sitting while working.  Review of Systems: Positive for swelling  pain and erythema in left lower leg  negative for fever  chest pain or shortness of breath.  Physical Exam: Alert  oriented  appears uncomfortable. Vital signs: Blood pressure 138/84 mmHg  pulse 76 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  temperature 98.6 F  BMI: 31. Left calf circumference greater than the right calf by 3 cm. Warmth and tenderness to touch over the left calf; palpable firmness along the posterior tibial vein. Negative Homans Sign. No visible varicosities or ulcers. Remainder of the exam was unremarkable.  Assessment: The given patient's symptoms  risk factors including recent prolonged sitting  history of smoking  obesity  and family history of VTE  leads to a high clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Further diagnostic tests  including a Doppler ultrasound  can help to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Information: A 57-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Left leg pain and swelling for five days.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports sudden onset of unrelenting left-sided calf pain and swelling that started five days ago. The swellings are bilateral  but predominant pain is on the left leg. No history of trauma. The pain is described as a deep cramp and increases with ambulation. Patient also reports mild shortness of breath when performing his daily functions.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of well-managed hypertension and a 15-year history of smoking at a rate of 15 cigarettes a day. Report of an uneventful knee surgery in the left leg one month ago. No history of blood clots.  Family History: His mother had a stroke at age 60 and his father has heart disease.  Physical Examination: Vital signs show a blood pressure of 145/95 mmHg  pulse 98 bpm  respiration 13 breaths per minute. Physical examination shows tender  warm and edematous left calf. Reduced range of motion in the left leg due to pain. No discoloration or visible veins. Positive Homan's sign. Reduced breath sounds and crackles at the bases of both lungs.  Impression: The history and physical examination are suggestive of a deep vein thrombosis  possibly complicated by a pulmonary embolism given his shortness of breath. Hospitalization  workup  and treatment are recommended.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the outpatient clinic with progressive swelling and pain in his right lower limb over the past week. He complains of a heavy  aching sensation associated with tenderness on palpation. He also mentions that the skin on his leg has become warm and discolored  appearing redder than usual. The pain worsens when standing or walking and eases somewhat when the leg is raised.  He denies any recent trauma to any part of his body. He reports being a current smoker with a 40-pack-year history. He is also known to have hypertension and diabetes mellitus type II which are controlled with medication. His father died from a stroke at an early age  making his familial history significant.  On further probing  he mentions that he had undergone hip replacement surgery 6 weeks ago and has been relatively immobile since the operation  spending most of his days sitting or lying down. He has recently taken a long-haul flight for a family visit about a week ago.  He doesn't have any known allergies. He is currently on metformin for his diabetes  amlodipine for his hypertension  and he uses an albuterol inhaler for occasional shortness of breath.  The above history and clinical presentation suggest a high suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with sudden left lower leg pain that started three days ago. He additionally notes moderate swelling  redness  and a warming sensation in the same area. He says the pain is more severe when standing or walking. The patient denies any risk factors such as recent surgeries  history of trauma  or prolonged immobilization. His past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease and hypertension. However  he reports a family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). His medications include Lisinopril for hypertension  Aspirin for coronary artery disease  and his daily intake of multivitamins. The patient lives alone  is a non-smoker  and does not drink alcohol. He has noticed an unintentional weight loss in the last six months but has ignored the same. He has been noticing more fatigue recently with a poor appetite. He has not been moving around much due to his lethargy. On physical examination  his left lower leg is swollen  tender to touch  and is warm compared to the right leg. No ulcers or varicosities are seen on any leg. Vital signs are within normal limits.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. McCarthy  presents to the emergency department complaining of a swollen  painful right calf that started 3 days ago.   Mr. McCarthy is an ex-smoker with a 30-pack year history who quit 5 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally  consuming about 3-4 units per week. He has a sedentary lifestyle and works as a long-haul truck driver. His diet is poor and mainly consists of fast food takeaways.  Mr. McCarthy has a medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both conditions are controlled with medication. He had a left-sided ischemic stroke two years ago  from which he has recovered well with minor residual left arm weakness. His therapeutic regimen includes aspirin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin.  He has no allergy history and there is no family history of blood clotting disorders.   On examination  there is significant swelling of the right calf  which measures 4cm larger than the left. The calf is warm and there is tenderness to palpation. Mr. McCarthy appears short of breath but is not hypoxemic. His blood pressure is within normal limits and his heart rate is slightly elevated at 95 beats per minute.  Based on the initial examination  there is a high suspicion for right lower extremity DVT possibly due to his job which requires him to sit for long periods of time. It also raises concerns for a possible PE given his mild shortness of breath. Immediate investigations and interventions were planned.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old overweight Caucasian male  Mr. X  presents to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of severe pain and swelling in his left lower leg that started a day ago. He describes the pain as ""sharp"" and ""constant."" He denies experiencing any recent trauma  surgery  or prolonged periods of immobilization. He has not been experiencing any shortness of breath  chest pain  palpitations  or symptoms suggestive of systemic illness.  His past medical history includes hypertension  for which he takes a daily regimen of amlodipine  and hyperlipidemia  for which he is managed with atorvastatin. He also has a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes everyday for the past 30 years. His family history is notable for a sister who had a pulmonary embolism in her 40s. The patient denies any known drug allergies. He is retired and lives with his wife. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use.   On physical examination  the left calf is noticeably swollen and warm to touch. On palpation  the patient expresses discomfort. The patient demonstrates a positive Homan's sign when his left foot is dorsiflexed.  Based on his presentation  there is a high suspicion of deep vein thrombosis in the left leg for Mr. X.

Patient Information: A 60-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents with new and increasing swelling and discomfort in the left calf area.  History of Presenting Illness: The patient reports that he first noticed his left calf was slightly swollen a few days ago  and that there was slight discomfort. He describes the pain as a weak but consistent pain throughout the day  about a 3 on a scale of 1-10  and the pain has slightly increased day by day. He denies fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath. There has been no recent trauma or injury to the area.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of recurrent unprovoked deep vein thrombosis. He was on warfarin for six months following his last episode of DVT 2 years ago but has not been on anticoagulation therapy since. The patient also has a history of hypertension  which is controlled with medication. No history of diabetes  heart disease  cancer  or hyperlipidemia.   Family History: His father passed away from a stroke at the age of 62  and his mother died of heart disease. He has one brother who is currently alive and healthy.  Social History: He is a former smoker (1 pack/day for 20 years) and quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies illicit drug use. He is married  has two children  and works as an account manager. The patient reports that his work involves sitting for extended periods.  Review of Systems: Negative for chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  fatigue  nausea  vomiting  abdominal pain  diaphoresis. No change in urinary or bowel habits.  Physical Exam: There is noticeable unilateral swelling in the left calf  and it is tender to touch. There is no difference in skin coloration  and his calf is warm to the touch  but there is no discernible difference in temperature between the left and right calves. No varicosities  rashes  or discoloration noted. His vitals are stable.   Ascertainment Given his significant history of DVT  current symptoms  and risk factors such as prolonged sedentary behavior at work  the suspicion for the recurrence of deep vein thrombosis is high. Further diagnostic investigation is warranted.

Patient Information: John Doe  a 65-year-old male  farmer  married with 3 children  non-smoker  moderate alcohol intake.  Chief Complaint: ""My right leg has been swollen for two weeks and is really painful.""  History of Present Illness: Patient states he noticed swelling and pain in his right leg 2 weeks ago. The pain is localized to the calf and is a constant dull ache; he rates it about a 7 out of 10 in severity. The swelling and pain have progressively worsened over this time period. Patient also reports a feeling of heaviness in his right leg. There are no associated symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or hemoptysis. Denies trauma or recent injury to the leg.  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of varicose veins for 10 years and was treated conservatively. He also has a history of hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine.   Recent history: Patient had a total knee replacement on the left side 1 month ago. He also notes prolonged periods of sitting and bed rest during his post-op recovery.  Family History: Father died of stroke at 75; mother had a pulmonary embolism in her late 60s.  Review of Systems: Denies fever  weight loss  or other systemic symptoms.  Physical Exam: Right leg is visibly swollen compared to the left. There is tenderness and warmth over the calf. No superficial vein engorgement. No signs of trauma or skin changes.  Based on this presentation  deep vein thrombosis is strongly suspected due to the presence risk factors such as recent surgery  immobilization  and a personal history of varicose veins  and the classic symptoms of leg pain and swelling.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John  a 52 year old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with chief complaints of five-day duration of left lower leg pain  swelling and redness. He describes the pain as constant and rates it 7 out of 10 on the pain scale. The pain becomes worst when he tries to walk. Also  he mentioned a low grade fever for the last two days.   He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are well-controlled with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He underwent a right total knee arthroplasty 2 weeks ago with no postoperative complications initially  and has been relatively immobile since then. He did not take proper prophylaxis for DVT post-surgery.  He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years  consumes alcohol occasionally  and denies any illegal drug use. His father had DVT and died of pulmonary embolism in his early 60s. He works as a computer engineer  which involves long periods of sitting. He does not have a history of any personal or significant family history of cancer  and no known drug allergies.   On examination  his vitals are stable except for elevated temperature of 38.2ºC. Left lower leg appears evidently swollen  erythematous and is warm to touch when compared to the right. Palpation revealed tenderness in the calf muscle. He denied any chest pain  shortness of breath or coughing up blood. Neurovascular examination is unremarkable.   Given his surgical history  immobility  personal and family history  DVT was suspected and further investigations were ordered.

Patient Information: Mrs. L  65-year-old  Caucasian  female  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. L comes to the clinic complaining of pain and swelling in her right lower leg. She describes the discomfort as a persistent aching and cramping sensation  worse when on her feet for long periods. Walking seems to exacerbate the pain. She also states that she noted a red area and a mild increase in warmth over the affected area.  Past Medical History: She has a past history of coronary artery disease and hypertension  for which she is on medication. She also recently underwent a right total hip replacement surgery three weeks ago.   Lifestyle Information: The patient reports being sedentary post-hip replacement surgery with decreased physical activities. She is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol. She reports a personal history of long-distance travel (6 hours or more) three months ago.   Family history: She has a family history of blood clots with her father having suffered from pulmonary embolism.  Weight/Height: She is overweight with her BMI calculated to be 30.8 kg/m2. She is 165 cm tall.  Her current medications include aspirin  a beta-blocker (atenolol)  and an ACE inhibitor (lisinopril).   Based on her complaints  past history  recent immobility  and family history  a preliminary diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is considered. Further investigations are needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Demographic Information:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a BMI of 35 named Mr. Peter Thompson. He is a retired long-distance truck driver and a 20 pack-year smoker  who quit 10 years back at the age of 60.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Thompson came in today complaining of increasing discomfort and swelling in his left lower limb for the past 72 hours. He describes the sensation as a gradual onset cramping pain and tightness in his left calf  accompanied by tenderness which is worsened upon movement. He also mentioned a noticeable reddening and warmness over the affected area.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Thompson's past medical history includes type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  all of which are managed by oral medications. He had an uncomplicated myocardial infarction 5 years ago. Mr. Thompson also underwent an elective knee surgery for osteoarthritis six weeks ago  post which he was largely bedridden for the first two weeks during the recovery period.   Family History:  His father had a history of myocardial infarction and died at age 65  his mother had a stroke at age 73  and his sister was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis at age 62.  Medication History:  He has been taking Metformin for diabetes  Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  and Lisinopril for hypertension. He is compliant with his medications.  Social History: He lives with his wife in a two-story house. Moderate alcohol consumption  doesn’t use illicit drugs  and quit smoking 10 years ago. He is sedentary and spent a significant amount of time sitting due to his previous profession.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male has presented with a 2-day history of progressive left lower leg pain and swelling. The patient states that he perceives his left calf to be significantly larger and harder compared to the right. The pain seems to exacerbate on trying to stand or take a few steps.
