Some associated symptoms noted were slight breathlessness and an uncommon fatigue.  The patient denied any trauma  recent long-duration travel  or surgeries. The patient’s past medical history includes smoking (35 pack-years)  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  and prostate cancer treated with prostatectomy 4 years ago. He doesn't report any past incidence of thrombotic events.   The patient is in retirement and had been more sedentary than usual due to the recent COVID-19 pandemic guidelines for those with a higher risk. He takes daily medication – including low dose aspirin  bronchodilators  and statins.  His father had a past medical history of coronary artery disease and his mother had deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient himself denied any long-term immobility  intravenous drug use  recent hospitalization  or known malignancy other than his previously treated prostate cancer.  Overall  the patient is worried about his symptoms which made him come to the emergency department.

Patient Information: A 58-year-old Caucasian female  retired nurse  non-smoker  lives alone  moderate weekly alcohol intake.   Chief Complaint: ""Pain and warmth in my right lower leg for the past three days.""  History of Present Illness: The patient has been experiencing a progressively worsening pain in her right calf that started three days ago. She rates the pain as 7/10 and describes it as a ""deep  aching pain."" She mentions that her leg feels warm to touch and appears slightly swollen. There is no associated redness or difficulty walking  but the pain somewhat increases with movement. The patient denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  palpitations  cough  or any other symptoms.  Past Medical History: Hypertension (well-controlled on medication)  ovarian cancer (treated with surgery and chemotherapy 5 years ago)  no known drug allergies.   Medications: Lisinopril 10mg daily  multivitamins.  Family History: Mother had venous thromboembolism  father with ischemic heart disease.  Social History: Retired nurse  lives alone  doesn't smoke and drinks moderately. She recently had a long car journey two weeks ago where she was sitting for long periods.  Review of Systems: Unremarkable.  Physical Exam:  General: Alert  oriented  not in acute distress. Respiratory: Breathing comfortably  no respiratory distress  clear to auscultation bilaterally. Cardiovascular: Regular rhythm  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Right Lower Extremity: Mildly edematous and warm to touch  Homans’ sign positive  no skin discoloration  pulses palpable.  These symptoms  along with her recent prolonged immobility and personal/family history of cancer and venous thromboembolism  increase her potential risk of deep vein thrombosis. Further investigation is recommended.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of left leg swelling and discomfort. The patient describes the discomfort as a cramping type feeling in his calf with warmth and slight redness over the area. The patient denies recent trauma  chest pain  shortness of breath  or abdominal pain. The pain is exacerbated with standing and walking. He has been using ibuprofen with minimal relief.   The patient is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago after a 30 pack-year history. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus which are reasonably managed with metformin  lisinopril  and a statin. He also has a family history of deep vein thrombosis in his elder sister.   He is retired but was previously a long-haul truck driver and admits to being relatively sedentary. The patient states that he had to travel overseas recently for a family emergency and the flight was approximately 12 hours each way. He denies any past surgeries. He admits to occasional alcohol consumption but denies drug use.   On physical exam  the patient has a swollen left calf which is tender to touch. The circumference is greater when compared to the right calf. There is slight erythema but no open lesion or sign of infection.   Given his presenting symptoms  recent long travel  with history of sedentary lifestyle and family history of DVT  a Doppler ultrasound is ordered to check for evidence of deep vein thrombosis.

A 63-year-old white male presents to the clinic today complaining of a one-week history of pain  warmth  and increasing swelling in his right lower leg. The pain is constant and worsening. He has noticed increasing tenderness and redness especially beyond the knee area.   The patient works as a long-haul truck driver and sits for long periods of time  recently returning from a cross-country job two weeks ago. His other history includes uncontrolled hypertension managed with medication and a heavy smoker for the past 40 years.  There is no known family history of blood clots or genetic clotting disorders. Also  he denied any history of cancer  or recent hospital admissions or surgeries. He expressed some concern as he stated his condition keeps him from doing his daily activities and he hasn't had such an episode before.   He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or any similar changes in the left lower extremity. The patient is non-compliant with his blood pressure medication due to negligence. His other history includes a daily alcohol intake that is problematic. No known drug allergies were reported.   Physical examination was significant for an overweight male in moderate distress. His right lower leg appeared swollen  erythematous  and tender to the touch  specifically along the course of the area possibly overlying the right calf veins. Vital signs were stable.   This patient’s clinical presentation  along with his risk factors including prolonged immobility  hypertension  smoking  and alcohol  make deep vein thrombosis (DVT) a primary concern.

Patient Presentation:  A 45-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Smith  employed as a long-distance truck driver  presents with a complaint of progressive right calf pain and swelling that has lasted for five days. Patient also reports a mild feeling of warmth over the affected area. The pain worsens when he stands or walks but partially relieves with elevation of the leg. Patient denies any injury to the leg recently. He is a non-smoker and denies any alcohol or illicit drug use.   His family history is significant for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with his father having had a DVT at the age of 60. On asking about his daily routine  he informs that his job involves sitting for long hours without any breaks for physical activity. His past medical history is notable for hypertension  for which he is on a medication regimen of daily lisinopril. He denies any history of surgeries or hospitalizations.  He has not noticed any chest pain  palpitations  or breathing difficulty. His vitals on examination are within normal ranges. Upon examination  his right calf appears swollen and erythematous as compared to the left calf. His BMI is calculated and falls in the overweight category. The clinical impression is consistent with a deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  and further diagnostic testing planned to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Brown is a 70-year-old male presenting to the emergency department with a three-day history of progressive left leg pain and swelling. He describes the pain as dull and constant  scoring it as a 6 out of 10. The pain is worse with movement and better with rest. He denies having any fever  chest pain  shortness of breath  or history of trauma.   He is a retired truck driver and describes his daily activity level as sedentary. Mr. Brown has a 50 pack-year history of smoking and has been diagnosed with hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril  and hypercholesterolemia for which he takes Simvastatin. He had an elective total hip replacement surgery for osteoarthritis two weeks ago  after which he had been immobile for a couple of days but denies any compliance with postoperative anticoagulant medications. He is not allergic to any medications.  On physical examination  the left calf measures 3 cm larger than the right  with erythema and warmth. There are no visible lesions or signs of trauma. His pulses are palpable and equal in both lower extremities. His breath sounds are clear  and heart sounds are rhythmic. Abdomen is soft with no tenderness. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.   Regarding his family history  Mr. Brown's father had a stroke  and his mother suffered from chronic venous insufficiency.  Given the patient's recent surgery  prolonged immobility  his smoking history  and hypercoagulable state due to his age and other risk factors  there is a high suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 73-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and a recent right hip replacement 3 weeks ago. He was non-compliant with his prescribed mobility and exercise plan after the surgery. He presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset  unilateral  and moderate to severe pain in his right lower leg that has been increasing over the past 24 hours. The pain does not radiate and is associated with swelling  warmth  redness  and calf tenderness. He denies any recent trauma or injury. Mr. Johnson has no known drug allergies. He is a retired businessman and non-smoker  drinks alcohol socially  and does not use any illicit drugs. He lives with his wife  and they have no pets. He denies any recent travel. He mentions his mother had ""blood clots in her legs"" though is unsure of any other family history of clotting disorders. His current home medications include amlodipine 5mg daily  metformin 500mg twice daily  and aspirin 81mg daily.

A 60-year-old overweight  Caucasian female presents to the clinic with complaints of increased swelling  warmth  and pain in her left lower extremity which have developed over the past several days. She notes the swelling as being markedly worse at the end of the day and slightly better in the morning  but hasn't completely subsided. She denies any history of trauma or injury. She reports no chest pain  shortness of breath  or any other systemic symptoms.   The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are fairly well controlled with medications. She also has a history of a transient ischemic attack (TIA) two years ago. She has a 40 pack-year history of smoking  but quit 10 years ago. Her medications include lisinopril  metformin  and aspirin. She has a positive family history with both her parents having had ""blood clots.""  The patient is retired and lives with her husband. She works part-time as a receptionist. She denies alcohol use but reports occasional use of over-the-counter diet pills. Her physical examination is significant for an enlarged  edematous  erythematous  and warm left calf when compared to the right. Her femoral  popliteal  posterior tibial  and dorsalis pedis pulses are 2+ bilaterally. No superficial vein distention or ulcers are noted. Her recent lower extremity Doppler ultrasound reveals presence of a thrombus within her left popliteal vein  confirming a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency department with a 2-day history of right calf pain and swelling  which he describes as a constant  dull ache rated 6/10 in intensity. He denies any recent injury  falling  strenuous physical activity  or long-distance travel but mentions recently being immobilized post-operatively following a right hip replacement procedure performed three weeks ago. He has never experienced a similar event in the past.  His past medical history is significant for obesity with a BMI of 32  controlled hypertension  and type 2 diabetes. His surgical history includes a recent right hip replacement and an appendectomy 15 years ago. His medication list includes ramipril  metformin  simvastatin  and aspirin. He denies any known allergies. He is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago and occasionally consumes alcohol during social events. No family history of any hematologic disorder.  On physical examination  the patient's right leg appears reddish and warmer compared to the left and has a significant size difference noted (right calf diameter 3 cm larger than the left). Homans' sign is positive. The rest of the systemic examination is normal. The patient is worried about his leg condition.

Patient Information: A 67-year-old Caucasian female presents to the clinic with an acute onset of left calf pain and swelling for several days.  Chief Complaint: Left calf pain and swelling  History of Present Illness: The patient reports that she first noticed discomfort in her left calf about 4 days ago. Since then  the pain has escalated and is now accompanied by swelling and redness. She denies any trauma to the leg. The patient also mentions she has been feeling warmer than usual but has not checked her temperature at home. She has significantly reduced her physical activity due to the pain. The patient denies any shortness of breath or chest pain.  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  managed with hydrochlorothiazide  and hyperlipidemia  managed with atorvastatin. She also underwent a right total hip replacement approximately 2 months ago.  Medications: Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily  atorvastatin 20 mg daily.  Social History: Former smoker  quit 10 years ago. Denies alcohol or recreational drug use.  Family History: The patient's mother suffered from coronary artery disease. There is no known family history of coagulation disorders or deep vein thrombosis.  Physical Examination: Vital signs are stable. Lower extremity examination shows left calf is erythematous  edematous  feels warm  and is tender on deep palpation. Positive Homan's sign on the left. No visible veins or skin breakdown. Abdomen  chest  and heart examinations are unremarkable.  Given her recent history of surgery  reduced mobility  and ongoing symptoms  a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis is highly suspected. She will be sent for a Doppler ultrasound for definitive confirmation and started on anticoagulant therapy pending results.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old African-American male presents to the ER with complaints of acute onset right calf pain and swelling for the past 2 days. The pain appears to worsen with walking and eases upon elevating the leg. He states that the pain is constant  with a severity of 8 out of 10  and describes it as a deep  aching discomfort.  A 30-year heavy smoker  he has a medical history significant for hypertension  diabetes mellitus type II  and hyperlipidemia. He had a total right knee replacement surgery 3 weeks ago. His BMI is 32  indicating obesity.  Mr. Johnson’s hypercoagulability risk factors include recent surgery  prolonged immobility post-surgery  smoking  hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and age. He is on medication for hypertension and diabetes but has had no anticoagulants postoperatively.  His family history reveals that his father died of a stroke at age 70 and his mother had a history of recurrent blood clots in her legs. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or hemoptysis. On physical exam  there is warmth  edema  erythema  and tenderness in the right calf muscle.  This presentation is concerning for a deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Smith  presents to the emergency department with a complaint of noticeable swelling on his left lower leg which began about three days ago. The patient reports an associated moderate pain that increases on ambulation but improves when the leg is raised. He denies trauma or injury. He describes a dull ache and tightness in his leg  denies any fever  chest pain or shortness of breath. On examination his left calf appears erythematous  warm and swollen compared to his right.   He has a past medical history significant for Stage II hypertension and hyperlipidemia controlled with lisinopril and simvastatin. Mr. Smith is an ex-smoker who quit 10 years prior but had a 20-year pack history prior to cessation. He leads a sedentary lifestyle  is a retired banker and recently completed a long transcontinental flight (14 hours) one week ago for vacation. He denies any allergies but reports a family history of heart disease. He denies any surgical history.   He lives with his wife and they have two adult children. He denies alcohol use and any illicit drug usage. His only exercise is light gardening on weekends. His diet is predominantly fast food.  His vitals are: Temp 98.7 F  BP 150/90  heart rate 90 bpm  respirations 18 per minute  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. His body mass index is calculated to 28. The patient admits noncompliance with antihypertensive medications at times but has good adherence with his statin.   Given the patient's presentation and recent long-haul flight  the provisional diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is suspected. Further investigations are warranted to confirm the diagnosis and begin treatment immediately due to the risk of pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and a recent right total knee replacement surgery two weeks ago. He presents to the ER with complaints of increasing right lower leg pain  swelling  and redness over the past 3 days. The pain is dull and constant but becomes more intense upon walking or standing. The patient also reports difficulty in flexing the foot. His wife noted the development of a low-grade fever yesterday. He denies any chest pain or shortness of breath. On examination  there's noticeable swelling and warmth of the right calf with mild tenderness. The patient's vitals are stable  but his temperature is slightly elevated. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable. Patient's current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and pain medication post-surgery. His family history is significant for coronary artery disease in his father. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Lydia Scott is a 64-year-old Caucasian female presenting with complaint of a two-day history of right calf pain and swelling  associated with mild intermittent fever. There's warmth and discoloration in the area as well. She also reports increasing shortness of breath  particularly on exertion  for the last 24 hours. In terms of constitutional symptoms  she denies any unintended weight loss  night sweats  or loss of appetite.  Her past medical history reveals stage 2 hypertension and hyperlipidaemia  which she manages with amlodipine and atorvastatin respectively. She also has a remote history of right femur fracture treated surgically 15 years ago. Notably  she underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy 2 weeks ago due to symptomatic gallstones  after which she was mostly bedridden. She's postmenopausal with a surgical history of hysterectomy for fibroids ten years ago.  Ms. Scott doesn't smoke and drinks alcohol occasionally. She has no known allergies and her family history includes a brother with pulmonary embolism. She lives alone  but has a supportive network of friends and children who live nearby.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the Emergency Department with complaints of persistent aching  warmth  and swelling in her left lower leg. She rates the pain as a 7 out of 10 and states it intensifies upon standing or walking. She also mentioned occasional shortness of breath and faint palpitations. Over-the-counter pain relief measures have resulted unsuccessful.  She has a past medical history of type II diabetes  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia  for which she is on metformin  lisinopril and atorvastatin respectively. She is also post-menopausal and underwent a total hip replacement surgery two months ago.  Her family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  with her father having suffered from a myocardial infarction and her brother  a stroke. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. Patient is retired and lives with her husband.  On examination  left calf is considerably swollen  warm to touch and tender. No external injuries or rash evident. Pulses palpable in both lower extremities.  Given her recent surgery  immobility  and other risk factors  there is a high suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency room with a swollen  painful right calf that has progressively worsened over the last five days. He notes that the pain is worse when standing  and that the leg has also become red and warm to the touch. He denies any recent injuries to the leg or any trauma. He reports slight shortness of breath but denies chest pain  dizziness  palpitations  or syncope. He has generally been sedentary in the last month  spending most of his time indoors during winter. He also states that during this period  he has had a loss of appetite and suboptimal fluid intake.   Past Medical History (PMH):   He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both well-controlled on medication. The patient is a smoker with a 40-pack-year smoking history  and consumes alcohol socially. He was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer and two months ago started hormonal therapy. He has no known drug allergies. His family history is notable for a father with deep vein thrombosis and a mother with myocardial infarction.   Current medications:   1. Lisinopril 20mg once daily for hypertension  2. Atorvastatin 40mg once daily for hyperlipidemia  3. Bicalutamide 50mg daily for prostate cancer.  This patient's demographics  personal and family medical history  recent sedentary lifestyle  and current status of active malignancy pose a high risk for deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 65-year-old African American male mechanics professional who presents today in the clinic with progressively worsening left leg pain  swelling and associated warmth over the last 4 days. He denies any recent long-duration travel  surgery  history of immobilization or trauma. His pain is reportedly non-radiating  constant and worsens with movement.   Demographic Details:  Mr. Doe resides within an urban setting with his wife of 40 years. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He limits his alcohol use to social gatherings. He is not engaged in regular physical activities and admits to a diet high in red meat and processed foods. He doesn't have any known drug allergies.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago  which is well controlled on daily medication (5mg Lisinopril). He also has a history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 8 years ago  managed with Metformin and lifestyle modifications. There's no known family history of malignancy or genetic disorders.   In conclusion  this patient's presentation and risk factors suggest a possible case of deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:   A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency clinic with an acute  worsening pain in his left calf that began three days prior. He also notices increasing swelling and redness in the same leg which is now warm to touch. He admits he ignored the initial discomfort  thinking it was related to his arthritis. Upon further inquiry  he mentions to have felt some occasional shortness of breath and mild chest discomfort which he dismissed as effects of his age and mild COPD.  Demographics:   Residence is in a rural assisted living community; occupation: retired military officer; married with three adult children; non-smoker; weekly alcohol consumption (2-3 beers); no illicit drug use.   Relevant Past Medical History:   This patient has a history of COPD for which he uses a Bronchodilator. In relation to one year ago  he suffered from a mild stroke with no major complications or current deficits. He also has a history of Rheumatoid Arthritis for 15 years controlled with NSAIDs. He recently underwent knee arthroplasty on the same leg two months ago  after which he has been mostly bedridden. No known drug allergies. Family history includes a brother who had DVT and subsequently pulmonary embolism in his early 70s. Previous travel history includes a long-haul flight journey about a month ago. No previous reports of varicose veins  ulcers  or any other conditions contributing to venous stasis.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents with complaints of a swollen  reddish  and tender right calf over the past 36 hours. He states the pain is aching in nature  rated as 6/10 on the pain scale  and is constant. The pain is not relieved by over-the-counter analgesics and is aggravated by walking or standing. He also mentioned feeling warm to touch over his right calf.  His past medical history is significant for a recent total right hip replacement surgery for osteoarthritis three weeks ago. He is a former smoker  quit smoking 10 years ago  and does not consume alcohol or illicit substances. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both well controlled on oral medications. Family history reveals that his mother had a stroke at age 70 and his father had chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).   He is on regular medications - Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. He also took prophylactic low molecular weight heparin for one week post-operatively but has stopped it since last week. He reports being compliant with his medications.  He denies any history of trauma  recent travel  or known malignancy. He does not have a personal or family history of coagulation disorders. He states that he has been mostly immobile due to his post-op recovery. There are no symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  hemoptysis  or recent changes in mental status.   Upon examination  the right calf is erythematous  edematous  and warm. It is visibly larger when compared to the left calf. Positive Homans' sign observed. The pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally and symmetric.  Based on the clinical presentation  history of recent surgery and relative immobility  a presumptive diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis is made. D-Dimer test and venous Doppler ultrasound of the right lower limb are ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:   Mrs. Shirley Brown is a 70-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and obesity. She is a non-smoker and retired secretary who lives independently. She complains of a sudden onset left leg swelling and discomfort that started three days ago. She describes the discomfort as a heavy  dull ache that worsens with walking. The patient denies chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or hemoptysis but confirms a recent prolonged car travel two weeks ago. On physical examination  her blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg  pulse rate is 86 beats per minute  SpO2 is 97% on room air  with unilateral swelling and tenderness on the left calf but no erythema or warmth. She denies any recent trauma or insect bites. She appears anxious due to her symptoms.  The rest of the examination is unremarkable  with no signs of congestive heart failure or peripheral vascular disease. She is currently taking Lisinopril for hypertension and Simvastatin for hyperlipidemia. Apart from these  she is not on any other medication including hormonal therapy or oral contraceptives. She has a family history of venous thromboembolism with her mother having had a deep vein thrombosis at the age of 80. She has no known drug allergies. She denies any history of cancer or surgery. Her mobility is generally good  but has been limited to some extent due to the current leg discomfort.

A 63-year-old Caucasian female presents to the clinic with a three-day history of progressive left calf pain and swelling. She reports that the pain is constant  aching in nature  and rates it as an 8 / 10 severity. She also noticed progressive calf swelling and some warmth over the area. She denies any history of trauma  fever  or chest pain.  The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She is also obese with a BMI of 32. She had a total knee replacement approximately two months ago on the leg now causing pain and was non-compliant with her prescribed post-operative anticoagulant medication due to financial constraints. She is currently on Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. No known drug allergies.  She has worked predominantly as a secretary for the past 25 years  often sitting for long periods of time. She is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. A positive family history of VTE was noted - her 66-year-old brother had a DVT three years ago secondary to prolonged immobility following a hip replacement surgery.

Patient Presentation:  A 46-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department complaining of a 48-hour history of significant  progressive pain in her left lower leg. The pain is accompanied by swelling  warmth  and tenderness  and she reports the leg appears somewhat reddened. She denies any recent trauma to the area  but admits to taking a 7-hour long flight two days before the onset of pain.   The patient is a sedentary office worker with a BMI of 32. She's a smoker and takes oral contraceptive pills. She has no known allergies. Her maternal grandmother had a history of recurrent pulmonary embolism. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or fainting spells.   Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both are well-controlled with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively). Aside from limited physical activity due to her sedentary job  she confesses to a poor diet  rich in fast food and sweets  citing lack of time to cook healthier meals as the main reason.   On examination  her blood pressure is 138/89 mmHg  pulse rate is 78 beats/min and O2 saturation is 98% in room air. Her left calf is visibly swollen compared to right  and there is palpable warmth and tenderness over the left posterior calf.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old obese Caucasian male patient presents to the emergency department complaining of progressive left lower limb pain and swelling for the past week. He also mentions mild redness and warmth over the affected area  and slight shortness of breath. The patient has a chronic history of smoking 1 pack/day for the past 30 years. Relevant past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He underwent a hip replacement surgery three weeks ago and has been relatively immobile since then. He reports no known drug allergies and takes a daily Aspirin (81mg) for blood pressure regulation and a statin for cholesterol control. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease: his father had a myocardial infarction at age 55 and his sister was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis at age 60. The patient denies fever  chest pain or recent trauma to the leg.

Patient Information: A 62-year-old African-American male  John Wilson.  Chief Complaint: Pain and swelling in the right calf for the past 2 days.   History of Present Illness: The patient has been experiencing a persistent discomfort and swelling in the right calf  which has worsened over the past 2 days. The pain is moderate  constant  and increases in severity with movement. He denies recent trauma or injury. He also reports recent flights and a sedentary lifestyle related to his job as a truck driver. He has never had this type of swelling before  and over-the-counter pain medications didn’t seem to help.  Relevant Past Medical History: Patient had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago and has been compliant with medication. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years. He's been a smoker for 20 years  1 pack/day. No history of prior deep vein thrombosis  pulmonary embolism  or blood clotting disorders.   Family History: Father died of a heart attack and mother had a history of deep vein thrombosis.  Physical Exam: The right calf appears to be somewhat larger than the left  with mild erythema  and tenderness upon palpation. The distal pulses of both lower extremities are equally strong. No shortness of breath or chest pain.  Social History: The patient lives with his wife  he is a frequent traveler due to his current job as a truck driver. Drinks alcohol occasionally  smokes one pack of cigarettes daily.  Review of Systems: No recent illnesses  fevers  or chills. Reports increased fatigue in recent weeks. Denies issues with urination or bowel movements. Denies chest pain or difficulty catching breath.

Patient is a 65-year-old African American female who presents with unilateral right lower leg pain  swelling  and erythema. She mentions new onset of lower limb pain that seems persistent  primarily localized in her calf. The pain intensifies when she points her toes upwards towards her head. Patient denies any recent surgery or history of prolonged immobilization. However  she mentions recently undergoing hormone replacement therapy for post-menopausal symptoms. Patient has a past medical history of hypertension  obesity with a BMI of 35  and Type 2 diabetes. She has no known drug allergies  and no history of varicose veins or previous blood clot conditions. Patient reports that her father suffered from recurrent deep vein thrombosis episodes. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. The patient adheres to her oral medication for diabetes and hypertension.   On examination  her right lower limb appears noticeably swollen and redder than her left limb  and it's warm to touch. Her calf circumference is significantly larger on the right side than the left. Differential leg measurements show a difference in size greater than 3 cm  suggesting presence of deep vein thrombosis. The patient’s vitals are normal except for a mild elevation in blood pressure which is 145/90 mmHg. Blood work is pending. An ultrasound Doppler study of the leg has been ordered. The patient was advised about the suspected diagnosis and the importance of further intervention and management. She seemed anxious but acknowledged understanding.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Shane Thompson is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker with a past medical history significant for hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and a recent left total hip replacement surgery. He presents to the clinic with complaints of a painful  swollen left leg which has been getting worse over the last 24 hours. He describes the pain as a constant heavy ache and notes that standing or walking seems to exacerbate the discomfort. He also mentions that the area of concern feels warmer than the surrounding skin and has become mildly reddened.  Besides hip replacement surgery  his past surgical history includes appendectomy 20 years ago. In terms of his family history  Mr. Thompson mentions that his mother underwent treatment for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) several years ago. Therefore  he is aware of this condition and expresses concern that his current symptoms may be indicative of DVT.  His medication regimen includes Metoprolol for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes  both of which he has been compliant with. He also reports a history of poor mobility due to ongoing recovery from the hip replacement surgery. He says that since the operation  he spends a considerable amount of time seated  which has significantly reduced his daily physical activity levels.   Mr. Thompson denies chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or any other systemic symptoms. He does not have any known allergies. He denies the use of alcohol or recreational drugs.   The symptoms combined with recent surgery and significant family history of DVT strongly suggest the possibility of deep vein thrombosis. An urgent Doppler ultrasound has been arranged to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez is a 65-year-old Hispanic male  with a prior medical history of metastatic prostate cancer  hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He presents to the emergency department with complaints of a sudden onset of swelling  warmth  redness  and increasing pain in his right leg over the last 24 hours. Mr. Rodriguez also mentions a recent long-haul flight he took 2 weeks ago.  Upon further questioning  the patient reveals he has been on hormonal therapy (androgen deprivation therapy) for his metastatic prostate cancer for the last 6 months. His hypertension is controlled with lisinopril and his diabetes is kept under control with metformin.   He reports adherence to his medications and has no known drug allergies. He also reports a smoking history of 20-pack years and daily alcohol use. His father died of a heart attack at 72 and his two older siblings have a history of cardiac disease.   On physical examination  there is noticeable swelling  redness  and warmness of the right calf  which is also tender on palpation. No ulcers or marks seen on the leg. His vital signs are stable  with blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  heart rate 85 bpm  respiratory rate 18 per min  temperature 37.3°C  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air.  There is a strong suspicion of deep vein thrombosis given the clinical presentation  patient's age  cancer diagnosis  recent long haul flight  and smoking history.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with swelling in his right lower leg  which he noticed just this morning. The patient reports that the swelling is accompanied by a dull ache  redness  and warmth over the area.  He is a retired construction worker with a past medical history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and has been on medication for controlling both conditions. The patient also reports that he traveled overseas two weeks ago on a 10-hour flight  following which he largely remained sedentary due to quarantine regulations.  He is an ex-smoker and quit smoking 5 years ago  after a 35-year history of smoking one pack per day. He occasionally consumes alcohol  about 2-3 units per week. He denies any recent surgical procedures or history of similar symptoms. There is no family history of clotting disorders or venous thromboembolism.   Upon physical examination  the entire right calf is swollen  warm and tender on palpitation. Pulses in the right leg are palpable  but dull. He has a BMI of 30.5 kg/m2. There is no noted trauma or injury to the leg.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. R.S.  presents to the Emergency Department with a complaint of increasing left lower leg pain and swelling for the past 3 days. He describes the pain as a constant  dull ache  rated as 7/10  worsening over time and not relieved by rest or over-the-counter pain medications. The left lower leg appears red and swollen compared to the right. There is no history of trauma or injury.   Mr. R.S. is a retired engineer  leads a sedentary lifestyle and recently had a long flight about 2 weeks ago. He reports no significant alcohol use or illicit drug use. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day for the last 40 years.   Relevant past medical history is significant for hypertension  well controlled with daily Lisinopril and has been overweight (BMI: 27.8). He did not have any previous surgery or documented blood clotting disorders. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction in his late 60s. He is noncompliant with his recommended regular exercise regimen.  This patient’s risk factors  including advanced age  sedentary lifestyle  recent long-haul flight (potential immobilization)  smoking  and being overweight  all suggest the possibility of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of pain and swelling in the left lower leg since the last 48 hours. He reports that the pain is constant  dull in nature  and worsens upon walking. He also noticed the skin over the affected area becoming warmer and a bit red. He denies experiencing any chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. The patient has a sedentary lifestyle and recently traveled on a long flight.   Past Medical and Family History:  The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He had an appendectomy at the age of 20 and a right total knee replacement 3 years ago. He has been smoking about a half pack a day since he was 18. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. Family history is notable for a mother who had stroke at the age of 80 and a paternal uncle with a history of pulmonary embolism. This patient's profile suggests that he has several conditions that could increase his risk of deep vein thrombosis  such as his sedentary lifestyle  long flight travel  and smoking.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired from his job as a long-haul truck driver  who presents today with complaints of a swollen  red  warm to touch  painful right leg that has been gradually worsening over the past week. He acknowledges a history of long periods without movement both during his career and recently during a long transatlantic flight. He also reports a dull  aching sensation in the affected leg  chiefly in his calf region.   He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are managed medically with an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (lisinopril) and a statin (simvastatin)  respectively. The patient states his compliance has been moderate with these medications. He reports no history of any coagulation disorders or thromboses.  The patient is a current smoker with a 30-pack-year history. He occasionally consumes alcohol  maybe about once or twice per month in social contexts. He denies any current substance misuse history or recreational drug use.   He is concerned about his symptoms  which are now making it difficult for him to mobilize. Therefore  he presents seeking medical attention to investigate and manage his symptoms.

Patient Information: Male  63 years old  overweight  a long-distance truck driver  Chief Complaint: Unilateral right leg swelling  pain  and redness for the last 4 days.   Present Illness: The patient describes a dull  aching discomfort in his right calf that is progressively worsening. He mentions that the pain is especially distinct after sitting for prolonged periods  which is a regular part of his truck driving job. The patient also reports mild shortness of breath on exertion.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  diabetes  and heart disease. He underwent hip replacement surgery 2 months ago.  Family History: The patient's father had a stroke at the age of 68. The patient's mother died of breast cancer at the age of 72.  Medications: Metformin  Lisinopril  and Aspirin.  Social History: The patient is a current smoker with a 30 pack-year history of smoking. He reports drinking alcohol occasionally. Denies any illicit drug use.   Review of Systems: - Cardiovascular: Positive for chest discomfort on exertion  - Respiratory: Positive for shortness of breath - Musculoskeletal: Positive for right lower extremity pain and swelling  Physical Examination: Right lower extremity is swollen  warm  and erythematous compared to the left leg. There is tenderness on palpation of the right calf.  Differential Diagnosis: Deep vein thrombosis  Cellulitis  Baker's cyst  Muscle strain  Peripheral artery diseases.  Recommended Investigations: CBC  D-dimer test  Compression Ultrasound of the right leg  possibly venography or MRI if ultrasound is inconclusive.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old  Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of intense  localized pain in his left lower leg that began 2 days ago. The patient also reports swelling  and warmth at the same site. Notably  he notes that his pain worsens when standing or walking. He denies any recent trauma or history of injury to his leg. He also denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or any other associated symptoms.  Relevant Past Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  for which he is on Amlodipine and Metformin respectively. His surgical history includes a recent hip replacement surgery on the right side  about 4 weeks ago  for which he was largely bedbound during the recovery period. He used to smoke almost a pack/day till 10 years ago  but has since quit. He reports drinking alcohol occasionally. His family history includes a brother with DVT.  Patient does not have known malignancy.  Current Medications:  - Amlodipine 10mg daily - Metformin 500mg twice daily.  Overall  the patient’s recent orthopedic surgery  age  family history of DVT and long period of immobility are significant risk factors suggesting a working diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of swelling  warmth  and pain in his left lower extremity  primarily in the calf region. The patient describes the pain as a dull ache that has progressively worsened over the past couple of days. He denies trauma  difficulty in walking  or other complaints elsewhere in the body.  The patient has a significant past medical history of total hip replacement surgery 6 weeks ago. He was also diagnosed with hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus approximately 4 years ago  for which he takes Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  and admits to occasional consumption of alcohol.  He recalls a long family history of clotting disorders  with his father having suffered from recurrent venous thromboembolism (VTE)  and his elder sister having been diagnosed with Factor V Leiden deficiency.  On physical examination  the patient's left calf appears noticeably swollen and erythematous compared to the right side  with tenderness on palpation. The vitals are stable  and the rest of the examination is unremarkable.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room with acute-onset left leg pain and swelling that started suddenly 24 hours ago. The pain is described as a constant  dull ache  rated 7/10 and localized to the calf region  slightly relieved with analgesic intake. The patient states leg is also warmer to touch and has noticed skin discoloration. There is no history of trauma or injury to the leg. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or other systemic symptoms.  The patient has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He underwent a total hip replacement surgery six weeks ago  after which he spent most of the time in bed. He is on Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He does not recall taking any anticoagulant prescribed post-surgery. He is an ex-smoker and denies alcohol or illicit drug use. His father had a history of pulmonary embolism.   On examination  the left lower limb is observed to be edematous with erythema and is warmer compared to the right leg. He is vitally stable and other systemic examinations including cardiovascular  respiratory  and neurological are unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Smith  a 50-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain and swelling in her left lower leg  which has been gradually worsening over the past week. The pain is described as a constant  aching pain  primarily in the calf area  that is exacerbated by walking or standing. She denies any history of injury or trauma to the area.   She has a past medical history significant for obesity with a BMI of 35  type 2 diabetes  and hypertension. That being said  all her chronic conditions have been well controlled with appropriate medication. She underwent Total Abdominal Hysterectomy seven days ago due to uterine fibroids and was subsequently discharged with low molecular weight Heparin for thromboprophylaxis  but she confesses to not having taken the medication regularly.  On examination  her vitals are stable. The left leg appears noticeably swollen compared to the right leg. A warmth and redness is observed over the area with mild tenderness on touch. Pedal pulses are equally strong in both legs.   She has a 20 pack-year history of smoking and stopped 5 years ago. She does not consume alcohol or use recreational drugs. She lives alone and is currently on medical leave from her job due to her recent surgery. There is no relevant family history such as thromboembolic diseases. She is currently on Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin.    On the basis of the clinical examination and history  her recent surgery and lack of compliance with prophylactic anticoagulation therapy puts her at a high risk for deep vein thrombosis. Doppler ultrasound of the leg has been ordered to further evaluate the condition.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jackson is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents in the emergency department with complaints of pain and swelling in his left leg  which has been persisting for the last two days. The pain is constant  dull in nature  and he rates it as 6 out of 10 on the pain scale. He also notes the skin overlying the region is slightly warm and red. He denies any recent injury  but divulges that he recently completed a transcontinental flight that lasted for about 14 hours.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  controlled with medication  and a myocardial infarction two years ago. He reports that he used to smoke  but quit 5 years ago  and has a glass or two of wine on the weekends. He denies any family history of blood clots.   Mr. Jackson’s current medications include Low-dose Aspirin and Lisinopril for his hypertension. He is retired and lives with his wife. He reports being compliant with his medications and regular check-ups. He reported he leads a currently sedentary lifestyle since his retirement and that he has gained weight in the past year.   Given his experienced symptoms and medical history  a risk of deep vein thrombosis is considered and further investigation is planned.

Patient Information: Mr. Johan Robertson  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  non-smoker  BMI 26.  Chief Complaint: Progressive left leg swelling  mild pain behind the knee  and redness for about three days.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Robertson has been experiencing discomfort in his left leg which has gradually worsened over the past three days. He describes the sensation as a pain in his calf region  specifically  a dull ache that becomes more severe when walking. There is associated left leg swelling which has increased in size and is warm to touch. The patient denies history of similar pain or swelling  any trauma  rash  or recent prolonged immobilization.  Past Medical History: Has a well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. History of one episode of pulmonary embolism 4 years ago. Takes lisinopril  metformin  and eliquis to manage these conditions.  Family History: Father died of a heart attack at 72  mother passed away from a stroke at 79. One younger brother is living with type 2 diabetes.  Review of systems: Denies chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or any recent surgeries. No history of any malignancies.  Physical Exam: Patient is alert and oriented. Vital signs stable. Left leg appears edematous  erythematous  and a bit warmer compared to the right leg. Homan's sign positive. Neurovascular assessment within normal limits. Cardiovascular assessment shows regular rate and rhythm. No cyanosis  clubbing  or edema in the right leg. Rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Assessment: Findings consistent with a concern for deep vein thrombosis  given the leg swelling  erythema  warmth  and his previous history of pulmonary embolism.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe  Age: 56 years  Gender: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Works as an IT manager  Presenting Complaints:  John came to the hospital complaining of a progressively worsening pain and swelling in his right leg for the last 4 days. He felt the pain was mostly in his calf and it was more intense when he walked. He also noticed the skin over the increasingly swollen area was warm and slightly redder than usual.   Past Medical History:  John was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes 10 years ago and has been managing his condition with oral hypoglycemic agents. He is also hypertensive  under treatment for the last 2 years. He underwent a total right hip replacement surgery 5 weeks ago due to severe osteoarthritis. His post-operative recovery was uneventful until recently. John has a significant history of smoking of around 20 cigarettes per day for the past 35 years.  Medications:  John is currently taking Metformin  a blood pressure medication (Lisinopril)  and a statin (Simvastatin).  Family History:  John's father had a stroke at the age of 61 and his mother was diagnosed with breast cancer in her late 50s. His elder brother had a pulmonary embolism after a surgery when he was about John's age.  Social History:  John drinks alcohol socially and is a current smoker. He has no history of recreational drug use. He works long hours  often in a sedentary position.   Travel History:  John took a long-haul 10- hour flight post his surgery for a business meeting about 7 days back.   This overall history and symptoms suggest the possibility of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  likely caused by the recent surgery  prolonged inactivity during the flight  as well as his sedentary lifestyle.

Patient Presentation:  Jane Smith is a 62-year-old Caucasian female  who presented to the office with a complaint of pain and swelling in her right lower leg that began two days ago. The pain is continuous  and increases with movement. No associated numbness or weakness noticed. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  coughing  or any systemic symptoms. Mrs. Smith has a history of obesity and sedentary lifestyle  and recently had a total knee replacement surgery two weeks ago. She has a known case of hypertension for which she takes medication.  On physical examination  the right lower leg appears more swollen than the left one  and is warm to touch. No discoloration was observed. The Homans' sign was positive. Her last Hemoglobin level was 12.7 g/dL  and BMI is 30.9.  A Doppler ultrasonography of the right lower extremity is planned to confirm the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. The patient was counselled about the need for anticoagulation therapy  physical therapy  and lifestyle modifications to control her obesity and sedentary lifestyle. She was warned about the danger signs such as chest pain  shortness of breath  which should prompt immediate medical attention.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Sandra  a 62-year-old postmenopausal African American woman  presented to the outpatient clinic with symptoms of pain and swelling in her right lower leg  which she initially attributed to a strained muscle from gardening. The pain had persisted over the last week  becoming more severe  with progressive swelling and redness of the right calf. She denied any trauma or injury to the leg.   She appeared to be overweight with a BMI of 32. She has a known history of varicose veins  which had worsened over the past few years. She also has a past medical history of hypertension  which is well controlled on medication (Lisinopril)  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with Metformin. She is a former smoker  having quit 3 years ago  and admits to occasional alcohol consumption.  She recently took a long haul flight back from visiting her daughter in Australia  which was over 16 hours of immobility  approximately 2 weeks ago. No known allergies were reported.   Her family history revealed her father had died of a stroke at age 80  and her maternal grandmother had peripheral vascular disease. She denies any familial history of clotting disorders.   On examination  her right lower leg appeared to have a circumference larger than the left and is warm to touch  with visible varicosities present. She experienced tenderness on calf compression.  Given her risk factors - immobilization during the long flight  overweight  advancing age  history of varicose veins  and hypercoagulability due to her hypertension and diabetes  the possibility of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) was considered. She was advised to undergo further diagnostic tests including a D-Dimer Test and Duplex Ultrasound. Until these results are available  she has been started on low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) as a precautionary measure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic today complaining of progressive pain  warmth  redness  and swelling in his left lower leg that has been worsening over the last few days. He denies any trauma to the leg and has not done any recent heavy lifting or straining.  Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for Type 2 diabetes mellitus  well-controlled on Metformin  and was recently initiated on hormone therapy due to prostate cancer. He quit smoking 10 years ago but had a 30-pack-year history before quitting. He does not exercise regularly and works as an accountant  sitting for long periods.   He took a long-distance  transatlantic flight about two weeks ago. There is no history of similar episodes and no known family history of blood clotting disorders.   On clinical examination  his left leg was found to be swollen  warm  erythematous  and tender to touch. Homan's sign is positive. There was no evidence of any superficial vein varicosities or ulceration. His vitals are stable; however  his BMI indicates obesity.   Given this clinical picture  a working diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis was made.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department complaining of an acute onset of pain and swelling in his left lower leg. The swelling began 2 days ago while he was driving  and it has been progressively worsening. The pain is constant  rated 7/10  and located in the calf area. He also reports mild shortness of breath. He denies any trauma  fever  chest pain or other systemic symptoms.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication  and he had a knee replacement surgery on the right side 6 years ago. The patient is a former smoker  having stopped 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and doesn't have any known drug allergies.  The patient is retired and lives with his wife  they recently returned from a trip to Europe where they had long periods of sitting during flight and car rides. He is currently on Lisinopril for hypertension and Simvastatin for hyperlipidemia. His parents had coronary artery disease and his father suffered from a stroke in his late 70's. Right now  the symptomology does suggest a possible case of deep vein thrombosis.

A 55 year old  Caucasian male  truck driver by occupation  presents to the emergency department with gradually increasing left leg pain and swelling persisting for the past week. The leg is warm to touch and appears slightly red. He describes the pain as a cramping type and non-radiating. Patient denies any recent trauma or surgery.   Additionally  he reports feelings of light-headedness  but denies chest pain  cough  or shortness of breath. Patient's past medical history includes poorly controlled Type II Diabetes Mellitus and a 35-year history of smoking a pack of cigarettes each day. Furthermore  he has a sedentary lifestyle and his work involves long hours of driving. He admits to non-compliance with his hypoglycemic medications. His father suffered a stroke at 60 years of age and mother was diagnosed with breast cancer  but no known family history of coagulation disorders.   He is allergic to Penicillin causing rash. Current medications include Metformin and Lisinopril. Vital signs on presentation are BP - 150/90 mmHg  Pulse - 90 bpm  Temp - 99°F  and Oxygen Saturation - 96% room air.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents with a five-day history of a persistent  dull ache in his left calf that began suddenly. He reports the pain gets worse during walking. He describes additional symptoms including slight swelling  warmth and redness around the affected calf area. He denies any recent injuries. Although he describes a sedentary lifestyle since retirement  he has recently taken a long-haul flight (12 hours) to visit his family.  The patient's past medical history is significant. He has a history of high blood pressure  controlled with Lisinopril  and was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation 3 years ago  for which he takes Aspirin. He underwent knee replacement surgery on the same leg 2 years ago. He's a former smoker  having quit around 20 years ago  and reports occasional alcohol use. No known history of malignancy or thrombotic events in the past  although his father had a stroke in his late 60s. The patient reports compliance to his medication regimen and has not noted any unusual bleeding or bruising.  On physical examination  the left calf is mildly swollen  erythematous  and warm compared with the right calf. There's a slight increase in calf diameter as compared to the right calf. No palpable cord is felt  and Homan's sign is positive. He has a regular pulse rate and his blood pressure is slightly elevated.  Considering his clinical presentation  recent travel history  sedentary lifestyle  and personal medical history  the patient is at high risk for deep vein thrombosis. An ultrasound examination of the lower extremities is organized to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with progressive left leg pain and swelling that has been persisting for the last four days. The patient reports a tight and sore sensation with intermittent sharp pains originating from the calf. There is no history of trauma  recent surgeries  or immobilization.  He notes no fever  chills  or respiratory symptoms. He has never experienced this before. The patient further reports a significant increase in calf circumference compared with the unaffected side.   The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension and he has been a smoker for 40 years. His father died from a heart attack at an early age (55yrs). He denies any history of cancer or known hereditary clotting disorders.   He is retired and leads a sedentary life. He reports being under high stress lately due to a personal crisis and admits that he has been moving less frequently than usual.   His medications include Lisinopril for his hypertension and Aspirin for prevention of heart disease. He has no known drug allergies.   Given his age  persistent symptoms  smoking history  sedentary lifestyle  and personal stress  there is an elevated risk for deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Information: Mrs. Elizabeth  White Female  Age: 65  Presenting Problem: Mrs. Elizabeth presents with complaints of unilateral swelling on her left lower leg for the past 2 days. She also reports associated pain  warmth  and redness in the same area. She denies any shortness of breath or chest pain.   Past Medical History: Significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes. She also underwent a total hip replacement 2 years ago. She has a family history of venous thromboembolism  her father had a pulmonary embolism in his late sixties.   Social History: She is an ex-smoker  quit smoking 10 years ago. Occasional drinker and has no history of drug abuse. She is a retired school teacher  lives with her husband.   Medications: Lisinopril for hypertension  Metformin for diabetes  and Rosuvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  Travel History: She recently returned from a 15-hour flight about a week ago.   Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Upon physical examination  the left calf is visibly swollen and warm to the touch. Mild tenderness is noted upon palpation and the pain seems to increase on dorsi-flexing her foot (Homans sign). No signs of trauma to the area are present.

Patient Information: 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired  lives alone  non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumption.  Chief Complaint: Unilateral leg swelling and pain for the past three days.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports his right leg started swelling three days ago with associated pain and tenderness. The swelling and pain have been worsening gradually. He denies any trauma  insect bites  or recent travel. He gets short of breath when walking short distances  which he attributes to his increased weight. There's been no chest pain  coughing up blood  or altered consciousness. He denies any history of similar episodes in the past.   Past Medical History: Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  maintained on medications (amlodipine 10 mg once daily). Underwent a total knee replacement surgery 2 months back. Medication allergy to penicillin group of drugs (gives him a rash).   Family history: Father had a stroke  mother had breast cancer and brother had history of recurrent deep vein thrombosis.  Review of Systems: Negative  except positive for fatigue  mild weight gain  mild shortness of breath  and leg swelling as described in HPI.  Physical Exam: Mildly obese  swelling  tenderness and warmth over right lower leg and calf area. No overlying skin changes or ulcerations. No palpable cord. Positive Homan's sign on right. Negative Homan's sign on left. No signs of chest distress or altered heart sounds.   Assessment: Unilateral leg swelling and pain with a recent history of orthopedic surgery  positive Homan's sign  and family history of recurrent DVT consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) likely due to postoperative state with possible genetic predisposition. He also presents mild shortness of breath which might indicate a possible Pulmonary Embolism. Further investigation is needed to confirm these conditions. Patient must be monitored closely and anticoagulant therapy initiated if confirmed.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old overweight  Caucasian male  retired construction worker  with a 10-year history of uncontrolled type II diabetes and hypertension  former smoker for 20 years  20 packs a year with occasional consumption of alcohol.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents with a swollen  red  and warm to touch right lower leg since two days.  History of Present Illness: The patient states that his leg started swelling after a 10-hour long car ride. The swelling was mild in the beginning but gradually increased and associated with moderate to severe pain  which gets worse with ambulation. He denies trauma  fever  chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness. There is no history of similar episodes previously. He started to restrict his mobility due to pain.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  bilateral venous insufficiency  and peripheral neuropathy. He previously had myocardial infarction 5 years ago and was stented. There is no family history of clotting disorders.  Medications: Glipizide  Lisinopril  aspirin  and Lipitor.   Physical Examination: Vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals that the right calf is swollen  firm  and 3 cm larger than the left calf. It has a warmer temperature than the left calf. There is tenderness upon palpation. Pedal pulses are diminutive but present bilaterally. There is no evidence of ulcers or skin lesions.  Other system examinations are unremarkable.  In this presentation  there is a suspicion of deep vein thrombosis. The patient's conditions and lifestyle put him at a higher risk for DVT - long periods of immobility from the car ride  uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  obesity  and history of smoking.  Please note that this is a presumptive diagnosis  confirmation of the diagnosis should be done through appropriate diagnostic tests like Doppler ultrasound leg.

Title: Case Presentation on Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  **Slide 1: Introduction**  Deep vein thrombosis refers to a condition where a clot forms in a deep vein  typically in the leg. Complications can include pulmonary embolism  an emergency situation. Raising awareness of DVT signs and risk factors allows for early detection and management  thus reducing complications.  **Slide 2: Demographics**  Patient Profile:  - Age: 65 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired (previous occupation: office worker) - Lifestyle: Sedentary  **Slide 3: Past Medical History**  The patient has a history of the following:  - Type II Diabetes Mellitus - Hypertension - High cholesterol - Surgery (knee replacement) six months ago - Non-smoker - Moderate alcohol consumption  **Slide 4: Clinical Presentation**  Recent presentation includes:  - Swelling in the affected leg - Leg pain and tenderness often described as a cramp or Charley horse - Reddish or bluish skin discoloration - Leg warm to the touch  **Slide 5: Diagnosis**  Given the patient's history and clinical presentation  Doppler ultrasound examination was done revealing a positive result for DVT in the left lower leg.  **Slide 6: Management**  The patient was initiated on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) alongside oral anticoagulant therapy (Warfarin)  to be continued for 6 months.   **Slide 7: Follow-up and Prevention**  The patient was advised on the importance of regular follow-up  adhering to medication  and lifestyle modification including increasing mobility  elevating legs when sitting  and maintaining a healthful diet.  **Slide 8: Summary**  DVT is a serious condition requiring prompt diagnosis and management. High-risk populations such as elderly  sedentary  and those with a history of surgery needs to be aware of the signs and symptoms. Early diagnosis and appropriate management can significantly reduce complications.   Thank you.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis: A Clinical Encounter  Slide 1: Introduction  ""Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a common condition  where a blood clot forms in the deep veins  often in the leg or pelvis. It has a variety of causes and risk factors  and can lead to serious complications  such as pulmonary embolism. Today  we'll discuss a case to enrich your understanding of the clinical presentation and management of DVT.""  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  · Patient: Mr. A  52-year-old male · Occupation: Truck driver  leads a sedentary lifestyle · Non-smoker  occasional drinker  · Known hypertensive and overweight   Slide 3: Past Medical History   · Diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago  occasional medication non-compliance  · Recently undergone right knee arthroplasty two weeks prior to presentation. · Family history of coagulation disorders (father diagnosed with DVT and Pulmonary Embolism)  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints    · Pain and swelling in the right calf · Reduced mobility due to pain · Mild fever  Slide 5: Clinical Examination  · Warmth and erythema over the right leg · Palpable cord felt · Positive Homan’s sign  Slide 6: Investigations   · D-dimer test: Elevated levels  · Ultrasound Doppler: Shows evidence of clot in the right calf vein. · BMI (Body mass index): 30 (suggesting obesity)  Slide 7: Diagnosis  · Based on the Risk factors such as hypertension  concurrent obesity  post-surgery immobility  and family history  along with symptoms  signs and tests results  the diagnosis is Deep Vein Thrombosis.  Slide 8: Management   · Initiation of anticoagulant therapy with Low molecular weight heparin followed by oral anticoagulant like Warfarin. · Pain management: Paracetamol or NSAIDs · Lifelong lifestyle change advice focussing on weight reduction  reducing sedentary lifestyle  regular checkups to monitor hypertension and medication adherence.  Slide 9: Patient Education & Follow-up  · Explaining the importance of regular medication and monitoring · Importance of regular exercise and a healthy diet · Warning signs to watch out for: Respiratory symptoms  increased leg swelling and pain · Regular follow-ups for monitoring coagulation profile and managing hypertension.  Slide 10: Summary    ""To manage patients with DVT  like Mr. A  it's essential not only to treat with anticoagulants  but also to address modifiable risk factors — like sedentary behavior and obesity — for a successful and comprehensive approach to prevent the recurrence of DVT and potential complications.""

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis: A Detailed Case Study  Slide 2: Demographics Title: Patient's Demographic Information Patient Profile: - Age: 55 years old - Sex: Female - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Sedentary job  Office Worker  Slide 3: Past Medical History Title: Overview of Patient's Medical History - Patient has been in good health  no chronic diseases. - Previous medical history includes an ankle fracture 3 years ago. - Previous surgical history includes a cesarean section 20 years ago. - Non-smoker  occasional alcohol consumption - No known drug allergies  - Family history: Mother had a stroke  father with history of heart disease.  Slide 4: Recent Medical Concern Title: Recent Medical Issues and Symptoms - Patient recently complained of swelling  redness  and tenderness in her left lower leg. - No history of trauma or injury to the leg. - Began feeling these symptoms after a long  non-stop flight from New York to Sydney two weeks ago. - Expressed feelings of slight fatigue and shortness of breath.  Slide 5: Diagnosis Title: Diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) - Ultrasonography confirmed the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left lower extremity. - D-dimer levels were positive and elevated.  Slide 6: Treatment Title: Treatment Plan for the Patient - Initiated on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for immediate anticoagulation. - The patient will transition to oral anticoagulation therapy (Warfarin) over next few days.  - Long term anticoagulation treatment for at least three months is recommended. - Patient was advised to avoid prolonged periods of immobility and encouraged to do leg exercises. - Patient will have consistent follow-ups for monitoring and adjustment of medication dosage.  Slide 7: Conclusion Title: Early Recognition and Intervention is Key  - Importance of recognizing symptoms of DVT in patients.  - Speak about risks associated with long periods of immobility. - Emphasize on patient's active role in dealing with DVT - e.g. regular movement  following prescribed therapy etc.

Title: Case Study of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Woman  Slide 1: Introduction  Description: Introduction of the patient subject- Mrs. Jane Smith  52 years old woman.  Slide 2: Demographics Description: Discusses some key demographic factors. Mrs. Smith is a Caucasian female  married  mother of two  living in a suburban area. She's a nonsmoker but is moderately obese (BMI 32). She works as a data analyst  which involves prolonged periods of sitting.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Description: Mrs. Smith has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  which are controlled with medications. She had a total knee replacement surgery 10 days ago. Her mother suffered from a pulmonary embolism  resulting from DVT  at the age of 58. There is no history of any hematological diseases or malignancies.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms Description: Mrs. Smith has recently presented with symptoms indicative of DVT. She is experiencing swelling  tenderness and redness in her right leg  local warmth  and painful ambulation.  Slide 5: Diagnosis Description: An ultrasound examination confirmed the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis in her right lower leg.  Slide 6: Risk Factors  Description: Mrs. Smith's risk factors for developing DVT include obesity  prolonged immobility due to her job and post knee surgery recovery time  genetic predisposition due to her mother's history.  Slide 7: Treatment Plan Description: Initial treatment has been started on low molecular weight heparin and transitioned to oral anticoagulants. Physiotherapy has also been recommended for better mobility.   Slide 8: Recommendations Description: Lifestyle modification is recommended including periodic mobilization at work  maintaining a normal BMI  and continuing anticoagulation therapy under regular monitoring. A potential consultation with a hematologist might be necessary for potential thrombophilia screening considering family history.  Slide 9: Conclusion & Follow-up Description: Regular follow-ups  constant monitoring of symptoms  evaluation of the efficacy and side effects of anticoagulants  and adherence to lifestyle modifications all play crucial roles in the prognosis.  Slide 10: Q & A Description: Allow time for any potential questions and a quick recap of the case study.

Title: Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Slide 1: Introduction Background of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT); it is a medical condition where a blood clot (thrombus) forms in the one or more of the deep veins  usually in the legs  leading to potential life-threatening complications like pulmonary embolism.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Our patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male from a non-smoking background. He has a sedentary lifestyle and works as an office clerk. He is overweight with a BMI of 30.2 and has a family history of Venous Thromboembolism (VTE).  Slide 3: Medical History Patient has a history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  both well controlled with medication. He has undergone right knee replacement surgery eleven months ago. He does not have a history of allergies or previous clotting disorders. His mother had a history of DVT.  Slide 4: Current Complaints The patient sought help from the emergency department  citing acute onset of right leg pain and swelling that had intensified over the past 48 hours. The patient also reported a slight discharge from the previous surgical site.  Slide 5: Physical Examination On inspection  the right lower limb appeared swollen and red  with a raised local temperature. The Homans' sign [pain in calf muscles on forced dorsiflexion of the foot] was positive.  Slide 6: Clinical Diagnosis and Investigations Based on the history and clinical presentation  a preliminary diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis was considered. Further investigations  such as Doppler Ultrasonography of the Lower Limbs  D-dimer test  and possibly Contrast Venography  were ordered to confirm the diagnosis.  Slide 7: Results Doppler Ultrasound showed a non-compressible right popliteal vein  which confirms DVT. D-dimer levels were significantly high  reinforcing the diagnosis.  Slide 8: Treatment Plan Treatment was started with parenteral anticoagulants  unfractionated heparin  and later patient was shifted to oral warfarin therapy. Measures were also taken to control his diabetes and hypertension.  Slide 9: Prevention   Patient education focused on increasing mobility  weight loss  ceasing inactive lifestyle  tight control of diabetes  and hypertension.  Slide 10: The importance of Early Diagnosis  The potential complications from DVT  such as pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome  highlight the importance of early diagnosis and treatment.  End of Presentation.
