A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of obesity  hypertension  and sedentary lifestyle presents with freshly diagnosed deep vein thrombosis following an extended plane travel.
A 65-year-old female smoker with a history of hypertension and obesity presents with evening swelling and redness in her left leg  suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

A 50-year-old male construction worker with a past medical history of obesity and hypertension presents with a new-onset left calf pain and swelling suggestive of a DVT  having a high-risk lifestyle due to prolonged sedentary work hours and infrequent physical activity.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female  non-smoker with a past medical history of hypertension and obesity  presents with a complaint of gradual onset  localized pain and swelling in her left calf for the past 48 hours. She reports no history of trauma nor immobilization. She also reports a recent long-distance flight 2 weeks ago. On further discussion  she shares she has stopped her regular walking due to fear of exerting her leg. She notices warmth over the painful area but denies fever or other constitutional symptoms. There is no history of similar episodes in the past; however  she does mention a previous history of miscarriages  although no definite diagnosis of a hypercoagulable state was ever made. No known history of cancer or family history of venous thromboembolism. Physical examination reveals a swollen left calf  with localized tenderness  warmth  erythema  and a positive Homans' sign. No palpable cords or superficial venous dilatation are perceived. Her vital signs are stable.

A 45-year-old female patient  non-smoker with a history of oral contraceptive use  presents to the emergency department following a recent 12-hour long haul flight. She reports a 3-day history of increasing pain and swelling in her right calf  which is now warm and slightly discolored. She denies any previous similar episodes or family history of clotting disorders. The patient is afebrile  with normal blood pressure and heart rate. The rest of her medical history is insignificant. The presenting symptoms  history  and risk factors raise a high suspicion for deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: The patient has a hypertension under control with medication. He is a former smoker and has a family history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. He recently underwent a hip replacement surgery 2 weeks ago and has been relatively inactive.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents with significant swelling in the right lower leg  which has developed over the past several days. He reports intense pain in the region  especially when standing or walking. He also experiences warmth over the swollen area with noticeable reddening. He reports no chest pain or shortness of breath.  Primary Medical Problem: Suspected deep vein thrombosis (DVT) secondary to prolonged immobility post-hip surgery  taking into consideration his family history and predisposing factors. The swelling  pain  tenderness  warmth and redness over the affected area are indicative symptoms.

A 65-year-old male patient with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a recent total right knee replacement surgery 3 weeks ago  presents to the clinic complaining of ongoing  progressive pain and firm swelling in his right lower leg for the past 5 days. The pain is described as constant  dull ache  moderate in intensity  non-radiating and aggravated by movement. He further reports associated signs of increased warmth  skin redness over the area  and mild shortness of breath. He denies any cough  chest pain or recent trauma. He has an inconsistent history of medication compliance  including his prophylactic anticoagulation post-surgery. He has no history of previous thrombosis or familial clotting disorders. On physical examination  the right lower leg is indeed edematous with erythema  but no evidence of wound infection at the surgical site. No other significant findings were seen in the cardiovascular and respiratory system examination. No chest pain or tachycardia is reported. Based on the clinical presentation and the recent history of knee surgery  the indication points towards a possible deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right lower extremity.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of obesity and recent total hip replacement surgery presents with swelling  warmth  and tenderness in his left lower leg. He reports of a mild pain that intensifies when standing or moving the affected leg. He also mentioned mild shortness of breath. The patient does not report any current medication or known allergies. He discloses to be an ex-smoker and drinks occasionally. Family health history includes a sister with diagnosed deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The symptoms suggest a possible DVT  potentially complicated by a pulmonary embolism given the mild shortness of breath.

The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presents with a two-day history of redness  swelling  and warmth in the left lower extremity  specifically in the posterior calf area. The patient also complains of sharp  cramping pain in the affected leg; however  denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or light-headedness. The patient leads a sedentary lifestyle and recently came back from a cross-continental flight. There is no family history of clotting disorders or deep vein thrombosis. She denies tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drug use. On examination  the left calf is noticeably swollen and warm to touch  with tenderness along the line of major veins. She is hemodynamically stable with adequate peripheral perfusion. The differential diagnoses are deep vein thrombosis  Baker’s cyst  and cellulitis.

A 58-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of obesity (BMI 32 kg/m2)  varicose veins and hormone replacement therapy  presents with a 3-day history of progressive left-sided calf pain and slight swelling. She states that the pain has slowly worsened over time  is primarily at rest presenting a 7 out of 10 in severity and somewhat intensifies upon standing. Over the past 24 hours  she has also noted the overlying skin on her calf turning mildly red with a warm touch. Physical examination reveals a tender  warm and erythematous left calf with slight pitting edema. There is no history of similar episodes  recent long trips  or immobilization periods. She denies any shortness of breath  chest pain or lightheadedness. She has no family history of thrombosis or known hereditary coagulation disorders. The clinical suspicion of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is high given her symptoms and risk factors.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  obesity  and recent hip replacement surgery presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of swelling and pain in the right leg  which he describes as a deep  constant ache. He also reports a mild shortness of breath. He denies chest pain  cough or febrile symptoms. He smokes 10 cigarettes daily for the past 40 years and is sedentary in lifestyle. He had been largely immobilized post-surgery for about 3 weeks. On examination  his right lower leg is swollen  erythematous and warm compared to the left. The calf is tender on palpation. No open wounds or discoloration are present. Pulses are present and symmetrical in both lower extremities. Active and passive movements of the right leg cause discomfort. Lungs are clear to auscultation.

A 68-year-old  overweight Caucasian female with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents in the ER with a one-week history of progressive swelling and pain in her left lower leg. She reports difficulty walking due to the severity of the pain. She recently had a total hip replacement surgery performed on the same leg four weeks ago and spent a lot of time in bed after the surgery. She has not taken any prescribed anticoagulant medications following her surgery. On examination  the left calf was found to be universally swollen  erythematous  and tender to touch with some warmth in the area  suggestive of a deep vein thrombosis.

A 62-year-old male  with a past medical history notable for obesity (BMI 35)  hypertension  and sedentary lifestyle  presents with symptoms of left calf pain and swelling over the past 5 days. The pain is described as crampy and as being located deep in the calf  worsened with calf flexion and improved with limb elevation. He reports no history of prior similar episodes  cancer  known thrombophilia  or recent surgical procedures  but he did recently complete a long-haul flight. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  cough or hemoptysis. Examination reveals left calf swelling with circumference 3 cm greater than the right  with no overlying erythema or warmth  but patient winces with calf squeezing. The patient's vitals are stable. Given his symptoms  risk factors  and physical findings  there is a high suspicion for left-sided deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Thus  further investigation and subsequent management are warranted.

Patient Representation:   Mr. Rodriguez is a 63-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history notable for obesity  sedentary lifestyle and a 20 pack-year smoking history. He presents with complaints of sudden onset  progressive left calf pain  and swelling. Over the last 4 days  the calf pain increased with weight bearing. He denies any recent trauma  surgery  travel  or history of cancer. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations.  On examination  his left calf is 3 cm larger in circumference than the right and demonstrates tenderness to palpation. He also has a positive Homan's sign (pain in the back of the knee upon forced dorsiflexion of the foot). He reports no systemic symptoms such as fever or malaise. His vitals are stable.  Given his risk factors and presentation  there's a high clinical suspicion for deep vein thrombosis. Essential diagnostic tests like Doppler ultrasonography are anticipated.

A 68-year-old male  known case of type II diabetes and hypertension  reported to the ER with progressively worsening pain and swelling in his left lower extremity for the past 5 days. The patient also reported awareness of a slightly elevated body temperature and complained of a slight shortness of breath. The patient discloses a recent (2 weeks prior) hip replacement surgery. He is a non-smoker but his sedentary lifestyle and overweight BMI pose a concern. His medications include antihypertensives and oral hypoglycemics. Family history reveals a cousin with diagnosed deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Physical examination reveals a warm  erythematous  and tender left calf with a positive Homans sign. The concern is of acute left lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  possibly precipitated by recent surgery and his risk factors of sedentary lifestyle  obesity  advanced age  diabetes  and familial predisposition.

Problem Representation:  A 47-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history significant for obesity  sedentary lifestyle  chronic smoking and recently completed a long transcontinental flight presents to the emergency department with a one-week history of increasing left lower leg pain and swelling. The pain is described as achy and constant  exacerbated by walking  and slightly relieved by elevation. The patient also reports a low-grade fever and mild shortness of breath. She denies chest pain  cough  dizziness  or syncope.   On examination  there is noticeable swelling  warmth  and redness over her left calf which is tender to touch. Her lower extremity is significantly larger than the right. No superficial venous distention is noticed. Her vitals show a slightly raised heart rate. Pulmonary auscultation and examination of other systems are unremarkable.  The combination of her risk factors – recent prolonged immobilization due to a long flight  obesity  smoking  along with the presenting symptoms and signs  raise high clinical suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) which may also have precipitated a potential pulmonary embolization given the shortness of breath. Timely diagnostic investigation and management is vital to prevent further complications.

Patient Information: 69-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: Former smoker  obesity (BMI 30)  hypertension controlled with medication  personal history of superficial venous thrombosis 5 years ago  non-compliant with weight management program.  Chief Complaint: Swelling and pain in the left leg for past 1 week  History of Present Illness: One week history of progressively worsening pain and swelling in the left lower leg. Not associated with trauma. No previous history of similar symptoms. No history of recent long-distance travel or prolonged immobilization. No signs of infection. No chest pain or shortness of breath.   Physical Examination: Vital signs within normal range. Lower extremity examination revealed skin warmth  erythema  calf tenderness  and significant edema of the left lower leg. No superficial venous distention or varicose veins seen. No palpable cord felt. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Provisional Diagnosis: Given the patient's history and clinical presentation  this is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Problem Representation:  A 45 year-old  obese Caucasian male  with a significant history of smoking and recent orthopedic surgery of the left knee  presents with a few days' history of severe and progressive swelling  tenderness and pain in his left leg. He denies any history of trauma to the leg. He reports no symptoms of chest pain or shortness of breath. His vitals are stable. On physical exam  the leg is warm and cyanotic  indicating possible venous congestion. The Homans' sign was positive which is a potential indication of deep vein thrombosis. There is a need for further assessment for possible deep vein thrombosis  potentially due to his recent surgery and other risk factors.

A 64-year-old Caucasian male  current smoker with a history of hypertension  and obesity currently treated with Lisinopril and Metformin  presents with increasing pain and swelling in his left lower extremity over the past week. He reported a recent long haul flight around 3 weeks ago. His work involves prolonged periods of sitting. He does not have a known history of cancer or thrombophilia  no known family history of thromboembolic diseases. He denies any chest pain  trouble breathing  coughing  hemoptysis  recent surgeries or hospitalizations. Physical examination reveals a warm  edematous  and erythematous left lower extremity with tender calf muscles. No signs of superficial vein varicosities or ulcerations. Achilles reflex is intact. Palpable popliteal and pedal pulses. His vital signs are stable. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Evaluations for deep vein thrombosis are warranted given the patient's unilateral symptoms and related risk factors.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and prior left hip replacement surgery ten years ago. He recently took a 10-hour trans-Atlantic flight  post which he experiences progressive pain and swelling in his right lower leg for 5 days. The pain is described as a deep ache with increasing intensity. No history of fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath. No recent trauma or injury to the extremity is reported. Upon examination  the right lower leg is found to be noticeably swollen  tender  warm  and erythematous compared to the left. No superficial veins are visible. Risk factors include prolonged immobilization during flight  underlying coagulopathy due to diabetes and potentially from post-surgical state from hip replacement. Symptoms and history are suspicious for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of smoking  obesity  and recent right-hip replacement surgery presents with a sudden onset of right calf pain  warmth  redness  and swelling for the past day. The patient reports that the pain is constant and worsens with the flexion of the foot. He denies any recent travel or family history of clotting disorders. The patient also mentions that he did not experience these symptoms after surgery and has been relatively immobile since coming home from the hospital a week ago.

A 65-year-old overweight Caucasian female with a history of prolonged bed rest after a recent total hip replacement surgery presents with increased discomfort and swelling in her right calf over the last 24 hours. Patient also has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. There is no history of smoking  alcohol  or drug use. She also complained of slight shortness of breath but denied experiencing chest pain. Examination reveals a warm  erythematous  and significantly swollen lower leg  with positive Homan's sign on the right side. She also displayed a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  but further physical examinations were unremarkable. The patient has a risk profile that includes postoperative status and immobilization  obesity  and older age  consistent with potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver with a history of obesity (BMI 30)  smoking and occasional alcohol consumption  presents with a two-day history of increased swelling  painful sensation and redness in his left lower leg. Patient also mentions a feeling of warmth over the swollen area. From his past medical history  he has been treated for hypertension and type 2 diabetes for the past five years  which are fairly controlled on medication. On examination  he also appears to be short of breath with a low-grade fever. There is no family history of blood clot disorders. He has no history of recent surgeries or long flights and denies any chest pain or palpitations. His main concern is the painful swelling in his left lower leg. These findings raise the suspicion of deep vein thrombosis. The differential diagnosis should include cellulitis  superficial thrombophlebitis  or a ruptured Baker's cyst.

Patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian female  non-smoker  known to have uncontrolled hypertension and long-term use of oral contraceptive pills. She presents with sudden onset of left leg pain  increased swelling  and slight skin discoloration over the past two days. On examination  her left leg is warm on touch  erythematous  and measures 3cm larger in circumference in comparison to the right leg. No previous history of DVT or PE  coagulopathies  recent surgery or prolonged travel history. The patient had no significant family history of hypercoagulable conditions. Her regular medications include Lisinopril for hypertension and oral contraceptive pills.

Patient Information: A 62-year-old obese Caucasian male   Medical History: The patient has a documented history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient also underwent a knee replacement surgery two months prior. He has never been a smoker or alcohol consumer.   Reason for Consultation: The patient came in complaining of increased swelling  tenderness  redness and warmth over the left calf region which he noticed about 2 days ago. He also reported difficulty in walking due to pain.   Physical Examination: He was noted to be afebrile but with higher blood pressure levels and elevated heart rate. The left calf appeared swollen  approximately 3 cm larger in circumference than the right  and there was palpable warmth and tenderness. His breath sounds were normal  and cardiovascular exam revealed regular rhythm without murmurs  rubs  or gallops.   Working Diagnosis: These symptoms suggest possible Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in the left leg.   Treatment Plan: Emergency venous duplex ultrasound to confirm DVT diagnosis is to be planned. Based on the results  will consider anticoagulation therapy. Risk factor management for DVT considering the patient's obesity  postoperative state  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia is to be addressed as well.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history significant for obesity  hypertension  and sedentary lifestyle  presents with increasing left lower leg swelling and discomfort over the past week. The patient reports a dull aching pain in her left calf and admits to having recently traveled on a long flight (8 hours) without moving around much. There is a visible difference in leg circumference  with the left leg appearing larger than the right. The skin over the left calf appears warm to the touch  erythematous  and tender. No shortness of breath  chest pain  or palpitations reported. No genetic predisposition or personal history of blood clot disorders. The patient is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. The physical exam is otherwise unremarkable. This presentation is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis likely secondary to prolonged immobility and other known risk factors.

Patient is a 65-year-old postmenopausal Caucasian woman with a history of recent total right-knee arthroplasty  hypertension  and BMI of 31. She presented with three-day history of progressive pain  swelling  and warmth over her right calf. The patient also reports shortness of breath that has worsened over the last day. She denies chest pain  cough or associated symptoms suggestive of common respiratory conditions. The patient is currently on hydrochlorothiazide and aspirin for her hypertension and was on prophylactic low molecular weight heparin for a week post-surgery. Her surgical wound is healing well. She denies smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use. The patient’s family history is positive for a brother with a pulmonary embolism at age 55. On examination  her right calf circumference was 3 cm more than the left  and a Homan sign was positive. Her vitals showed a heart rate of 92 bpm  blood pressure 135/85 mmHg  respiratory rate 22 bpm  and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air.

A 52-year-old female patient of Caucasian ethnicity  non-smoker  presents with unilateral leg pain  swelling and redness of her left leg that began 2 days ago  without history of trauma. She reports mild shortness of breath. She has a medical history significant for Type 2 diabetes mellitus managed by oral hypoglycemic agents  and an episode of superficial venous thrombosis 2 years ago. She does not have any known malignancies. She traveled on a long-haul flight (more than 6 hours) three days ago and admits to prolonged sitting. Her mother had a pulmonary embolism at age 50. On examination  there is tenderness  warmth and redness in her left calf. She has a positive Homan's sign. There is no pitting edema in the contralateral limb. The rest of the physical examination  including lung and heart examination  is unremarkable.

A 63-year-old Caucasian female with a known history of breast cancer status post-chemotherapy completed one year ago and a sedentary lifestyle presents with a 3-day history of progressive pain and swelling in her left lower leg. She reports no recent surgeries  long-distance travel or use of hormonal medications  but has noticed increased difficulty walking due to pain. On physical examination  there is significant tenderness to palpitation in calf region  warmth and erythema in the left lower leg with positive Homan’s sign. Her vitals are stable but slightly tachycardic  and she denies any chest pain or shortness of breath. These findings raise concern for a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.

A 65-year-old white male  former office-worker  recently retired  with a no tobacco or alcohol consumption history  presents with two week history of increasing pain and swelling in his left lower limb. He reports no recent surgical procedures  travel  or immobilization. On physical examination  the patient's left leg is visibly swollen and warm to touch compared to the right leg. The patient also details recent unintentional weight loss but denies any history of cancer. The patient has a personal history of a peptic ulcer disease treated effectively six years ago but no family history of thrombotic events. The patient is not on regular medications  but takes over-the-counter NSAIDs occasionally for arthritis symptoms.   His body mass index (BMI) is 31 kg/m2  indicative of obesity. On Doppler ultrasound imaging  there is evidence of deep vein thrombosis in left lower limb  specifically involving femoral and popliteal veins. Labs reveal elevated D-dimer levels. There's no evidence of pulmonary embolism on CT angiography. His other routine investigations  including chest radiograph and Electrocardiogram (ECG)  and liver function tests are normal. He is currently physiologically stable.

Patient Demographics: Ms. L  a 52-year-old woman  office-based job  non-smoker.  Medical History: Diagnosed hypertensive  history of recurrent miscarriages related to Factor V Leiden mutation  sedentary lifestyle due to the nature of her work  family history of venous thromboembolism (her mother).  Presentation: Ms. L attends the clinic complaining of an acutely painful  swollen right lower limb  especially the calf region. The pain seems to be worsening  especially when she tries to stand or move. She denies any history of recent trauma to the limb. She endorses recent interstate travel involving prolonged sitting within the last week. Physically  the leg is warm to touch  tender  and the circumference is larger compared to her other leg. She denies any chest symptoms such as breathlessness or chest pain. She is overweight with a BMI of 29. Her blood pressure reading is elevated at 155/90. She appears anxious at the appointment.   Assessment: Given Ms. L's age  hereditary Factor V Leiden mutation  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  long-haul travel  hypertensive state  and the acute onset of unilateral pain  swelling  and warmth in her right leg – a high index of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is warranted. A diagnostic confirmation with a Doppler ultrasound and D-dimer tests conducted at the earliest will be beneficial for the next course of treatment.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a known medical history of Stage II hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents with symptoms suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  reporting unilateral left lower extremity pain and swelling persisting for the past week associated with mild skin changes such as redness and warmth over the affected area. The patient also mentions increased difficulty in walking due to the pain. He denies recent travel  surgeries  or immobilization; has no history of malignancy  genetic coagulopathies or previous DVT/PE. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. There is no family history of venous thromboembolic events. The patient does not demonstrate any signs of respiratory distress or chest pain suggestive of pulmonary embolism. On examination  there is a noticeable calf swelling with circumference significantly increased when compared to the opposite leg. The patient’s D-dimer test results are awaited. He is hypertensive with a blood pressure of 150/92 mm Hg and is otherwise hemodynamically stable. Labs thus far reveal poor glycemic control with an elevated HbA1C. The patient is currently on Lisinopril and Metformin  with poor compliance reported regarding his medications.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a relevant past medical history of high blood pressure  recent hip replacement surgery  and a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with acute onset of right leg pain and swelling over the last 24 hours. He describes pain as constant  throbbing  and increasingly worse with standing or walking. He also reports a low-grade fever. There is no history of trauma  similar previous episodes  or any recent long-distance travel. There is a family history of blood clotting disorders on his mother’s side. On physical examination  the patient’s right leg is erythematous  edematous  warm  and tender on palpation. Pulses are notably absent in the right lower limb.

Demographic Information: 62-year-old Caucasian male  accountant  non-smoker and occasional drinker  lives in a suburban neighborhood with wife.  Presenting Problem: Patient presents with swelling in the left leg  which started gradually and has been progressing over the last week. In addition  he has been experiencing occasional cramping pain in the leg  especially towards the end of the day. He denied any recent history of injury or trauma.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension for the last 7 years  which has been well-controlled with Lisinopril. No known drug allergies. Formerly an avid runner  but mostly sedentary for the last year due to the outbreak of COVID-19  with reported significant weight gain (120 lbs to 150 lbs). No recent surgeries. He had a long-distance car journey 10 days ago. No known family history of bleeding or clotting disorders.   Symptoms on Presentation: Upon examination  the left leg was visibly swollen as compared to the right  with a circumference difference measuring approximately 3 cm. There was tenderness to palpation along the course of the popliteal vein  warmth over the swollen area  but no detectable erythema or peripheral edema. Pulses in the affected leg were palpable and symmetric to the other leg.  Impression: This presentation of unilateral leg swelling  increased warmth in the limb  history of recent long-term immobilization in conjunction with risk factors of hypertension and recent weight gain indicate possible Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Further diagnostic tests necessary for confirmation.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history of obesity and recent hip arthroplasty 3 weeks ago  now presenting with acute onset of unilateral swelling and pain in her left lower extremity. She also complains of heat sensation at the swollen site. She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  cough or hemoptysis. She has a history of taking oral contraceptive pills in her younger years and a family history of deep vein thrombosis in her father. Symptoms are consistent with deep vein thrombosis. She has not had any recent travel  immobilization or surgery. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has no history of malignancy or thrombophilia. She is not on any anticoagulant therapy.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a significant medical history of recent hip replacement surgery two weeks ago  obesity and sedentary lifestyle has presented to the ER with symptoms of pain  warmth  redness  and swelling in the left lower leg and calf which he has been experiencing for two days. Additionally  the patient describes the swelling as progressive and constant. He denies chest pain  cough  shortness of breath or any similar symptoms in the right leg. No history of smoking  anticoagulant use  malignancies  or previous DVT. Family history reveals his father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 70. Physical examination reveals a tender  swollen  and erythematous left calf which is warm to touch. Homans' sign is positive. Rest of the physical examination  including cardiovascular and pulmonary system  is unremarkable. He was hemodynamically stable at the time of examination. His symptoms  coupled with his significant medical history  suggest a likely case of deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old African-American woman  retired.  Medical History: Patient has a 10-year history of systemic hypertension and hyperlipidemia. No history of smoking or alcohol consumption. She had total knee replacement surgery on her right knee three weeks ago. She has been largely immobile since operation.  Presenting Issues: She presented with a gradually worsening  unilateral swelling and redness in her right lower limb  starting at the calf. Associated dull ache and discomfort especially while walking. Negative for fever  chest pain or dyspnea. No history of similar episodes in the past.  Assessment: Given her recent surgery  prolonged immobilization  her age  and symptoms progresses over a week  she is suspected to have deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Additional tests are required to confirm the diagnosis.

A 62-year-old Caucasoid female with a history of obesity  sedentary lifestyle and recent long-distance travel presents with a 3-day history of progressive calf pain and swelling. The pain is dull  persistent  and localized to the left lower leg associated with warmth and positive Homans' sign. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or recent trauma. Family history is significant for her mother having had a pulmonary embolism. She denies smoking and alcohol intake. She takes no medications and has no known drug allergies. General examination reports an obese woman appeared in mild distress. Vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals a swollen  erythematous  and warm left calf with a positive Homans' sign. No evident signs of superficial vein thrombosis or skin changes. The remainder of the examination  including cardiovascular and respiratory  are otherwise unremarkable. No palpable abdominal or inguinal lymph nodes. She has no history of cancer.

Problem Representation:  An 80-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. J  with a past medical history of congestive heart failure  recent major orthopedic surgery (hip replacement two weeks ago) and a 35-year history of smoking  presents with a 2-day history of progressive left lower limb swelling and mild pain. He reports no relief after elevating the leg. In addition  he has noticed the leg has become warm and red compared to his right. No other acute symptoms are reported. The patient is overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 29. His current medications include Lisinopril  beta-blockers  aspirin  and post-operative analgesics. No known drug allergies. Vital signs are within normal limits  except for a slightly elevated heart rate of 102 beats per minute. There is no history of trauma. His family history is significant for a brother who experienced a deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. The patient denies any history of varicose veins  cancer  or recent travels. He admits he has been less mobile since his surgery.

Patient is a 65-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type II diabetes  recent hip arthroplasty 3 weeks ago  and obesity  who presents with a 4-day history of progressive pain  swelling  and warmth in his right calf. Patient also reports experiencing a dull ache in his right leg  especially when standing or walking. He denies shortness of breath  chest pain  recent injuries to the area or fever. Physical examination reveals a swollen  erythematous  and tender right calf  and a positive Homan's sign. Given the recent hip surgery  immobility  and other risk factors  the presentation is concerning for a deep vein thrombosis. The differential diagnoses include DVT  cellulitis  and musculoskeletal strain.

Patient Profile: A 62-year-old Hispanic male truck driver.   Medical History: The patient has a 13-year history of hypertension for which he takes Amlodipine 5mg daily  and a recent history of a right hip arthroplasty that was done four weeks ago following a motor vehicular accident. Non-smoker and occasional alcohol drinker. No known allergies.  Presentation: The patient present with unilateral swelling  redness  and a dull aching pain in the lower leg which he noticed has been persistent over the past 2 days. Symptoms worsen when standing or walking but are relieved slightly when the leg is elevated. There was no fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath.   On physical examination  the patient's right lower limb was swollen  erythematous  and edematous when compared to the left one. Homans sign was positive  but the pulses in the lower extremities were palpable. No prominent superficial veins or ulcers were noted. His blood pressure is 155/85 mmHg and pulse rate is 76 bpm. His BMI is 27.  Based on the patient's recent hip surgery  sedentary work lifestyle  clinical features  there is a high suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The next step would be to obtain a Doppler ultrasound of the lower limb to confirm the diagnosis. An anticoagulant will probably be started once the diagnosis is confirmed  to avoid potentially life-threatening complications like pulmonary embolism.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of third stage chronic kidney disease  obesity  and a relatively sedentary lifestyle presents to the clinic with a complaint of acute onset of left leg pain and swelling. He reports a heaviness in his left calf that began three days ago and has progressively worsened  causing limited mobility. The patient denies any trauma  fever  or recent surgery. The patient admits to occasional tobacco use and taking over-the-counter NSAIDs for arthritis pain. Physical examination reveals pitting edema  redness  and tenderness along the path of deep leg veins  more prominent in the left leg when compared to the right leg. The patient demonstrates a positive Homan’s sign. No chest pain  dyspnea  or hemoptysis was reported. Family history includes a sister who had a pulmonary embolism.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female who presents with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She has a past medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. She was recently immobilized due to a hip fracture surgery four weeks ago. Patient is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. She was on oral contraceptives until five years ago.   On presentation  she reports a one-week history of increasing pain and swelling in her right lower extremity which is now extended up to the thigh region. She also describes a dull ache in the affected extremity and it is warm to touch. No fever or chills are reported. No shortness of breath  no chest pain or palpitations. No previous episodes of DVT or family history of DVT or pulmonary embolism. Patient denies recent trauma or injury to the lower extremities.   Physical examination reveals swelling of the right lower limb with superficial vein distention and tenderness on deep palpation along the course of the deep veins. Vital signs are stable and rest of the general physical and systemic examination are within normal limits.

Problem Representation:  Patient is a 65-year-old obese  Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for multiple risk factors for venous thrombosis  including three prior pregnancies  hypertension  and long periods of immobility due to her work as a truck driver. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. She presents to the emergency department with complaint of unprovoked  sudden onset  progressively worsening left calf pain and swelling for the past three days. The pain is associated with palpable cord-like structure  increased warmth  and erythema over the affected area. She also reports shortness of breath on exertion which resolved at rest. She denies chest pain  palpitations  or dizziness. She has no documented allergies and is currently not on any regular medications besides an occasional paracetamol for headaches. She also denies any family history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Her vitals are stable but she is tachypneic. Physical examination reveals a swollen and tender left lower extremity with dilation of superficial veins. No signs of infection are noted. Both heart and lung examination were unremarkable.   This patient's demographics  history and presentation with unilateral lower extremity pain and swelling  positive Homan's sign and shortness of breath is concerning for deep vein thrombosis with a potential to pulmonary embolism if not treated immediately. The patient's risk factors including her age  obesity  smoking habit and immobility increase her likelihood to develop venous thrombosis.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation  for which he is on medication (including warfarin)  presenting with sudden swelling and pain in his left leg. There is no history of trauma or recent surgery before onset. He has a history of sedentary lifestyle and long-haul flights. He reports no shortness of breath  chest pain  or light-headedness. On examination  his left lower limb is swollen  tender with visible distention of surface veins and increased warmth compared to the right leg. His O2 saturation level is normal and vital signs are stable.

A 70-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  and recent total hip replacement presents with a 2-day history of right lower leg swelling and pain. She reports that the swelling and pain are not associated with any injury or trauma. She also mentions that she is having difficulties in walking. Additionally  she remarks that she does not regularly take her prescribed antihypertensive medications and admits to not having much physical activity since her surgery. On examination  her right lower leg is significantly swollen  warm to the touch  erythematous  and tender along the deep venous distribution. She has a positive Homan's sign. She doesn't report any chest pain  shortness of breath  or hemoptysis. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

A 67-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for obesity (BMI 35) and recent left total hip replacement 2 weeks ago presents with complaints of left leg swelling and low-grade fever for the past 2 days. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. She reports moderate to severe pain in her left leg  with progressive worsening in symptoms. She also noticed the sudden onset of swelling and redness in the same leg. She is a nonsmoker and does not consume alcohol. There is no history of previous blood clots or family history of thromboembolic diseases. On examination  her left leg appears significantly swollen  erythematous  and warm to touch compared to the right leg  with a positive Homan's sign. Other physical examination findings are within normal limits. Prior to this event  the patient was largely independent in ambulation and daily activities. A clinical impression of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is suspected.

Patient Profile:   A 63 year-old Caucasian male  married  with two adult children  retired engineer.  Medical History:   The patient has a known history of hormone-resistant prostate cancer. He is currently on Docetaxel chemotherapy. He also has type-2 diabetes mellitus  well-controlled on Metformin  and hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril. He has no known allergies.  Presentation:  The patient presents with sudden onset of left lower leg swelling and pain that started two days ago. The pain is described as aching and constant  and aggravated with standing or walking. No prior trauma reported. No recent traveling or prolonged periods of immobilization. He also reports noticing that the skin around the swollen area feels warmer to touch.   Additionally  reports slight shortness of breath but denies chest pain  loss of consciousness  hematuria or difficulty urinating. Recent review of systems was otherwise unremarkable. No other notable changes in his health.  Speculations:  Considering his medical history and the current symptoms  the primary suspicion is deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's condition is complicated due to the underlying malignancy and chemotherapy. Shortness of breath could indicate a possible pulmonary embolism  a known complication of DVT. Further evaluation is necessary to confirm these suspicions.

Patient Information: Mr. Harrison  a 67-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of morbid obesity (BMI 39)  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  controlled with diet and Amlodipine. Mr. Harrison is a former smoker  who quit 22 years ago. He underwent knee replacement surgery three weeks ago and has been largely immobile since.  Chief Complaint and Presentation: Mr. Harrison came in to the emergency department complaining of swelling  warmth  redness  and pain in his left calf for the last four days. He denies any respiratory symptoms  chest pain  or lightheadedness.   Vitals & Physical Examination: Vital signs are stable. Physical examination revealed a swollen and erythematous left calf with mild tenderness on palpation. The left calf circumference was 3 cm greater than the right calf.  Assessment & Plan: The findings are suggestive of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  particularly in the context of recent surgery and prolonged immobilization. Further evaluation with Doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremities is recommended to confirm the diagnosis. If confirmed  anticoagulation therapy should be initiated. Given his risk factors for DVT  comprising obesity  recent surgery and prolonged immobilization  it may be prudent in the future to consider prophylactic anticoagulation in similar circumstances.

Problem Representation:  Patient Information: Mr. Smith  a 60-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: The patient has a history of smoking 1 pack a day for the past 40 years. He has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are currently managed by medication (lisinopril and atorvastatin  respectively). He is also obese with a BMI of 32. No known family history of clotting disorders.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with a week-long history of unilateral  swollen  painful and reddened left leg. The pain is described as constant  aching in nature  and intensifying upon standing or walking. Mr. Smith also notes recent fatigue and mild shortness of breath.  These symptoms are suggestive of deep vein thrombosis possibly complicated by a pulmonary embolism. Immediate diagnostic imaging and further examinations are required to confirm the diagnosis and manage the condition accordingly.

A 64-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history of obesity and hypertension presented with complaints of left leg swelling and tenderness. She reported her symptoms started suddenly about two days ago and have progressively worsened. She has not experienced this before nor has she had any history of injury or prolonged immobility. The patient denied chest pain  shortness of breath or cough. She has no known history of coagulopathy  cancer or prior blood clots. She has not undergone any recent surgical procedures but admits prolonged inactivity in her office job. Physical examination reveals a warm  tender and erythematous left leg with positive Homan's sign. Venous Doppler ultrasound confirms her diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. The patient denies smoking and alcohol intake. She is currently on antihypertensive medications. Her family history is notable for her father having a stroke at the age of 73.

A 66-year-old  obese  male patient with a history of hypertension and non-compliant with current medications presents with recent onset (1 week) of unilateral lower limb pain and swelling primarily in the left calf. Upon further questioning  the patient also mentions mild shortness of breath. Patient denies chest pain  cough  or any other systemic symptoms. Patient has been experiencing immobility due to home quarantine for 3 months in the Covid-19 situation. No known history of malignancy  previous venous thromboembolism event or blood clotting disorders in the family. He is an ex-smoker (quit 10 years back) and takes occasional alcohol. His mother died of stroke at 70  while the father had diabetes and died of unrelated causes. He has not been on any prophylactic anticoagulation.

A 60-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of obesity  inactive lifestyle  and recent long-haul flight travel presents with new-onset  severe right lower leg pain  swelling  warmth  and erythema. No previous history of similar symptoms. Also notes generalized fatigue. No known family history of coagulation disorders. Current smoker  with a 30-pack-year history. No known drug allergies. Vital signs are stable; physical examination finds a positive Homans' sign. With these clinical features  the high suspicion is deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Representation:  Mr. Smith  a 65-year-old retired factory worker with a medical history of hypertension  obesity  and a recent total knee replacement surgery on his right knee  presented with increasing pain and swelling in his right lower leg over the last 24 hours. He denies trauma  fever  or recent travel. He discloses sedentary lifestyle and cessation of his post-surgical exercises two weeks ago due to his unremitting knee pain. He is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago. On presentation  physical examination reveals warmth and redness over the right calf and tenderness on palpation with a positive Homan's sign. He also reported abrupt onset of right-sided chest pain and some shortness of breath. No family history of coagulopathies. His vital signs are normal except for a mildly elevated heart rate. The patient is worried about the findings and discomfort.

Patient is a 48-year-old African American male  software engineer by profession with a sedentary lifestyle. Presenting with complaints of recent onset of swelling  pain  warmth  and reddish discoloration in the right lower leg. Personal medical history includes obesity (BMI 35) and hypertension. No previous history of DVT  pulmonary embolism  or thrombophilic disorders reported. No recent history of surgery  trauma  or immobility. Patient's father had a history of DVT. On further examination  right calf circumference is larger than the left. Homans' sign is positive on the right. No evidence of chest discomfort  shortness of breath  or tachycardia. Based on clinical findings  deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the right lower extremity is highly suspected and requires further diagnostic testing.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of varicose veins  uncontrolled hypertension  and obesity  recently underwent a total knee arthroplasty 3 weeks ago. He presents with progressive left lower extremity pain and swelling. He describes the pain as ""aching"" in nature  progressively worsening over the past 4-5 days  and rated as 8 out of 10 in severity. Swelling is noted chiefly around the calf region. In addition  he reports mild shortness of breath on exertion. There is no known history of similar occurrence nor familial history of clotting disorders. He denies recent long-distance travel  chest pain  or syncope. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. He is not on any anticoagulation therapy. His symptoms are consistent with a likely diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Williams is a 65-year-old overweight Caucasian male with a medical history significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension who exhibits symptoms consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient presents with a swollen  painful right lower extremity that has progressively worsened over the past three days. Notably  the patient's initial pain was associated with a long-distance travel by car resulting in prolonged immobilization. The patient also mentions both a family and personal history of clotting disorders. He denies any recent surgery or traumas. On inspection  the lower limb is red  warm and engorged. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  and hemoptysis  but does note a mild  unexplained fatigue over the past couple of days. He typically manages his chronic conditions with metformin and lisinopril. The patient has a 30-pack year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. His physical activity is low. His diet is high in cholesterol and fat which  along with his obesity and diabetes  may increase his risk for DVT.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female with a known medical history of obesity  hypertension  and recent total knee arthroplasty (2 weeks ago)  presenting with sudden onset left calf pain and swelling. Additionally  she reports warmness  redness in the area and it has become increasingly difficult for her to put weight on her left leg. She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough  but expresses increased anxiety due to her current symptoms. Her arthroplasty wound appears fully healed with no signs of infection and her lower extremities' pulses are intact. Risk factors include recent surgery  obesity  and advanced age.

Patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  working as a long-haul truck driver  who presents with unilateral swelling and redness of the right lower leg for 3 days. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and obesity (BMI of 32)  with no known history of blood clotting disorders or thromboembolic events. He reports increasing discomfort in the right leg worsened by walking or standing  but denies any other concurrent symptoms such as chest pain  dyspnea  or recent trauma to the leg. He states that his job involves sitting for extended periods of time. Family history includes a brother who experienced pulmonary embolism at the age of 57. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. Current medications include Lisinopril for hypertension  . Physical examination reveals a noticeably swollen  warm to touch and erythematous right leg compared to left. His symptoms  profession involving prolonged immobility  personal medical history  and family history suggest the possible diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old obese male with a past medical history of atrial fibrillation and hypertension  for which he has been non-compliant with his anticoagulant medication  presents with a 2-day history of increased swelling  warmth  and pain in his right lower leg. He denies trauma but reports recent long-haul flight of over eight hours and has limited mobility due to arthritis. He admits smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and occasional alcohol use. On physical examination  his right lower extremity is markedly swollen with tenderness to palpation along the course of the deep venous system  but no evident skin changes or ulcers. There are palpable cord-like blood vessels around the thigh area. Homans' sign is positive. The rest of the physical and systemic examination is within normal limits.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with symptoms of significant unilateral leg pain  warmth  redness and swelling in the right lower extremity. The patient mentioned that he recently underwent a total knee arthroplasty 2 weeks prior. Past medical history is also significant for controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He is a retired academic professor  non-smoker and non-drinker. He also reported prolonged periods of immobility due to post-surgery recovery. Upon physical examination  right calf was found to be tender with a positive Homan's sign. The bulbous nature of the swelling also pointed to possible deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient rates the pain 7 out of 10 on the pain scale  and it increases with ambulation. The patient denied any dyspnea  chest pain  or palpitations. Contrast-enhanced venography or Doppler ultrasonography would be the next step in affirming the diagnosis.

The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver residing in rural Mississippi  presenting with recent onset of severe unilateral pain and swelling in the right leg with associated slight shortness of breath. History includes 35 pack-years of smoking  obesity with a BMI of 32  and remaining sedentary for extended periods due to previous occupation. There is no known history of traumatic injuries  heart or lung disease  blood clotting disorders  or malignancies. He has never had recent surgeries or stays in hospital. His medications consist of aspirin  occasional use of over-the-counter ibuprofen for arthritis pain. On examination  significant findings are severe tenderness  warmth  and erythema on his right lower limb. No other abnormalities have been found on a complete system examination. He denies current tobacco use  alcohol consumption  and recreational drug use. Family history includes a father who died of a stroke at 76 and a mother with thrombophlebitis. The patient's symptoms raises suspicion for deep vein thrombosis.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of prostate cancer (treated with radiation therapy 12 months ago) and hypertension presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of progressive left leg discomfort  redness  and swelling. The patient reports difficulty in walking due to severe pain on weight-bearing on the left lower limb. He denies any recent surgery  prolonged immobilization  personal or family history of any clotting disorder. The patient is a former smoker and regularly consumes alcohol. He is currently on antihypertensive medication and maintains a sedentary lifestyle. The patient denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or visible blood clots in his sputum.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male  truck driver by profession  with a past medical history significant for obesity (BMI 38)  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypertension presents to the emergency department with left leg swelling  pain and warmth over a period of 2 days. The patient denies any recent history of surgery  trauma  or extended periods of immobilization. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or fainting spells. He reports non-adherence to his prescribed diabetic  hypertensive  and lipid-lowering medications over the last month. His current vitals include BP: 140/90 mmHg  HR: 85 bpm  Temp: 98.6°F  RR: 16 breaths per min  Oxygen saturation: 98% on room air. Multiple 5 cm areas of red palpable cord-like structures are evident in his left upper calf on physical examination. His respirations are clear and cardiac exam reveals regular rhythm with no murmur. His electrocardiogram and chest X-ray are normal.

A 68-year-old African American woman with a medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with a four-day history of swelling  warmth  and pain in the right lower leg  which has been worsening. She denies any recent long-distance traveling  hormone therapy or past clots. She denies chest pain or difficulty in breathing  has a BMI of 32  and has low physical activity levels. The patient was on medication for hypertension and diabetes but admits non-compliance. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Upon examination  her right calf is found to be swollen and tender with a positive Homan's sign. Labs reveal a positive D-dimer test  suggesting the possibility of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Further confirmatory investigations are being planned.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for obesity  hypertension  smoking and recent right hip replacement surgery three weeks prior  presents with acute onset of pain  swelling and marked redness in his right calf. The patient also reports mild shortness of breath and occasional light-headedness. He denies any chest pain  cough  fever  trauma or recent travel. Physical examination reveals an increase in calf circumference with pitting edema  tenderness  and warmth over the area. His vital signs are stable except for an elevated heart rate of 100 beats per minute. Respiratory examination reveals mildly decreased breath sounds at the bases of both lungs. No other abnormalities were noticed on cardiovascular and neurological examination.

Patient representation: A 45-year-old  Caucasian male  working as a long-haul truck driver  presents with left leg swelling and pain ongoing for the last 3-4 days. No significant past medical or surgical history. No known allergies. He reports difficulty walking without discomfort and minor leg discoloration. The patient reports no recent injury but admits to prolonged periods of sitting due to his work. Non-smoker and non-alcoholic. No known family history of coagulation disorders  deep vein thrombosis or any chronic illnesses. On examination  the left calf is swollen  erythematous and demonstrates tenderness on deep palpation. His vitals show a slight increase in heart rate and BP.

Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of smoking for 40 years  Stage II hypertension  and recent total hip replacement on the right side 2 weeks ago. He has presented today with a 2-day history of increasing pain  swelling  and redness in his right lower leg. The pain intensifies upon standing or walking. Physical examination findings reveal unilateral limb edema  and differential skin temperature (affected leg warmer). He denies history of any hematologic disorders or previous thromboembolic events but his mother had a history of deep vein thrombosis. He has no known allergies and he is currently taking an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor and a beta-blocker for his hypertension.

Patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male recently hospitalized following hip replacement surgery and is now presenting with signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He reports a four-day history of increasingly severe left calf pain and swelling. He also notes the area has become warm to touch and slightly red. Prior medical history is significant for obesity and occasional smoking  but has no previously diagnosed malignancy  family history of clotting disorders or history of prolonged immobility. Currently  he is completely ambulatory post-operation with no additional signs of infection or complications. His regular medications include pain-killers  antibiotics to prevent infections  and anti-coagulants given post-operation. No history of allergic reactions to these medications. The patient is currently experiencing no chest pain or breathing complications  no fainting spells  or other signs of potential pulmonary embolism.

Patient Information: A 58-year-old Caucasian male schoolteacher presents in the emergency department.  Medical History: He has a known history of hypertension and obesity. He has been sedentary for several months due to remote teaching due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Family history includes a sister with recurrent venous thromboembolisms. The patient denies any history of smoking or alcohol abuse and is currently on medications for hypertension.  Presenting Signs and Symptoms: He presents with unilateral swelling in the left lower extremity  calf pain that is worsened with flexion of the foot  and mild erythema over the calf. There is no noted trauma or injury to the leg. He reports increasing shortness of breath over the past 2 days.  Impression: The patient’s complaints and physical examination findings raise a high suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The combination of his hypertension  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and family history of venous thromboembolisms elevates his risk for a DVT. The increasing shortness of breath is concerning for a possible concurrent pulmonary embolism. Urgent imaging and consultation with vascular medicine or hematology is indicated.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired police officer  presents with a 3-day history of increasing pain and swelling in right lower limb. The patient also reports mild generalized malaise. He denies any history of recent surgery  prolonged travel  or immobility. The patient has a significant history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin. He also smoked 10 cigarettes a day for over 20 years  but quit 10 years ago. On examination  there is warmth  edema  erythema  and notable tenderness over the right calf muscle  suggestive of deep vein thrombosis. No signs of superficial vein thrombosis are observed. The patient has adequate circulation to the distal part of the lower limb and there are no signs of ischemia. There is no chemosis  otorrhoea  or calf bulbosity to suggest pulmonary embolism. The suspicion of right lower limb deep vein thrombosis needs to be confirmed by a Doppler ultrasound.

Patient is a 55 year-old Caucasian female who presented with acute onset of swelling and pain in her left leg  more significant on her calf and extending up to her thigh. She reported a week-long sedentary period due to a virtual conference. The patient has a medical history significant for obesity and oral contraceptive use. She also revealed a family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). On physical examination  her left calf was found to be tender  swollen  and warm compared to her right leg. No other significant symptoms were noted  specifically chest pain  shortness of breath or diagnosed malignancies. The patient’s pain and swelling combined with her risk factors of obesity and oral contraceptive use  coupled with her recent prolonged immobility suggests the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.

A 55-year-old African American male  truck driver by profession  presents with a 3-day history of progressive left lower extremity pain and swelling. The pain intensifies upon standing and is moderately relieved by elevation. No trauma  skin changes  or recent travels. Past medical history is significant for obesity (BMI 32)  smoking  and hypertension controlled with Lisinopril. Family history includes a brother diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at age 60. Examination reveals a warm  erythematous  and swollen left leg  with a positive Homan’s sign. No palpable inguinal nodes. Patient denies fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath.

Patient Description: A 60-year-old Caucasian female  non-smoker  office worker.  Medical History: The patient has a known family history of Factor V Leiden mutation but has never been tested. She has a history of hormonal therapy due to menopause and is overweight (BMI of 30). No history of surgery or recent travels. No prior incidence of venous thromboembolism.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient complains of persistent pain  swelling  tenderness  redness  and warmth in the right calf area for the past couple of days. She also mentions experiencing slight shortness of breath  which is of new onset. The patient recalls the pain began as a cramp-like discomfort that gradually worsened. The patient has not experienced any associated chest pain  fever  or leg ulcers.   This presentation might suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT) potentially complicated by a pulmonary embolism.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of obesity  smoking  and recent total knee replacement reports to the emergency department with complaints of swelling  redness  and pain in his left lower leg of two days duration. The severity of pain has been increasing and is associated with shortness of breath while climbing stairs. He denies recent travel or previous clotting disorders  but his therapeutic mobility has been significantly reduced post-surgery due to pain. On examination  his pulse rate was 90 bpm  blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg  and respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. Local examination reveals edema in the left lower leg with tenderness along the posterior tibial vein. His body mass index is 32 kg/m2.

A 65-year-old female patient with a known 10-year history of type II diabetes and hypertension presents with a 3-day history of unilateral leg swelling and pain. The pain is described as cramping and is localized to her left calf. She notes that the pain has been worsening and is especially aggravated by standing and walking. She denies having fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath. She is adherent to her oral hypoglycemic agents and antihypertensive therapy. The patient also discloses recent prolonged in-flight air travel (10 hours) two weeks ago. Her maternal side of the family has a history of blood clot disorders. Ongoing physical examination reveals a warm  erythematous  edematous left calf which is tender to palpation. Pulses are palpable and comparable with the right leg. Dorsiflexion of the left foot elicits pain in the calf (positive Homan's sign). There are no evident traumatic injuries to the leg. The patient denies recent surgery  malignancy  or use of oral contraceptives. Given the clinical scenario  deep vein thrombosis is suspected.

Problem Representation:  A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  obesity (BMI= 33.5)  and recent hip replacement surgery (four weeks ago)  presents in the emergency room complaining of progressive onset  unilateral left lower extremity swelling  pain  and redness for the last two days. The patient reports no associated chest pain or dyspnea  no familial history of clotting disorders. The patient has been non-ambulatory due to post-operative complications and was not prescribed post-operative thromboprophylaxis. He has been taking Lisinopril for hypertension. On examination  left lower extremity is erythematous  edematous and warm with positive Homans' sign. No signs of ulcer or infection are present. No sign of superficial vein engorgement. There is no cardiac abnormality detected. The lungs are clear.

A 60-year-old African American female presents with a 2-day history of right leg pain and swelling  increasing gradually. She reports discomfort on ambulation and denies trauma or injury to the leg. Her past medical history is significant for obesity (BMI of 32) and recurrent UTIs for which she has been regularly taking nitrofurantoin for the past 1 year. No known history of surgery  smoking or malignancies. Family history is unremarkable. There is no previous history of similar symptoms and she denies any recent travel  immobilization  or contraceptive use. Upon examination  her right leg is noticeably edematous compared to the left  with tenderness along the deep venous system and increased warmth over the calf. No superficial venous dilation or erythema is observed. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. She demonstrates a positive Homan's sign in the right leg.

Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  and a former smoker who presents with a two-day history of unilateral right leg swelling  redness  and increasing discomfort. Also reports a dull ache and heaviness in the same leg with no history of trauma  recent surgeries  prolonged travels or immobilization. No present shortness of breath or chest pain. Reports compliance with his antihypertensive medications  no known allergies or family history of coagulopathy or venous thromboembolism. Physical examination reveals a markedly swollen right leg compared to left  warm to touch and tender along the deep venous distribution with a positive Homan's sign. No signs of a superficial vein thrombosis were noted. No palpable or audible calf or abdominal mass. The remainder of the cardiorespiratory examination was unremarkable. He denies having any recent infections or cancer diagnosis  no acute illness  cough  or hemoptysis. No use of hormone therapy. Homan's sign was positive on the right side. The remainder of the cardiorespiratory examination was unremarkable.

Patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history of obesity  hypertension  and unregulated type 2 diabetes mellitus. She recently underwent hip replacement surgery three weeks prior to presentation. The patient presents complaining of unilateral leg swelling  redness  discomfort  and warmth over the affected area in her left lower extremity. She also reports shortness of breath which started two days ago and has progressively worsened. She denies chest pain or trauma to the leg. She has no known allergies. The patient is an ex-smoker who quit 10 years ago and denies alcohol or illicit drug use. Family history is significant for a brother recently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis. Her current medications include Lisinopril 10mg once daily for hypertension and Metformin 500mg twice daily for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current physical examination indicates a distended  tender  and erythematous left lower leg with a positive Homan's sign. She is tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation at 92% on room air  and shows signs of respiratory distress. Symptoms and signs suggest potential deep vein thrombosis with suspected pulmonary embolism.

A 56-year-old Caucasian male  smoker  with a history of hypertension and obesity  presents in the clinic with a 5-day history of increasing pain and swelling in his left lower leg. Prior to his visit  he had a long haul flight around two weeks ago. He also mentions the intermittent occurrence of mild shortness of breath. His vitals are stable except for an elevated blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg. The patient denies chest pain  cough  or fever. On examination  his left lower extremity is noticeably swollen  warm  and tender to touch  particularly in the gastrocnemius muscle area and surrounding region. The symptoms suggest the possibility of deep vein thrombosis  made more concerning by the risk factors of long distance travel  obesity  hypertension  and smoking. The patient's recent shortness of breath might indicate the presence of pulmonary embolism  which needs urgent investigation.

Patient is a 72-year-old male  Caucasian  with a past medical history significant for obesity with BMI of 32  inactive lifestyle  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a former smoker and currently abstains from alcohol. He presents with a sudden onset of unilateral edema in his left lower extremity. He reports a dull ache in his leg  along with warmth and redness over the affected area. The pain has been progressively worsening over the past five days. Additionally  the patient has experienced shortness of breath  mild chest discomfort and fatigue over the same duration. He denies recent trauma  long distance travel  previous similar episodes  or any known hypercoagulable state. On examination  patient shows a positive Homan's sign on his left extremity. No signs of superficial venous dilation. Labs reveal elevated D-Dimer levels. Given the clinical presentation and past medical history  the working diagnosis is deep vein thrombosis.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for obesity (BMI 33)  sedentary lifestyle  and recent major knee surgery four weeks ago presents with pain and swelling in his right leg  which has been ongoing for a week. Additionally  the patient reports feeling slightly dyspneic. On examination  the right lower limb appears swollen and is tender to touch. The skin over the swollen area is warm and is mildly reddened. The patient also reports mild intermittent chest pain which he attributed to his gastric reflux. There is no history of cancer  heart disease  smoking  or genetic thrombophilias.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for obesity  hyperlipidemia and recent right hip arthroplasty. A 58-year-old male patient  with a known history of Type 2 diabetes and obesity  presents to the clinic with a swollen  red and painful right leg for the past two days. Patient is a 67 year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and known varicose veins  as well as a recent knee replacement surgery 3 months ago. Patient is a 58-year-old female with a past medical history significant for obesity (BMI 35) and recurrent miscarriages. Patient is a 61-year-old Caucasian male with a history of obesity (BMI 31)  sedentary lifestyle  and recent total knee replacement surgery who now presents with a 2-day history of progressive left lower extremity pain and swelling. The presence of recent immobilization  surgery  and non-compliance with anticoagulation therapy along with the symptoms indicate a possible left lower extremity deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Profile:  A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the outpatient clinic. Overweight with a body mass index of 35. She has a previous history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) about two years ago. Patient Profile: Mr. James Thompson  a 65-year-old male  retired construction worker  based in Wisconsin. This clinical presentation with a history of recent hip surgery  non-mobility  personal history of diabetes and hypertension  and family history of DVT suggests the potential diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and recent hip replacement surgery  presenting with unilateral swelling  warmth  pain  and redness of the right lower leg of four days duration. Patient reports that pain increases with foot dorsiflexion. Clinical examination confirms moderate to severe tenderness along the distribution of the deep veins  indicating possible deep vein thrombosis. Patient has no history of prophylactic anticoagulation therapy post-surgery. The patient has no known drug allergies and time of symptom onset is unclear. At first  he attributed the pain to post-op recovery  but swelling and redness have persisted and worsened. He denies any associated chest pain  shortness of breath  or recent travel. He’s a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. Patient mentions family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his father. Patient is currently on metformin and losartan for his comorbid conditions. No previous episodes of similar symptoms.

Patient Profile:  A 65-year-old male accountant  non-smoker  with a known history of hypertension and sedentary lifestyle  presents to the clinic.
