There is no known history of surgeries  malignancies  coronary artery disease  diabetes mellitus  or other coagulopathies. The patient is not on any anticoagulants or aspirin. His mother suffered from deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following knee replacement surgery.   Presenting Symptoms:  The patient reports sudden onset of unexplained  severe pain in the left calf for the past 2 days. The pain is more noticeable with foot movements or when standing up. The affected leg appears mildly swelled and warm to touch with visible surface veins. There are no ulcers  syncope or cyanosis. The patient denies having any cough  chest pain  or shortness of breath. No symptoms suggestive of systemic illness such as fever or weight loss. His blood pressure is slightly elevated 140/90 mm Hg at office visit. He states that he's been working extended hours recently and hence  sitting for prolonged periods at a stretch.    Working Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical presentation and medical history  a presumptive diagnosis of left lower extremity deep vein thrombosis is suspected. Referral to vascular specialist is done for Doppler ultrasound and further management.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for obesity (BMI 33)  long-distance travel  and recent total hip replacement presents to the emergency department reporting severe left leg swelling and unilateral leg pain that has progressively worsened over the past 3 days. She also endorses moderate dyspnea on exertion which is unusual for her. She denies chest pain  cough  or syncope. On examination  the left calf is noticeably larger than the right  is tense and tender with a positive Homans' sign. Her vital signs include hypertension (BP 150/90 mmHg)  tachycardia (HR 108 bpm)  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. Her saturation on room air is 94%. No familial history of coagulation disorders is reported. She is a non-smoker and denies alcohol or illicit drug use. Use of hormone replacement therapy after menopause for the last 10 years is reported. Her physical assessment indicates possible deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

A 68-year-old male  retired factory worker  with a history of hypertension and recent total knee replacement surgery presents with sudden onset of unilateral swelling and redness in his right leg  which is the same side as the knee surgery. He also reports a low-grade fever and tender calf muscles. He has no history of malignancies  smoking  or inherited blood clotting disorders. The patient also mentions intermittent chest discomfort  shortness of breath  and lightheadedness. He is currently on antihypertensive medication and was on blood thinners until one week post knee surgery. The patient is overweight with a BMI of 28. He lives with his wife  and they have 2 adult children. Family history is significant for hypertension and stroke. The patient's presentation and history are suggestive of deep vein thrombosis  possibly complicated by pulmonary embolism.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a history of obesity and recent hip replacement surgery presents with a 3-day history of increasing pain  redness  and swelling in her right lower extremity. Patient has been non-mobile post-surgery and compliant with anti-coagulant therapy. She denies any recent trauma  fever  chills or respiratory symptoms. Her vitals are stable  and physical exam reveals a swollen  erythematous right calf that is warm to touch. Her BMI is 33  blood tests show elevated D-dimer levels. The symptoms are suggestive of deep vein thrombosis. She has no known allergies. Family history is notable for a sister who had a venous thromboembolism. She has never smoked and does not consume alcohol. The confluence of post-surgical inactivity  obesity  and family history place her at a high risk for this condition.

Patient Profile: A 60-year-old Caucasian female   Medical History: The patient has a personal history of estrogen-receptor positive breast cancer for which she underwent mastectomy 5 years ago. She is currently on hormonal therapy with Tamoxifen. She has a non-smoking history but is obese with a BMI of 32. She has hypertension which is well-controlled on medication (Losartan).  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with pain and swelling in the left lower extremity that has been increasing over the past 4 days. The pain is constant  aching in character  and increases with ambulation. She also complains of mild shortness of breath on exertion. She denies chest pain  cough  or hemoptysis.  Vitals: Temperature 36.8°C  Pulse 92/min  Blood Pressure 139/84 mmHg  Respiratory Rate 18 breaths/min  Oxygen Saturation 97% on room air.  Physical Examination: Examination reveals a swollen  erythematous left calf that is warm to touch. Calf circumference is 3 cm greater on the left than on the right. No palpable cords or surface veins. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no pitting edema.  This patient's presentation is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis  which could be related to her history of cancer  obesity  and/or treatment with Tamoxifen  a known risk factor for thromboembolic disease. The shortness of breath raises further concern for possible pulmonary embolism.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history significant for obesity and sedentary lifestyle  presenting with unilateral lower extremity swelling and discomfort. Symptoms began approximately three days ago and have progressed. The patient describes the discomfort as a cramp-like sensation in her left leg  from the calf down. The patient denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  recent surgeries  or history of malignancy. Physical examination shows erythema  warmth  and significant edema of the left lower extremity. Her personal history includes use of hormone replacement therapy for menopausal symptoms. She is a non-smoker. D-dimer level is elevated. Ultrasound of the extremity confirms deep vein thrombosis.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  and smoking who presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of painful  red  and swollen right calf. A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a history of obesity and recent hip replacement surgery presents with symptoms consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She reports sudden swelling  tenderness  redness  and warmth in her right leg. The patient also complains of a heavy ache in the same leg. The patient is found to have a BMI of 32 and her recent high blood pressure checks have shown consistently borderline values. She has no known allergies  is currently under post-operative medication including analgesics and does not take any blood-thinning drugs. Her mother reportedly had a DVT following a knee replacement. The patient's signs and symptoms along with her risk profile warrant immediate evaluation for deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver.  Medical History: The patient is an active smoker with a 45-pack-year history. The patient denies experiencing chest pain  shortness of breath  or recent travel history.   Possible Diagnosis: Given the recent orthopedic surgery  prolonged sedentary lifestyle due to his occupation  advanced age and smoking history  this patient's signs and symptoms may be indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right leg.

Patient Demographics: A 68-year-old African American woman.  Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and she is obese  with a BMI  of 32. Presentation of Symptoms: The patient presents with complaints of new onset swelling and dull ache in her left leg  which is noticeably larger than the right. No notable symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  or some other signs of pulmonary embolism.   Summary: This is a 68-year-old African American woman with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and obesity  presenting with swelling and pain localized to her left leg and low-grade fever  two weeks following a hip replacement surgery  raising clinical suspicion for deep vein thrombosis.

A 65-year-old  Caucasian female presents with a three-day history of progressive left leg pain and swelling. She has a past medical history of obesity (BMI: 35) and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) for which she has been on corticosteroid treatment for a long-term period. On physical examination  her left lower extremity appears swollen and erythematous with visible distended veins compared to the right leg. She rates her pain as 7/10  which worsens upon moving her leg. Symptoms further include warmth to touch over the area and light-headedness. The patient denies experiencing any chest pain  dyspnea or hemoptysis. On review of systems  symptoms are solely localized to the left lower extremity. The constellation of her risk factors  symptoms  and history suggest a possible deep vein thrombosis.

A 52-year-old Caucasian male presented at the clinic with complaints of pain  redness  and swelling in his left lower leg for the past 36 hours. His medications include an over-the-counter multivitamin. The patient demonstrated significant calf tenderness and noticeable limb swelling on the affected leg upon physical examination  which presented a high suspicion of deep vein thrombosis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: Mrs. Brown  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  retired librarian  from a rural area  non-smoker  presenting with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Presenting Complaint: She complains of sudden onset of unilateral swelling  redness  and tenderness of her right lower leg. The pain increases with standing or walking. She noticed the symptoms three days ago  they have steadily progressed and not subsided.  Medical & Family History: The patient has a positive history for hypertension controlled with medication (lisinopril). She also has a history of obesity (BMI 32)  sedentary lifestyle and uses oral estrogen replacement therapy for post-menopausal symptoms. She has no known allergies.  Her mother had a history of DVT and a subsequent pulmonary embolism.  Social & Lifestyle Factors: The patient has been living alone since her husband's death five years prior. She has a sedentary lifestyle  spending most of her time reading  watching TV or doing puzzles. She has two children who visit her regularly but live out of town.  Medications: Apart from lisinopril  for hypertension  she takes Premarin (conjugated estrogens) for post-menopausal symptoms.  Physical Examination: On examination  the right calf is swollen  warm  and painful with deep palpation. Her blood pressure is controlled (135/85 mm Hg)  but her body mass index is in the obese range.  Recent Events: The patient recently (two weeks prior) traveled on a long haul flight (greater than 8 hours) to visit her son's family.  Laboratory/Test Results (hypothetical): D-dimer test - elevated Ultrasound of the right lower leg - shows evidence for DVT  Problem Summary: Given the above data  the problem is likely an acute right lower extremity DVT precipitated by a long haul flight (impaired mobility)  use of estrogen  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  and genetic predisposition. The history of hypertension is also a non modifiable risk factor for DVT.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics: - Name: John Doe  - Age: 64 years old  - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired civil engineer  - Race: Caucasian  - Location: Lives alone in a suburban area - Social History: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol use  increasingly sedentary lifestyle  Presenting Complaint: The patient reported new-onset left calf pain and swelling of about 4 days duration. Family Medical History: - Father had a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) - Mother suffered from stroke  - Older brother has a history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol  Current Medications:  - Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension - Atorvastatin 20mg daily to manage hyperlipidemia - Aspirin 81mg daily for coronary artery disease  Allergies:  - Penicillin causes a rash  Physical Examination: The patient is alert and oriented. Chest is clear and abdomen is soft with no distention or tenderness.  Working Diagnosis: From the history of cancer  recent surgery along with prolonged immobilization  the symptom of calf pain and swelling  the family history of DVT  and physical examination findings  there is a high likelihood of Left lower limb Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).

Problem Representation:   Patient Characterization: Mr. Smith is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  an ex-smoker who quit 10 years ago  with a sedentary job. He is a long-haul truck driver  often sitting for prolonged periods  and is overweight with a BMI of 29.  Mr. Smith's eating patterns are erratic and poor  due to life on the road  which is predominantly fast food. He enjoys a couple of beers at the end of the day to unwind.  Relevant Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of high blood pressure which is controlled with a beta blocker and statin. He also has a familial history of cardiovascular disease- his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 66 and his mother had intermittent peripheral artery disease in her 70s.   Presenting Complaint: The patient has come in complaining of unilateral leg pain in the calf region of the left leg  notably worse than any pulled muscle or strain he has experienced before. The pain has been ongoing for the last few days and he reports it as being a constant ache that becomes sharper on walking. The left leg also appears slightly reddened and more swollen than the right  particularly at the end of the day  according to the patient. He denies any recent injury  but admits to having driven some particularly long hauls lately.    Potential Illness Script:  Given the patient's risk factors (age  obesity  sedentary job leading to prolonged immobility  history of high blood pressure  and familial cardiovascular disease)  as well as the unilateral nature of his leg pain and observable edema  the symptoms are suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Demographic Characterization: - Gender: Female - Age: 65 years - Occupation: Retired teacher - Residency: Urban setting  living in a two-story house - Socioeconomic Status: Middle class - Marital Status: Widowed - Lifestyle: Sedentary  with minimal exercise - Alcohol: Minimal  occasional glass of wine  - Tobacco: Non-smoker - Family History: Mother had a deep vein thrombosis  Father had stroke  Past Medical History:  - History of hypertension  managed with medication - History of hyperlipidemia  managed with diet and medication - Prior oral contraceptive use  - Right hip replacement surgery  two years ago - History of frequent prolonged air travel - No previous diagnosis of cancer - No history of bleeding disorders  - Allergic to Penicillin  Current Situation:  The patient has presented with unilateral swollen  warm  red  and painful leg. The pain began suddenly a couple of days ago and has progressively worsened. The patient reports no chest pain  difficulty in breathing  or other systemic symptoms but expresses some anxiety about her mother’s history of deep vein thrombosis.   Physical Examination:  On examination  there is unilateral edema and tenderness along the distribution of the right femoral vein. There are no signs of an infection  skin breakdown or ulceration. Her blood pressure  temperature  pulse  and respiration are within normal limits.   Diagnostic Tests:  D-dimer test  compression ultrasonography and  possibly  a venography will be necessary to confirm the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. Other blood tests including coagulation studies (PT  APTT  INR) may be necessary to understand potential underlying causes and guide treatment.   Possible Medication:  After obtaining the patient's past medication history  oral anticoagulants may be considered such as Warfarin or newer direct oral anticoagulants  depending on the patient's medical background and preference.   Patient Education:  The patient has been advised about the risk factors for deep vein thrombosis and has agreed to start incorporating more physical activity into her daily routine. She is also interested in understanding more about possible treatment options.

Patient Problem Representation:  Demographics: - Patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male.  Occupation: - A retired sanitation worker.  Chief Complaint: - Patient presented with a five-day history of progressive swelling  redness  warmth  and pain in his right lower leg. He also complains about mild shortness of breath and mild chest discomfort.  History of Present Illness: - He hasn't undergone any recent surgeries or invasive procedures.  - No recent travels within the past 2 months.  - He denies any history of trauma or leg injuries.  - The shortness of breath and chest discomfort started a few months back and has progressively flared up together with the leg symptoms.  Past Medical History: - The patient was diagnosed with hypertension and hypercholesterolemia 15 years ago  which has been controlled with diuretics and statins respectively. - He was also diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago and is being managed by metformin. - He has a smoking history of 30 years  having quit 5 years ago. - He also reports a history of pulmonary embolism 12 years ago.  Family History: - His parents are deceased. His father died of a stroke and his mother had breast cancer. - His older brother suffered from a heart attack.  Social History: - He lives alone in a one-story home and is able to perform daily activities independently. - He is a widower with three adult children. - He quit smoking five years ago and consumes alcohol occasionally.    Medications: - He regularly takes a combination of hydrochlorothiazide  atenolol  rosuvastatin and metformin.  Allergies: - He reports an allergy to penicillin  which causes him to develop a skin rash.  Review of Systems:  - Apart from the aforementioned symptoms  he denies any headache  abdominal pain  changes in bowel habits  or any other systemic symptoms.   Vaccination: - He is up-to-date on all his vaccinations  including annual flu shots and the pneumococcal vaccine.   Psychiatric History: - He reports mild anxiety and has not undergone any treatment for psychological or psychiatric conditions.  Physical Examination:  - On examination  his right calf is markedly swollen  and erythematous  warmer than the other leg with severe tenderness particularly in the calf region. - Positive Homan’s sign (pain in calf on forced dorsiflexion of foot). - The chest is clear on auscultation and heart sounds are normal. - Rest of the general and systemic examination is unremarkable.  Laboratory And Imaging: - A comprehensive metabolic panel  complete blood count  coagulation studies  and Doppler ultrasound of the right leg should be done as part of his diagnostic work-up.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 64-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with discomfort  swelling  and warmth over the lower part of the left leg  which has been progressive in nature over the past week. The patient also reports mild dyspnea and chest discomfort  especially on deep inspiration.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is fairly controlled with metformin. He also has a history of hypertension on treatment with amlodipine. He is a 30 pack-year smoker  and has been physically inactive due to desk job. Family history of cardiovascular disorders is notable. His BMI is 28 kg/m2  falling into overweight category. He underwent right total knee arthroplasty a month ago.  Surgical History: No additional major surgeries apart from the recent right total knee arthroplasty.  Medication History: Taking metformin for diabetes and amlodipine for hypertension. No known drug allergies.  Social History: Married  has 2 children. Used to be an active basketball player in his younger years. His alcohol intake is 2-3 standard drinks on average weekly and he is a smoker.  Travel History: No recent travel history.   Based on the above information  the likelihood of DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis) is high given the typical symptoms  post-surgical status  increased BMI  history of uncontrolled hypertension  tobacco use  older age  and sedentary lifestyle - all of these are known to elevate the risk of developing DVT. In addition  the mild dyspnea  chest discomfort and his risk profile may also suggest a possible pulmonary embolism  a serious complication of DVT.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 64-year-old postmenopausal woman  Mrs. Atkins  is presenting with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She is Caucasian  married  retired  with two adult children. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Medical History: She has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and was just recently released from a three weeks hospital stay due to hip replacement surgery. She has been taking metformin for her diabetes  and lisinopril for her hypertension. Her BMI is 30 indicating obesity.   Presenting Problem: The patient complained of a sudden swelling in her right lower leg  which is warmed to touch  reddened and exhibits some pain on palpation. There's no sign of any injury or trauma to the leg.  Background Information: Given her recent hospitalization and hip surgery  the patient is at an increased risk for developing DVT. Other risk factors include her age  obesity  and history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes.   We would need to confirm the presence of DVT through Doppler ultrasound or venography. If DVT is confirmed  we may potentially adjust her current medications  introduce anticoagulants  and recommend lifestyle modifications to manage the DVT while minimizing her risk for pulmonary embolism.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Demographics: 68-year-old Caucasian male - Occupation: Retired Engineer  limited physical activity - Social History: Non-smoker  Moderate alcohol consumption - Family History: Paternal history of cardiovascular disease and stroke  Presenting Complaints: - Sudden swelling in the left lower leg - Mild to moderate pain in left leg  worsening with ambulation  - Warmth over the area of swelling - Skin discoloration (redness)  Past Medical History: - History of prolonged bed rest following a hip replacement surgery two months ago - History of multiple long-distance travels (flight travel >4 hours) in the past half-year - Previous diagnosis of obesity (Body Mass Index of 32) - Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension controlled with oral medications - No known allergies   Physical Examination: - Vital signs: stable - Left lower limb: Calf swelling  erythematous  warm  tender on palpation - Distal pulses intact  no signs of arterial insufficiency - No ulcer or weeping discharge - Rest of the examination is unremarkable   Investigations: - A presumptive diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis(DVT) is made  and a venous Doppler ultrasound is ordered to confirm the diagnosis. - Investigations for the patient's coagulation profile (PT  APTT  D-dimer levels) and baseline blood investigations are planned. - Considering the patient's age and history  tests to rule out malignancy or other hypercoagulable states are proposed.   This problem representation would then guide the physician in planning a comprehensive intervention and management plan for the patient.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 61 years Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Airline Pilot Ethnicity: Caucasian Residential History: Lives alone in a suburban environment Alcohol: Drinker (10 units per week) Smoking: Non-smoker  Presenting Problem: The patient is presenting with an uncomfortable burning sensation and swelling in left leg  more noticeable in the calf region. He mentioned ongoing tenderness and warmth around the area. Notably  the skin around the affected area has become red and discolored. He also reports occasional chest discomfort and sudden shortness of breath.  Relevant Medical History: John was diagnosed with non-insulin dependent diabetes (type-2) 10 years ago. He takes Metformin twice daily. Seven years ago  he suffered a minor heart attack and was discovered to have high blood pressure and elevated cholesterol levels. He is under medication for both conditions - Amlodipine for high BP and Atorvastatin for high cholesterol. He also had a hip-replacement surgery six months prior due to osteoarthritis.   Family History: His father had deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and his mother had rheumatoid arthritis. He has two siblings. His brother has type-2 diabetes and his sister has a history of stroke.  Current Medications: 1. Metformin - 500 mg  twice daily 2. Amlodipine - 5 mg  once daily 3. Atorvastatin - 20 mg  once daily  Allergies: Penicillin. Problem Representation:   Patient Profile: A 64-year-old Caucasian male is presenting with symptoms suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol and reports being generally sedentary due to an office job requiring long hours of sitting. He admits to lack of regular exercise. He is a married man and has two adult children. His family history does not reveal any cases of blood clot disorders.  Chief Complaint: The patient complains of pain and swelling in his left lower leg that has progressively worsened over the past week. The patient reports no history of trauma to that area. He also notes occasional shortness of breath  particularly after walking for short distances.  Presenting Vital Signs: Vital signs indicate a slightly elevated heart rate of 95 bpm  body temperature is 36.7°C  blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  and a respiration rate of 20 breaths per minute.  Relevant Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are managed through medication. Six months ago  he underwent a right total knee arthroplasty due to severe osteoarthritis. His recovery was uneventful  and he was placed on low-dose aspirin for post-procedure protocol. He has no history of any bleeding disorders or malignancies. He also experienced a transient ischemic attack (TIA) three months ago with full recovery.  Medication: The patient is currently taking atenolol for his hypertension and atorvastatin for his hyperlipidemia  as well as daily low-dose aspirin.  This case combines augmented risk factors for DVT such as age  prior surgery  sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia in a male patient. The patient’s symptoms of pain and swelling in the lower leg alongside his elevated heart rate  hypertension  TIA  shortness of breath  and recent history of knee surgery could potentially indicate the presence of DVT. However  more diagnostic tests would be required to make an accurate diagnosis.

Patient Profile:  Mrs. Elizabeth Thompson  a 62-year-old African American lady  presented with symptoms suggestive of deep vein thrombosis. She is a retired school teacher  a widowed  and lives alone in uptown Chicago. Her body mass index (BMI) is 32  indicating that she is obese. She has a dual diagnosis of type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both managed with oral medication for the past ten years. Her blood pressure is generally well under control. However  her glycemic control remains poor despite treatment due to episodic non-compliance to diet regimen. She has no known allergies.  Mrs. Thompson has had two previous hospital admissions: one in 2010 for right-sided ischemic stroke with resultant left-sided weakness  from which she recovered well  and another in 2015 for a cholecystectomy due to acute cholecystitis. She is a former smoker  with a history of 30 pack-years but quit right after her stroke in 2010. She doesn't drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her father died at the age of 67 from complications of a stroke  and her mother passed away at the age of 72 from breast cancer.  Presenting Complaint:  She visited her primary care doctor with a 2-day history of swelling  redness  and warmth in her left calf  combined with a dull aching pain. The symptoms are exacerbated by walking and relieved by elevation. The patient denies trauma to the area  recent travel  history of venous insufficiency  or any personal or family history of DVT or PE.  Current Medications:   - Metformin 500 mg twice daily for type II Diabetes Mellitus. - Lisinopril 10 mg once daily for Hypertension. - Aspirin 81mg once daily since her stroke in 2010.  Under these circumstances  the high clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis requires urgent investigation using Doppler Ultrasound to confirm DVT  and appropriate medical management should commence promptly. She is at risk of pulmonary embolism; hence  the clinical team should be vigilant about any signs of dyspnea  chest pain  and hemoptysis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  A 66-year-old woman named Martha is a retired school teacher. She is Caucasian and lives in the Midwest with her husband of 40 years. She has been generally healthy throughout her life. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol on social occasions. She enjoys gardening and reading in her spare time.  Complaint: Recently  Martha has noticed swelling and pain in her left leg. She describes the pain as ""a dull ache"" and notes that it becomes more pronounced when she walks. The pain tends to decrease with rest. She also observes that her left leg appears red and warmer to touch compared to her right leg.  Past Medical History: Martha has a history of hypertension  managed with Lisinopril  and she has been taking it consistently for the past decade. She was also diagnosed with obesity (BMI 30.1) two years ago  for which she tries to control with diet and moderate exercise.  Family History: There is a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in Martha's family. Her mother suffered from venous thromboembolism (VTE) and pulmonary embolism (PE) in her late sixties.  Recent Activities / Lifestyle:  Martha recently underwent a total knee arthroplasty about a month back. Post her surgery  she had been relatively less mobile and spends most of her time either seated or recumbent. After the surgery  she was put on prophylactic low molecular weight heparin which was stopped after two weeks.  Relevant Risk Factors: Martha's obesity  a recent immobility due to knee surgery  advanced age  hypertension  and a family history of DVT comprise several risk factors for developing DVT. Her complaint of the unilateral leg swelling  redness and warmth are consistent symptoms of DVT  suggesting that Martha may be presenting with this condition.  Next Steps:  The primary physician should consider scheduling diagnostic tests  such as Doppler ultrasound  D-dimer test  and perhaps venography if necessary  to confirm the suspected diagnosis of DVT. A review of her medications and management plan  considering her potential DVT diagnosis  is also warranted. The consideration of starting anticoagulants or thrombolytics  based on the results of her tests and her risk profile  could also be discussed.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  turned up to the emergency department with concerns of moderate tenderness and swelling of his left leg.  Presenting Complaint -  The patient complained of a swollen and red left leg that is sensitive to touch. This condition has been coming on and off for the last four days but got aggravated overnight. Additionally  noticeable warmth in the area and difficulty in walking due to pain.  Demographics: The patient lives in an urban residential area  is married  and is a retired construction engineer.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a history of peripheral vascular disease for which he had surgery three years ago. His medical history also reveals that he was diagnosed with hypertension and type II diabetes  which are under control due to medication and lifestyle changes. He has an inactive lifestyle and is overweight (BMI 30.2)  but a non-smoker and has no history of alcohol or substance abuse.  Recent Past Events: He has recently taken a cross-country road trip  in which he was mostly immobile and in a sitting position for extended hours. He had a minor surgical procedure a month ago for a hernia.  Family History: There is a family history of heart diseases and thrombotic disorders; his father died of a heart attack  and his older sister has recurrent venous thromboembolisms (VTEs).   Current Medication: He is currently on Metformin for his diabetes and Lisinopril for his hypertension.  Objective Findings: Upon examining  the patient's lower left extremity was found noticeably swollen and red with tenderness upon touch. The calf diameter was found greater on the left side compared to the right. His vitals include BP 140/90 mmHg  HR 85 bpm  RR 16 breaths per minute  T 98.6°F.  Based on these scenarios  a differential diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is considered. The presentation of the leg's symptoms  a history of peripheral vascular disease  recent surgery  sedentary lifestyle  long-distance travel  and family history supports this hypothesis. Other potential differential diagnoses  based on his symptoms  could include cellulitis  muscle strain or peripheral artery disease.   Further diagnostic testing  like D-dimer assay  ultrasound  or a venography  will help confirm the diagnosis of DVT for the patient.

Further investigation is warranted to confirm diagnosis and determine appropriate treatment. This may include blood tests  ultrasound  venography  or CT/MRI scans  as well as consultation with a vascular specialist. If confirmed  this condition can be serious that require immediate medical attention. Patient education and regular follow-up care would also be integral parts of the therapeutic strategy.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:   A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the clinic reporting a 3-day history of swelling  pain  and redness in her left calf.   Demographics:   Residing in a suburban community  she lives alone since the death of her husband two years ago. She is a retired school teacher. She reports being a non-smoker and consumes alcohol rarely  during social occasions.   Past Medical History:  She is a known case of hypertension and type 2 diabetes which are managed with medications – amlodipine for hypertension and metformin for diabetes. She underwent elective knee replacement surgery about 2 weeks ago and since then has been relatively immobile. She mentions that her mother had a history of stroke and her elder brother had a heart attack in his mid-60s. Routine blood tests done prior to the surgery were all normal. Her BMI is above average  indicating her to be slightly overweight.   Problem List:  1. Recent major surgery 2. Relative Immobility 3. Hypertension 4. Type 2 Diabetes 5. Moderate Risk Family History – Stroke  MI 6. Obesity  Clinical Encounter:  During physical examination  her left calf appears swollen with localized warmness and erythema. It is painful upon touch or when attempts are made to flex the foot. Her blood pressure is slightly raised.  This clinical scenario strongly suggests a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  potentially precipitated by her recent knee surgery and immobility status. Further diagnostic tests like a Doppler ultrasound or D-dimer test can be carried out to confirm the diagnosis. Considering her history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  as well as her family history  there's an increased risk for complications such as Pulmonary Embolism  and therefore  prompt intervention is warranted.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Age: 53 years  - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Office worker - sedentary lifestyle - Social history: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol consumption   Chief Complaint: Patient presents at the Emergency Department with consistent  severe pain in the left calf for the past 48 hours. The calf is warm to touch and visibly swollen when compared to the right calf. Patient describes the pain as getting worse when trying to stand or walk.   Relevant Past Medical History: - Patient had a hip replacement surgery on the left side two months prior.  - He had been taking ibuprofen for post-surgical pain.  - He has a history of obesity with a BMI of 30.2.  - Family history of heart diseases. His father had a heart attack at the age of 65.  - High cholesterol level for the last five years and on statins.  - No known allergies or past instances of hematological disorders.  Recent Significant Events: - Patient had a long-haul flight (7+ hours) a week ago.  - He had been adhering to post-operative instructions  but had not been consistent in doing recommended physical activities since his surgery.   Lifestyle Factors: - Sedentary lifestyle with low physical activity.  - Mostly consumes fast food with a high content of fat and cholesterol. - Does not consume recommended quantities of fruits and vegetables.  - Drinks 1-2 glasses of red wine per week.  Given the patient’s existing health conditions  recent surgery  prolonged inactivity  long-plane flight  and family history  he is at a high risk of deep vein thrombosis. A venous ultrasound should be used to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient profile:  Name: John Smith Age: 60 Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Office job  sedentary lifestyle.  Demographic Information:   John Smith is a 60- year-old Caucasian male. He lives in the city and works in a software development firm with a sedentary lifestyle. He doesn't regularly do physical activities or exercise.  History of Present Illness:  John has recently complained of moderate to severe pain and swelling in his right lower leg particularly in his calf muscle. The pain is exacerbated when he is walking or standing. He has noticed that the affected leg has become slightly red and warm.  Past Medical History:  John has a history of smoking for the last 30 years but he has reduced its frequency in the last few years. He was diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago which is well managed with antihypertensive medication. Last month  he was hospitalized for a major surgery followed by a prolonged bed rest of two weeks.  Family History:  His mother was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the past.  Review of Systems:   No complaints of chest pain  breathlessness  cough  or weight loss. No noticeable recent changes.  Relevant Risk Factors:  1. Advanced age - The risk for DVT increases with age especially after age 60. 2. Sedentary lifestyle – Lack of physical activity is a known risk factor.  3. Personal history of major surgery and prolonged immobility which can result in blood pooling in the leg veins. 4. Family history - If a blood relative has had DVT or pulmonary embolism  John might be more at risk. 5. Smoking - damages the inner lining of blood vessels and decreases anti-clotting activity.  Possible Diagnosis:  Considering John's age  symptoms  known risk factors  and past medical history  he might be suffering from Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Further diagnostic tests are needed for confirmation.  Intervention recommendation:  Refer to a vascular specialist for confirmation of the suspected diagnosis and potential anticoagulants treatment under close supervision. Lifestyle modifications including quitting smoking  keeping blood pressure under control  moving around after being stationary for a long time or post-surgery are recommended. An exercise regimen including walking  jogging  cycling  or swimming is advisable.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male known to John  a physician in a suburban community hospital. He is a retired teacher  a non-smoker with a history of moderate alcohol consumption. His BMI indicates he is overweight.   Presenting Problem: The patient presents with a two-day history of unilateral leg swelling and aching heaviness in his right lower extremity that intensifies with standing or walking. The leg has a visibly red and warm area. He also mentions experiencing mild shortness of breath.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia managed with medications (lisinopril and atorvastatin respectively). He was previously hospitalized for a total hip replacement surgery on his right leg 2 weeks ago. He reports being sedentary post-surgery due to reduced mobility.   Family History: There is a family history of cardiovascular problems. His father died of a heart attack at 67 and his older brother has been diagnosed with coronary artery disease.  Social History: The patient lives with his wife  has two children and three grandchildren who visit often. He enjoys bird-watching and used to be a regular walker before his hip surgery.   The suspicion from this representation is Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  likely due to his recent hip surgery  reduced mobility  family history of cardiovascular disease  and predisposing factors like hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and being overweight. These potentially increase his risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (suggested by the mild shortness of breath). Diagnostic investigations  including a venous ultrasound (Doppler) and D-dimer levels  should be ordered to confirm the diagnosis. In addition  a thorough risk-benefit analysis for anticoagulation therapy is suggested based on the outcomes of these investigations.

Problem Representation:   Patient Description: A 67-year-old  Caucasian male  retired mechanic. He is a smoker with a 35-pack year history and consumes moderate alcohol. He is obese with a BMI of 31 and has a sedentary lifestyle. He lives with his wife in a suburban locality. He is uninsured and often hesitates to seek health services due to high costs.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a swollen  warm  pinkish-red and painful left leg. He experiences difficulty in walking due to pain which is gradually worsening over the past week. He denies any history of trauma.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril. He has undergone a total left knee replacement 2 years ago. He had a significant hospital stay post-knee surgery due to a postoperative infection. However  no thrombotic episode was recorded in the past.  Family History: His father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 74  and his mother had a stroke. His elder brother has Type 2 diabetes and suffers from peripheral vascular disease.  Social History: He is a retired mechanic and mostly spends his time at the home. He does not pursue any physical activities. He has been smoking for around 40 years and usually smokes a pack per day. He also drinks alcohol moderately.  Current Medications: Lisinopril 10 mg daily for hypertension.  Physical Examination: On examination  remarkable finding is that his left calf is swollen  with a leg diameter 3 cm larger than the other side  and warm to the touch. He has a positive Homan's sign. Rest of his examination including a cardiovascular exam is essentially normal.  Summary Problem Representation: A 67-year-old male smoker and moderate alcohol drinker  who is sedentary  obese with a history of hypertension presents with a week-long history of progressive  painful  unilateral left leg swelling. Considering his post knee surgery history  lack of physical activity  obesity  hypertension  and family history  there is a strong suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Problem Representation:   Demographic Information: Mrs. Madison is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who lives in Colorado. She is a non-smoker but reports occasional alcohol consumption. She is a retired school teacher and lives with her husband.   Relevant Past Medical History: Mrs. Madison has been diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled by medication. She was hospitalized once in her late 50s due to appendicitis and had her appendix surgically removed. Her family history reveals that her mother had a heart attack at age 75  and her grandmother suffered a stroke at 80.  Presenting Problem and Symptoms: Mrs. Madison presents with left leg swelling and discomfort which she reports has been ongoing for a week. She indicates that she recently took a long car drive and noticed the symptoms a few days after her trip. She also mentions that her left calf is visibly more swollen than the right one  and she feels a dull ache and warm sensation. She denies any chest pain  cough  or shortness of breath.  Based on the patient's history and symptoms  a possible diagnosis could be deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The extended car drive (a period of immobility)  her age  and her hypertension and diabetes contribute to her risk. Mrs. Madison will need further diagnostic tests  including D-dimer test and/or a lower extremity venous ultrasound  to confirm the diagnosis. It is also important to consider her potential risk for pulmonary embolism (PE)  given the potential life-threatening nature of this condition. In the meantime  anticoagulant medication might be initiated to prevent the progression of DVT and stop the formation of a new blood clot. Consultation with a haematologist or a vascular medicine specialist could be beneficial for Mrs. Madison.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Robert Anderson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male presented on 12/03/2022 with symptoms consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He is a retired truck driver  previously a heavy smoker (~30 pack-years) but quit fifteen years ago. He reports a sedentary lifestyle since retirement 10 years ago and a diet rich in processed and fatty foods. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 30.2 kg/m2  indicating clinical obesity. The patient is a widower living alone and is a high-functioning daily alcohol consumer.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Anderson’s previous medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed seven years ago. The patient is currently treated with Lisinopril 20 mg once daily for hypertension and Metformin 850 mg twice daily for diabetes. His last recorded HbA1c was 7.6%  indicating suboptimal glycemic control. He was hospitalized with a myocardial infarction five years ago and underwent successful angioplasty. He has also been under regular medication with aspirin 81mg/day and Atorvastatin 40 mg/day for secondary prevention of coronary artery disease. He has no history of surgeries  injuries  or malignancies.   Family History:  Mr. Anderson’s father passed away at the age of 65 due to a stroke. His mother died at 76 from complications of diabetes. He has one older sister with coronary artery disease  and one younger brother  deceased  with early-onset Alzheimer’s disease. No family history of venous thromboembolism.  Medication:  • Lisinopril 20mg QD • Metformin 850mg BID • Aspirin 81mg QD • Atorvastatin 40mg QD  Allergies:  No known drug allergies  Social History:  Ex-smoker  quit 15 years ago but had smoked one pack/day for around 30 years. High-functioning daily alcohol consumer  but with no identified dependency. No known illicit drug use. Retired truck driver living alone with limited physical activity.  Chief Complaint:  Complained of severe  persistent calf pain and swelling in the left lower leg that developed over the past 3 days. No noted chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. No history of recent long-distance travel or long periods of immobility.  Given the age  medical history  lifestyle factors  and clinical picture  the risk factors for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) are quite prominent in this patient  making it a rational clinical suspicion necessitating further diagnostic investigations. This includes imaging studies (duplex ultrasound) and possible laboratory tests like D-dimer.  Treatment measures focusing on anticoagulation therapies and lifestyle modifications may need to be discussed. Further management would depend on the results of the diagnostic measures and risk stratification.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Information:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male currently working as a truck driver. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian female  moderately overweight with a BMI of 29. She's a smoker with a 20 pack-year history. She lives alone and is a retired elementary school teacher. She admits to being mostly sedentary  with a diet rich in red meat and processed foods. She has a family history of cardiovascular disease: her mother experienced a stroke at the age of 72  and her paternal grandfather died of a heart attack at 57.   Chief Complaint: The patient presents with a 3-day history of increasing pain and swelling in her left lower leg.   History of Present Illness: The onset of the pain was gradual  starting as a mild discomfort and progressively becoming severe. The pain seems to get worse with walking and improves slightly with rest. A moderate swelling has also developed in the affected leg. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations.  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension for the past 20 years  currently on Lisinopril 5 mg daily. 2. Hyperlipidemia  controlled with statin therapy (Atorvastatin 20 mg every night). 3. Gastroesophageal reflux disease  managed with over-the-counter antacids  as needed. 4. An episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) 10 years back with complete resolution of symptoms.  Recent Events: Traveled on a long-haul flight (10-hour journey) about a week ago.   Physical Examination:  Unilateral leg swelling and warmth over the left calf noted  with palpable cord. Mild tenderness noted in the left calf region. The left calf is 3 cm larger in circumference than the right when measured 10 cm below the tibial tuberosity. No visible skin discoloration  ulcers  or varicose veins seen. Peripheral pulses palpable bilaterally. Rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Based on the clinical presentation and risk factors  the patient is suspected to have a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left lower extremity. A duplex ultrasound is recommended to confirm the diagnosis followed by blood tests to check coagulation parameters. She will likely be started on anticoagulant therapy. Her risk factors such as obesity and smoking will also need to be addressed as part of her treatment plan.

Patient Profile: Mr. John Smith is a 64-year-old male who presents to the clinic with complaints of swollen leg. The patient describes the swelling as unusually painful and may have been present for several days.   Demographics: Mr. Smith is a Caucasian retired engineer  who is currently staying in Tampa  Florida. He lives with his wife and is a non-smoker. He admits to alcohol use but mostly restricts it to social occasions. He is neither overweight nor underweight for his height.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith was previously diagnosed with hypertension at age 57 and was managed using medication (Losartan). He also has a consistent cholesterol problem but is managed well by statin therapy. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer when he was 61  which required radical prostatectomy. No other comorbidities were reported.   Family History: He has a family history of thromboembolic disorders  with his mother having experienced an episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and his father suffering from a stroke in his late seventies.   Current Complaint and illness:  He explains that the painful swelling in his right calf started about three days ago and has been progressively increasing. He denies having any sign of trauma or injury. He also denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or neurological symptoms.   Surgeries and Hospitalizations: Mr. Smith has had surgical intervention for his prostate cancer three years ago.  Lifestyle: He follows a balanced diet and manages light gardening as the form of bodily exercise. He maintains a body mass index within healthy limits. He worked as a civil engineer and didn't involve much physical activity.   Allergies: He reports no known drug allergies.  Medications: He is regularly taking On Losartan (50mg/day) for his hypertension and Atorvastatin (20mg/day)  a statin  for his high cholesterol levels.   Given the patient's presentation  it is considered likely that the presenting swelling may be related to a venous thrombosis. Specifically  the sudden onset  his familial history of thromboembolic disorders  and his limited physical activity may have increased his risk for a DVT. Further investigations would be necessary to confirm this provisional diagnosis.

Patient Profile:  Mr. John Doe is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who currently resides in the city. He is married and has two adult children. His occupation is a financial analyst  which involves sitting at a desk for long hours. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and does minimal physical activity. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He is well-nourished with an average body mass index of 28.7. John does not have allergies. His family history includes a brother who had deep vein thrombosis at the age of 65.  Chief Complaint:  John presented to the hospital with complaints of progressive pain and swelling in his right lower leg for one week. He denies any trauma  fever  chest pain or shortness of breath.  Past Medical History:  John was diagnosed with hypertension five years ago which is well-controlled on amlodipine 5mg daily. He had gallbladder removal surgery fifteen years ago. John is also mildly hypercholesterolemic for which he takes atorvastatin 20mg daily. He has no history of diabetes mellitus  heart disease or respiratory conditions. He denies any history of blood clots or bleeding disorders. He has never taken medications that may increase the risk of clotting such as hormone replacement therapy or oral contraceptives.  Review of Systems:  Upon questioning  the patient reported generalized fatigue and occasional leg cramps. He denied recent international or long-distance travel. He also denied recent exposure to immobility (such as hospitalization or bed rest). No chest pain  palpitations  cough  dyspnea or diaphoresis were reported. He denied symptoms suggestive of liver or kidney disease. His bowel habits are regular  and he denies nocturia or dysuria.  Physical Examination:  John's vital signs are stable with blood pressure 130/85 mmHg  pulse rate 68 beats per minute  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute  and temperature 37 degrees Celsius. Examination of his right lower limb showed a mildly swollen calf  which was tender on deep palpation. There was no discoloration  and the leg was warm to touch. His peripheral pulses were intact. The remainder of his physical examination was unremarkable.  Based on the above presentation and physical examination findings  clinical suspicion for deep vein thrombosis is high. Therefore  relevant investigations including D-dimer tests and venous duplex ultrasonography are planned.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Characterization:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John  who is currently residing in the urban area of San Francisco. Mr. John had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago and has been on daily aspirin since then. Last year  he underwent hip replacement surgery on the right side due to severe osteoarthritis. Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 65 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Office Worker Marital Status: Married Residence: Urban  lives alone as his children are grown-up Smoking Status: Non-smoker Alcohol: Occasionally drinks in social gatherings  Past Medical History: - Type II Diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago  on oral hypoglycemics - Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  taking antihypertensives - Underwent a hip replacement surgery two months ago - History of prolonged periods of immobility due to sedentary lifestyle  Family History: - Father died of stroke  aged 70 - Mother has a history of arthritis - Brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease at age 60  Presenting Complaint: The patient came to the clinic complaining of new onset  gradually progressive  left calf pain  and swelling for the past 3 days. Physical Examination: Examination showed a swollen left calf  around 3 cm larger in circumference than the right calf. Warm to touch and tender along the distribution of the deep venous system. Palpable cord along the line of left leg veins. No sign of any skin breakdown or ulceration  and no superficial venous varicosities.  Vitals: - Temperature: 37.2°C - Pulse rate: 82/minute - Blood pressure: 130/85 mmHg - Respiratory rate: 18/minute - Oxygen saturation: 97% room air  Reasonable assumptions: Given the history of recent hip surgery  prolonged periods of immobility due to a sedentary lifestyle  and the presenting symptoms of leg pain and swelling  one must consider a clinical diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). This should be confirmed with a Duplex ultrasound  and management should be initiated promptly to prevent potentially fatal complications such as a pulmonary embolism.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile ---------- A 52-year-old Caucasian male who works as an office administrator.  Presenting Complaint: ---------- The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT): a warm  red  swollen  and painful right lower leg.  Medical  Family  and Social History: ---------- The patient has a medical history of being overweight with a BMI of 32. He has been suffering from mild hypertension for the past five years  controlled with medication (Lisinopril). He recently had a knee surgery (6 weeks ago) following a sports injury. His father (deceased) had a history of myocardial infarction at the age of 59  his sister (57 years old)  was diagnosed with DVT last year. The patient is a non-smoker  but drinks moderately. His lifestyle is quite sedentary as his job involves sitting for extended periods.  Relevant Past Medication History: ---------- In addition to Lisinopril for the control of hypertension  the patient has been on a regular dose of ibuprofen for post-operative knee pain.   Clinical Examination: ---------- On examination  the right calf is warm to touch  erythematous  swollen  and tender along the deep venous system. There is mild pitting edema. Pulses in the right leg are normal. No ulcers or skin changes indicating chronic venous insufficiency.   Risk stratification: ----------   1. Obesity (BMI 32)   2. Family history of DVT   3. Recent knee surgery   4. Sedentary lifestyle   5. Hypertension   6. Moderate alcohol intake   7. Age over 40   8. Prolonged use of NSAIDs (Ibuprofen)  Laboratory Tests: ---------- D-dimer  complete blood count  coagulation studies  renal and liver function tests are currently being done.  This problem presentation suggests a classic clinical picture of possible deep vein thrombosis  with numerous potential risk factors contributing to this patient's presentation. Further investigation with imaging and lab results can help confirm the diagnosis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Demographics: 62-year old Caucasian female - Occupation: Retired teacher (sedentary lifestyle) - BMI: 33 (obese) - Smoker: Yes-history of 20 years of smoking  10 cigarettes/day - Alcohol: Occasionally  about 2 standard drinks on weekend  Chief Complain: - Complains of progressive pain & swelling in her right calf for the last week. - Associated symptoms: Light-headedness  shortness of breath at times.  Past Medical History: - Essential hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago (on medication) - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago (Metformin) - History of recurrent urinary tract infections - Several long-haul flights in the past two months  Family History: - Mother had a stroke at 72 and a history of varicose veins.  Travel History: - Recent long-haul flights visiting grandchildren overseas.   Clinical Examination: - Vital signs: slightly elevated blood pressure - Right lower limb examination reveals an erythematous  swollen  warm & tender area on the calf. Positive Homan's Sign. - Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations are unremarkable.  Relevant test results: - D-dimer level: raised - Dupplex ultrasound of the right leg: reveals clot in the deep vein of the right calf region. - Fasting Blood glucose: slightly elevated. - HbA1c: 7.1%  Diagnosis: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right calf  possibly secondary to prolonged immobility associated with long flights and sedentary lifestyle. High-risk factors also include her obesity  smoking and a family history of thromboembolism.  Plan of Management: 1. Anticoagulant therapy: initiation of heparin  transitioning to warfarin or direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) as long-term therapy. 2. Graduated compression stockings for symptom relief and to prevent post-thrombotic syndrome. 3. Lifestyle modifications: weight loss  smoking cessation  exercises and avoidance of prolonged immobility. 4. Regular follow-ups and INR monitoring  managing diabetes  and hypertension.   Close monitoring of symptoms for any signs of Pulmonary Embolism  such as worsening shortness of breath  chest pain  coughing up blood  and monitor for any complications of anticoagulation therapy.

Chief Complaint:  Patient reports pain and swelling in her left lower leg for a week.   Patient Profile:  A 57-year-old Caucasian female  married  who is a former high school teacher from Houston  Texas. She lives with her husband.  Present Illness:  Patient describes a constant  throbbing pain in her left lower extremity that began a week ago  shortly after a long-haul flight from London. The pain is accompanied by noticeable swelling and redness and has steadily increased in intensity. There's no history of trauma or injury to the leg. She denies any shortness of breath  chest pain  or palpitations.   Past Medical History:  1) Hypertension controlled with daily amlodipine 5mg for the past 5 years 2) Recently underwent a total knee replacement surgery on the right knee 3 months ago   underwent physical therapy and rehabilitation.  3) No known history of clotting disorders in the family. 4) Smoker for 20 years  approximately half pack per day. 5) Postmenopausal  on Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) for hot flashes for about 10 months.   Family History:  1) Mother has hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. 2) Father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 62.   Medication History:  1) Daily amlodipine 5mg for hypertension 2) Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT)   Allergies:  No known drug allergies.   Social History:  Former high school teacher  now retired. Engages in gardening for physical activity. Smokes half a pack a day. Occasional alcohol consumption  about 1-2 wine glasses during family gatherings but none on regular days.   Physical Examination:  Swelling of the left lower extremity compared to right. Warm to touch with noted erythema and tenderness along the medial aspect of the left leg. Range of motion limited due to pain. No observable signs of cellulitis.   Assessment:  The presentation of left leg pain with swelling  redness  heat  and tenderness after a long journey  combined with her recent surgery  HRT use  and smoking habit point towards a high likelihood of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).   Plan:  To confirm the diagnosis  arrange for Duplex ultrasound of the suspected leg as it has a high sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing DVT. Depending on the results  initiation of anticoagulation therapy may be needed. Also  consider a smoking cessation plan and reassessment of the necessity of HRT considering its risks.

A co-existing condition of respiratory involvement considering the breathlessness may indicate pulmonary embolism.    Plan: - Blood tests including D-dimer levels. - Doppler ultrasound for the left leg. - Echocardiography considering past medical history. - Chest CT angiogram to rule out pulmonary embolism. - Consultation with a Cardiologist.  - Consider starting on Heparin  pending diagnosis confirmation. - Strict observation and vital signs monitoring.  - Encourage leg elevation and gentle mobilization.   This problem representation would be subject to changes evolving with the patient's condition and test results.

His body mass index is 28  indicating an overweight status.   Relevant Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a history of hypertension controlled with medication (lisinopril) and was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes five years ago managed with Metformin. He underwent a total knee replacement operation two weeks ago due to severe osteoarthritis. Three years ago  he was also treated for prostate cancer with successful radiation therapy but has been in remission since. He denies any known coagulopathy or previous history of venous thromboembolic events in himself or close family. He is not known to have any allergies.  In connection to these past illnesses  he is under regular medical supervision with routinely done blood tests and follows up appointments with his endocrinologist and cardiologist. In post-operative period  he did not receive prophylaxis for deep venous thrombosis.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Smith Age: 60  Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Profession: Long-haul truck driver Lifestyle: Smokes half a pack of cigarettes every day  sedentary work and lifestyle  Presenting Problem:  Mr. Smith is presenting with persistent pain and swelling of the right leg which he has noticed worsening over the past week. He is reporting suffering from intense cramping  particularly along the inner thigh and calf region. His right leg feels warmer to touch and has taken on a reddish discoloration. He also reports experiencing occasional fatigue and a faint shortness of breath.   Relevant Past Medical History:  1) Hypertension - diagnosed 10 years prior to admission  currently under control with diet and medication (Lisinopril  10 mg  once daily). 2) Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - diagnosed 8 years prior to admission  lower limb peripheral neuropathy reported  under management with insulin and dietary control. 3) Morbid obesity - BMI of 35.  4) Had abdominal surgery (Cholecystectomy) 3 years ago. 5) Family history: his father suffered from a myocardial infarction at age 62 and an uncle had Pulmonary Embolism at age 64.  This is a serious case given the potential for a Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) to dislodge and cause a Pulmonary Embolism (PE). Immediate investigation and intervention if necessary are warranted. The patient's advanced age  hypertension  DM  obesity  and sedentary lifestyle significantly contribute to his overall risk for the development and exacerbation of a DVT. His current condition is likely further complicated by his smoking habit and a genetic predisposition for vascular disease (as suggested by his family history of heart attack and PE).

Problem Representation:  Patient Characterization: A 60-year-old  African American female presents with a chief complaint of unilateral leg pain and mild swelling. She works as an office administrator where she sits for long periods and also references a 4-hour car trip she took approximately 5 days ago. She is a nonsmoker but has been on oral contraceptives for the past few years. Her Body Mass Index (BMI) is 31  indicating obesity. Family history is significant for grandparents on both sides having experienced venous thromboembolism.   Relevant Past Medical History:  She has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and takes beta-blockers. Around 3 years ago  she underwent a surgical hip replacement after a fall in her home. She also has a diagnosed history of type II diabetes mellitus and is under metformin therapy. She denies any history of cancer  heart disease  or any other significant illnesses.  Patient Presentation:  The patient is anxious about her symptoms due to the family history of thromboembolism. Upon physical examination  her right lower calf appears slightly swollen and feels warm to touch when compared to the left. A positive Homan's sign is noted. The rest of the physical examination shows no significant abnormalities.   Clinical Impression:  Given the patient's personal and family history  clinical presentation  lack of movement due to occupation  oral contraceptive use  obesity  and recent long journey  she is considered to have a high pre-test probability for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Plan:  She is suggested for confirmatory tests for DVT like Doppler Ultrasonography  D-Dimer Test and possibly  a venogram. A discussion also needs to be held about her future risks  lifestyle changes such as increase in physical activity  weight loss  possible contraceptive method switch  and thrombophilic workup due to family history of DVT.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics: A 55-year-old white female  non-smoker  who is a high school teacher and has been fairly sedentary due to remote teaching.  Relevant Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of obesity (BMI 32) and type 2 diabetes mellitus which is controlled using metformin. She has a sedentary lifestyle and is on birth control treatment for heavy menstrual bleeding. She reports no known prior thrombotic events  no family history of thrombotic events  no history of malignancy  and has never been pregnant. The patient has no known drug allergies.   Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with unexplained swelling of the left leg that has worsened over the past week  with pain and redness in the calf area. She has also mentioned recently experiencing intermittent shortness of breath while performing day-to-day activities.   Preliminary Diagnosis: Given the patient’s ongoing symptoms of unilateral leg swelling  calf pain  redness  and shortness of breath  there's a high suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) that might have potentially led to a pulmonary embolism. It is compounded by her risk factors  which includes obesity  age  limited physical activity  and the use of hormonal contraception.   Further Investigation: Venous duplex ultrasound for confirmation of DVT and computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) for pulmonary embolism (PE) should be considered. Moreover  lab tests including complete blood count  coagulation profile  and D-dimer test might be required.   Plan: Based on the investigation results  treatment might include anticoagulation therapy. The patient should also be advised about lifestyle modification for diabetes and obesity management including regular exercise and a balanced diet. Finally  re-evaluation of the necessity of hormonal contraception in light of the present conditions should be discussed.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  A 65-year-old female  minutes away from the rural area where she resides  came in for a consultation. She's Caucasian  moderately overweight with a BMI of 27  and lives a sedentary lifestyle working a desk job. She has a history of heavy smoking but quit ten years back. Family history shows a pattern of cardiovascular diseases which includes her mother having had a stroke at age 70.   Chief Complaint:  She expressed concerns about progressive pain and swelling in her left lower extremity for the last five days  with tenderness in the calf region which started suddenly after sitting for a prolonged period during a long car journey. The leg appears slightly redder and warmer than the right leg with moderate edema. Additionally  she reports shortness of breath experienced periodically over the past three days.  Past Medical History:  Her past medical reports show a history of hypertension  effectively managed with medication (Diuretics - Hydrochlorothiazide). Her blood pressure today is 130/85 mm Hg. No history of diabetes was noted. She had a hysterectomy about fifteen years ago due to fibroids. She is on hormone replacement therapy post-menopause.   Medication history:  Other than Hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension  she takes daily multivitamins and occasional over-the-counter painkillers for arthritis. She also takes estrogen as part of her hormone replacement therapy.  Pattern Recognition: Considering the patient's age  gender  history of prolonged immobility  hormone replacement therapy  hypertension  obesity  family history and clinical presentation such as swelling  pain  redness  warmth in one leg and shortness of breath  this pattern suggests a high suspicion of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) with a possible pulmonary embolism. The Virchow’s triad of venous stasis (long car travel)  hypercoagulability (HRT  family history of vascular conditions) and endothelial injury (age  hypertension) are all present thus increasing the likelihood of DVT.    Plans:  Possible next steps would be diagnostic tests to confirm the diagnosis (Duplex ultrasonography and D-Dimer test if required)  and if confirmed  medication (possibly anticoagulant therapy) and lifestyle modifications would be discussed. It's also important to rule out potential life-threatening conditions such as pulmonary embolism given her shortness of breath. More testing  such as a CT angiography  may be necessary. It is also equally important to advise her about the urgent need for smoking cessation due to her risk profile.

Patient Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  residing in the suburbs of New York. He is retired and spends most of his time indoors due to mobility issues. He is a non-smoker and moderate drinker. His family history includes a mother who developed Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in her late 50s.   Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history significant for obesity  Hypertension (HTN) and Type II Diabetes Mellitus. He has been on medication for his HTN and diabetes for the past 10 years. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is 32.1  which classifies him as obese. Regarding surgeries  the patient underwent a hip joint replacement two years ago due to osteoarthritis. There were no complications in the postoperative period and he received adequate prophylaxis for DVT.  Presenting Issue: The patient presented to the ER complaining of swelling and intermittent pain  which he described as a deep ache  in his left calf for the last week. He reported no history of trauma  fever  chest pain or respiratory issues. The patient noted no alleviating or aggravating factors for the swelling and pain.  Clinical Examination: On clinical examination  the left calf was observed to be significantly swollen and warm compared to the right. Homans' sign was absent. Peripheral pulses were intact and there was no sign of any skin discoloration or ulcers.  Investigations: Blood tests were carried out  revealing raised D-Dimer levels. An emergency lower limb venous Doppler ultrasound was performed confirming the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in the left leg; showing a non-compressible segment in the left popliteal vein.  Management: The patient was immediately commenced on low molecular weight Heparin and oral anticoagulation (Warfarin). Adequate hydration and analgesia were maintained. He was advised for compression bandaging and leg elevation to reduce swelling.  Prognosis: The patient's response to the initiated treatment was positive with a decrease in swelling and pain. He was counseled about the importance of compliance with medication  weight control  regular exercise  optimal control of diabetes and blood pressure  and to avoid prolonged periods of immobility. He was also given advice about the signs and symptoms of pulmonary embolism – a known complication of DVT  and was informed to seek immediate medical attention if these symptoms appear.  Follow Up: Follow-up appointments were scheduled for regular INR checks and medication review. In addition  contact information for a vascular surgery consultation was provided in case symptoms persist or worsen.  Though this patient was at a high risk of developing DVT due to his prior surgery  family history  obesity  and sedentary lifestyle  the DVT was diagnosed early  minimizing his risk of potential serious complications.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 62-year-old Male  Patient Information: The patient is a 62-year-old African American male with a historical record of hypertension and Type II diabetes. He is a non-smoker and lives a fairly sedentary lifestyle courtesy of his occupation as an accountant. The patient's family history exposed a positive record for cardiovascular disease  with both parents succumbing to myocardial infarctions in their early 70s. The patient is currently on medication for diabetes (Metformin) and hypertension (Lisinopril) respectively.  Presenting Complaint & Clinical Findings: The patient presented at the outpatient department with complaints of increasing pain and swelling in the left lower limb for the past week. The pain progressively worsened and was associated with a feeling of heaviness in the leg. The physical examination findings revealed a reddened  swollen left lower limb that was warm to touch. Palpable femoral pulses were present  but the distal pulses were difficult to locate due to the marked swelling. No significant skin discoloration was observed. The patient did not have a fever  and apart from the acute pain and swelling in his left leg  he did not report any additional symptoms.  Investigations: An urgent compression ultrasonography was undertaken which showed presence of a clot in the left popliteal vein extending up to the femoral vein  confirming the clinical suspicion of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). D-dimer levels were found to be significantly elevated (>500 ng/mL). INR test showed a value of 1.0 which is within the normal range. The patient’s renal function and complete blood count were found to be within the normal range.  Treatment and Progress: The patient was admitted and was started on anticoagulant therapy with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) followed by oral anticoagulants (Warfarin) to maintain a target INR of 2.0 - 3.0. The patient was encouraged to mobilize and compression stockings were applied to the affected limb to mitigate swelling.  After a week of hospital admission  the swelling and pain were remarkably reduced.  Follow-up: The patient was discharged with advice on prolonged anticoagulation therapy  to maintain a more active lifestyle to prevent recurrence  and to continue with regular follow-ups to ensure therapeutic INR values. The patient was also provided with education concerning the warning signs of Pulmonary Embolism as DVT can be a precursor for this serious condition.  Conclusion: This case illustrated a typical manifestation of deep vein thrombosis  affirming the need for high clinical suspicion in patients presenting with unilateral lower limb pain and swelling  especially in the setting of relevant risk factors.

Title: A Case Report of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 65-year-old Male with Previous Cardiovascular Disease  Introduction:  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a thromboembolic disorder characterized by the formation of a blood clot within deep veins  predominantly in the lower extremities. This case concerns a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of cardiovascular disease who developed DVT.  Patient information:  The patient is a 65-year-old  Caucasian gentleman  non-smoker  domiciled in rural Iowa. Professionally  he is a retired farmer  slightly overweight with a BMI of 26. He confesses to an inactive lifestyle since retirement  with less than 30 minutes of moderate physical activity per week.  Prior Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension  which has been controlled with Lisinopril for the last 10 years. He also had a myocardial infarction five years ago  following which he underwent placement of drug-eluting stents for multiple coronary vessel disease. The patient was then started on Clopidogrel  a medication to hinder the formation of new clots.
