Presenting Concerns: The patient presented to the outpatient department with complaints of acute onset  unilateral  painful swelling of his left lower limb. Based on clinical suspicion and D-dimer testing  the patient was suspected of having a deep vein thrombosis. An immediate lower limb venous doppler ultrasound was hence requested.  Clinical Findings: The doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a non-compressible segment within the left popliteal vein  consistent with the diagnosis of DVT. The patient was found to be hemodynamically stable; vital signs showed blood pressure 140/85 mmHg  heart rate 85 beats per minute  respirations 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 98% in room air.  Intervention: The patient was promptly started on anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin alongside his Clopidogrel and was admitted for further management. Risk factor analysis noted hyperlipidemia  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  and prior coronary artery disease possibly culminating in the development of DVT.  Clinical Follow-Up: During hospitalization  the patient’s symptoms improved with anticoagulant treatment. Warfarin was added to his medication regimen with a target INR of 2-3  and he was discharged home with plans for extended anticoagulation and close outpatient follow-up. Education was also provided regarding the importance of regular physical activity  diet modification  and recognizing symptoms of DVT and pulmonary embolism.  Conclusion: The case emphasizes the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling  especially in the presence of known risk factors such as cardiovascular disease. It also underscores the importance of DVT prophylaxis in patients at risk  even when on antiplatelet therapy for other comorbid conditions.

Case Report  Patient Information: Mr. J. Smith is a 68-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired banker and a non-smoker with moderate alcohol use. He is currently living alone in an urban setting. His height is 180cm  and he weights 85kg with a BMI of 26 kg/m2.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith presented with sudden onset pain and swelling in his right calf of 3-day duration. The pain was described as sharp  constant  non-radiating  and was getting progressively worse.  Clinical History: Mr. Smith had been relatively healthy  his last hospital admission was in 2001 for a total knee replacement surgery due to osteoarthritis. His past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension diagnosed in 2007  and type 2 diabetes diagnosed in 2010. His mother had a history of stroke in her late 70s.  Recent History: Two months before the onset of current symptoms  he was diagnosed with prostate cancer for which he commenced on chemotherapy. He did not have any recent travel history or previous history of DVT.  Examination Findings: Upon physical examination  erythema  edema and tenderness were noted on the right calf; the left leg was normal. His vital signs included a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  a pulse rate of 78 beats per minute  temperature of 36.7°C and a SaO2 of 96% on room air.  Investigation Results: A Duplex ultrasound of the right leg was ordered that documented an acute deep vein thrombosis in the right posterior tibial and peroneal veins. A D-dimer test was positive. His complete blood count  kidney function  liver function and electrolytes were within normal ranges. His HbA1c was 7.4% indicating that his diabetes is under control.   Management: Anticoagulation therapy was initiated with low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) followed by oral warfarin. He was also given compression stockings to wear every day to help decrease swelling and pain. His chemotherapy regimen was reviewed by the oncology team.  Follow-up: Mr. Smith is regularly following up with the vascular and oncology team. His condition has improved significantly. His INR has been within therapeutic range during regular follow-ups.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the classic presentation of deep vein thrombosis in an elderly patient on chemotherapy for prostate cancer. High index of suspicion and timely diagnosis are crucial in managing this potentially fatal condition. Management may require multiple interventions including cancer treatment adjustment.   Keywords: Deep Vein Thrombosis  chemotherapy  prostate cancer  elderly patient.

Title: A Case Report of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Female: An Insight into an Atypical Presentation and Management  Patient Profile: Name: Ms. Jane Doe (name changed to maintain confidentiality) Age: 48 years Sex: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Office worker (sedentary job)  Medical History: Ms. Doe is a known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus that is well-controlled with metformin. She is also obese (BMI 30) and has a history of hypertension controlled by lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. She has no history of smoking  alcohol consumption  or drug abuse. Her family history is significant with her mother having suffered a stroke at 62.  Presenting Concern: Ms. Doe presented to the emergency department with a 3-day history of unilateral leg pain and swelling in the right calf. The pain was described as a persistent  calf cramp-like discomfort  which was increasingly severe and non-radiating. The patient also expressed a feeling of warmth around the affected area. She denied any history of trauma  recent surgeries  or long-distance travel.  Physical Examination: Upon inspection  her right calf was visibly swollen compared to the left with erythematous skin and raised local temperature. There was marked tenderness on deep palpation of the right calf.  Investigations: A Doppler ultrasound was immediately conducted  which showed a non-compressible popliteal vein suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Her D-Dimer levels were elevated  consistent with a recent clot formation. Complete blood count  renal function test  and liver function test were within normal limits. Electrocardiogram and chest X-ray were unremarkable.  Management: The patient was started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for immediate anticoagulation along with compression stockings to manage swelling and pain. After 5 days  oral anticoagulant (Warfarin) was introduced and LMWH was discontinued on the 7th day. The patient was advised for strict glucose control and weight management.  Outcome and Follow-up: Her symptoms gradually improved over 10 days. The swelling and pain significantly reduced. She was discharged on oral anticoagulants and was advised regular follow-up. Counselling for lifestyle modification  including increased physical activity and dietary changes  was emphasized.  Discussion:  This report highlights the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling and pain  even in the absence of risk factors such as recent surgery  trauma  or travel. Her case suggests that a sedentary lifestyle  along with obesity and inadequate control of predisposing conditions like diabetes  may increase the risk of developing DVT. It underscores the need for early suspicion  prompt diagnosis  and appropriate management to prevent life-threatening complications  such as pulmonary embolism.

Case report: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Information: A 59-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department. He is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. The patient lives in a suburban area and was previously employed as a commercial truck driver.  History of Present Illness: The patient presented with a 5-day history of painful swelling in his left calf area. The pain was gradually progressive and associated with moderate erythema. He reported no history of injury to the concerned leg. There was no report of fever  chest pain or cough. He recently came off a long haul drive across the country  with limited opportunity for leg movement.   Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension for the last 16 years  managed with amlodipine. He was obese with a BMI of 30 kg/m2  but there were no known allergies or previous surgeries. The patient had no previous or family history of thrombotic diseases. He denies any history of illicit drug use and is not on any form of hormone treatment.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  the left calf was swollen  warm and tender compared to the right. There was no distinct mass palpable in the calf  and skin overlying the calf showed mild erythema but was intact.   His vital signs were all within normal limits: Blood pressure was 130/80 mmHg  pulse rate was 80 bpm  respiratory rate was 16/min and SpO2 was 97% in room air.  Diagnostic Assessment: The patient's D-Dimer test was significantly elevated  and a Doppler ultrasound showed deep vein thrombosis in popliteal and femoral veins.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was administered an initial dose of low-molecular-weight-heparin (LMWH) subcutaneously and was initiated on oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban. Compression stockings were provided and he had been advised on calf muscle exercises.   Follow-up: The patient was educated about the importance of medication compliance  lifestyle modification  weight reduction  and was instructed to promptly report any symptoms like chest pain or difficulty in breathing.   He has been asked to follow up in the outpatient department in one week for reassessment and to ensure the effectiveness of the oral anticoagulant with a prothrombin time test.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the role of prolonged immobility as a risk factor for DVT in an otherwise healthy individual. Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to prevent potential life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome.

Patient Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis Case Study   Patient Information:  The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian female  a passive smoker who has a BMI of 30. She leads a sedentary lifestyle  is employed at a desk job  and only takes walks for exercise. The patient reported that she does not have any known allergic reactions to medication.   Chief Complaint:  The patient presented complaining of prolonged  severe  and acute pain in her left calf which began about three days ago. She complained of swelling  redness  and a feeling of warmth in the same area.   Historical Information:  The patient’s medical history reveals that she has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. She was diagnosed with the condition 10 years ago. She also has a history of hyperlipidemia  for which she receives statin therapy. Her maternal grandmother had a stroke at the age of 70  her paternal grandfather was diagnosed with coronary artery disease in his sixties. There is no family history of coagulation disorders.    Current Medication:  The patient is currently on Metformin 750 mg twice daily for her diabetes and Atorvastatin 40 mg once daily for hyperlipidemia.   Physical Examination:  On examination  her left lower limb was visibly swollen. There was tenderness and warmth in the left calf muscle  with no sign of trauma. Moreover  Homan's sign was positive. Her blood pressure was 130/85 mmHg  her pulse rate 90 beats/min  temperature 98.5°F  and respiratory rate 18 breaths/min. Cardiovascular  respiratory  and abdominal examinations were normal.   Diagnosis:  Given her clinical presentation  a preliminary diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was made. Doppler ultrasound of the left lower limb was performed and confirmed the diagnosis by revealing a non-compressible venous segment with internal echogenic material consistent with acute thrombosis in the left popliteal vein. Subsequent D-dimer level was also elevated.  Treatment and Follow-Up:  The patient was admitted to the hospital and commenced on weight-adjusted intravenous unfractionated heparin. She was switched to oral anticoagulant (Warfarin) after 2 days and was discharged on the fifth day with INR within the therapeutic level.  The patient was educated concerning the risk factors and potential complications of DVT  including the risk of pulmonary embolism. She was urged to increase her physical activity and to manage her weight better and to adhere strictly to her medications. She was given a two-week follow-up appointment to check INR and for evaluation and was encouraged to use compression stockings.  Conclusion:  This case report highlights a typical presentation of deep vein thrombosis in a patient with multiple risk factors including obesity  sedentary lifestyle  diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. It emphasizes the importance of a high index of suspicion in patients presenting with unilateral leg pain and swelling  particularly in those with risk factors for venous thromboembolism.

Title: A Case Report of Recurrent Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 54-year-old Caucasian Female with a History of Breast Cancer  Patient Description: The subject of this case report is a 54-year-old Caucasian female with a history of invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) of the right breast. She is from a suburban neighborhood of Columbus  Ohio  USA  and is a high school teacher by profession. She is a known case of IDC  diagnosed three years ago. With no history of smoking  the patient is generally an active individual with no other significant past medical history. The patient takes tamoxifen for her breast cancer treatment and has no known allergies.  Presenting Complaint: The patient consulted the Outpatient Department reporting progressive pain and swelling in her right leg over seven days. The pain was localized primarily in the calf region  gradually increasing in intensity. The patient described the pain as a persistent ache  exacerbated by walking or prolonged standing  and relieved slightly by rest.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a visibly swollen  warm  and erythematous right lower leg. There was positive Homan's sign  local tenderness in the right calf muscle  and slight pitting edema. The left leg appeared normal on examination. No other significant clinical findings were reported.  Timeline: The patient was immediately admitted considering her symptoms and received a diagnostic workup. The swelling was first noticed one week prior to presentation and had consistently worsened over seven days. Since the onset  the patient had not noticed any changes  anomalies  or patterns related to the pain or swelling.  Diagnostic Assessment: Given the clinical presentation and history  a presumptive diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was made. A Doppler Ultrasound of the right leg was ordered  which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the right femoral and popliteal veins. Complete blood count  coagulation profile  and D-Dimer level were within normal limits.  Therapeutic Intervention: Anticoagulation therapy was initiated immediately with subcutaneous low-molecular-weight Heparin (LMWH)  with a plan to transition to oral anticoagulants. Analgesics were also administered for pain management.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient responded well to the initiated therapy with notable improvements in pain and swelling. She was discharged on day 5 with prescribed oral anticoagulants  and a follow-up visit scheduled after two weeks. On the follow-up visit  the patient reported no pain and the swelling had significantly subsided.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed gratitude for the prompt and effective treatment and management. She was counseled about the potential complications of DVT and was advised to maintain regular follow-up.  Lessons Learnt: This case underscores the importance of vigilant monitoring for DVT in patients with a history of cancer  especially those receiving tamoxifen therapy  due to their increased thrombotic risk. Prompt diagnosis and early initiation of anticoagulation therapy are essential in the management of DVT.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 55-year-old Man with a History of Physical Inactivity and Recent Surgery   Patient Information: The patient is Mr. A  a 55-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  Type II diabetes mellitus  and obesity. He lives a sedentary lifestyle which includes minimal physical activity and a work-from-home job. He is a nonsmoker and does not consume alcohol regularly. He had recently undergone a total right hip replacement surgery undertaken three weeks ago.  Clinical Findings: Mr. A reported persistent  unilateral leg swelling in the right lower extremity which had noticeably worsened over the past two days. Accompanying symptoms included a localized  throbbing pain  warm surface temperature over the swollen area  and increased discomfort when walking or standing. There were no reported symptoms related to chest pain or shortness of breath.   Diagnostic Assessment: Physical examination showed reddening and swelling of the right lower extremity. No signs of a superficial vein thrombosis were evident. An ultrasound of the leg was done  which showed the presence of a non-compressible right popliteal vein  indicating a Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). No other significant abnormalities were detected in the ultrasound. His blood pressure was 150/95 mmHg  heart rate was steady at 80 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation was 96% on room air.  Further laboratory testing was done  where the D-dimer level was found to be 1 200 ng/mL (reference range: 0-500 ng/mL). Other investigations including full blood count screening  liver function test  and electrolytes level were all within normal ranges. An oral glucose tolerance test confirmed a pre-existing diagnosis of controlled type II diabetes.  Therapeutic Intervention: Due to the confirmation of DVT  the patient was started immediately on anticoagulation therapy. The choice of anticoagulant was low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) subcutaneously twice daily  as well as initiation of oral anticoagulant (warfarin).   Follow up and Outcomes: Regular INR monitoring was done to monitor Warfarin’s efficacy and adjust the doses accordingly. After a week of concurrent therapy  the patient was transitioned completely to warfarin  which was to be taken for 6 months. The patient was also advised to lose weight  increase physical activities  and manage diabetes carefully to prevent recurrence.  Patient’s Perspective: Mr. A expressed significant concern over the situation but understood the importance of immediate treatment and lifestyle changes. He was willing to cooperate fully with the medical team and was relieved when provided with a comprehensive management plan.  Discussion: This case underscores the importance of identifying risk factors for Deep Vein Thrombosis  including sedentary lifestyle  obesity  and recent surgery. Moreover  this case illustrates the effective use of anticoagulant therapy for managing DVT and preventing potential thromboembolic events. Furthermore  it emphasizes the critical role of lifestyle changes and management of co-morbidities in DVT treatment.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 64-Year-Old Female with History of Breast Cancer: A Case Report  Introduction:  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a blood clot in a deep vein  usually in the leg. Risk factors can include prolonged bed rest  obesity  smoking  and certain genetic factors. Herein  we present the case of a 64-year-old female diagnosed with DVT  having a medical history of breast cancer.  Case Description:  A 64-year-old African-American female presented to the clinic with complaints of swelling  tenderness  and sudden pain in her right lower leg  which she rated as 7 on a pain scale of 0-10. She also reported difficulty in walking due to the severity of the discomfort. The patient denied history of trauma  recent long-distance travel  surgeries  or prolonged immobilization. She did  however  report a history of breast cancer (Bilateral Invasive Ductal Carcinoma) diagnosed 5 years prior  which had been successfully treated with lumpectomy and adjuvant hormonal therapy (Tamoxifen). She also reported a 30-year history of smoking  1 pack per day  and a family history of vascular diseases including DVT.   On examination  her right calf muscle circumference was 2 cm greater than the left  indicating notable swelling. Homan's sign was positive. Rest of her systemic examination was unremarkable.  Investigations:  Her D-dimer test showed elevated levels (900 ng/ml  normal being less than 500 ng/ml). The ultrasound Doppler study of the right lower extremity revealed a non-compressible popliteal vein  confirming a diagnosis of DVT. Her CT scan did not reveal any pulmonary embolism. Moreover  additional blood test results showed a high platelet count and elevated coagulation levels.   Management and Follow-up:  The patient was immediately treated with low molecular weight Heparin (Enoxaparin) and Warfarin was initiated for long term anticoagulation. The patient was admitted for monitoring. After 3 days  her pain and swelling started to decrease. Daily INR was monitored and on the fifth day  it was in a therapeutic range (2-3). Enoxaparin was then discontinued  and Warfarin therapy was continued. She was discharged on the seventh day on oral Warfarin therapy and advised to quit smoking.   The patient was closely followed up and encouraged to continue wearing compression stockings and maintain active foot/ankle exercises. On her one month follow-up  the patient reported a significant reduction in symptoms.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of vigilance in patients with a history of cancer due to their predisposition toward thromboembolic events. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent serious complications such as pulmonary embolism. This case also highlights the need for rigorous follow-up care and patient education in managing DVT  particularly in those with significant risk factors.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 53-year-old Female Patient  Patient Profile Name: X (name changed due to confidentiality reasons) Age: 53 years old Sex: Female Ethnicity: African-American Occupation: Cashier  Presenting Complaint Miss X presented with pain and swelling in her left lower leg  primarily localized to the calf region. There was also mild discoloration in the affected area which was warmer to touch compared to her right leg. The patient rated the pain as a 7 out of 10.  History of presenting Complaint The discomfort and symptoms began approximately five days ago. Initially  the pain was tolerable  but over time it has escalated  prompting her visit to the clinic.  Past Medical History Miss X is a known hypertensive and has been on medication (atenolol 50mg daily) for the past seven years. She is overweight with a BMI of 32 and was diagnosed as a pre-diabetic two years ago. The patient has no family history of any cardiac or hereditary diseases but reports that her mother also suffered from hypertension.  Social History Miss X has a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit around five years ago. She occasionally consumes alcohol but denies any illicit drug use. The patient admits to being sedentary due to her job nature and acknowledges her craving for high-sodium and high-fat foods.  Clinical Examination On examination  her left leg was apparently swollen with visible distended superficial veins. There was no leg ulcer or signs of cellulitis. Her blood pressure was elevated at 165/95 mmHg  the pulse was 95 beats per minutes  and other vital signs were within normal range.   Investigations and Diagnosis Based on the clinical findings  a provisional diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was assumed. A Doppler ultrasound of her left leg confirmed the diagnosis by revealing a clot in the femoral vein. Blood tests results showed slightly raised D-dimer levels.   Management and Prognosis The patient was discharged on oral anticoagulants (Rivaroxaban 15mg twice daily for 21 days  followed by 20mg daily) and referred to a cardiologist for management of her hypertension  and an endocrinologist for her pre-diabetic status. She was also advised on lifestyle modifications  including dietary changes and a basic exercise routine.   Conclusion Considering her risk factors such as hypertension  smoking history  obesity  and a sedentary lifestyle  Miss X was at a greater risk for DVT. The prognosis appears promising if she adheres to her treatment regimen and lifestyle modifications. Early detection and proper management of deep vein thrombosis are crucial to prevent fatal complications like pulmonary embolism. It is essential to stress the importance of regular health checks and lifestyle modifications to patients with multiple risk factors to prevent such medical situations.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  A 69-year-old Caucasian woman with a body mass index (BMI) of 30.1 kg/m^2. Personal habits include smoking (a pack/day for the past 40 years) and moderate alcohol consumption. She is a retired teacher  living alone in an urban area. She has two adult children  and both are living in the same city but separate from the patient. The patient has no known drug allergies.   Chief Complaint:   She presented with a 2-day history of swelling  pain and tenderness in the right lower extremity  particularly in the calf  which had slowly been worsening. No associated chest pain  shortness of breath  fainting or palpitations. No history of recent trauma and immobilization.   Past Medical History:   The patient is known to have type 2 diabetes mellitus and dyslipidemia for the past 10 years  which are well controlled with medications. She has hypertension  controlled by medication (ace inhibitors) for 6 years. The patient’s drug regimen includes Metformin  Atorvastatin  Lisinopril and Aspirin prophylaxis.   Family History:   The patient has a positive family history  with both of her parents having cardiovascular diseases. Her father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and her mother had a stroke at age 70.  Clinical Findings:   Physical examination showed a visibly swollen and erythematous right lower leg involving the calf and extending to the thigh. The warmth was felt over the area  and it was tender to touch suggesting deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  No ulcers were present in the lower limb. Other investigations – Chest and heart were normal on examination  blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg; BMI was 30.1 kg/m^2; pulse rate was 82 beats per minute.  The patient was sent to radiology for a definitive diagnosis. The doppler ultrasound of the right lower extremity showed non-compressibility of the femoral and popliteal veins  thereby confirming DVT.  Management:   She was admitted and oral anticoagulants(Factor Xa inhibitor - rivaroxaban) were started immediately with an initial dose of 15 mg twice daily for 21 days  then 20mg once daily. She was also advised to elevate her leg and use compression stockings to help reduce swelling and pain.  Conclusion:  This case demonstrates the potential risks of DVT in elderly patients with underlying comorbidities  notably cardiovascular diseases and poor lifestyle habits. Early suspicion  diagnosis  and immediate intervention of DVT play a vital role in preventing complications. It is crucial to include DVT in the differential diagnosis while dealing with patients of this demographic profile  presenting with unilateral leg swelling and pain.    Follow-Up:   The patient is scheduled for a follow-up examination in two weeks to ensure progress and manage her oral anticoagulant regimen. An assessment of her condition for post-thrombotic syndrome in later follow-ups will also be important given her age and comorbidities.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Introduction: This case report discusses a 48-year-old Caucasian male  referred to as Mr. X for privacy matters  who presented with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Patient Information: Mr. X  48  is an office worker from Wisconsin with no notable travel history. His family history is significant with his mother having a history of DVT at the age of 60.   Medical History: The patient is overweight with a BMI of 29 and has a history of hypertension  treated with a daily dosage of 5 mg Amlodipine. He is a former smoker  reported to quit smoking ten years ago. He is also known to have a sedentary lifestyle  as he spends approximately 8-10 hours daily in a sitting position due to his work requirements. The patient does not take any form of regular exercise.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. X presented at the outpatient department with a one-week history of progressive swelling and pain in the left lower limb. The pain increased when he stood up or walked. He denied any history of trauma or injury to the leg.   Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the left lower limb appeared swollen and warm compared to the right. The calf circumference of the affected limb was 3cm larger than the unaffected one. A palpable cord was also identified running along the posterior medial side of his calf. No superficial veins were visibly engorged. His vital signs were stable.  Diagnostic Assessment: A Doppler ultrasonography of the left extremity was performed  which revealed thrombosis of the left posterior tibial and peroneal veins suggestive of DVT. His D-dimer levels were also significantly elevated. The results of his complete blood count  renal function test  and liver function test were within normal limits.   Therapeutic Interventions: Mr. X was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin  followed by oral anticoagulant therapy (Rivaroxaban). He was also advised to elevate his left lower limb and fitted for a graduated compression stocking.  Outcome and Follow-up: Mr. X experienced relief from the pain and reduced swelling within a few days after initiating treatment. After two weeks  a follow-up Doppler ultrasound was done  showing reduced thrombus size. He was continued on an anticoagulant therapy plan since he showed signs of improvement. He was also given advice on lifestyle modification  including regular exercise and maintaining a healthy weight.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of considering DVT in patients who present with unilateral leg swelling and pain  even without risk factors such as recent surgery or traveling history. This case may suggest a genetic predisposition to thrombosis as an underlying etiology  given the positive family history. Moreover  this underscores the significance of lifestyle modification in DVT prevention and management.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Female Patient  Introduction:  This case report describes a 55-year-old Caucasian female patient  who was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the lower left extremity.  Patient Description:  The patient is a retired librarian from Houston  Texas. She presented to the emergency department with signs of left leg swelling  redness  warmth  and pain  which had been progressively worsening over the past 4 days. The patient denied a history of similar episodes  recent surgeries  or long periods of immobility. She reported no history of medication compliance and denied the use of tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drugs. Her family history suggested no genetic predisposition or related disorder.  Past Medical History:  She has a known history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and obesity with a body mass index (BMI) of 32. The patient also reported that she had been on hormonal replacement therapy (HRT) for the past 7 years due to living with post-menopausal symptoms. She takes metformin for her diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension. She has no known allergies.  Clinical Findings and Investigation:  On physical examination  the patient's left leg was swollen  erythematous  and tender  particularly in the calf region  with a positive Homan's sign. Her vitals were stable. Hematological investigations revealed elevated D-dimer levels (920 ng/ml)  while her platelet count  coagulation profile  and creatinine levels were within the normal range. The patient's blood glucose level was slightly elevated.  A Doppler ultrasound of the left lower extremity was performed  which demonstrated thrombosis of the left posterior tibial and peroneal veins  confirming the diagnosis of DVT.  Treatment & Prognosis:  The patient was prescribed a course of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and later transitioned onto oral anticoagulants  warfarin  with a planned duration of treatment for at least 3 months or until resolution of DVT. She was also advised to use compression stockings to alleviate symptoms and to prevent post-thrombotic syndrome.  The patient was advised to lose weight  and control her diabetes and hypertension. She was also counseled to discontinue HRT considering her diagnosis of DVT and provided information regarding the risks and benefits of the therapy in the context of her new diagnosis. Follow-up in the outpatient clinic was arranged to monitor her progress.  Conclusion:  This case of DVT highlights the importance of considering venous thromboembolism in patients presenting with unilateral leg pain and swelling. This case also reiterates the need for physicians to be mindful of the thrombotic risk associated with HRT  particularly in individuals with other predisposing factors such as advanced age  obesity  diabetes  and hypertension.

Title: Management of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal woman: A Case Report  Introduction:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a severe condition characterized by the formation of blood clots in deep veins  typically in the legs. DVT can lead to serious complications if left untreated  necessitating early diagnosis and intervention. This case report discusses the presentation  diagnosis  treatment  and follow-up of a 63-year-old female patient diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis.  Case Presentation:  The patient  a 63-year-old Caucasian woman  resident of the rural Midwest  presented at our outpatient clinic with a complaint of increasing pain and swelling in her right lower leg that had been persisting for a week. The patient was a retired school teacher  living with her husband. She was a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. She had postmenopausal status and was previously diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes and hypertension  for which she was on metformin and amlodipine  respectively.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient’s right calf was significantly swollen compared to the left  and it was tender on palpation. The Homans’ sign was positive. Pulses in the right leg were intact and strong. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable  with her vitals within the normal range and no signs of heart or lung disease.   Timeline:  Patient symptom onset was one week prior to the initial clinic visit  with no previous history of similar episodes. The diagnosis was confirmed on the same day through Doppler ultrasound  revealing a blood clot in the deep veins of the right lower leg.   Diagnostic Assessment & Treatment:  The differential diagnosis encompassed cellulitis  superficial vein thrombosis  Baker's cyst  musculoskeletal injury  and deep vein thrombosis. Venous Doppler ultrasonography of the right leg confirmed a thrombus in the popliteal vein  leading to the diagnosis of DVT. The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy. She was prescribed Enoxaparin injections for initial high-intensity anticoagulation treatment along with oral Warfarin.   Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient was advised to follow up after a week. An INR test was done in the follow-up visit  achieving a therapeutic range of 2.0-3.0. The patient reported an improvement in swelling and pain of the affected limb. Follow-up Doppler ultrasound was done after six weeks. There was a significant reduction in the size of the thrombus. Based on the results  it was decided to continue oral anticoagulation therapy for three months and follow up after that.   Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of providing timely diagnosis and appropriate treatment to prevent serious complications related to DVT  such as pulmonary embolism and post thrombotic syndrome. Regular follow-up is crucial for patients with DVT to achieve therapeutic targets and monitor for any residual disease or complications.   Keywords: Deep vein thrombosis  postmenopausal women  case report  anticoagulation therapy.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 55-year-old Female Patient  Patient Information--   A 55-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department complaining of a 2-day history of swelling and pain in the left lower extremity. This pain was described as a constant  aching and was rated as a 7 on the numerical rating scale. She reported no recent surgeries  long plane flights or car rides  no family history of similar symptoms. The patient further indicated that the pain increased with movement and was non-radiating. The patient appeared anxious due to the sudden onset of symptoms. However  she denied any history of fever  cough  chest pain  or shortness of breath. She has a medical history of high blood pressure and diabetes both controlled by medication. She is a smoker and has been for thirty years.  Clinical Findings--   On physical examination  her left calf was swollen  noticeably larger than the right. Vital signs were within normal limits with a blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg  heart rate of 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  temperature of 98.6 Fahrenheit  and oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. Cardiovascular system examination was normal  her chest was clear on auscultation  no signs of heart murmurs  regular rhythm  no added heart sounds. The abdomen was soft and non-tender.  Timeline--  The patient's symptoms began 2 days ago with the onset of pain and swelling in the left lower extremity. Given the patient's medical history and presentation  an assessment of deep vein thrombosis was established within the first day of her admission.  Diagnostic Assessment--  Laboratory investigations  including full blood count  renal function  coagulation  and D-Dimer assay  were conducted. D-Dimer was elevated with other laboratory findings within normal limits. An ultrasound Doppler of the left lower extermity confirmed the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis(DVT) as it showed thrombosis in the left lower limb superficial femoral vein.  Therapeutic Intervention--  Anticoagulative therapy was initiated using low molecular weight heparin and later transitioned to warfarin  aiming at a therapeutic INR between 2-3. Patient was also counseled for a lifestyle modification that includes a balanced diet  exercise  and smoking cessation.  Follow-Up and Outcomes--  Inpatient follow-ups over a one-week period showed considerable improvement in the symptoms. On discharge  she was asked to continue warfarin  control her blood pressure and blood sugar levels  and stop smoking. A follow-up plan was put in place for the patient's outpatient care  including consultations with a diabetologist and a cardiologist. INR monitoring and potential warfarin dosage adjustment were scheduled.  Patient Perspective--  The patient expressed relief over the improvement in her symptoms and was responsive and cooperative with the suggestions for lifestyle alterations  including the cessation of smoking.  Additional Information--  Deep vein thrombosis can be fatal if not diagnosed and treated promptly. This case emphasizes the need for high clinical suspicion of DVT in patients presenting with a swollen  painful lower limb  to enable suitable treatment and prevent complications like pulmonary embolism.    Informed Consent--  The patient has consented for the case to be presented in this report.  Date: Format (Month/Dates/Year) Reporter: [Name  title  location] Reference No: [XXXXX]

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in 58-year-old Caucasian Female  Patient Information  The case patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian female  non-smoker  and non-alcoholic  with a body mass index (BMI) of 31  indicating obesity  which falls under Class 1 as per the World Health Organization (WHO) classification. She lives in a suburban community and works as a bank officer  where her work primarily involves prolonged sitting. Patient is postmenopausal and on hormone replacement therapy. There is no history of drug abuse or personal history of significant trauma or surgery. Family history is positive for cardiovascular diseases but negative for blood dyscrasias and malignancies.  Clinical Findings  Presenting symptoms included left leg pain and swelling of about a week's duration. The patient also reported a mild fever but denied chest pain  dizziness  or shortness of breath. The physical examination revealed a swollen  warm  and erythematous left lower limb. Pedal pulses were palpable  and limb ischemia was not noted.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment  A high index of suspicion led to further investigations. D-dimer level was elevated at 1500 ng/ml (normal is <500ng/ml). Ultrasonography demonstrated an occlusive thrombus in the left lower limb popliteal vein extending into the femoral vein. Pulmonary (V/Q) scan was normal  ruling out pulmonary embolism.  Past Medical History  The patient adopted a sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activity. She had history of recent long-haul air travel around 2 weeks prior. She was hypertensive and had been on medication (amlodipine 5 mg) for the past 5 years. Previous lab reports showed dyslipidemia controlled with statin treatment. The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus approximately 10 years ago  managed by oral hypoglycemic drugs. There was no history of liver disease  renal disease  or malignancies  and she was not on any anticoagulants prior to this event.  Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was initially put on intravenous unfractionated heparin. The dose was adjusted according to the prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). As soon as the aPTT reached therapeutic levels  oral anticoagulation (warfarin) was initiated. The patient was kept on both heparin and warfarin until prothrombin time-international normalized ratio (PT-INR) reached therapeutic range on day 5 of admission. She was then transitioned to warfarin alone.  Discussion and Follow-Up  The patient's outcome was good after 6 months of anticoagulation therapy. Regular follow-ups ensured INR remained in a therapeutic range. Her leg swelling reduced significantly  and she was advised to wear compression stockings. Lifestyle modifications were encouraged which included adopting a balanced diet  losing weight  enhancing physical activity  and avoiding long periods of immobility.   As part of chronic care  she continues her regular medication for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and dyslipidemia alongside the long-term anticoagulation treatment. Early detection and prompt anticoagulation treatment likely contributed to the good outcome in this case. Additionally  the case underlines the importance of considering DVT in patients presented with unilateral leg pain and swelling.   Confidential patient data were anonymized throughout this case study.

Title: Unilateral Lower Extremity Swelling in a 45-year-old nonsmoking man: A Case Report of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:  A 45-year-old African American male presents with unilateral right lower extremity swelling and discomfort. He denies smoking  illicit drug use  and alcohol consumption. He has a sedentary lifestyle and works as an office worker with limited physical movement. There's no known family history of coagulation disorders.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient had a swollen  erythematous  and warm right lower extremity consistent with inflammation. The patient reported a slight pain (4/10) in the right calf muscle with mild pitting edema. There were no visible varicose veins. The left lower extremity was unaffected.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Investigations were undertaken to rule out potential causes. A Complete blood count (CBC)  liver function test  renal function test were normal. Coagulation profile revealed prolonged Prothrombin time (PT) and Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (APTT).   A Doppler ultrasound of the right lower extremity showed thrombosis in the posterior tibial vein and peroneal veins in the calf suggestive of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Therapeutic intervention:  The patient was admitted and initiated on anticoagulation therapy with subcutaneous Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)  bridging to oral warfarin. Compression stockings were applied and leg elevation was advised to reduce edema. Thrombolysis was not considered given the distal nature of the thrombosis.   Follow-Up and Outcomes:  After 5 days of hospital stay  the patient's symptoms improved considerably with reduced swelling and pain. The warfarin dose was adjusted to maintain an INR level between 2.0 and 3.0. The patient was discharged with advice to continue warfarin for at least three months and to maintain a more active lifestyle. He was scheduled for regular follow-ups in the outpatient clinic to monitor his progress and any potential side effects of the medication.   Patient Perspective:  The patient was initially anxious about the hospital admission  however  he subsequently conveyed that he was satisfied with the treatment and understood the importance of medication adherence and lifestyle modifications.   Informing Clinical Practice:  This case reiterates the necessity to consider DVT in the differential diagnosis of unilateral leg swelling and the importance of timely intervention to prevent severe complications like Pulmonary Embolism. It also raises awareness about the role of sedentary lifestyle as a potential risk factor for DVT.   Learning Points:   1. Always consider DVT as a differential in unilateral lower limb swelling. 2. Timely detection and proper management can avoid serious complications such as Pulmonary Embolism. 3. In addition to medical intervention  lifestyle changes are crucial for the prevention of recurrence. 4. Regular follow-up is required to monitor INR levels and anticoagulation efficacy in patients with DVT. 5. Engaging patients in understanding their diagnosis and treatment plans promotes better outcome and compliance.

Patient Details: Age: 67-years old  male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired civil engineer Insurance: Medicare Marital Status: Married Social History: Non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumption (1-2 drinks a week)  no recreational drug use. Lives a mostly sedentary lifestyle.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient presents with unexplained soreness and swelling in the right lower leg  which has persisted over the duration of the past week. The pain was described as a dull ache  especially noticeable when walking or standing  and there was slight reddening of the skin over the calf.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  which is well-managed by current treatment (Lisinopril). He underwent a total knee arthroplasty on his right knee about a month ago. He also has a sedentary lifestyle  which is likened to prolonged periods of inactivity  thereby increasing his risk for conditions such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT). There is no history of any thromboembolic events or malignancy in the past. He is not on any anticoagulant or antiplatelet drugs. The patient is otherwise healthy.  Examination: On examination  the right calf was slightly swollen and warm to touch with mild tenderness. No palpable cords were felt and Homan's sign was negative. There was no shortness of breath or chest pain.  Investigations: The patient underwent a Doppler ultrasound examination which confirmed the presence of a non-occlusive thrombus in the right posterior tibial vein suggesting deep vein thrombosis. Pulmonary embolism was ruled out with an EKG and chest x-ray.  Management: The patient was admitted for observation and started on subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). Post evaluation of his clinical condition and potential risks  he was later transitioned to oral anticoagulants. Counseling was provided on the importance of regular ambulation.  Outcomes: Prompt recognition and initiation of anticoagulation therapy likely prevented propagation or dislodgment of the thrombosis  and a potential pulmonary embolism. The patient responded well to the treatment plan and was discharged with follow-ups arranged with the internal medicine and hematology departments.  Discussion: This case resembles the general profile of patients who get DVT. Indeed  factors like postoperative status and a sedentary lifestyle put the patient at an increased risk of DVT. It’s vital to educate such individuals about the importance of regular movement and physical exercise as a preventative measure against thrombosis. Early recognition of symptoms and immediate medical attention play a crucial role in successful outcomes in DVT management.    Diagnosis: Deep vein thrombosis in the right leg due to post-surgical immobilization and a sedentary lifestyle.   Summarized by: Dr. XX  Cardiology Department  XYZ Hospital

Title: Unilateral Lower Limb Edema Secondary to Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 52-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Introduction  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) often presents with symptoms of unilateral lower limb edema  pain  warmth  and discoloration. This case report describes a 52-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with DVT  highlighting his presenting symptoms  complications  management  and outcome of the treatment provided.  Case Presentation  A 52-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension presented to the emergency department (ED) with a 7-day history of progressive  painful swelling in his left lower limb. He is a current smoker with a 30-pack year history and has a sedentary job as an accountant. He described the pain as a dull ache  initially rating it as 3/10 severity but it had recently escalated to a 7/10. He had no history of trauma  recent surgery  or prolonged immobilization. He reported no shortness of breath  chest pain  or any symptoms suggesting pulmonary embolism.  Clinical Examinations and Investigations  Physical examination revealed noticeable unilateral edema of the left lower limb with no associated skin color changes  ulceration  or increased warmth over the affected area compared with the normal side. The limb was tender to palpation. The body mass index was calculated to be 30.5 kg/m2  indicative of obesity. Vital signs on presentation were stable.   Investigations included contrast-enhanced venous Doppler ultrasonography which confirmed a DVT in the left common femoral vein. A d-dimer level was also elevated at 1000 ng/mL (normal <500 ng/mL). Complete blood count  renal function  and coagulation profile were within normal ranges. An ECG and chest X-ray were carried out  both returned unremarkable reducing the suspicion for concurrent pulmonary embolism.   Management and Outcome  Intravenous unfractionated heparin was initiated immediately to achieve a therapeutic activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). The patient was bridged to oral warfarin therapy with a target international normalised ratio (INR) of 2-3.   He was advised to elevate the affected limb and was fitted with compression stockings. Patient education was provided regarding symptoms of pulmonary embolism and the importance of adhering to anticoagulant therapy  monitoring INR in the community  maintaining a healthy weight  regular physical activity  and smoking cessation. The patient demonstrated good understanding and compliance.   At the three month follow-up  the patient had made good clinical progress  with a significant reduction in the limb edema and the INR consistently within therapeutic range. The patient had also successfully quit smoking  lost weight and opted to include more physical activity in his daily routine.  Conclusion  This case highlights the importance of considering DVT in the differential diagnosis of unilateral lower limb edema  particularly in individuals with multiple risk factors such as advanced age  obesity  smoking  and sedentary lifestyle. Prompt diagnosis and management are imperative to prevent complications such as pulmonary embolism. Patient education plays an important role in achieving a successful outcome.

Case Report:  Title: Management and Treatment of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 68-year-old Male  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  who is nulliparous and married  based in California  USA. He is a retired schoolteacher and a non-smoker with a history of moderate alcohol use.   Medical History: The patient has a history of type II diabetes for the past six years and stage III hypertension for the past four years. He had previously undergone an abdominal laparoscopic hernia repair six years ago but had no known allergies. He was under medication for his diabetes and hypertension control (Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively).  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with a three-day history of a painful  swollen  warm  and erythematous left calf. He denied any recent trauma or immobilization. He also denied any symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  or other similar symptoms suggesting a pulmonary embolism.   Clinical Findings: On physical examination  Homan's sign was positive. The other systems' examination was inconclusive. His pulse rate was 82 beats/minute  blood pressure being 160/94 mmHg  respiratory rate 18 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation 97% in room air.  Diagnosis: A high D-dimer level and a compressive ultrasound of the left lower extremity revealed a non-occlusive thrombus in the left femoral vein suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Lower extremity venogram confirmed the presence of DVT. A CT scan ruled out any signs of a pulmonary embolism.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was promptly started on parenteral Anticoagulation therapy with Low Molecular Weight Heparin. After 5 days  Warfarin was initiated  and Heparin was overlapped and discontinued on the 6th day once the INR was therapeutic for 24 hours.  Follow up and outcomes: The patient demonstrated significant clinical improvement with no further risk of embolization. He was discharged on oral Anticoagulation therapy with Warfarin and advised on long term treatment for at least three months. Regular check-ups for monitoring the therapeutic levels of INR were also advised.  This case highlights the importance of a high index of suspicion for DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg pain  redness  and swelling especially with a background of risk factors like hypertension and diabetes. Early diagnosis and anticoagulant therapy significantly improve patient outcomes in DVT  preventing serious complications such as pulmonary embolism.   Patient Consent: Obtained.  Peer Review: Not applicable.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 56-Year-Old Male with History of Smoking and Hypertension  Introduction:   This case report describes a 56-year-old male presenting with symptoms and subsequent diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's prior medical history included chronic smoking  hypertension  and a sedentary lifestyle which might have contributed to his present condition.  Case Presentation:   A 56-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with acute onset of left leg pain and swelling of 2 days duration. The patient reported that the pain was constant  rated it as 8/10 on the pain scale  and noted that it was particularly severe when walking. The patient had also noticed a change in color to a red/purple hue around the swollen area. The patient denied any fever  chest pain  shortness of breath  or trauma to the area.  The patient’s past medical history was significant for hypertension for the past 5 years  which was being managed with a daily dose of 5mg amlodipine  and a 40-year history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day. The patient had recently retired from an office job where he spent long hours seated  which continued even after retirement. He reported no known drug allergies  family history of blood disorders  previous surgeries  or long-distance travel.   On physical examination  the left leg was visibly swollen compared to the right  red  and warm to touch. The circumference of the affected calf was 3.5 cm greater than the unaffected side. The Homans' sign test was positive. His blood pressure was 150/100 mmHg  pulse rate was 88/minute  and other vitals were within normal limits.  Upon these findings  the patient was evaluated for suspected DVT. An urgent Doppler ultrasound concluded with findings consistent with left lower extremity DVT. No extension into the iliac or femoral veins was observed. Blood tests revealed a slightly raised D-dimer level of 500 ng/mL.  The patient was hospitalized and treatment commenced immediately with intravenous heparin  which later transitioned into oral warfarin for long-term therapy. Patient education regarding the need to quit smoking  lifestyle modification  and the importance of regular exercise was provided.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering DVT in patients with prolonged periods of inactivity  hypertension  and chronic smoking. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent potential severe complications such as pulmonary embolism.   This report further emphasizes the need for strong preventative strategies  such as lifestyle modifications  in patients with risk factors for DVT. Patients with hypertension and chronic smoking need to be educated about the risks associated with these conditions  especially if they are already leading a sedentary lifestyle  to prevent venous thromboembolic events.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Male  *Patient Demographics* The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian male with a prior medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. He is a nonsmoker  rarely consumes alcohol  and works as an administrative assistant which requires long sedentary periods at a desk. The patient lives in an urban area and has a family history of thromboembolic disorders.  *Past Medical History* The patient was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension approximately ten years ago and has been managing these comorbidities with diet  regular exercises  and oral medications (Metformin and Amlodipine). The patient maintains routine follow-ups for these conditions. He is not currently on any anticoagulant therapy.  *Presenting Complaints and Symptoms* The patient presented to the emergency department with chief complaints of gradual onset  left leg pain and swelling that has progressively worsened over the past week. He states that the pain seems to be more severe when he stands or walks. He also mentions the area around his left calf feels warmed and looks slightly discolored. The patient denies any history of trauma to the leg  recent long-distance travel or surgery.  *Clinical Findings and Diagnosis* Upon physical examination  the left lower leg was noted to be erythematous (reddish)  edematous (swollen)  with localized heat compared to the right lower leg. A slight tenderness to touch was also observed over the left calf muscle. His vital signs were stable.  A Doppler ultrasound test was performed to visualize the blood flow in the veins. The ultrasound showed an obstructive thrombus in the left popliteal vein  leading to a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  *Course of treatment and prognosis* The patient was admitted to the hospital for monitoring and started on anticoagulant therapy; specifically low molecular weight Heparin was initiated and later transitioned to an oral anticoagulant agent  Warfarin. Lifestyle changes and advice on leg exercises were also provided to prevent post-thrombotic syndrome.   Anticoagulation therapy  in combination with lifestyle modifications and physical activity  should aid in treating and preventing a recurrence of DVT.  He will undergo regular clinical follow-ups and monitoring of his international normalized ratio(INR) due to the Warfarin therapy.  The patient was counselled about the potential complications of DVT  such as Pulmonary Embolism (PE) and the importance of adhering to the prescribed medication regime.  *Conclusion* This case highlights a typical presentation of DVT in a middle-aged male with a sedentary lifestyle and a history of diabetes and hypertension. Regular physical activity  early diagnosis  prompt anticoagulation therapy  and vigilant monitoring are vital in managing DVT and avoiding life-threatening complications like PE.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 58 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Office Worker Living environment: Urban   Presenting Complaint:  On the date of 15th April 2021  Mr. Doe presented to the clinic  complaining of increasing pain and swelling in the right leg over a period of one week. He also noted skin redness and warmth over the affected area.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has been diagnosed with hypertension and Type II diabetes  which were well controlled with medication. He is a past smoker with a history of 30 pack-years and quit smoking 10 years ago. He disclosed a sedentary lifestyle due to his office job and minimal physical activity. His regular medications include Metformin (1000mg twice daily for diabetes) and Captopril (25mg twice daily for hypertension). He has no recorded allergy to medications. Family history is significant as his mother had a pulmonary embolism at the same age.  Examination:  Upon physical examination  the right lower leg was found to be erythematous  swollen  and tender. Homan's sign  discomfort behind the knee upon flexing the foot  was present. His pulses were intact  and there were no signs of tissue necrosis or an ulcer.   Investigations:  Due to the high suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  venous Doppler ultrasound was performed which showed a thrombus in the right popliteal vein. Complete blood count  coagulation profile  and D-Dimer levels were ordered to underpin the diagnosis further. D-Dimer level came high i.e.  780ng/ml (N<500ng/ml)  Previous Surgery:  There is no history of any previous surgical intervention as told by the patient.  Treatment:  The patient was started on anticoagulation with parenteral low-molecular-weight heparin and oral warfarin. He was also advised to wear compression stockings to manage symptoms better.  Discussion:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a common yet serious condition where a clot forms in the deeper veins of the body  usually in the lower limb. Known risk factors for DVT include immobilization  surgery  obesity  malignancy  and inherited clotting disorder  among others. Our patient goes to show that sedentariness and family history can be significant risk factors too.  Conclusion:  Mr. Doe's past medical conditions  sedentary lifestyle  and a significant family history predisposed him to develop DVT. Early recognition of the symptoms and aggressive management have been initiated to lower the risk of potential complications such as pulmonary embolism. He is encouraged to increase his physical activity  control his diet and remain compliant with his prescribed medications and follow-ups.

Title: Case Report: An Incident of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Male with a History of Smoking  Patient's Information Name: Confidential Age: 52 Sex: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Accountant   Presenting Complaints: The patient complained of persistent  intense pain  and swelling in left lower leg  accompanied by increased warmth in the affected area and visible superficial veins. He also reported mild shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: The patient has a 30-pack year history of smoking and quit 2 years ago. He also has a history of obesity(BMI 31)  hypertension (controlled with medication)  and occasional alcohol consumption. There have been no previous incidents of any clotting disorders  nor is there any known family history of clotting disorders. No history of recent major surgeries or prolonged immobilization.  Clinical Findings: Upon examination  the left calf was noticeably swollen and warm to touch. A positive Homans' sign was observed indicating possible deep vein thrombosis. His vitals were stable apart from mildly raised blood pressure. Initial laboratory tests including complete blood count and coagulation profile were within normal limits.  Diagnostic Assessment: Since clinical suspicion for deep vein thrombosis was high  the patient was subjected to a Doppler ultrasound scan which revealed a significant thrombus in the left popliteal vein  decisively diagnosing the patient with deep vein thrombosis. Chest X-ray and D-Dimer test was performed to rule out pulmonary embolism due to his mild shortness of breath.  Therapeutic Intervention: Treatment was initiated with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin. The patient was also started on oral anticoagulants  specifically rivaroxaban. Physical therapies including leg elevation and the use of compression stockings were advised to the patient to alleviate the symptoms and prevent complications.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient responded well to the treatment. The swelling reduced and pain eased after 5 days of initiating the treatment. After 3 months of therapy  a follow-up ultrasound confirmed the resolution of the thrombus. The patient is currently under routine monitoring.  Patient’s Perspective: The patient acknowledged his previous unhealthy lifestyle and shared his willingness to maintain a healthier regime  including continued abstinence from smoking and maintaining a healthy weight to prevent future health problems.  This case indicates the role of risk factors like smoking and obesity in the development of deep vein thrombosis. It emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate therapeutic interventions for favorable outcomes. It also underlines the importance of lifestyle modification in preventing such events.

Case Report: Demographic Information: Patient: Female Age: 55 years old Race: Hispanic Marital Status: Married Occupation: School Teacher Location: New York  United States  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with pain  swelling  and warmth in the right lower leg  specifically in the calf area. The symptoms had begun 5 days ago and have steadily grown worse.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of obesity (BMI 32)  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes. No surgical history was reported. The patient was prescribed Metformin for diabetes and Amlodipine for hypertension. No history of smoking or alcoholism was reported. The patient has recently traveled overseas on a long-haul direct flight from Sydney to New York.  Clinical Findings: On examination  her right lower leg was visibly swollen with areas of erythema. It was tender and warm to touch with a palpable cord noted. She had a positive Homans sign and an elevated D-dimer level.   Investigations:  The patient was sent for a duplex ultrasound which revealed thrombus in the deep veins of her right calf  consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). No pulmonary embolism was detected on a CT pulmonary angiogram. Her clotting profile was normal but her cholesterol was high.  Treatment:  The patient was initiated on anticoagulation therapy with low-molecular weight heparin and later transitioned onto oral warfarin. She was also fitted with a compression stocking and was advised to elevate her leg.  Follow-up:  She was discharged on warfarin with a scheduled follow-up in one week for INR monitoring. The patient was instructed to continue compression therapy and was given lifestyle management advice including weight loss  regular exercise  and healthy diet for her comorbidities.   Summary: This case highlights the importance of considering deep vein thrombosis in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling  especially in those with predisposing risk factors such as obesity  hypertension  long plane journey and diabetes. Timely diagnosis and treatment can prevent potentially life-threatening complications.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in a 42-year-old Female Post Knee Arthroplasty: A Case Report  Patient Information:  The patient is a 42-year-old Caucasian female who presented with pain and swelling in the right leg. The patient is a non-smoker and moderate alcohol consumer. She does not have any known drug allergies. Her BMI is 28.9  indicative of being overweight. She holds a desk job and has a sedentary lifestyle. The patient mentioned having a knee Arthroplasty one month prior to the new complaints.   Clinical Findings:  The patient complained of discomfort  swelling  redness  and a feeling of warmth in her right leg. Her vital signs were within normal limits except for a slightly elevated heart rate. The physical examination showed a swollen  reddened right calf that was tender to touch. She reported a sudden onset of these complaints with escalating intensity.  Medical  family  and psychosocial history:  There was no significant familial history to record. Upon taking a detailed medical history  it was revealed that the patient had undergone a total knee arthroplasty one month ago. She had been on bed rest for three weeks following the procedure. Her past medical history was significant for hypertension  being controlled by medications. Also  the patient went through two uneventful pregnancies before and during those times she did not have any clotting issues.  Diagnostic Assessment:  A D-dimer test was conducted immediately  the elevated levels of which raised suspicion for deep vein thrombosis. An ultrasound Doppler of the right leg was done which identified a blood clot in the right femoral vein confirming the diagnosis of DVT. Further tests like coagulation profiles were ordered  and they showed inherited Factor V Leiden mutation which predisposes to DVT.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was admitted and immediately started on intravenous Heparin and later was bridged to a long-term oral anticoagulant  Warfarin. Leg elevation  compression stocking  and moderate physical activity like walking were encouraged.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient showed significant improvement within a week with a reduction in the swelling and pain of her leg. She was discharged with advice to continue oral anticoagulant therapy  to monitor INR levels  and was directed to follow up in the clinic after two weeks.   Discussion: This case report provides insights into the potential risk of developing DVT following orthopedic procedures like knee arthroplasty. In this patient  the post-operative immobilization  addition of obesity and hypertension with inherited Factor V Leiden mutation increased the risk. This emphasizes the importance of early mobilization  thromboprophylaxis in susceptible patients  and active monitoring for signs of DVT in post-operative patients.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Asian Female with Sedentary Lifestyle: A Case Report  Patient Information: The patient is a 55-year-old Asian female  a bank clerk by profession  present residing in an urban environment. She is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. Her body mass index (BMI) fits in the overweight category (BMI = 27.6).  Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the emergency department with a 3-day history of progressive right calf pain and swelling  despite no trauma or injury. She also mentioned experiencing occasional shortness of breath over the past couple of days. There was no history of chest pain  palpitations  light-headedness  or syncope. There were no signs of infection such as fever  chills  or localized skin changes on the affected leg.  Medical History: The patient has a known case of type 2 diabetes for 10 years  controlled on medication. She also suffers from hypertension managed with a combination of medications. Her sitting job and an unhealthy diet have led to obesity. She also has a 20-year history of oral contraceptive use. No personal or family history of thrombotic or bleeding disorders was noted.  Diagnostic Assessment: Physical examination revealed a swollen  warm right calf with mild erythema but without any distal neurovascular compromise. Ultrasonography demonstrated a thrombus in the right popliteal vein extending to the trifurcation of calf veins consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  D-dimer level was highly elevated (2300 ng/ml)  and a computed tomography (CT) pulmonary angiogram showed segmental pulmonary emboli in the right lower lobe suggestive of DVT with pulmonary embolism (PE).  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) followed by oral warfarin therapy. She was given compression stockings and advised leg elevation and mobilization. The importance of weight loss  regular exercise  and control of diabetes and hypertension were explained.   Follow-Up and Outcome: At follow-up after three months  she presented with reduced swelling and almost no pain in the calf. Repeat ultrasonography of the leg veins showed the resolution of the thrombus. She had commenced lifestyle modifications with diet and exercise and showed some weight loss.  Conclusion:  This case report highlights the importance of lifestyle modification in the prevention of DVT  especially in those with risk factors such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle and oral contraceptives use. Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to prevent fatal complications such as PE.  Patient consent: Obtained.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 45-year-old African American Male with Sedentary Lifestyle   Introduction: A 45-year-old African American male presenting with pain  swelling  and redness in his left lower limb was evaluated for suspected deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Patient Information: The patient  a computer programmer by profession  had a sedentary lifestyle  primarily sitting for long periods at work. He was a non-smoker and consumed alcohol socially. His family history was significant for cardiovascular diseases (his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 60). The patient had no known drug allergies.  Clinical findings: The patient was afebrile with blood pressure reading of 130/85 mmHg  pulse rate of 88 beats per minute (bpm)  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. On examination  the left lower limb was erythematous  swollen with tenderness along the course of the veins. A positive Homan's sign (pain in the calf or popliteal region with abrupt dorsiflexion of the foot) was noticed.  Timeline: The patient reported gradual onset of left lower limb pain over the last seven days  which increasingly worsened two days before presentation to the hospital. There were no associated symptoms such as chest pain  difficulty in breathing  or fainting spells.  Diagnostic Assessment: The D-dimer test was positive (>500 ng/mL; normal range: 0-500 ng/mL). A subsequent duplex ultrasonography of the left lower extremity showed acute deep vein thrombosis in the left popliteal and femoral veins. There was no evidence of any free-floating thrombi. Rest of the lab investigations including coagulation profile were within normal limits.  Therapeutic intervention: The patient was started on intravenous unfractionated heparin  following which he was bridged to oral anticoagulants (Apixaban). Strict bed rest was advised along with elevation of the affected limb. He was then referred to a hematologist for further coagulation testing as an outpatient  mainly to rule out possible hereditary thrombophilias.  Follow-up and outcomes: At the one-month follow-up  the patient reported considerable improvement in his symptoms. On examination  the swelling in his leg had significantly reduced. Follow-up Doppler ultrasound showed partial recanalization of the thrombosed veins. The patient was encouraged to maintain a more active lifestyle and to continue the oral anticoagulants as recommended by the hematologist.  Conclusion: This case underlines DVT's potential link with sedentary lifestyles. Early recognition and intervention  along with lifestyle modification  play a crucial role in the management of such cases to prevent potential life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism. Regular follow-ups are necessary to assess the efficacy of treatment and adjust therapy as needed.

Title: Case Report - Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 51-year-old Female Patient  I. Patient Information:  a. Demographics: The patient is a 51-year-old Caucasian female. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol regularly. She works as a secondary school teacher and lives in a suburban area.  b. Presenting complaint: The patient presented with symptoms of lower extremity pain and swelling in the right leg. The pain was described as a dull ache  intensified while standing or walking  accompanied by warmth and redness over the affected area.   II. Clinical Findings:   a. Physical Examination: On examination  the right leg appeared noticeably swollen compared to the left. The region was tender to touch  with redness and local warmth. No ulceration or skin discoloration was present. Pulses were palpable in both lower extremities.   b. Diagnostic Assessment: The patient’s symptoms and clinical examination findings led to a presumptive diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). This was confirmed by a Doppler ultrasound showing a clot in the femoral vein.   III. Patient's Medical History:   The patient's medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with oral medication  and hypertension  managed with a combination of diet and antihypertensive medication. She is not on any hormone therapy. There's no history of any surgical procedures. The patient has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  her father having experienced a myocardial infarction and her maternal grandmother having suffered a stroke.   IV. Therapeutic Intervention:  a. Immediate Intervention: The patient was immediately started on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin. She was advised bed rest with the affected leg elevated to reduce swelling.  b. Long Term Management: Post discharge  the patient was continued on oral anticoagulants. She was advised to keep her leg elevated when possible  increase her physical activity  and was referred to a dietitian to help manage her weight and blood pressure.   V. Outcomes and Follow-Up:  a. The patient responded favorably to the treatment with a visible reduction in swelling and pain over the course of a week. She was advised to continue oral anticoagulant therapy for three months minimum  and regular follow-ups were scheduled to monitor her progress and adjust dosages as needed.  b. Patient was educated about the signs of potential complications such as pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome. She was advised to seek immediate medical attention if she experiences chest pain  shortness of breath  or similar symptoms.  VI. Conclusions:  Prompt diagnosis and treatment of deep vein thrombosis contributed to a positive patient outcome in this case. The case underscores the importance of early recognition of symptoms  particularly in individuals with risk factors such as a sedentary lifestyle and family history of cardiovascular diseases. The role of patient education is also important in the long term management and prevention of complications associated with DVT.   VII. Consent:  Consent was taken from the patient for the publication of this case report.

Case Report:   Demographics:  The patient is a 54-year-old Caucasian male  who works as a tech consultant. He is married with two children and lives in an urban area.
