Presenting Symptoms:  The patient initially presented to the emergency department with severe pain in his left leg  which had been increasing over the course of a few days. The pain was primarily located in his calf and had gradually become accompanied by significant swelling. He also noticed that his left leg turned slightly blue.  Past Medical History:  The patient had a past history of major orthopedic surgery  specifically a left hip replacement  which occurred about two months prior to this incident. The surgical recovery had been uneventful  and the patient gradually resumed his normal activities. There were no known allergies or adverse reactions to drugs. The patient has a history of being a smoker for around 15 years but quit five years ago. His family history includes a father and an elder brother who suffered from coronary heart disease in their late fifties. Other medical history includes occasional stress-related migraines and moderate Hypercholesterolemia  which is managed through dietary changes.  Investigation & Diagnosis:  After clinical examination  a Doppler ultrasound was performed which showed a large thrombus in the left popliteal vein  confirming a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Treatment & Follow-up:  The patient was immediately admitted and started on a course of anticoagulant therapy. Heparin was administered first  followed by oral Warfarin  monitoring the International Normalized Ratio (INR) closely. Post two weeks  patient’s leg pain and swelling had nearly disappeared. After leaving the hospital  the patient continued with a course of prophylactic treatment with Warfarin to prevent other thrombi from forming and was evaluated for a potential thrombophilic condition. The patient was instructed to avoid prolonged periods of immobility  and work by standing or walking intermittently.  Conclusions:  This case highlights the risk of DVT associated with a post-operative state  prolonged immobility  and potential genetic predisposition. In patients with prior orthopedic surgery  physicians should discuss the susceptibility to DVT  signs to watch for  and preventive measures to take to lower their risk. It is essential to remind these patients of the need for prompt medical attention if any symptoms suggestive of DVT occur. Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine recommends a DVT risk assessment for all patients admitted to hospital  and our patient will be included in our own study to determine the utility of such an assessment.   Patient's Consent:  A written informed consent for publication was obtained from the patient for this case report and any accompanying images.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 68-year-old Male with a History of Diabetes and Hypertension: A Case Report  Patient Presentation Mr. A  a 68-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of progressive pain and swelling in his right leg which began 4 days ago. The pain was severe and described as a dull aching soreness.   History of Present Illness He also mentioned about a feeling of warmness in the same area of the leg. Mr. A reported having been largely sedentary for the previous two weeks due to a bad winter weather  which resulted in him staying indoors most of the time.  Medical History Mr. A has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he is on Metformin  and Hypertension  being treated with Lisinopril. There was no history of smoking  alcohol or substance abuse. He also did not report any family history of blood clotting disorders. However  he did mention that he took a long-haul flight about a month ago.  Physical Examination Upon examination  patient was in visible distress due to pain. His blood pressure was 145/90 mm Hg  heart rate 89 beats/min  with a regular rhythm and his weight was recorded as 102 kg. The right lower limb was significantly swollen  erythematous and tender on palpation  especially in the calf area. There were no palpable cords or visible superficial venous dilation. No deformity  scarring or skin changes were noted.  Laboratory Findings Lab investigations revealed elevated D-dimer levels indicative of thrombosis. Complete blood count  liver and renal function tests were within acceptable limits. Blood sugar level was elevated consistent with his history of diabetes. Electrocardiogram (EKG) did not reveal any acute abnormalities.  Imaging Color Doppler ultrasound of the right leg was performed  indicating the existence of a noncompressible segment in the femoral and popliteal veins consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Treatment Mr. A was admitted to the hospital and treated with anticoagulant therapy (low molecular weight heparin initially  transitioning to Warfarin)  along with medications specific for his diabetes and hypertension.   Outcome and Follow-Up His leg swelling significantly decreased and pain was controlled after started on anticoagulants. His DVT was most likely associated with prolonged immobility and history of long-haul travel with diabetes and hypertension as possible risk factors. On discharge  he was educated about the importance of regular movement  specially during prolonged periods of sitting or immobility  and was put on long-term Warfarin therapy. The patient is currently being followed up regularly at the outpatient department  and his INR levels have been maintained within the therapeutic range.  Conclusions Physicians should consider DVT in the differential diagnosis in elderly patients reporting leg pain and swelling  particularly in those with recognized risk factors. Systemic history taking and physical examination can lead to timely identification and treatment thereby preventing serious complications.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in an Elderly Male with Hypertension  Patient Information: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male. His ID is HJ27ZZY for purposes of anonymity. He is a retired teacher and has been living an actively monitored life at a local nursing home for the past five years.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension that has been managed with medications (Lisinopril  daily) for the past eight years. He also has a known case of peripheral vascular disease but has declined surgical intervention on multiple occasions. His family history includes a brother with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) diagnosed in his mid-sixties. The patient leads a sedentary lifestyle  has a history of smoking (15-pack years)  and his diet is rich in fat content. He has no known allergies to medications.   Presenting Complaints: The patient had swelling on his left leg that was persistent for 2 days  which led him to seek advice from a health professional. The swelling was associated with moderate to severe pain and the leg was warm to touch. The patient reported no prior history of trauma to the leg.   Clinical Findings: On physical examination  his blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate regular at 72 bpm  temperature was within normal range  and oxygen saturation was 98%. On inspection  the left leg was visibly swollen and discolored (erythemal)  with palpable heat and tenderness. Positive Homans’ sign was noted.   Diagnostic Assessment: A Doppler ultrasound was performed revealing a blood clot in his left posterior tibial vein confirming the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. Laboratory studies showed within normal range complete blood count  kidney  and liver function tests. However  D-dimer levels were significantly elevated  and coagulation profiles were altered indicating an ongoing coagulative process. ECG was normal.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was promptly started on low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin  subcutaneously) that overlapped with oral Warfarin sodium. Adequate hydration and pain management with Paracetamol were ensured. Additionally  mechanical measures such as graduated compression stockings were applied.   Follow Up and Outcomes: The patient responded well to the treatment  showing a reduction in swelling  pain  and erythema over a week. Warfarin dosage was adjusted according to the INR levels obtained daily. The patient was educated about the importance of medication adherence  and lifestyle changes including dietary modifications  leg exercises and importance of periodic movements.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed gratitude for the identification of DVT before any severe complications could occur. He seemed motivated to make lifestyle changes to aid his recovery and prevent thrombotic events in the future.  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Patient Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Demographics:  Mrs. Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian woman  residing in Ontario  Canada  was presented to the emergency department [ED] of the local hospital with complaints of pain  swelling  and redness in her left lower leg which had persisted for four days. She is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. She has no known environmental or occupational exposures. She is a retired primary school teacher and lives with her 75-year-old husband. She has two children and five grandchildren. She and her husband have a quiet lifestyle  with a lot of sedentary leisure activities like reading and knitting.   Past Medical History:  Mrs. Smith is obese (BMI 32)  and has a medical history significant for Type II Diabetes and Hypertension  for which she has been taking Metformin and Ramipril respectively. She maintains adequate glycemic control (latest HbA1c 7.1%) and her blood pressure has been stable (average 130/80 mmHg). She also has osteoarthritis for which she takes Paracetamol when needed. She underwent a total knee replacement surgery on her right knee five years ago due to severe osteoarthritis.   She has no known allergies. Her family history is significant for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) and Pulmonary Embolism (PE); her brother had a PE at age 55.  Event:  According to the patient  she had recently returned from a long road trip to visit her son and his family  where she was sitting for extended periods in the car. In the ED  on physical examination  her left leg was visibly swollen and warm to touch. There was tenderness along the distribution of the deep veins. The Homans sign was positive.   Investigations and Management:  With a high level of clinical suspicion of DVT  an urgent Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities was ordered which confirmed the presence of DVT in her left posterior tibial and peroneal veins.   She was started on low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) for the acute management of DVT. After discussion with the patient and her family regarding her risk factors for DVT  including her recent travel  family history of venous thromboembolism  and personal medical history  it was decided to start her on a course of oral anticoagulation therapy (Rivaroxaban).  Outcome:  Mrs. Smith responded well to treatment. On follow-up after six weeks  her symptoms had resolved completely. She will continue on Rivaroxaban and she was also referred to a dietician and physiotherapist to address her obesity and promote a more active lifestyle.  Conclusion:  This case illustrates that prolonged immobility such as during long-haul travel combined with other risk factors like obesity  age  and genetic predisposition can precipitate DVT even in a generally stable patient.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 58-year-old Male   Patient Information:  The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male  married  working as a construction engineer  residing in Seattle  WA. He is a former smoker with a history of pack-a-day for 20 years  quitting approximately 10 years ago. The patient is known to enjoy social drinking and has no history of illicit drug use.  Chief Complaint:  The patient presented to the Emergency Department with the main complaints of left leg pain and swelling that has been progressively getting worse over a period of three days. The pain was localized to the calf area  described as constant  aching  and with a severity of 7 out of 10. The patient also mentioned shortness of breath that has been worsening concurrent to his leg symptoms.  History of Present Illness:  The patient stated that he had taken a non-stop flight from Seattle to Sydney  Australia (approximately 19 hours) 7 days prior for a business meeting. Upon return  he noticed discomfort and swelling in his left calf which he initially dismissed as muscle strain due to long sitting hours.  Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago and has been on oral hypoglycemic agents. He also has a history of hypertension for the past 10 years  which is well-controlled on medication. The patient's paternal history includes coronary artery disease and hypertension  while his maternal history reveals type 2 diabetes and breast cancer. There is no known family history of blood clotting disorders. This patient is currently taking metformin and losartan.   Physical Examination:  The left leg was visibly swollen with warmth and redness over the calf area. Palpation revealed tenderness along the line of the deep vein. Pedal pulses were symmetric. Heart rate was slightly elevated at 92 bpm  blood pressure 130/85 mm of Hg  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 95%.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  The D-dimer blood test result was elevated  prompting a duplex ultrasound which revealed a clot in the left posterior tibial vein confirming the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Treatment and Progress:  The patient was admitted and started on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin and warfarin. Pain and swelling improved over the course of his stay. On discharge  the patient was advised to continue on warfarin  regular follow-up for INR checks  and to wear compression stockings. He was also counseled about the importance of movement during prolonged travel to prevent DVT recurrence.    Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of considering DVT in patients with unexplained unilateral leg pain and swelling  especially if risk factors such as prolonged immobilization are present. Early detection and treatment are crucial to prevent serious complications like pulmonary embolism.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Geriatric Patient  Patient Information  Age: 74-years-old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Asian Indian Medical history: Hypertension  Type II diabetes mellitus Personal history: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol use Occupation: Retired engineer   Presenting Complaints  The patient presented at the emergency room with a three-day history of swelling and pain in his left leg. He also complained about cramped  sharp leg pain that worsened with movement. The patient had not traveled long distances  undergone surgery  or experienced trauma recently. There was no family history of thrombotic disorders reported.  Clinical Findings  On examination  the left leg was found to be swollen  specifically the calf was noticeably larger than the right. There was localized tenderness and warmth  and the skin was reddish-blue in color. The differential temperature between the legs was apparent. His vitals were stable  and cardiovascular examination showed controlled blood pressure  regular heart rate  and rhythm. No signs of deep vein thrombosis were found in the right leg.  Diagnostic Assessment  The patient’s high D-Dimer levels were suggestive of a clotting disorder. The Doppler ultrasonography of his lower extremity was then performed  providing definitive evidence of deep vein thrombosis. It showed thrombus in the left popliteal and femoral veins. The other radiological investigations  including a CT scan  did not detect any pulmonary embolism.   Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was immediately started on low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH - Enoxaparin 1mg per kg subcutaneously twice daily) and oral anticoagulant therapy with warfarin was initiated the next day  with a target INR of 2-3. The patient was also advised to elevate his leg and wear graduated compression stockings to prevent post-thrombotic syndrome.  Follow-up and Outcomes  The patient responded well to the treatment. His symptoms improved remarkably over the next five days. The swelling and pain abated considerably  and the skin discoloration subsided. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue oral anticoagulants for at least three months and to continue wearing compression stockings. Regular outpatient follow-ups were scheduled for INR testing and monitoring. The patient was advised to report immediately if he experienced symptoms such as chest pain  shortness of breath  or leg pain  signifying potential complications of DVT.  Patient Perspective  The patient expressed relief about his improvement and was cooperative in following the prescribed therapeutic treatment. He was understandably worried about the risks and potential complications associated with his condition  but was reassured by the tangible improvement he experienced after starting the treatment.  Conclusion  This case emphasizes the need for early diagnosis and prompt management in elderly patients with DVT to prevent complications  such as pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome. It also highlights the importance of considering DVT in differential diagnoses of unilateral limb pain and swelling  even in the absence of traditional risk factors. Regular monitoring and follow-up are crucial in managing such cases effectively.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 58-year-old Caucasian male: A Case Report  Introduction: A 58-year-old Caucasian male patient  weighing around 90 kg and standing 1.75 m tall was presented in the ER  complaining about acute onset of pain  swelling  and redness in the right lower extremity.  Demographics: The patient  a smoker with a 40-pack annual history  is a known case of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  managed with insulin for the past 15 years. He also carries a history of chronic back pain for which he is under chiropractic care and occasionally uses NSAIDs. The patient  an accountant by profession  leads a sedentary lifestyle and denied any history of recent long-duration travels or surgeries.  Clinical Findings: On initial examination  the patient's right leg was visibly edematous and warm to touch compared with the left  with some signs of erythema present. Vitals showed a mildly elevated blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg  heart rate of 90 beats per minute (BPM) and respiratory rate at 20 breaths per minute (BRM) with a temperature of 98.6°F. His heart sounds were normal as was his lung examination.   Diagnostic Assessment: Lab results demonstrated an elevated D-Dimer at 800 ng/mL (Normal <500 ng/mL). Given the patient's history and clinical presentation  he was strongly suspected for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). A Doppler ultrasound was performed  which confirmed the presence of a clot in the lower segment of the right femoral vein  thus confirming the diagnosis of DVT.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initiated on anticoagulation therapy using low-molecular-weight heparin with a transition to oral factor Xa inhibitor for longer-term management. The patient was also advised regular ambulation and use of compression stockings for symptom management.  Follow-Up: The patient responded well to the provided treatment. At the 1-month follow-up visit  a repeat Doppler ultrasound showed significant reduction in clot size and the patient reported a notable improvement in pain and swelling.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of recognizing DVT in outpatients  particularly those with risk factors like advanced age  sedentary lifestyle  smoking  and prior history of venous thromboembolism. Early recognition  diagnosis  and treatment primarily aimed at anticoagulation can mitigate the risk of fatal complications  such as pulmonary embolism.

Case Report of Mr. Hart  a 65-year-old male with Deep Vein Thrombosis   1. Patient Information:  Mr. Hart  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents with severe swelling  warmth  and pain in his left leg  especially in the calf area  worsening over the past week. This individual is a retired construction worker from Brooklyn  New York  United States. He lives with his wife and has two adult children who live away from home.   2. Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the left lower limb was noticeably swollen with elevated local temperature and calf tenderness indicative of a positive Homans' sign. There was a visible color change  with the affected leg appearing redder than the right one. His vital signs were as follows: temperature – 37.8-degree Celsius  pulse – 88 beats per minute  blood pressure- 145/90mmHg  and respiratory rate- 18 breaths per minute.  3. Past Medical History:  Mr. Hart is a non-smoker with a history of hypertension controlled with medication  namely Amlodipine 5mg daily. He is also being treated for hypercholesterolemia with Simvastatin 20mg daily. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 3 years ago and managed with lifestyle modifications and Metformin. He underwent a total knee replacement surgery on the same leg around two months ago.   4. Diagnostic Assessment:  Doppler ultrasound of the left leg was performed  which revealed a non-compressible segment in the left popliteal vein  supportive of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Lab results showed an elevated D-dimer level of 800 ng/mL (normal range: 0-500 ng/mL)  while other markers like complete blood count (CBC)  liver function test (LFT)  and renal panel were within normal limits.  5. Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was started on parenteral Anticoagulants - low molecular weight Heparin (Enoxaparin 1mg/kg subcutaneously every 12 hours). After five days  the treatment strategy was transitioned to an oral anticoagulant - Warfarin (5mg/day)  considering his medical history.  6. Follow-up:  Mr. Hart was advised regarding the importance of medication compliance  potential signs of complications (like chest pain  shortness of breath)  and the need for regular follow-up appointments. A repeat ultrasound will be scheduled in one month to assess the resolution of the clot. Lifestyle modifications such as regular exercise  a healthy diet  and maintaining optimal body weight were also emphasized.  7. Conclusion:   The high risk of DVT in this case is multifactorial  including underlying comorbidities (hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  diabetes)  advanced age  and recent major surgery. A multidisciplinary care approach and patient compliance in long-term anticoagulation therapy will be pivotal in preventing recurrence or complications of DVT in this patient.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Information:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  weighing 75 kilograms and standing at 1.75 meters in height. He is a retired construction worker living in a suburban community with his wife. The patient is a non-smoker and reports moderate alcohol intake.   History of Present Illness:  The patient presented to the emergency department with a 48-hour history of progressively worsening pain and swelling in the right lower extremity. No history of trauma or recent travel was reported. There was no fever  chest pain  dyspnea  hemoptysis  or history of prior similar episodes.   Past Medical History:  The patient previously survived a myocardial infarction five years prior and had been diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus over the past decade. No history of any psychiatric illness  cancer  pulmonary disease  renal disease or liver disease was elicited. He never had any surgeries or hospitalizations.   Current Medications and Allergies:  The patient has been on a stable regimen of aspirin  metformin  and lisinopril. He is allergic to penicillin  which causes a rash.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient was afebrile  blood pressure was 132/84 mm of Hg  pulse rate 78 beats per minute  respiration 18 per minute  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. A noticeable swelling of the right calf (3 cm more in diameter compared to left calf) was observed along with tenderness on palpation. No superficial venous varicosities or skin changes were noted. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment:  D-Dimer levels were elevated. Subsequently  an ultrasound of the right lower extremity confirmed a deep vein thrombosis in the femoral vein. Chest X-ray and ECG did not reveal any abnormalities.  Treatment and outcome:  The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy (low molecular weight heparin)  followed by oral anticoagulants (warfarin) for long term management. The swelling and pain gradually subsided over the following week and he was discharged.  Discussion:  Deep vein thrombosis is a frequent complication in patients with underlying cardiovascular disease. The presence of type 2 diabetes and hypertension in the present patient further augmented his risk. Thus  primary preventive strategies as well as an early detection program targeted at such high-risk groups should be in place.  Consent for publication:  The patient provided informed consent for the publication of this case report.

Case Report: Female Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female  residing in an urban setting. She is a retired high school teacher  non-smoker  and reports occasional alcohol consumption. She is widowed  living alone  and has two adult children who live within the same region.  Medical History  The patient has a significant medical history including hypertension controlled with Lisinopril and Amlodipine  type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin  and hypercholesterolemia treated with Rosuvastatin. She has a history of hypothyroidism which is currently regulated with Levothyroxine. She also had a hysterectomy due to fibroids at the age of 52. She hasn't had any prior surgeries or hospitalizations.  Presenting Symptoms  The patient came to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset of swelling  warmth  and pain in the left lower extremity. She also reported difficulty walking due to the discomfort. On questioning  she reported feeling short of breath and fatigued for the past few days  but associated it with her age and did not pursue medical evaluation.  Clinical Findings  On examination  her left leg showed notable edema  warmth  and tenderness along the inner side. Her vitals were stable although her heart rate was slightly elevated at 98 bpm. There was no palpable cord  and Homan's sign was equivocal. Her lungs were clear to auscultation and her heart sounds were regular with no added sounds.  Diagnosis  Given her complaints and physical examination findings  a venous Doppler ultrasound was performed urgently which revealed a thrombus in the left popliteal vein suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). A CT pulmonary angiogram was also performed  due to her reported shortness of breath and slightly elevated heart rate  which did not show any evidence of pulmonary embolism.  Treatment  The patient was promptly started on low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) with plans to bridge her to an oral anticoagulant  likely Apixaban or Rivaroxaban  once her renal tests return as suitable. She was provided education regarding the importance of compliance with her anticoagulation therapy and other risk reduction strategies.  The patient was also referred for a thrombophilia workup in the outpatient setting to rule out any underlying pro-thrombotic state. Her medications were reviewed and no potential contributors to her DVT were identified.  Patient's Progress  At her two-week follow-up at the thrombosis clinic  she reported significant improvement in her symptoms of leg swelling and discomfort. Her outpatient thrombophilia workup did not reveal any hereditary or acquired thrombotic disorders suggesting her DVT was likely provoked by her sedentary lifestyle  particularly during the recent COVID-19 lockdown.  She has been regularly followed up in the internal medicine clinic since then to monitor her progress and to manage her comorbid conditions.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 54-year-old Male Patient  Patient Information:  A 54-year-old  Caucasian male patient  weight 92 kg and height 6'1  known to be a heavy smoker and habitual alcohol consumer was evaluated in an outpatient setting in our hospital. He is a cab driver by profession and has a history of chronic hypertension (18 years) and was recently diagnosed as Type II diabetic (4 months ago). He is also known to have high cholesterol. He does not have any known allergy towards any medications. Family medical history includes a father who died of myocardial infarction  and a mother diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis.  Clinical Findings:  The patient presents with a two-week history of progressive pain and swelling of the right lower limb  extending from the calf to the thigh. He also reports a low-grade fever and occasional fatigue. On examination  the patient’s vitals were stable  his lower limb was swollen with an increase in size of about 3 cms compared to the left limb  and it was warm to touch.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Due to the patient’s symptoms and risk factors  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) was suspected. A Doppler ultrasound showed an extensive thrombus in the right common femoral  superficial femoral  and popliteal veins suggesting right lower limb DVT.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately treated with therapeutic doses of subcutaneous Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) which was overlapped with oral warfarin until a therapeutic INR of 2-3 was reached. He was also given compression stockings for his lower limb swelling.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  A follow-up after two weeks showed a significant reduction in right limb swelling and pain. His INR level was within the therapeutic range  and no bleeding complications were observed. The patient was counseled for lifestyle alterations  including smoking cessation and reducing alcohol consumption  increasing physical activity  diet modifications  and the need for regular monitoring and timely follow-ups. Oral anticoagulation therapy advised to continue for at least three months.  Patient's Perspective:  The patient expressed relief from his acute symptoms and appreciated the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle and medication adherence to prevent similar situations in the future.  Informed Consent:  The patient provided informed consent for the publication of this case report.  Conclusion:  This case underlines the significance of early diagnosis and management of DVT  particularly in patients with significant risk factors such as chronic hypertension  diabetes  high cholesterol  sedentary habits  and smoking. It also emphasizes the importance of lifestyle modification and regular monitoring in preventing DVT.

Patient Profile: A 54-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and mild obesity  presented with the complaint of a painful  swollen left lower limb. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack-year smoking history and does physical work as a construction worker. There is no history of any previous major surgery or significant trauma. The patient has no known allergies and routinely takes antihypertensive medication daily.  Presenting Complaint: The patient mentioned that he had noticed mild discomfort and swelling in his left calf over the past four days. Swelling seemed to be worsening with a progressive increase in pain. He denied having any symptoms of shortness of breath  chest pain  or palpitations. He reported no recent injuries to the leg and no long periods of immobilization.   Clinical Examination: On examination  the patient had a blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  heart rate of 85 bpm  respiratory rate 14 breaths per minute  and temperature of 36.9°C. His left calf was more swollen than the right  with a difference in calf circumference of about 3 cm. The area was slightly heated  erythematous  and caused pain on palpation. The peripheral pulses were symmetrical. No rash  ulcerations  or obvious varicose veins were noted. The breath sounds were normal bilaterally  and the chest was clear. His cardiovascular and abdominal examinations were also within normal limits.  Investigations & Diagnosis: Bloodwork showed slight leukocytosis  but no other significant abnormalities were present. D-dimer levels were found to be elevated at 752 ng/mL (normal range being up to 500). Given the severity of his symptoms  an urgent duplex ultrasound was performed which showed a non-compressible left popliteal vein and evidence of thrombosis  confirming the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Management & Follow-up:  The patient was initiated on anticoagulation therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin  followed by a transition to an oral anticoagulant (Apixaban) as per standard DVT clinical protocols. He was also educated about the importance of leg elevation  wearing compression stockings  and to continue his normal physical activities as tolerated.   The patient  however  was advised to follow up in one week to monitor his response to therapy and again in three months to reassess the need for prolonged anticoagulation  given his unprovoked DVT.  Takeaway: This case underlines the importance of a detailed physical examination and timely investigation for early diagnosis of DVT  particularly in patients with underlying risk factors like hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity  and a history of smoking.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Female with a History of Hypertension and Sedentary lifestyle  Patient Information: Mrs. Karen Mills  a 50-year-old Caucasian woman presented to the emergency department with severe and sudden onset pain coupled with swelling in her left leg. She is a businesswoman by profession  leading a sedentary lifestyle given her desk-bound job and frequently undertakes long-haul intercontinental flights for her business commitments. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol in moderation.   Prior Medical History: Mrs. Mills was diagnosed with hypertension two years ago and has been on regular medication. However  her compliance rate to medication has been inconsistent. The patient's family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  with her father suffering from stroke and her older brother being managed for chronic atrial fibrillation.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  Mrs. Mills had a swollen  red  and warm left leg. The circumference of her left leg was significantly larger than her right. Her left calf was tender on palpation. She had a slightly elevated heart rate and blood pressure was noted to be 144/92 mmHg.  Baseline labs: Her lab results showed a slightly elevated D-dimer level (0.8 mg/L)  with all other investigations including complete blood count  renal function test  liver function test  and lipid profile within normal range. EKG was also within normal limits.  Diagnostic Assessment: Given her symptoms  clinical findings  and the markedly elevated D-dimer  a Duplex ultrasound was ordered which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in her left femoral vein. A diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was made.  Therapeutic Intervention: Mrs. Mills was treated with low molecular weight heparin and referred to a vascular specialist for further management and evaluation.  Follow-up and outcomes: Within 48 hours of initiation of treatment  Mrs. Mills reported a decrease in pain and swelling. However  given her risk factors including hypertension  sedentary lifestyle  and family history  she was advised lifestyle modifications for long term management and prevention of recurrence. This includes regular exercise  dietary changes  better management of hypertension  and appropriate preventative measures during her long flights.  Conclusions: This report highlights the importance of considering DVT in patients with unilateral leg swelling  despite having only risk factors like a sedentary lifestyle and uncontrolled hypertension. Early recognition and treatment have resulted in an improved short-term outcome for Mrs. Mills  and rigorous lifestyle changes will play a pivotal role in her long-term health and prevention of DVT recurrence.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  a resident of Texas  U.S. He is a retired banker. He lives with his wife and is a non-smoker while consuming alcohol socially. He has lived a sedentary lifestyle post-retirement.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented with a week-long history of progressive pain  swelling and warmth in the right lower leg. He also reported discomfort in the calf muscle. He denied any trauma to the leg  at the time of presentation. No history of recent travel or prolonged immobilization was reported.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known case of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  controlled on medication including hydrochlorothiazide and metformin respectively. The patient has no known allergies.  Family History:  His mother had a history of stroke at age 65. His father was diagnosed with coronary heart disease in his late 50s. His sister died of ovarian cancer at the age of 50.  Clinical Examinations:  On examination  the patient’s vitals were stable. Right calf diameter was found to be larger as compared to the left calf accompanied with skin warmth and tenderness. A palpable cord was also noted along the right popliteal vein. No skin ulcers or discoloration were noticed.  Laboratory Investigations:  Laboratory tests were essentially within normal limits. Coagulation profile was within the normal range and D-Dimer levels were elevated.  Imaging Findings:   A Doppler ultrasound of the right lower extremity was conducted  which revealed a non-compressible femoral and popliteal vein consistent with the presence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Management:  The patient was hospitalized and anticoagulation was initiated with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) along with a planned course of oral warfarin therapy. The need for compression stockings for the reduction of swelling and prevention of post-thrombotic syndrome was discussed. His recovery was uneventful  and he was planned to be followed up as an outpatient.  Summary:  The case report highlights the presentation of a 62-year-old male patient with signs and symptoms suggestive of DVT. The diagnosis was confirmed using Doppler ultrasound and was effectively managed with hospitalization  anticoagulation therapy and planned outpatient follow-up. It underscores the importance of considering DVT in the differential  in a patient presenting with unilateral leg swelling and pain  especially in patients with known risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes.

Title: Pulmonary Embolism Secondary to Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 55-year-old Male with a History of Obesity and Sedentary Lifestyle  Patient Demographics:  A 55-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with acute onset of chest discomfort and shortness of breath. The patient is a lawyer by profession  with a sedentary lifestyle seated behind a desk for about 8 hours each day. He is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol. There were no known drug allergies. He is from suburban Texas  living with his wife with two adult children who live separately.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of obesity (BMI 34)  hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which lipitor and losartan are taken every day. He has no known history of major surgery  previous incidents of blood clots  diabetes mellitus or cancer. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in his father who died at the age of 62.   Presentation:  The patient complained of sudden onset chest discomfort  shortness of breath and mild cough with no known precipitating event. He also mentioned prolonged periods of calf pain and swelling which he had wrongly assumed as related to his weight. There was no fever  fatigue or uncontrolled hypertension at the time of presentation.  Examination and Investigations:  On physical examination  his blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate was 96/min  respiratory rate was 20/min  pulse oximetry showing a significant drop in oxygen levels at 90%. There were no signs of cyanosis. Chest auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds on the right side. Swelling and redness were observed on the left lower leg. Lab tests showed an elevated D-dimer and troponin levels. Chest CT angiogram showed filling defects in the pulmonary arteries confirming pulmonary embolism. Lower extremity Doppler ultrasound showed thrombus in the left popliteal vein  indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Diagnosis and Treatment:  Diagnosis of pulmonary embolism secondary to DVT was made based on the clinical presentation  lab tests  CT angiography and Doppler ultrasound findings. The patient was given immediate oxygen therapy. Intravenous administration of unfractionated heparin was initiated  and the patient was transitioned to oral anticoagulant apixaban on the second day.   Follow-up:  Patient was advised regular follow-up with cardiologist and also referred to physiotherapy to aid in mobilization and reduction of obesity. Nutritionist consultation was provided to regulate diet. Lifelong anticoagulation therapy was recommended considering his risk factors like obesity  sedentary lifestyle and previous DVT episode.  Learning Point:  This case highlights the importance of recognizing symptoms of DVT and providing timely interventions to prevent life-threatening complications like pulmonary embolism  especially in high-risk individuals with sedentary lifestyles and obesity. Encouragement towards lifestyle modification can play a key role in prevention and management of DVT.

Title: Case Report on Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 52-Year-Old Male Patient   Patient demographics:   This case report concerns Mr. A  a 52-year-old Caucasian male who works in an office job with a high stress level. His lifestyle involves minimal physical activity  due to the nature of his work. He is a non-smoker but has an extensive past of chronic alcohol consumption. He was born and raised in central United States and currently resides there.   Background:  Mr. A has been suffering from hypertension along with hypercholesterolemia for the past seven years and has been on medication for both conditions. He also had a body mass index score of 28  indicating him being overweight. His family history includes his father who died of myocardial infarction at the age of 64  and his mother  who has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus.   Presentation:  Mr. A came to the emergency department with severe pain and swelling in his right lower leg that had been worsening over the previous three days. He also reported an acute onset of breathlessness dating back to the same time period. The patient had never experienced any similar symptoms in the past.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  the right calf was found to be noticeably swollen and tender. Duplex ultrasonography of the right lower extremity revealed the presence of thrombus in the popliteal and superficial femoral veins suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Further investigations including chest X-ray and computed tomography scan were conducted due to the breathlessness experienced by the patient. These showed signs of multiple segmental and subsegmental pulmonary emboli. A D-dimer test  which is a blood test that can indicate the presence of a clot  was also done and was reported to be positive.  Diagnosis:  With the clinical presentation and subsequent radiological findings  a diagnosis of DVT with subsequent pulmonary embolism was made.  Management:  Anticoagulation therapy was promptly initiated with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) along with oral warfarin to treat the DVT and prevent clot extension. As his breathlessness was severe  a decision was made to proceed with thrombolysis. Moreover  Mr. A was encouraged to have frequent ambulation  lose weight  and maintain a balanced diet to manage his chronic conditions and reduce the incidence of recurring DVT.  Discussion:  In this case report  it is observed that factors such as lack of physical activity  being overweight  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia significantly contributed to the development of DVT  which underscores the importance of lifestyle modifications  maintaining a healthy weight and good control of the chronic ailments for prevention of DVT.   This report should serve as a reminder to clinicians of the importance of considering a diagnosis of DVT in patients with unexplained leg swelling and pain  especially in the presence of risk factors such as a sedentary lifestyle  obesity  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Introduction:  This case report describes the demographic profile  medical history  clinical presentation  diagnosis  and management of a 56-year-old female patient diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Patient Information:  The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian female  married  nonsmoker  living in suburban Pennsylvania. She works as a high school teacher and frequently travels.   Previous Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  controlled by medication (Amlodipine 5 mg once daily). She has hypertension for around 10 years and is on regular follow-ups. She also suffers from obesity (BMI: 31.2). She has no history of surgeries or hospital admissions. The patient's mother had a stroke at the age of 62  and there is no family history of blood clot disorders. She does not have diabetes or any other systemic disease.   Presenting Symptoms:  The patient presented to the emergency department with a 2-day history of sudden onset left lower limb pain and swelling that gradually worsened. She reported a recent international flight tour a week ago. There was no history of trauma or injury. She also reported a history of calf pain during the flight.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  her left leg was swollen  noticeably larger than the right leg  and warm to touch  particularly in the calf region. There was tender and palpable cord in the popliteal fossa.  Investigations:  A Duplex Doppler ultrasound scan confirmed the diagnosis of DVT. The scan showed an occlusive blood clot in the left popliteal vein. Routine blood investigations were within normal limits. Her blood pressure was elevated (150/95 mmHg)  and a cardiac examination was unremarkable.  Treatment:  Anticoagulation therapy was initiated with subcutaneous Enoxaparin 1 mg/kg twice daily  followed by oral Warfarin to achieve a target INR between 2 and 3. Her hypertensive medication was revised  and her doctor suggested doing lifestyle modifications for better control.  Outcome and Follow-Up:  Over the next few days  her symptoms of pain  swelling  and tenderness significantly improved. The patient was advised leg elevation  compression stockings  and regular monitoring of INR levels. She was referred for a detailed cardiovascular risk assessment considering her age  hypertension  and recent DVT.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling  especially those with risk factors such as recent long-haul travel and underlying hypertension. Prompt diagnosis and initiation of anticoagulation are vital to prevent potential complications such as pulmonary embolism. Comprehensive cardiovascular risk assessment and management are crucial in such patients.

Title: Diagnosis and Treatment of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Adult  Patient Information:  Mr. A  a 52-year-old African-American male  was admitted to an outpatient clinic on October 31  2022. He is a non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumer and stands 5'9"" tall  weighing 187lbs (BMI: 27.6) indicative of slight overweight. His profession requires him to have long periods of sitting. Previous medical history includes controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has a family history of myocardial infarction and stroke in his father and a younger brother  respectively.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented with a gradual onset of a painful  swollen right leg that was visibly redder than the left one. The pain had started four days prior to the visit and was progressively worsening. The patient reported no history of trauma  difficulty in breathing  or chest pain.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed swelling  erythema  increased warmth  and tenderness  more pronounced in the calf region of his right leg. There was no notable lymphadenopathy. His vitals were stable; blood pressure 137/82 mmHg  pulse rate 78 beats/min  and respiratory rate 18 breaths/min. Laboratory tests  including a D dimer test  were suggested and completed.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Elevated D dimer levels were noted from the laboratory results  raising suspicion of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). A lower extremity venous duplex ultrasound confirmed the presence of an acute  non-occlusive thrombus in the right common femoral vein extending to the popliteal vein.   Therapeutic Intervention: Upon confirming DVT diagnosis  the patient was promptly started on a high-intensity anticoagulant regimen. An intravenous (IV) bolus dose  followed by a continuous infusion of unfractionated Heparin was administered. This treatment was overlapped with oral Warfarin  commenced on the same day.  Follow-up and Outcome:  The patient's symptoms improved remarkably two days after initiating therapy. After achieving the desired International Normalized Ratio (INR) range of 2-3 consistently for two consecutive days  the patient was discharged on only Warfarin with detailed instructions and scheduled for routine follow-ups.   Patient's Perspective:  The patient verbalized understanding and satisfaction with the treatment plan and expressed willingness to comply with regular follow-ups  medication regulations  and lifestyle changes to manage his conditions better and prevent recurrent DVT events.  Teaching Points:  This case report emphasizes the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling  particularly in those with predisposing factors like a sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  and diabetes. The case also highlights the use of anticoagulant drugs in the treatment and prevention of DVT recurrence. Early diagnosis and management of DVT can prevent serious complications  including pulmonary embolism.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Hypertensive Female: A Case Report  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  a serious condition resulting from the formation of a blood clot in a deep vein  usually in the lower limbs  can lead to life-threatening complications like pulmonary embolism. This case report describes a case of DVT in a middle-aged female with a known history of hypertension.  Patient Information: The patient presented is a 57-year-old Caucasian female  married  from the suburban area  working as a sales representative. She has no history of smoking or substance abuse and has maintained a relatively sedentary lifestyle due to the nature of her job.   Clinical Findings: The patient came in complaining of redness  swelling and pain in her left lower leg  worsening over a period of four days. She did not mention any history of recent trauma or prolonged immobilization. On examination  vitals were stable except for a slightly elevated blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. The left lower leg showed signs of edema  tenderness and warmth.  Medical History: She has a known history of hypertension  diagnosed ten years earlier  well-controlled with calcium channel blocker medication. She also mentioned occasional use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for osteoarthritis. She has no known allergy to medications. Her family history includes her mother with hypertension and a brother who experienced a stroke in his early sixties.  Diagnosis: Doppler ultrasound of the lower leg was done due to high suspicion of DVT based on the clinical findings; it showed a non-compressible popliteal vein suggestive of DVT. Routine blood tests showed a slightly elevated D-dimer levels and normal renal and liver function tests.  Treatment: The patient was hospitalized and managed initially with low molecular weight heparin followed by oral anticoagulation with Warfarin.   Discussion: This case highlights the importance of considering DVT in patients even with no apparent provoking factors like trauma  surgery  or prolonged immobilization. The presence of hypertension  sedentary lifestyle and occasional use of NSAIDs could have elevated the patient's risk of developing DVT  showing the relevance of these factors in patients with a similar history.  Conclusion: This case report emphasizes the need for high clinical suspicion and prompt investigation of DVT in patients  especially those with risk factors such as hypertension and a sedentary lifestyle. Early diagnosis and treatment can help prevent serious complications and improve patient outcomes.  Consent: Informed consent for the case report was obtained from the patient.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Stern  a 65-year-old male  Caucasian  lives in a suburban neighborhood in Philadelphia  Pennsylvania. He is a retired engineer and has a past medical history significant for hypertension and high cholesterol for which he takes Hydrochlorothiazide and Atorvastatin. His family history includes a father who suffered a stroke at age 73 and a mother with congestive heart failure in her late 60s. He is an ex-smoker  quit smoking 15 years ago  has a moderate intake of alcohol  and has no known drug allergies.  Reason for Consultation:  Mr. Stern presented to the hospital with complaints of a two-day history of progressive swelling  warmth  and pain in his right lower extremity. The pain is described as an ache that is most severe in the posterior aspect of his right calf. He also mentioned having an intermittent low-grade fever.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  Mr. Stern's vitals were stable. His right leg was visibly swollen. Palpable cord could be felt in his right calf with a positive Homan’s sign and measured 3 cm larger than his left calf. Laboratory tests signified a slightly raised D-dimer level of 600 ng/ml (reference range <500 ng/ml). The remainder of his bloodwork  including renal function and electrolytes  was normal.  Diagnosis:  Based on clinical findings and patient's medical history  a provisional diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right lower limb was considered. The patient underwent a lower extremity venous duplex ultrasound  which confirmed the presence of thrombotic clot in the deep veins of the patient's right calf  confirming the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.  Treatment:  The patient was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) with a transition to Warfarin for long term anticoagulation. He was also advised compression stockings and educated about regular leg exercises.  Outcome and Follow-Up:  Over the next couple of days  the patient showed significant improvement with reduced pain and swelling. He was discharged with Warfarin and advised regular INR checks. Following discharge  he was scheduled for a follow-up visit and further surveillance three months later in the vascular clinic.   Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the clinical presentation of DVT in an elderly patient. Ensuring prompt diagnosis and correct treatment is key in the management of deep vein thrombosis to prevent complications such as post-thrombotic syndrome and potentially life-threatening pulmonary embolism.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Introduction:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a serious condition in which a blood clot forms in the deep veins of the body  most commonly in the lower leg or thigh. This case report presents a 45-year-old male with a history of DVT.  Patient Information:  Mr. X  a 45-year-old Caucasian male  presented with intense pain and swelling in his left lower leg. The patient is a long-distance truck driver  having a sedentary lifestyle  and is an active smoker. He suffers from obesity (BMI: 32 kg/m2) and hypertension. He has no known drug allergies. His medications include antihypertensive (Losartan potassium) and lipid-lowering agents (Atorvastatin). He has a family history of cardiovascular disorders with his father suffering a stroke at an age of 60.   Clinical findings:  Clinical examination revealed a palpable cord along the course of the popliteal vein  positive Homan's sign (pain in the calf upon dorsiflexion of the foot)  and swelling of the left calf.   Diagnostic Assessment:  A Doppler ultrasound was performed  confirming the presence of a clot in the left popliteal vein indicating a deep vein thrombosis. His complete blood count (CBC)  liver function tests (LFTs)  and kidney function tests (KFTs) were within normal limits. However  his lipid profile was deranged with raised LDL levels.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately started on anticoagulants (low weight molecular heparin) and further advised to switch to oral anticoagulants (Warfarin). He was counseled regarding the importance of exercise  weight loss  and smoking cessation. The use of compression stockings was suggested to reduce symptoms and decrease the risk of complications.   Outcome:  The patient experienced significant relief from pain within 2 days of the treatment. A follow-up after 1 month showed reduced swelling  increased mobility  and the absence of Homan's sign. The patient successfully reduced his smoking habit and began making efforts towards a healthier lifestyle.   Conclusions:  This case underscores the role of a sedentary lifestyle and other risk factors like smoking  obesity  and family history of cardiovascular disorders in the formation of deep vein thrombosis. Regular exercise  healthy eating habits  and smoking cessation are crucial for people having these risk factors to prevent DVT. Early diagnosis and prompt treatment play a vital role in preventing morbidity and mortality.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 67-year-old Male with Past Medical history of Smoking  I. Patient Information   The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired  and residing in the suburban Midwest. He lives with his wife of 45 years  has two adult children  and four grandchildren. He is a former smoker  having clocked 45 pack-years before quitting two years ago.  II. Chief Complaint   The patient presented at the clinic with a two-day history of severe pain and progressive swelling in the right lower extremity with no discernible injury.   III. History of Present Illness   The patient complained of pain in the right leg  primarily in the calf region with a scoring of 8 out of 10 on a pain rating scale. He had observed swelling for two days and noticed that the mobility of his right leg was restricted due to pain. He reported no associated fever  chest pain  or dyspnea. However  he did recall instances of occasional cramps in the same leg over the past week.  IV. Past Medical History    The patient had a medical history of hypertension for which he had been taking medication regularly for the past ten years. He has also been treated for hypercholesterolemia for the past five years and recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus which is being managed by oral hypoglycemic agents. Previously  he had undergone gastric ulcer surgery about fifteen years ago. He admitted to tobacco use  with 45 pack-years history  though he had quit about two years back  inspired by cessation counseling. He also consumes alcohol moderately.  V. Physical Examination   On physical examination  his height is 5 feet 11 inches and his weight is 200lbs (BMI 27.8kg/m2)  suggesting he is overweight. His blood pressure is 135/85 and pulse rate is 80 beats/min. His right lower extremity was erythematous  warm  substantially swollen  and tender  particularly in the calf region. Pulses were palpable. Rest of the systemic examination is normal.  VI. Relevant Test Results   The D-dimer test was elevated and an ultrasound Doppler study of the right lower extremity confirmed the presence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the proximal veins.   VII. Treatment   The patient was immediately started on subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin along with oral rivaroxaban. He was also advised to elevate his leg and use compression stockings to alleviate swelling.  VIII. Follow-up and Prognosis   The patient is currently being monitored closely for any worsening of symptoms or side effects from the anticoagulation therapy. The patient was educated about the signs and symptoms of pulmonary embolism  as an extension of deep vein thrombosis.  IX. Learning points   This case highlights that elderly patients  especially those with multiple risk factors including history of smoking  hypertension  dyslipidemia  obesity  and recent onset of diabetes are at a higher risk for developing deep vein thrombosis. Practitioners must consider these risk factors and have a high index of suspicion for DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg pain/swelling. Effective treatment and thorough patient education can potentially prevent severe complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 65-Year-Old Male Patient  Patient Information:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents with symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his left lower leg.   Demographics:  He is a retired engineer  a non-smoker who drinks alcohol moderately. He lives with his wife and has a supportive home environment. He denied any drug use.  Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes and under medication control with Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and Metformin respectively. He also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 62. The patient also reports that he had an aunt who was diagnosed with a blood clot in her leg when she was in her seventies.  Physical Examination: During the physical examination  the patient’s vital signs were relatively stable  showing a normal respiratory rate and a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. On inspection  his left leg was observed to be swollen and visibly larger than the right leg. Upon palpation  the patient indicated that he experienced tenderness in the area.  Clinical Findings: The patient reported symptoms of swelling and pain in his left lower leg  which has been progressing over the last 5 days. He didn’t report any recent surgeries  long term sitting or periods of immobility. No other symptoms were reported at the time of consultation.  Diagnostic Assessment: Based on the patient's symptoms  a venous duplex ultrasound was conducted which confirmed the presence of a clot in the deep vein of the left calf. Lab tests including a complete blood count  D-dimer test  and PT/INR were ordered. D-Dimer level came out to be elevated  which further supported the diagnosis of DVT.  Therapeutic Intervention: Anticoagulant therapy was initiated with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) for immediate anticoagulation along with oral Warfarin. Overlapping therapy was planned for the initial 5 days till the time INR reached a therapeutic range of 2-3. During the in-hospital phase  the patient was encouraged to ambulate.  Follow-up and Outcomes: A follow-up appointment was arranged in 2 weeks to reassess the clot and ensure the patient's response to treatment. The patient was also given advice on risk factor modification  weight management  and lifestyle changes to prevent future episodes of DVT.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed relief after the diagnosis was made and anticoagulant therapy was initiated. His main concern was the prevention of future episodes  and he was eager to make necessary lifestyle changes for the same.  Informed consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publishing this case report.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 45-Year Old Caucasian Male  Patient Information:  A 45-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. B  visited the clinic with complaints of persistent pain and swelling in the right lower extremity. His occupation as a software engineer involves long sitting hours. His BMI was noted to be 28.5 indicating overweight. He is a non-smoker and has a moderate alcohol intake of approximately one to two drinks per week. His past medical history included hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin respectively. He had no known allergies or family history of venous thromboembolic disease.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient's right calf was markedly swollen and warm to touch with a notable redness. Homan's sign was positive (pain in the calf upon dorsiflexion of his foot).   Diagnostic Assessment:  We suspected deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  due to the patient's clinical presentation  sedentary occupation  and his hypertension and hyperlipidemia which are known predisposing factors for DVT. Loss of pulsation in the dorsalis pedis and popliteal arteries were noted. Doppler ultrasonography was ordered and confirmed the presence of a thrombus within the right posterior tibial vein. A D-dimer test was positive with a level of 950 ng/ml (normal range: up to 500 ng/ml).  Therapeutic Intervention:  Anticoagulant therapy was immediately initiated with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). He was later bridged to oral apixaban  a Factor Xa inhibitor  which he is to take for at least three months. His leg was also elevated to reduce swelling and he was advised to wear compression stockings. Exercise and mobilization were encouraged.   Follow Up and Outcomes:  He was asked to return to the clinic for regular follow-ups  focusing on assessment of symptom resolution  monitoring of potential bleeding complications  or development of post-thrombotic syndrome. On his return after a week  there was a significant reduction in the swelling of his right lower limb  and after four weeks  the patient reported complete resolution of the previous symptoms.   Teaching Points:  This case underscores the importance of considering DVT while evaluating leg or calf pain with swelling especially in patients with known risk factors. Morbidity and Mortality from DVT can be greatly reduced by appropriate and timely intervention. Individuals with sedentary jobs should be counseled about the potential risks and advised to take frequent short breaks to mobilize. Regular exercise and maintaining a healthy weight are also pivotal in prevention of DVT.

Patient Information:  Ms. Judy Garner  a 63-year-old Caucasian female  presented with abrupt and severe pain in her left calf.  Presenting Issue:   The client reported alarming swelling accompanied with warmth and redness around the affected area. The pain amplified significantly while standing or moving. There were no associated symptoms  such as breathlessness  cough  hemoptysis  or chest pain.  Medical History:   Ms. Garner has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is managed with insulin and dietary modifications. Her hypertension is controlled through a daily low-dose of ACE inhibitor. She is also on a low dose of statins for hyperlipidemia. The patient has reported no previous episodes of similar nature. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She reported a recent long car journey (continuous driving for about 10-12 hours each day)  which had happened about six days prior to the onset of symptoms.  On examination  her Body Mass Index (BMI) was 29.5 kg/m2  and all peripheral pulses were palpable and symmetric. No surface veins were visible  but the left calf was significantly swollen relative to the right.   Investigations:  Laboratory data revealed deranged coagulation profile with D-dimer of 1500 ng/mL (normal range: 0:243 ng/mL). She exhibited no leukocytosis  anemia  or signs of bacterial infection. Venous Doppler ultrasound of the left lower extremity revealed acute thrombus in the popliteal and femoral veins  indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). There were no signs of any peripheral arterial disease on angiography. Echocardiography and pulmonary angiogram were normal ruling out any pulmonary embolism.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was hospitalized and treated with Unfractionated Heparin (UFH) initially and then overlapped with Warfarin. Tear hose was initiated for compression. Regular lab monitoring and follow-ups were encouraged. Her insulin was adjusted to maintain sugar in the desired range  and blood pressure was managed appropriately. After a course of seven days  her symptoms started to decrease. She was counseled regarding the importance of regular follow-ups  lifestyle modifications  and the necessity for compliance with medication. She was discharged with advice for a regular checkup and further evaluation.   Discussion:  The long duration of the recent car journey  without moving around may have contributed to the occurrence of a DVT  given the patient's existing co-morbidities leading to a hypercoagulable state. Education about the need for ambulation during long transit is necessary for such patient categories.   This case demonstrates the importance of evaluating for DVT in patients with unexplained extremity pain and swelling  especially in the setting of known risk factors such as prolonged immobility  obesity  advanced age  diabetes  and hypertension.

Title: Case Report on Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 58-year-old Woman with a History of Long-Distance Travel and Oral Contraceptive Use   Patient Information:   The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian female who presented with a two-day history of progressive left leg pain and swelling. She has a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 26.5 kg/m2 and works as a software consultant  which requires her to sit for prolonged periods of time. Her lifestyle involves little physical activity. Mrs. H is a smoker and has been taking oral contraceptives for 20 years due to severe menstrual symptoms. She had recently returned from a long-haul flight from Australia to the United States.  Clinical Finding:   On examination  the left leg was swollen and tender along the distribution of the femoral vein. There was warmth on palpation but no visible redness. Homan’s sign was positive on the left side. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable. Her heart rate was 88 beats per minute  blood pressure was 130/80 mmHg  respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 97% on room air.  Diagnostic Assessment:   A complete blood count showed slight leukocytosis (White Blood Cells- 11 000/µL) but no other abnormalities. Coagulation parameters were within normal limits. A venous duplex ultrasound was performed on her lower extremities  which showed acute thrombosis of the left femoral vein.   Therapeutic Intervention:   Anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) was started. The patient was transitioned to an oral anticoagulant  rivaroxaban  to be taken for six months. The patient was advised to stop using oral contraceptives and to cease smoking.   Follow-Up and Outcomes:   At one month follow-up  the patient reported significant reduction in the leg pain and the swelling. A follow-up ultrasound done at 3 months showed resolution of the clot in the femoral vein. She has quit smoking and has switched from oral contraceptives to a non-hormonal method of birth control.   Patient Perspective:   ""The whole episode was scary  but I am relieved to see the improvement now. I have decided to quit smoking and realized how important it is to move around especially when I am sitting for long hours during work.""  Discussion:  This case highlights the importance of recognizing risk factors for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  such as long haul travel  oral contraceptive use  sedentary lifestyle  and smoking. Patient education on modifiable risk factors is essential for prevention and management of DVT. It also brings attention to the necessity of early recognition and treatment of DVT to prevent complications such as post-thrombotic syndrome and Pulmonary Embolism (PE).

Title: Acute Onset of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Female  Patient Information: Mrs. S.  a 52-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department out-of-the-blue with complaints of acute onset swelling and pain in her left lower limb. She reported no history of trauma  injury  or recent surgical procedures.   Medical History: She has a known history of Stage 2 Hypertension  which is being managed with a beta-blocker (Metoprolol). Her BMI was recorded at about 30  indicating obesity. Mrs. S. is a former cigarette smoker and quit around 3 years ago. She does not consume alcohol and does not have any known drug allergies.   She also has a significant family history as her father and grandmother both experienced episodes of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and her mother had a stroke in her early 70s.  Clinical Findings and Diagnostics: On physical examination  her left leg was significantly more swollen  erythematous  warm to touch  with mild tenderness than her right leg. Ultrasound Doppler investigation of the left lower limb confirmed a thrombus lodged in the left popliteal vein  and signs of acute DVT. Coagulation panels were unremarkable  and Basic Metabolic Panel findings were within normal range.  Treatment: Considering the patient's clinical presentation and ultrasound findings  she was immediately started on a therapeutic dose of subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) as anticoagulation therapy.   Patient's Course: Over the course of a week  with consistent administration of LMWH  Mrs. S. experienced a significant decrease in pain and swelling. The patient was transitioned to oral Factor Xa inhibitor (Rivaroxaban) for long term anticoagulation. She was counseled about the importance of lifestyle modifications  including the need for weight reduction  healthy diet  and regular exercise to manage her hypertension and obesity  which would also aid in preventing recurrent DVT.  Conclusion: Management of DVT is multifactorial and requires individual assessment. This case emphasizes the importance of systematic and comprehensive risk factor evaluation and an individualized approach to prevent recurrence. Furthermore  it demonstrates that despite no triggering events  a predisposing risk factor such as a family history of DVT  along with other factors  in this case  hypertension and obesity  could result in DVT. The role of primary care physicians in recognizing potential risk factors is vital for the prompt diagnosis and management of DVT.

Title: A Case of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Postpartum Female  Patient Demographics:  - Age: 32 - Sex: Female  - Race: African American - Occupation: Office worker - Location: New Jersey  Clinical History: The patient was in good health until 2 weeks postpartum  when she started experiencing persistent pain and swelling in her right calf. The pain was dull  aching  and was more pronounced on standing and walking. There was no history of trauma  fever  constitutional symptoms  or any calf muscle cramps. The patient reported a history of three uncomplicated pregnancies with vaginal deliveries and did not have any significant medical history. She denied any family history of blood clots.  Clinical Examination: On physical examination  the patient appeared to be in mild distress due to pain. The vital signs were normal. General and systemic examination revealed no significant findings. Lower extremity examination revealed that her right calf was swollen  erythematous  and warm to touch. There was tenderness on deep palpation with a positive Homan's sign.  Investigations: Laboratory investigations revealed slightly elevated D-dimer levels. Other investigations including CBC  LFTs  RFTs  coagulation profile were within normal limits. A Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremity revealed a non-compressible right popliteal vein suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Management: She was admitted and started on subcutaneous enoxaparin. On the second day  oral anticoagulant rivaroxaban was added. Following 5 days of hospitalization  her symptoms alleviated. She was discharged on a continuing course of rivaroxaban  with follow-up appointments and instructions to observe for any signs of pulmonary embolism.  Summary: This case highlights the importance of considering a diagnosis of DVT in postpartum women presenting with unilateral leg pain and swelling. As pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state  this group has a relatively high risk of venous thrombosis. Early suspicion  prompt investigation and initiation of anticoagulant therapy can prevent complications like pulmonary embolism  and long-term sequelae such as post-thrombotic syndrome.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in A Post-Menopausal Woman with Past History of Prolonged Immobility  Patient Information: A 62-year-old Caucasian woman presented at our outpatient clinic reporting intermittent pain and noticeable swelling in her right calf over the past week. The patient  a retired office worker  lives alone and is a non-smoker with no known allergies. She is not on any form of regular medication but was taking over-the-counter painkillers for the presenting issue.  Past Medical History: The patient has a previously diagnosed history of osteoarthritis  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. She underwent a total right knee replacement surgery about a month ago. The surgery was uncomplicated  with the patient having a slightly delayed recovery due to limited mobility and difficulty adhering to postsurgical physical therapy. Besides  there is no family history of venous thromboembolism or other hematological disorders.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a moderately tender right calf with edema and erythema. The Homans sign was negative  but the prudential sign was positive. No other specific signs or symptoms were noted. The patient's blood pressure was slightly elevated  at 150/80 mmHg  and other vitals were within normal ranges.  Diagnostic Assessment: Given the degree of swelling  pain  prolonged immobilization after knee surgery  and her risk factors such as age  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension  a preliminary diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was made. A venous Doppler ultrasound of the right lower limb was ordered  which confirmed the presence of a nonocclusive thrombus in the distal femoral vein.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initiated on therapeutic low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and advised to elevate the affected leg. An elastic compression stocking was also recommended. After five days  the patient was switched to oral anticoagulation therapy (rivaroxaban) for long-term management.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: At her one-month follow-up  the patient reported significant symptom improvement with a noticeable reduction in leg swelling and pain. A repeat Doppler ultrasound confirmed the successful reduction in the size of the thrombus. Her anticoagulant therapy will be continued for three months with periodic monitoring.   Conclusions: This case underscores the importance of recognizing DVT as a potential complication in individuals with prolonged immobilization  especially post-surgically. Its prompt diagnosis and management could prevent serious complications like pulmonary embolism.
