Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-menopausal Female  Patient Information  The subject of this report is a 65-year-old Caucasian woman from rural western United States. She is single and lives alone. She is moderately active  though recently retired from her job as a schoolteacher. She is a nonsmoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Presenting Complaint  The patient presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of pain in her left lower leg  describing it as a deep throbbing pain accompanied by redness  swelling  and warmth to touch. The pain intensity progressively worsened over a period of three days prior to presentation and was not relived by over-the-counter pain medications.  Past Medical History  The patient has a significant medical history notable for obesity (BMI - 30.5 kg/m2)  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypertension  which have been adequately managed with Metformin and Losartan  respectively. She had a total abdominal hysterectomy 15 years ago due to uterine fibroids. She is not on any hormonal replacement therapies. She doesn't have any known allergies.  Investigations and Diagnosis  Her clinical presentation raised the suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Definitive diagnosis was made using the Duplex ultrasound  which revealed an extensive deep vein thrombosis in her left leg. The patient's D-dimer level was also elevated. Further investigations including chest CT angiography ruled out associated pulmonary embolism.  Treatment  Prompt treatment was initiated with anticoagulation  namely Low-Molecular-Weight Heparin (Enoxaparin). The patient was also prescribed with oral Rivaroxaban  to be taken for at least three months.  Follow up  The patient was instructed about signs of potential complications such as pulmonary embolism and asked to report immediately for emergency care in such case. She was also advised on life-style modifications including weight loss  regular exercise  and foot elevation during rest. She is now scheduled for regular follow-up visits in the clinic to monitor her progress and response to treatment.  Discussion  This case highlights the importance of early recognition and treatment of DVT in reduction of potentially deadly complications. The patient's obesity and sedentary lifestyle post-retirement  in conjunction with her diabetes and hypertension may have significantly contributed to her risk.

Case Report  Patient Information  Mr. M  a 65-years-old Caucasian male  was referred to the vascular department by his primary care provider. He is a retired mechanic  a former smoker with a 30-pack year history who quit around 10 years ago. He lives with his wife in the urban area and does not have any known allergies.  Chief Complaint  Mr. M reported an increasing discomfort in his left lower leg  describing it as a dull ongoing ache. Furthermore  he noticed progressive swelling and redness over the week.  Past Medical History  Mr. M has a history of high blood pressure and type II diabetes  both managed with medication (Metoprolol Succinate 50mg once daily and Metformin 500mg twice daily respectively.) He also had an angioplasty 5 years ago due to a heart condition.  Examination  On examination  his left lower leg was swollen  warm  and erythematous (red)  particularly on the calf area. Pitting edema was evident up to the mid-shin level. His pulses were palpable with mild difficulty due to the swelling.  Investigations  A doppler ultrasound of the left lower limb was performed  which showed evidence of a thrombus in the left femoral vein  consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Blood tests showed a D-dimer level of 4000 ng/ml (normal range 0 - 500 ng/mL)  elevated fasting glucose and cholesterol levels.  Management  The patient was immediately admitted to the hospital due to his high risk of pulmonary embolism. He was started on parenteral anticoagulation (low-molecular-weight heparin) until his next INR test. This was later switched to oral warfarin for long term anticoagulation therapy. His tobacco history was addressed and counseling was provided. His diabetes and cholesterol medication were adjusted based on his current test results.  Follow-up  In the following month  the patient reported less pain and swelling. His INR maintained within the target range (2-3 for DVT). He was regularly followed-up in the clinic with blood tests and surveillance ultrasounds. He also attended the smoking cessation and diabetic counseling sessions as advised.  Conclusion  This case underscores the necessity of promptly diagnosing and treating DVT to prevent severe complications like pulmonary embolism. With appropriate management and changes in lifestyle  Mr. M was able to recover successfully from his DVT episode.

CASE REPORT:  Patient Information:  - Gender: Female - Age: 57-years-old - Ethnicity: Caucasian  Chief Complaint: Chronic pain and swelling in left lower leg.  Presenting History: The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of significant pain and swelling in her left lower leg that has progressively worsened over the past week. The pain is described as a deep throbbing sensation that intensifies after being on her feet for long periods. The symptom is relieved partially by limb elevation. She also reported associated symptoms of mild shortness of breath but denied any chest pain or palpitations.  Past Medical History: Significant past medical history includes Hypertension controlled with Amlodipine 5mg daily and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus controlled with Metformin 500mg twice daily. The patient is a non-smoker with a BMI of 29 indicating overweight status  and her family history reveals her mother suffered from a pulmonary embolism in her late 60's.  Examination: On clinical examination  the patient’s left lower leg appeared swollen and erythematous. There was localized warmth and tenderness noted on palpation. Her vital signs were stable  with oxygen saturation of 96% at rest on room air. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations were unremarkable. No signs of ulceration or skin breakdown were observed. Homans sign was positive which is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis.  Investigations: Doppler ultrasound of the left lower limb revealed a non-compressible left popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). D-dimer levels were significantly raised. The chest X-ray appeared normal and blood tests revealed her renal and liver functions were within normal ranges.  Management: The patient was anticoagulated with subcutaneous Enoxaparin as an initial treatment and a transition to oral Rivaroxaban was initiated for long-term therapy. She was educated on the signs to monitor for worsening symptoms (chest pain  sudden breathlessness) which could suggest a pulmonary embolism. The patient’s diabetes and hypertension were managed with ongoing treatment.  Follow-up: She was advised to follow-up in the outpatient department for monitoring of her anticoagulant therapy and repeat Doppler study to assess the resolution of DVT. A weight loss plan has been recommended to help reduce her BMI and a physical therapy consultation was arranged to determine suitable leg exercises to promote blood circulation.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of promptly diagnosing and managing DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling and pain  even in the absence of major risk factors like recent surgery or active malignancy. It also underlines the necessity to monitor and manage co-morbid conditions like diabetes and hypertension which could increase the risk of DVT.

Case Report  Patient Profile:  A 65-year-old male patient  employed as an engineer  and a resident of New York City presented to the Emergency Department of our hospital. He belongs to Hispanic ethnicity and lives with his wife. He has been suffering from moderate obesity  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a former smoker and quit smoking ten years prior to this presentation. No known drug allergies were identified. His family history was significant as his father suffered from deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and myocardial infarction.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient complained of increasing pain and swelling in the left lower extremity for the past eight days. He described the pain as ‘dull and achy’ and rated it a 7 on a scale of 1-10. Additionally  he mentioned a low-grade fever and malaise. He denied any recent long-distance travels or immobility.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  vital signs were within normal limits except for mildly elevated blood pressure (145/90mmHg). His left calf was swollen  tender  warm and erythematous. Positive Homan's sign was noted. No signs of chest distress were observed. Lower extremities showed no peripheral arterial disease. Also  no varicose veins were observed. His cardiovascular and respiratory system findings were unremarkable.  Investigations:  Complete blood count revealed mild leukocytosis. D-dimer test was high  indicating a possible clot formation. To confirm the diagnosis  a Duplex ultrasound was performed which revealed an occlusive thrombus in the left femoral and popliteal veins extending to the calf veins. No other systemic involvement was noted. Coagulation screening was normal.  Assessment:  Based on the clinical presentation  positive D-dimer test and Duplex Ultrasound  the patient was diagnosed with acute left lower extremity deep vein thrombosis.  Plan of Care:  The patient was immediately started on subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin and oral anticoagulant warfarin with a monitoring plan for therapeutic INR. Compression stockings were suggested for use during the day to alleviate symptoms and prevent post-thrombotic syndrome. The patient was educated about signs of pulmonary embolism and asked to return immediately if he experienced chest pain  shortness of breath  or light-headedness.  Teaching and learning:  This case perhaps serves as a reminder of the importance of recognizing leg pain and swelling as potential signs of DVT in patients with associated risk factors such as obesity  hypertension  diabetes  family history  and advancing age. Prompt diagnosis and management can avert potentially fatal complications like pulmonary embolism.   Follow-up:  The patient was scheduled for a follow-up appointment at our anticoagulation clinic in one week.  --- This case report was written with the patient's consent. The identity of the patient is protected according to HIPAA regulations.

Patient Information:  - Age: 55 years old. - Sex: Female. - Occupation: School Teacher. - Residence: Urban. - Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Complaints: Swelling and pain in the right leg  more specifically the rear part of the leg.  Physical Examination:  Findings revealed edema and a somewhat warm right leg. The patient was in a moderate pain state  and her pain worsened when conducting some specific movements with her leg. There was no cyanosis  ulceration  varicose veins  or scar observed on the skin of the right lower extremity.  Medical History:  The patient is known case of hypertension under treatment for the past five years. It was also revealed that she has been smoking for past 30 years  with a frequency of about 8 to 10 cigarettes daily. Patient has no known history of diabetes or any other heart disease  but her mother had died of myocardial infarction at the age of 75. Coccyx fracture was observed 2 years ago  but there are no known surgeries. She is intermittently taking over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medicines for the pain and swelling in the leg for the past week. No known drug allergies.  Investigative Findings:  On conducting Doppler ultrasound  it was confirmed that deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was present in the femoral and popliteal veins in her right leg. Current blood work shows a slightly increased d-dimer level. Complete blood count  renal function tests (creatinine and urea)  and electrolyte levels were within the normal range. The coagulation profile (prothrombin time  activated partial thromboplastin time  and international normalized ratio) was also within normal limits. Her lipid profile showed high low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (160 mg/dL) and total cholesterol levels (230 mg/dL). Other blood work and ECG findings were unremarkable.  Current Medications:  - Amlodipine 5 mg per day for hypertension - NSAIDs for pain relief  Plan of Care:  The treatment plan for the patient includes parenteral anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin followed by oral anticoagulants. Considering her risk factors  smoking cessation advice was given. Diet therapy and lipid-lowering medications to control her lipid levels were also suggested. The patient was advised to wear compression stockings to avoid post-thrombotic syndrome.  Discussion:  This case report represents an instance of a patient in a high-risk category for DVT due to her age  sedentary work  smoking  and hypertensive status. Timely evaluation and management are critical in preventing severe complications  including fatal pulmonary embolism. Regular monitoring of prothrombin time and international normalized ratio is suggested during her treatment course. Further  regular check-ups are advised to assess her treatment response and DVT status. As the patient is at risk for coronary heart disease  educating her about lifestyle modifications to reduce this risk is essential.

Patient Case Report  Patient Identifier: A 58-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Complaint: Pain in the left calf  swelling  and warm skin  Medical History: The patient is hypertensive (stage-1) and has a history of previous myocardial infarction five years ago. He is a current smoker (25 pack-years) and keeps a sedentary lifestyle. He also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases with both parents dying from heart stroke in their late 50s. There is no history of any drug or alcohol abuse. He is also diagnosed with obesity with a body mass index (BMI) of 34. The patient's presumed exposure to risk factors includes prolonged immobility due to frequent long-distance travels for work.  Examinations & Investigations: Physical examination revealed left lower leg swelling and redness  tenderness on palpation  and raised local temperature. Lab results showed prolonged PT (Prothrombin Time) and aPTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) as well as elevated D-Dimer levels  indicating a probable blood clot. Ultrasound of the left leg showed a non-compressible left popliteal vein which is highly suggestive of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Differential Diagnoses:  Cellulitis  calf muscle tear  Baker's cyst  Peripheral Artery Disease  Treatment: This patient was treated with a therapeutic dose of Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) followed by oral anticoagulation therapy (Warfarin) for the long-term to prevent recurrent DVT and pulmonary embolism. He was also advised to elevate his leg to reduce swelling and was given graduated compression stockings. Lifestyle modification  smoking cessation  and weight loss were also advised to better manage his hypertension and prevent any potential cardiometabolic risk.  Outcome: Patient followed up after 1 month with reduced leg swelling and pain. However  he continued to struggle with smoking cessation and weight loss. Hence  he was referred to dieticians and psychologists for further management.  Learning Points: Early diagnosis and management of DVT are crucial to prevent fatal complications like Pulmonary Embolism. A sedentary lifestyle and smoking remain significant modifiable risk factors for DVT. The case underscores the importance of a comprehensive approach involving drug therapy  lifestyle modifications  and psychological commitment in the long-term management of such conditions. Medical practitioners should monitor such patients closely for effective treatment and prevention of any potential complications.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 68-year-old Female: A Case Report  I. Demographic Information: The patient  Ms. A  is a 68-year-old Caucasian female. She is a retired teacher and leading a sedentary lifestyle. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. Her BMI is 28 indicating overweight. She lives alone as a widow and is reliant on relatives for social support.  II. Past Medical History: In the past  the patient reported a history of hypertension for which she is on medication (amlodipine 5 mg once daily). Additionally  she has a known history of type-2 diabetes mellitus for the past ten years  managed with metformin (500 mg twice daily). Her medical history also reveals a prior hospitalization for pneumonia five years ago. She has also been operated for a left hip replacement four years ago due to arthritis.  III. Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with a two days history of sustained pain  redness  and swelling in her left lower limb. She complained of increased warmth over the same area. The patient also mentioned a slight shortness of breath.  IV. Clinical Findings: On physical examination  she had a pulse rate of 98 bpm  blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  respiration rate of 22 breaths/min  and a temperature of 37.1°C (98.78°F). Her left lower leg was swelling with a noticeable increase in its circumference compared to the right. Her skin color in the area was erythema  warm and tender  also eliciting Homans' sign. Her respiratory system examination revealed mild tachypnea but no other abnormalities.  V. Diagnostic Assessment: A complete blood count showed a slightly raised D-dimer  elevated ESR  and CRP. An ultrasound of her lower limb confirmed the presence of a clot in the left femoral vein supporting the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. A chest X-ray was performed to rule out pulmonary embolism.  VI. Therapeutic Intervention: Treatment was initiated with anticoagulants in the form of low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) and oral warfarin. She was also advised to elevate her legs regularly  wear compression stockings  and increase mobility as her condition improved.  VII. Follow-Up and Outcome: A three-month follow-up showed the patient had adhered to her medication schedule and lifestyle modifications. She reported a markedly reduced leg swelling and pain. Her oral anticoagulant was adjusted based on her INR values. She also had instruction on the warning signs of pulmonary embolism.  This case is an example of deep vein thrombosis in a senior patient with multiple comorbidities. The patient’s adherence to her therapeutic regimen positively impacted her prognosis  underlining the importance of patient education in managing such conditions.

Title: Recurrent Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 54-year-old Male: A Case Report  Case Presentation: A 54-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. J  presented to the emergency department with complaints of increasing discomfort  swelling  and redness in his left leg for the last 48 hours. The patient works as an accountant  a sit-down job that requires minimal physical activity. He reported no history of trauma  long-distance travel  or surgical procedures recently. He further mentioned that his leg pain gets worse when standing or walking and lays bare the difficulty he has while putting weight on the leg.   Past Medical History: Mr. J has been a smoker for three decades  consuming almost 10 cigarettes a day. His past medical records reveal a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed six years ago  hypertension for five years  and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the same left leg  five years back. He had completed treatment with Warfarin for DVT incidentally. Aside from these  he has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings: On examination  his left leg appeared swollen and reddened compared to the right leg. The Homans sign test was positive  presenting calf pain upon dorsiflexion. His pulse rate was slightly elevated  and blood pressure readings were above normal levels consistent with his history. Body mass index was 28  indicating obesity.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Complete blood count  liver function test  and renal function tests were within normal limits. D-Dimer test came back positive. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a clot in the deep veins of the patient's left lower leg  consistent with DVT.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was given a low molecular weight heparin injection  and oral Rivaroxaban was prescribed.   Mr. J was counseled about the importance of lifestyle changes  including smoking cessation  regular exercises  maintaining a balanced diet for his diabetes and hypertension  and the perilous side of prolonged sitting and inactivity at work.   Follow up: The patient was told to follow up in the outpatient clinic after a week  and regularly thereafter. He was also informed to return to the emergency department immediately if symptoms worsened or if he experienced chest pain or difficulty in breathing.   This case underscores the importance of effective secondary prophylaxis  and lifestyle modifications in managing patients with a recurrent episode of DVT  especially those with multiple risk factors like age  diabetes  hypertension  smoking and sedentary lifestyle.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in an Elderly Male with Prior History of Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus  Patient Information: Patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presenting to the emergency department with complaints of a painful  swollen  and reddish left lower extremity. He is a retired engineer  resides with his wife  and maintains a sedentary lifestyle. The patient is a former smoker and has quit smoking 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially. There is no known drug allergy.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  both being managed successfully with oral medications for the last 15 years. His hypertension is controlled under medication with lisinopril and amlodipine. His diabetes mellitus is managed with metformin. He has a sporadic record of compliance to medication and scheduled medical check-ups. There is no history of any surgeries or hospital admissions in the past  nor does he have any family history of coagulopathy.  Presenting Concerns: The patient noticed pain in the left leg five days ago  which was initially mild and progressed to severe. The pain was accompanied by swelling and redness over the past two days. There is no history of recent injuries  prolonged immobilizations  or recent long-distance travel.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the left leg appeared swollen  red  and warm with tender calf muscles. There was no evident pus or ulceration. Pedal pulses were palpable and equal in both lower extremities. Other systemic examinations were unremarkable.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: A Doppler ultrasound of the lower limb was conducted  which confirmed the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his left lower extremity. Subsequently  a D-Dimer test was performed and showed significantly elevated levels indicating a high likelihood of an active clot formation.  Other routine blood parameters  liver and renal function tests  and chest radiographs were within normal limits.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment: Treatment was initiated with low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) concurrently with oral anticoagulation therapy (warfarin). Patient’s pain and swelling started improving after 48 hours of initiation of therapy. He was educated about the importance of medication adherence and lifestyle changes to prevent morbidity associated with DVT.  Follow-up and Outcomes: After a hospital stay of one week  the patient was discharged with an instruction to continue oral anticoagulation therapy and to follow up in the thrombosis clinic. Moreover  instructions were given about the necessity of leg exercises  walking  and keeping the legs elevated when possible.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed his relief on learning about the diagnosis and seemed determined to adhere to medical and lifestyle advises.  Informed Consent: The patient was informed adequately about his condition  the need for diagnostic tests  and the benefits and risks of the prescribed treatment. He provided written consent for the management plan and case report publication.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 56-Year-Old Female Patient  Patient Information:  The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian female  who resides in an urban area in New York City  United States. She is a homemaker by occupation and does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings:  The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of progressively worsening pain and swelling in the left lower leg that had begun five days earlier. On examination  the patient’s left leg was swollen and tender on palpation  predominantly in the calf area. Her vitals on presentation were stable with a blood pressure of 130/80mmHg  pulse of 82/min  saturation of 98% on room air  and temperature of 98.6F.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension for which she takes Lisinopril 20 mg daily  and hyperlipidemia managed by Atorvastatin 40 mg daily. She reported having a recent major surgery (hysterectomy) four weeks prior due to uterine fibroids. She is overweight with a BMI of 28.7. No family history of venous thromboembolism or clotting disorders. She has no history of long-term immobility.  Diagnostic Assessment:  A two-points D-dimer test was positive with a high level of 1100 ng/mL (Normal: Up to 500 ng/ml). Further diagnostic evaluation was done using a lower extremity venous ultrasound  which revealed acute deep vein thrombosis in the left superficial femoral vein.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was admitted to the hospital and anticoagulation therapy was initiated with low molecular weight Heparin (Enoxaparin  1mg/kg subcutaneous twice daily). On the second hospital day  she was transitioned to Apixaban (10 mg oral twice daily for 7 days  then 5 mg twice daily).   Follow-up:  The patient’s condition improved significantly over the seven days in the hospital. After a successful course of treatment  patient was discharged from hospital while continuing on anticoagulation therapy with apixaban. She was advised to decrease weight  maintain activity level  and was scheduled for a follow-up appointment in one month at our anticoagulation clinic.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the risk of DVT post major surgery  particularly in a patient with co-morbid conditions such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia. It underscores the importance of early detection and treatment to prevent potential life-threatening complications like pulmonary embolism. It also emphasizes the need for prophylactic measures and early mobilization especially in post-operative and overweight patients to reduce the chances of developing deep vein thrombosis.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Male  I. Patient Information The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a history of obesity and hypertension. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack-year history  but quit approximately five years ago. He works as an accountant and leads a fairly sedentary lifestyle.   II. Chief Complaint The patient presented to our clinic with complaints of progressive left lower extremity pain and swelling for the past five days. He denied any trauma  recent surgery  long travels  history of malignancies or usage of hormone therapy.   III. Clinical Findings Upon examination  he had a swollen and tender left leg with noticeable warmth over the left calf. His right leg appeared normal. The circumference of the left calf was 4 cm more than the right one. He also had a slightly elevated pulse rate but maintained normal blood pressure. The findings pointed towards a probable case of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  IV. Timeline Five days prior to visit  the patient began experiencing an unusual discomfort behind his left knee which progressively worsened. He initially attributed it to possible strain and assessed it with over-the-counter analgesics with no relief.   V. Diagnostic Assessment A preliminary venous duplex ultrasound was conducted  which revealed non-compressibility of the left popliteal and femoral vein due to a thrombus. His D-dimer level measured 1200 ng/mL (marker of DVT; normal limit: <500 ng/mL)  signaling a possible extend of the thrombosis. Blood work showed an elevated INR (1.6)  along with marginally elevated blood glucose and cholesterol levels. To confirm  a Magnetic Resonance Venography was performed which displayed a filling defect in the left popliteal vein  thus confirming DVT.  VI. Therapeutic Intervention The patient was immediately started on an anticoagulant therapy with an initial dose of IV unfractionated Heparin and transitioned to oral Warfarin. The patient was hospitalized for monitoring and to educate on the signs and symptoms of potential pulmonary embolism.   VII. Follow-up and Outcomes Warfarin therapy continued for three months post-discharge and was monitored through regular INR checks. The follow-up venous ultrasound after three months showed near-complete resolution of the thrombus. The patient was educated about lifestyle modification including weight management  regular exercise  and a balanced diet. He was also advised to wear compression stockings to prevent reoccurrence of DVT.  VIII. Patient Perspective The patient expressed relief in understanding his condition and was compliant with his medication and lifestyle changes. He was appreciative of the continuum of care received  from diagnosis and treatment to follow-up.  IX. Informed Consent The patient provided informed consent for this case report. Identifying details of the patient were omitted to maintain confidentiality.  Final Comments: This case emphasizes the importance of early suspicion  diagnosis  and treatment of DVT  especially in patients with risk factors such as obesity  hypertension  and a sedentary lifestyle  to prevent possible fatal complications like PE.

Patient Information:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presented to the hospital with a complaint of progressive swelling and redness of his left lower extremity  associated with mild tenderness and warmth. His medical history was significant for hypertension  diabetes type II  and obesity  with a BMI of 35. He was previously a chronic smoker with a 30 pack-year history but quit smoking 10 years ago. He is a retired engineer who leads a sedentary lifestyle. The patient denied any history of recent surgery  trauma  or prolonged periods of immobilisation  and there was no familial history of clotting disorders.  Clinician’s assessment:  On physical examination  the patient's left lower extremity was visibly swollen and red compared to the right. There was tenderness along the medial thigh  and the calf was warm to touch. Distal pulses were intact in the affected limb. The overlying skin appeared normal with no visible ulcers or signs of infection. A pitting edema was observed  which was more noticeable on the left side compared to the right.   Diagnostic assessment:  Lab work  including a complete blood count  BMP  coagulation panel  and D-dimer came back normal except for an elevated D-dimer at 900 ng/ml. Ultrasound imaging confirmed the presence of a non-compressible left femoral and popliteal vein  consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Therapeutic intervention:  The patient was started on subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) 1mg/kg every 12 hours  and oral anticoagulant therapy with warfarin was initiated. In addition  he was advised to elevate the affected leg when possible and wear graduated compression stockings.  Follow-up and outcomes:  The patient's pain and swelling improved significantly after a few days of treatment. Two days later  the INR was found to be in the therapeutic range  and subcutaneous heparin was stopped. Warfarin therapy was continued  with the patient set to be discharged soon. The patient was educated on the importance of movement and lifestyle modifications  including smoking cessation  exercise  and dietary changes. A follow-up check-up was scheduled after a week in the anticoagulation clinic for INR monitoring and a vascular surgery clinic for the reassessment of DVT.  This case Highlights the risk of DVT in patients with sedentary lifestyle  obesity  and uncontrolled diabetes type II  necessitating a high index of suspicion  appropriate use of D-dimer testing  and confirmatory imaging to facilitate a timely diagnosis and treatment.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a middle-aged male: A Case report  Case Presentation:  The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian male with a chief complaint of severe pain and swelling in his lower right leg. He has an established medical history of obesity  hypertension  and a sedentary lifestyle. He is a nonsmoker and rarely consumes alcohol. His family history is significant with his mother having suffered from deep vein thrombosis (DVT) previously.  Upon examination  the patient’s right lower leg appeared swollen and erythematous  with local warmth and tenderness. Findings suggestive of a positive Homan’s sign were also evident. The rest of the patient's physical examination including cardiovascular  abdominal and respiratory systems were unremarkable.  Clinical Findings:  Considering the medical history and physical examination  the patient was suspected of having thrombosis of the lower limb veins. Doppler ultrasonography was performed  which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the right lower leg popliteal vein. Laboratory tests revealed an elevated D-dimer level of 1400 ng/mL (normal <500 ng/mL). Other laboratory findings including complete blood count  coagulation profile  kidney and liver function tests were within normal limits.  Treatment:  The patient was hospitalized  and anticoagulant therapy was initiated immediately with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin at a therapeutic dose  accompanied by oral anticoagulant warfarin.   Outcome and Follow-Up:  The severity of the patient's pain and swelling gradually diminished after three days of anticoagulant therapy. The patient was subsequently discharged on the seventh hospital day with instructions to maintain oral warfarin therapy and attend regular follow-ups for International Normalized Ratio (INR) monitoring.  Over the next six months  the patient was maintained on an INR of 2-3  managed to lose weight  developed an active lifestyle and reported no further events of venous thromboembolism.  Discussion:  This case underscores the importance of considering deep vein thrombosis in patients with unilateral leg pain and swelling  particularly in the setting of risk factors such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and a positive family history. Prompt diagnosis and initiation of anticoagulation therapy ensure a good prognosis and prevent complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 62-year-old Female Patient  Patient Information:  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian female named Mrs. A  living in New York City. She retired as a school teacher and is currently living with her husband. She quit smoking 15 years ago and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. She is not overweight (weight: 65kg  height: 165cm  BMI:23.9 kg/m2).  Clinical Presentation: Patient was brought to the emergency department by her son for severe left leg pain and swelling that had been persistently worsening over the course of three days that prior to the presentation  she had been on a 15-hour flight back to New York from Asia. She reports no trauma or injury to the area but mentions she was immobilized for most of the flight. There is no chest pain  shortness of breath  or symptoms suggesting metastasis.  Past Medical History: She has a past medical history of hypertension for which she takes low dose aspirin and lisinopril. She underwent a hysterectomy 20 years ago due to fibroids. However  she has no history of malignancy  thrombophilias  or a family history of blood clots. She has relatively active lifestyle  having done strength-training exercises regularly and having no impaired mobility. She has no known allergies.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the noticeable signs were significant edema  warmth  erythema  and tenderness along the course of the left calf  which was considerably swollen in comparison with the right leg.  Diagnostic Process: She was immediately sent for a D-dimer test  which came back positive. It was followed by a duplex ultrasound examination confirming acute deep vein thrombosis in the left popliteal and femoral veins. The patient had no signs of PE (pulmonary embolism) on subsequent chest imaging.  Therapeutic Interventions:  The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy. Subcutaneous low molecular weight Heparin was started and concurrently Warfarin was also initiated. Compression stockings were additionally applied to improve venous return.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  On her 10-day follow-up visit  she has shown good therapeutic response. The edema of the affected leg reduced considerably  and her leg pain was better. The regular INR test showed therapeutic anticoagulation levels.  Patient Perspective:  Mrs. A  initially anxious  acknowledged her relief that the condition was identified and managed promptly. She recognized the need for continued anticoagulation and regular follow-up visits.  Informed Consent:   Written informed consent was taken from the patient for the publication of this case report.  Sincerely  Dr. [Doctor’s Full Name] [Doctor’s qualifications] Department of [Department] [Name of the Hospital]

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in Middle-aged Female Patient  1. Patient Information   The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian female who presented to the emergency department complaining of increasing pain and swelling in her left leg for the past four days. She works as a receptionist leading a sedentary lifestyle. She is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. She denies any threats of trauma or hematoma to the affected area and any recent surgeries or prolonged periods of immobility.  2. Presenting Complaints  The patient reported experiencing a sudden onset of pain and swelling in her left calf. The painful area was warm  tender  and red upon examination. She rated her pain as 7/10 by the Visual Analog Scale (VAS).  3. Past Medical History   She has a history of hypertension for 10 years and is under medication (Losartan 50mg/day). She also noted that her mother had suffered from a similar leg condition in the past  suggesting a potential familial pattern.  4. Examination  On physical examination  her left calf was appreciably swollen  approximately 3 cm larger in circumference than the right. Her blood pressure was 145/90 and her BMI was in the overweight range. Pitting edema was observed in her left leg. No peripheral arterial pulses were absent.  5. Diagnostic Assessment  Laboratory testing revealed a high D-dimer level of 750 ng/mL (normal range: 0 to 250 ng/mL). A duplex ultrasound of both lower extremities was performed  which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the left posterior tibial and peroneal veins  consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  6. Treatment  The patient was started on subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) at 1mg/kg twice daily. Meanwhile  anticoagulation therapy was initiated using oral Rivaroxaban. The patient was educated on weight management and advised to practice frequent movements to promote good circulation.  7. Outcome and Follow-up  The patient returned for a follow-up visit after two weeks. Her symptoms significantly improved with decreased leg swelling and pain. She was continued on Rivaroxaban and was advised to follow-up every 3 months for regular monitoring.  In conclusion  due to her age  sedentary lifestyle  a family history of DVT  and being overweight  she was at high risk for developing DVT  exemplifying the relevance of incorporating these risk factors into regular evaluation and counseling of patients. Early diagnosis and management lead to a favorable outcome in this patient. This case underscores the importance of early recognition  diagnosis  and appropriate treatment.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 65-year-old Male with a Medical History of Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) refers to the formation of a blood clot within a deep vein  predominantly in the legs. Common risk factors include prolonged immobility  prolonged bed rest  recent surgery  cancer  oral contraceptives  and previous history of DVT.  Case presentation: A 65-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with complaints of progressive swelling and pain in his right lower leg for the past three days. The patient reported the pain as being more severe when walking and somewhat relieved with rest. He denied any recent history of trauma  surgery  long duration travels  or a sedentary lifestyle.  The patient's medical history included Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which was adequately controlled with metformin  and hypertension that was managed with losartan. He weighed around 87 kilograms and had a height of 1.75 meters (BMI: 28.4  indicating overweight). He was a former smoker and had quit smoking ten years prior. His family history was significant for myocardial infarctions in both parents.  Clinical findings: The physical examination revealed a swollen  erythematous right lower extremity that was notably warmer to touch compared to the other leg. No obvious deformity or surgical wounds were noted. A palpable cord along the line of a vein was not detected. His blood pressure was controlled at 130/80 mmHg  his heart rate was 78 beats per minute  and his oxygen saturation was within normal limits.  Diagnostic assessment: A venous duplex ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis of a proximal deep vein thrombosis in the right lower extremity. Blood investigations revealed  among other findings  increased D-dimer levels (1100 ng/ml) which is indicative of active clot degradation. His glucose and lipid profiles were moderately controlled.  Therapeutic intervention: The patient was initiated on low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin  1 mg/kg) subcutaneously twice daily and oral Rivaroxaban (15 mg twice a day). Diabetic and hypertensive medication regimen was continued.  Follow-up and outcomes: After five days of hospital stay  the patient was discharged with Rivaroxaban for six months and instructed to maintain control over diabetes and hypertension. He was informed about the signs of Pulmonary embolism and Post Thrombotic Syndrome and was advised to return immediately if any of such symptoms were noted. Follow-up visits were scheduled.  Conclusion: This case underlines the importance of early detection and treatment of deep vein thrombosis  especially in patients with risk factors such as diabetes and hypertension. Even in the absence of significant predisposing factors like immobility  obesity  or recent surgery  DVT can occur. Further attention and research are needed to enhance our understanding of the correlation between DVT  hypertension  diabetes  and other possible risk factors.

Case Report:  I. Patient Information:  - Demographics: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who is citizen and a resident of California  USA. He is living with his wife and two adult children. He is a retired mechanical engineer and a non-smoker. He reports an occasional consumption of alcohol socially.     - Past Medical History: The patient has multiple comorbidities  including Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 12 years ago  Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  Chronic Kidney Disease (Stage-3)  and a history of previous Myocardial Infarction 7 years back. His medications document metformin  lisinopril  and low-dose aspirin. He had also undergone bypass surgery post his Myocardial Infarction.  II. Presenting Complaint:  The patient reported sudden onset of sharp  non-radiating pain in his left calf for the past 48 hours. He noted visible swelling in his lower left leg  which was getting progressively worse. He did not report any trauma  injury  or recent travel where he could have been immobile for long periods.  III. Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a visibly swollen  warm  red  and tender left lower leg. The patient was vitals-stable with a slightly elevated blood pressure (145/90 mmHg). Examination of the heart and lungs were normal. However  an absent left pedal pulse was noted.   IV Laboratory Investigations:  The patient's blood investigations revealed a D-Dimer of 1500 ng/mL (Normal: <500 ng/mL)  random blood glucose levels were 190 mg/dL (Normal: 140-199 mg/dL)  and serum creatinine levels were 1.5 mg/dL (Normal: 0.6-1.2 mg/dL). Elevated D-Dimer with an increase in swelling and pain pointed towards a probable deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   V. Diagnostic Assessment:  The patient's clinical picture prompted further investigation with a Doppler Ultrasound. The ultrasound showed non-compressibility of the left posterior tibial vein and femoral vein and also a thrombus which confirmed a diagnosis of left lower limb DVT.  VI. Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was administered unfractionated heparin as an acute management strategy. Oral anticoagulation therapy with Warfarin was initiated.   VII. Follow-Up:  On a two-week follow-up  the swelling and pain had significantly reduced. He was advised to continue oral anticoagulação and follow-up regularly.  In summary  in light of the patient’s medical history and the results of his investigations  acute left lower limb DVT was diagnosed. The patient was treated initially with heparin and later switched to Warfarin. The patient was advised of the potential risks and complications  importance of adherence to the medication regimen  and follow-up appointments.   This case emphasizes the importance of prompt recognition and management of DVT in high-risk patients  including those with advanced age and multiple co-morbidities.

Case Report:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  a retired mechanic  residing in the suburbs of Denver  Colorado. He is a smoker with a 30-pack year history. He is a teetotaller and has no history of recreational or illicit drug use. He lives with his wife and has two grown children.  Presenting Issue: The patient presented to our clinic with a 3-day history of severe  progressive left leg pain and swelling. He reported no recent trauma  long distance travel  surgeries or new medications. However  he cited a recent episode of shortness of breath  which he attributed to his smoking habit.  Past Medical History: His previous medical history includes a 5-year management of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He previously had a heart attack six years ago  and a subsequent angioplasty was performed. He is regularly compliant with his medications  including metoprolol  aspirin  lisinopril  and metformin. His family history reveals that his father suffered a heart attack at age 64  and his mother had a stroke at age 75.  Clinical Examination & Investigation: On physical examination  his left calf was noted to be considerably swollen  red  and warm to the touch. His vital signs were stable with a blood pressure of 135/80 mmHg  a heart rate of 82 beats per minute  a respiratory rate of 18 per minute  and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. The calf circumference was 3 cm larger on the left side compared to the right. His distal pulses were present and equal bilaterally.  An ultrasound venous Doppler examination was done due to high clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and it confirmed the presence of acute proximal DVT in the left popliteal vein. A CT angiogram was also performed which ruled out the presence of a pulmonary embolism. His complete blood count  liver function tests  and kidney function were within normal ranges. His hemoglobin A1c level was 7.3%.  Management: The patient was admitted to the hospital for further management. As part of his treatment regimen  he was started on a heparin drip  following which he was bridged to Warfarin for long-term anticoagulation as per the hospital's DVT protocol. He was also given appropriate patient education regarding the risk factors of DVT  need for adhering to anticoagulation therapy  as well as the importance of periodic follow-up. After four days  the patient's symptoms improved considerably  and he was subsequently discharged with a plan to follow up in the outpatient clinic.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of acknowledging severe unilateral leg pain and swelling as an indicator for DVT  especially in patients with significant risk factors such as hypertension  smoking  diabetes mellitus  and past history of heart disease. It is crucial to initiate appropriate diagnostic work-up to rule out DVT to prevent grave complications like a pulmonary embolism.

Title: Acute Left Lower Extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Female with Prior Medical History of Hypertension and Diabetes  Patient Profile:  The patient is a 54-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department with symptoms of left lower leg swelling  redness  warmth and significant pain on movement. The patient reported experiencing these symptoms for the past 3 days and mild progressive worsening over time. She denied any recent long-distance travel or history of trauma.  Past Medical History:  Her past medical history is significant for hypertension which was diagnosed 10 years ago and type II diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago  both conditions are currently managed with medications. The patient is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol only occasionally. There is no history of inherited hypercoagulant states or venous thromboembolism in the family.   Evaluation and Diagnosis:  Physical examination revealed localized warmth  erythema  swelling  and tenderness over her left calf. Differential diagnosis possibilities at the point included cellulitis  hematoma  and DVT. The patient was fibrile with temperature of 100.5 F. Laboratory findings displayed slightly elevated D-dimer levels  normal platelet count  and normal activated partial thromboplastin and prothrombin times.  Further investigation via a Doppler ultrasound confirmed the clinical suspicion of DVT  showing an acute clot in the left posterior tibial and peroneal veins. Her Wells score was calculated to be 4  indicating a moderate risk for DVT.  Management and Follow-up:  The patient was admitted to the medical ward for close monitoring and was initiated on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) as per the protocol for acute DVT management. Her condition improved significantly over the course of a week.   She was discharged on oral anticoagulant Rivaroxaban with scheduled follow-up in the outpatient clinic. She was informed about the disease process  possible complications and importance of adhering to the treatment regime. The patient was also instructed to mobilize and regular exercise to enhance venous return.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of considering DVT in our differential diagnosis for patients presenting with unilateral leg pain and swelling  even in the absence of classical risk factors. An early diagnosis and initiation of anticoagulation treatment are vital in preventing complications such as pulmonary emboli.

Title: A Case Report on Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Male with History of Prolonged Immobility  Patient Description:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male who presented at the emergency department complaining of persistent pain and swelling in his left lower leg. His condition had worsened over the past week. Upon physical examination  the left calf appeared swollen  tender  and warm to touch with spots of redness and slight discoloration.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and elevated cholesterol levels. He does not smoke or consume alcohol regularly. He had been following a regimen of oral hypoglycemic agents  angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  and statins. He had a myocardial infarction five years ago  for which he underwent successful coronary artery bypass grafting. Post-surgery  he had been on aspirin therapy. His family history is significant with his father having suffered from stroke secondary to chronic hypertension.  Current Presentation: Two weeks ago  the patient had a motor vehicle accident  resulting in a left hip fracture. The patient underwent orthopedic surgery and since then had been largely immobilized  using crutches only for essential movements. At present  the patient is not experiencing any chest pain or shortness of breath.   Diagnostic Assessment: An ultra-sonogram was performed on the left leg  which revealed an occlusive thrombus in the left popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). His D-dimer test was positive  further suggesting the presence of a clot. There were no abnormalities detected on chest x-ray or ECG.   Clinical Course: Given the diagnosis  the patient was immediately started on parenteral anticoagulant therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin and bridged to warfarin for long-term prevention of thrombus propagation. He was also advised to use compression stockings and encouraged to mobilize as much as pain allowed under monitoring.   Conclusion: The patient's post-orthopedic surgery immobilization  combined with his pre-existing cardiovascular risk factors  significantly increased his risk of developing DVT. The management of DVT requires prompt diagnosis and effective anticoagulant therapy. This case highlights the importance of vigilant monitoring for thrombotic complications in immobilized patients  especially those with additional risk factors.

Patient Information  Mr. J  a 68-year-old retired male builder  native to Minnesota  USA  currently residing in a suburban area with his wife. He is a non-smoker and a casual drinker.  Presenting Complaint  He attended the ER complaining of acute  progressive left leg pain and swelling over the previous two days  mainly in his calf area. Furthermore  he stated that he felt a light ‘cramp-like’ discomfort while walking.   Medication History  He is on medication for hypertension with 10 mg lisinopril once a day and type 2 diabetes mellitus with 500 mg metformin twice a day. He also mentioned an occasional use of over-the-counter ibuprofen for decision-dependent arthritic pain.   Social History  He leads a rather sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity and follows an average diet. He reported no recent air travel  prolonged immobilisation or illnesses. He had a history of a fracture in his left tibia two decades back which was managed by a cast.  Physical Examination  Physical findings were largely unremarkable except for a notable difference in the size of the calves: the left being considerably larger than the right. The left calf appeared erythematous and somewhat warm to touch. The popliteal pulse was present but weak compared to the right side. Neurological examination showed nothing extraordinary.  Investigative Findings  Upon suspicion of deep vein thrombosis  a Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities was ordered  which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the left popliteal vein with restricted blood flow. Lab tests reported an elevated D-dimer level at 900 ng/mL (normal range: less than 500 ng/mL). He had no sufficient signs of progressive renal impairment to contra-indicate CT pulmonary angiography  which showed no evidence of pulmonary emboli.  Management and Outcome  Initial phase was managed by Anticoagulant therapy (Apixaban 10 mg twice daily for seven days  followed by 5 mg twice daily). During the hospital stay  his symptoms gradually improved  and repeat Doppler ultrasound after a week showed a marked reduction in thrombus size. The patient was discharged after 10 days with an advised daily dose of apixaban 2.5 mg twice a day for six months and a recommendation to maintain a healthy lifestyle.  Conclusion  This case underscores the importance of considering deep vein thrombosis in patients presenting with unspecific leg pain  irrespective of the absence of traditional risk factors. Early diagnosis and appropriate treatment can effectively manage the disease and prevent complications  such as pulmonary emboli. It re-emphasizes the value of comprehensive history taking and physical examination when dealing with such non-specific presentations.  Note: Any resemblance in the above case report to actual persons  living or dead  is purely coincidental. This report is a hypothetical construct for demonstrating the template for a medical case report. It does not include individual patient data or identifiable patient characteristics.

Patient Information:   Abstract: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  presented with a three-day history of severe left leg pain and progressive swelling.  Patient description: The patient is overweight weighing 96kg with a height of 5'10'' resulting in a BMI of 30. He is a former smoker  having quit 5 years prior. The patient has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. There are also familial predispositions to cardiovascular complications  with his father passing away from myocardial infarction and a brother diagnosed with peripheral artery disease.   Chief Complaint: The patient reported severe  persistent left leg pain initially assumed to be due to his chronic osteoarthritis but which had since progressed unusually. He also informed about a significant increase in the size of his left calf over the course of 3 days. There was no prior history of trauma.   Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a visibly enlarged  erythematous and warm left calf compared to the right. There was tenderness on palpation from the calf to the thigh. The patient’s left calf circumference was 5 cm greater than the right one. The superficial veins were dilated. There was no evidence of surface ulcers. Pedal pulses were palpable but reduced in the left compared to the right  and there was a slight reduction in sensation in the left foot.   Diagnostic Assessment: The Wells criteria for deep vein thrombosis was used  and the patient scored a 3  indicating a high likelihood of DVT. A Doppler Ultrasound was immediately ordered which revealed a thrombus in the left femoral and popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Blood investigations showed raised D-dimer levels. His blood sugar levels were elevated  and so was the blood pressure  handling his hypertension and diabetes mellitus.  Therapeutic Intervention: Anticoagulation therapy was initiated immediately with intravenous unfractionated heparin. After stabilizing the patient  he was shifted onto oral anticoagulation (Warfarin) therapy and was advised weight reduction  calf muscle exercises and to use compression stockings.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Patient's pain and swelling started reducing after four days of anticoagulation therapy. He was discharged with advice to continue on oral anticoagulation  manage his diabetes  and control his BP. He was also recommended a follow-up after two weeks to monitor his PT/INR levels due to Warfarin therapy.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed relief with the therapy outcome and resolved to follow the treatment plan  including lifestyle modifications seriously.  Informed Consent: The patient consented to reporting of his case for academic and research purposes.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 73-year-old Male   Patient Information  Demographic data: A 73-year-old Caucasian male patient  retired engineer  non-smoker with moderate physical activity levels  residing in an urban area.  Presenting Concerns: The patient arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of a dull ache and swelling in his left leg  which was red and warm to touch. The symptoms had been progressively worsening over the past two days. He also reported having occasional shortness of breath.  Medical History: The patient has a known history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus (DM) for 20 years  managing it with dietary control and oral hypoglycemic agents. His most recent HbA1c reading was 7.2. Additionally  he has been hypertensive for the past 8 years  currently managed via a beta-blocker and a diuretic. He underwent a total knee arthroplasty five weeks ago for osteoarthritis and had a slightly complicated post-op period with prolonged immobilization. Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease; his father died from myocardial infarction at age 62. He denies any previous episodes of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE).   Clinical Examination: Physically  the patient appeared stressed and in moderate discomfort. Height 170 cm  weight 82kg  BMI 28.4 indicating the patient is overweight. Vital signs read as follows: Blood Pressure - 145/90mmHg  Pulse - 92 beats per minute  Respiration rate - 20 breaths per minute  Temperature - 98.4°F. The left lower limb was visibly swollen and reddish compared to the right. Upon palpation  the limb was warm and tender along the course of the posterior tibial and popliteal veins. Homan's sign (pain in the calf upon dorsiflexion of the foot) was positive.   Investigation Findings: An Ultrasound Doppler of the left lower limb revealed a thrombus in the femoral vein  confirming the diagnosis of DVT. D-dimer levels are significantly elevated. Complete blood count  kidney function test  and blood glucose levels were within the acceptable range for the patient's existing DM condition. Nonspecific T-wave inversion noted on EKG.  Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with Left Lower Limb Deep Vein Thrombosis.  Initial Plan: Immediate anticoagulant therapy was commenced with intravenous Heparin  with a plan to switch to oral Warfarin. A referral was made to the clinical pharmacist for necessary dosage adjustments and monitoring therapy. Physiotherapy consultation was sought for limb elevation  compression stockings and to understand exercises to improve venous return. Lifestyle modification strategies and dietary advice was initiated considering obesity  hypertension  and diabetes.  Long Term Plan: The patient will need a repeat Doppler post completion of anticoagulation treatment. Diabetes  hypertension and weight management will need to be intensified with medication review and lifestyle modifications. Patient education on symptom recognition for possible PE is critical. This patient should be closely followed considering his high risk for recurrent DVT or PE.   This case highlights the significance of recognizing DVT in patients who have recently undergone orthopedic surgical procedures  especially coupled with other risk factors like prolonged immobilization  age  hypertension  diabetes  and a family history of cardiovascular disease. Timely treatment is vital to mitigate severe complications  including PE  which could prove fatal.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Profile:  Name: Not provided due to confidentiality reasons Age: 52 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Engineer  Presenting Complaint:  The patient came in with a new onset of right leg swelling and pain for the last two days. The pain was described as constant and aggravated by movements  with a rating of 7/10 on the severity scale. There is no history of similar symptoms in the past. He also reported sitting long hours at his work desk and recently a long-haul flight with minimal leg movement.  Past Medical History: The patient is known to have hypertension which is controlled by antihypertensive medications. He had a myocardial infarction two years ago and recovered well post angioplasty.  Social History: The patient is a non-smoker  occasional alcohol drinker and does not use any illicit drugs.  Clinical Examination:  On examination  the right leg appeared swollen and red  with a circumference 3 cm more than the left leg. Shortness of breath or chest pain on palpation was not observed. Veins appeared distended with the limb slightly warmer than the left leg. A Homans' sign was positive.  Investigations: A Duplex ultrasound showed thrombus formation in the deep veins of the right leg. Blood tests including a D-dimer assay was positive for the breakdown of fibrin clots. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) was done to rule out any potential new onset myocardial ischemia.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical features  patient history and investigation results the diagnosis of unprovoked deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the right leg was made.  Treatment and Outcome: The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy with heparin and bridged to warfarin. He was advised leg elevation and the use of compression stockings. He was educated regarding the signs of pulmonary embolism  a potential complication of DVT  which he was to report immediately. On one-month follow-up  the patient had a significant reduction in leg swelling and pain  and no incidences of pulmonary embolism were reported.  This case highlights the importance of immediate attention and treatment in patients presenting with symptoms of DVT. The patient's sedentary lifestyle and profession may have contributed to the unprovoked DVT  hence lifestyle modification and regular exercises were advised to reduce the risk of recurrence.   Addressing DVT early can minimize the risks of complications like pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome  thereby improving patient's quality of life.

Patient Case Report - Deep Vein Thrombosis  Demographics: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker  regular alcohol consumption  residing in an urban area with his wife. He is an insurance consultant  leading a sedentary work lifestyle.  History of Present Illness: The patient was presented to the emergency department with a three-day history of progressing right lower leg swelling and pain. No history of fever  calf tenderness  erythema or any significant traumatic injuries. He also reported recent long-haul air travel. No symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath or syncopal episodes were reported.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension under medication (ACE inhibitors) for the past five years. He also has hyperlipidemia and a family history of cardiovascular disease. There is no history of diabetes  renal disease  or any clotting disorders. He was put on oral anticoagulants for three months after a knee replacement surgery ten years ago.   Family History: The patient has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father suffered a stroke at the age of 70 and his mother suffered from irregular heart rhythm diagnosed late in life.  Examination and Investigation: On examination  the right calf appeared swollen  warmer  and erythematous. Pulses were palpable bilaterally  but there was notable tenderness in the affected leg. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed a thrombus in the right popliteal and femoral veins demonstrating Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Complete blood count demonstrated a normal platelet count  but there was a noticeable elevation of D-dimer (2000 ng/ml). Coagulation function tests were normal  but the lipid profile was mildly deranged.   Management and Follow-up: The patient was hospitalized and got started on low molecular weight heparin along with continuation of his hypertensive medication. After two days of stabilization  he was transitioned to oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban  recommended for at least three months. Lifestyle modifications  including a low-salt  low-fat diet  regular exercise and avoidance of long sedentary periods were encouraged.   The patient's condition improved over subsequent days  and he was discharged home with a follow up scheduled in one month. The prolonged anticoagulation treatment and lifestyle changes are anticipated to reduce recurrence and complications associated with DVT.  This case underlines the importance of awareness of DVT  especially when patients have risk factors including long-distance travel  sedentary lifestyle  or previous surgery. Costly and serious complications can be prevented with prompt diagnosis and management.

Title: A Case Report of a 54-Year-Old Male with Unilateral Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Information: Mr. J.D.  a 54-year-old Caucasian male patient  was admitted to the hospital with severe  unilateral calf pain and noticeable swelling of the lower extremity reported to have started three days before hospitalization.  Medical History: Mr. J.D. is living a sedentary lifestyle with a poor diet  leading to obesity with a BMI of 32. He is a chronic smoker with a 30 pack-year smoking history. He has a medical history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus established seven years back and Hypertension for which he has been taking metformin and lisinopril respectively. He reported no known drug allergies.  Presenting Complaints: His presenting complaints were swelling  pain and tenderness in his left calf which started suddenly while he was walking. The pain was constant  sharp in nature and rated as 8 on a pain scale of 10. The patient also mentioned a slight difficulty in breathing and occasional bouts of lightheadedness.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  his left calf was noticeably swollen and warm to touch with noticeable redness. His vital signs were measured; Blood Pressure: 145/90 mmHg  Pulse: 105 bpm  Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths per min  Temperature: 98.7 ºF. His peripheral pulses were intact  and no ulcers were found in the lower extremities.  Diagnostic Assessment: Based on his medical history and presenting symptoms  a working diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) was set. The Wells Score was calculated to be 3  indicating moderate probability of DVT. Duplex ultrasonography was immediately performed confirming the presence of a thrombus in the left popliteal vein. A prompt D-dimer test was conducted which resulted in an elevated level of 1300 ng/mL  supporting the ultrasound findings. There were no signs of lung involvement as per the chest x-ray findings.  Therapeutic Intervention: Treatment began immediately with Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) enoxaparin. The patient was started on a drug regimen of anticoagulants  followed by oral administration of warfarin. He was counseled regarding the importance of drug adherence due to the high risk of thrombus dislodgement and potential pulmonary embolism  which can be life-threatening.   Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient was scheduled for a follow-up visit one week later  and then every month for the next six months  to monitor the international normalized ratio (INR) and respond to any present complications. On the first follow-up  the patient reported reduced swelling and pain  indicating effective treatment.  Patient Perspective: ""I am well informed about my condition and the importance of adhering to my medication. I am grateful for the prompt intervention  which has significantly reduced my condition's discomfort.""  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying images.   This case highlights the importance of high clinical suspicion and urgent diagnosis in patients with high-risk factors and symptoms suggestive of DVT  coupled with the importance of patient lifestyle modifications.

Title: A Case Report of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in a 68-Year-Old Diabetic Male Patient  Presentation and Case Details:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with complaints of pain and swelling in his right lower limb. He reported that the symptoms have been developing since three days ago  and the pain has been progressively worsening  making it difficult for him to walk.  This patient had a history of type II diabetes mellitus  diagnosed around 15 years ago  and managed with oral hypoglycemic agents (metformin). His latest glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) reading  taken 2 months ago  was 7.2. He also has a 10-year history of hypertension but has been non-compliant with antihypertensive medication (lisinopril) intake for the last six months. The patient used to smoke but quit ten years ago. His BMI on presentation was 29.5 kg/m^2.   On examination  his right lower limb was visibly swollen. Palpation revealed a painful  warm and tender calf muscle. The Homans' sign was positive  indicating possible DVT. His blood pressure was 155/90 mmHg  heart rate was 84 beats/min and the respiratory rate was 16 breaths/min.   Investigations and Treatment:  The D-dimer test was positive. Given the high clinical suspicion of DVT  a duplex ultrasound was conducted which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in his right popliteal vein. Complete blood count  coagulation profile  and other test results were within normal range. ECG showed no acute changes.   The patient was admitted to the medical ward and was initiated on subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) as per DVT management guidelines. He was concurrently continued on his oral hypoglycemic medications and was restarted on his antihypertensive medication.   Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient responded well to the LMWH therapy  with a reduction in his right lower limb pain and swelling. He was trained on self-administration techniques of LMWH injections and discharged from the hospital on the fifth day of the admission. He was advised to continue treatment with LMWH and was scheduled for regular follow-ups.  This case illustrates the importance of DVT suspicion in patients with significant risk factors such as age  diabetes  hypertension  obesity  and medication non-compliance. The patient's delay in seeking medical attention  as well as non-compliance to antihypertensive treatment  would have contributed to his DVT development. It is essential for medical practitioners to maintain a high degree of suspicion for potentially life-threatening conditions like DVT in patients with similar risk factors.  Keywords: Deep vein thrombosis; diabetes mellitus; hypertension; case report.

Case Report - Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Details: A 58-year-old Caucasian male  residing in the suburbs of New York  was referred to the vascular clinic at our institution. The patient is a non-smoker but has a history of occasional alcohol consumption. He has an active lifestyle involving frequent travel for business purposes. He is married  has two children  and works as a financial consultant.  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for obesity (BMI 31.5)  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which has been managed with oral hypoglycemic agents for the past 10 years. He denies any history of heart disease  stroke  or previous thromboembolic events. He has no known allergies and no significant family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or other clotting disorders.  Present Illness: The patient presented with complaints of a swollen  red and warm right leg  which he noticed three days ago. He reported progressive discomfort and pain in the leg. He denied any history of recent trauma or surgery to either leg. He also reported a feeling of heaviness and aching  particularly after long periods of sitting. No other symptoms such as shortness of breath  chest pain  cough  or fever were reported.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the right leg was indeed swollen compared to the left  with the highest circumference difference of approximately 3 cm. Local warmth and erythema were noticed  but no ulcers or skin changes. His vital signs were stable but a mild tachycardia was observed at 101 bpm. No cranial nerve abnormalities were detected.  Investigations: Laboratory investigations revealed a slight increase in D-dimer at 0.7μg/mL (normal <0.5μg/mL). Other labs including CBC  CMP  PT  and INR were within normal limits. Ultrasonography of the right leg showed a non-compressible segment suggestive of thrombosis within the right popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of DVT.   Clinical Course & Outcome: Treatment initiated with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin. The patient was also advised to wear compression stockings and to elevate the affected limb whenever possible. On outpatient follow-up after four weeks  the patient reported significant relief of symptoms. Repeated ultrasound revealed resolution of the thrombus.  Summary: This patient with multiple risk factors for DVT  including obesity  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presented with typical symptoms of DVT. The diagnosis was confirmed using ultrasonography and responded well to treatment with anticoagulants and supportive care. His case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and timely management of DVT to prevent severe complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Case Report: A Case of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 57-Year-Old Female  Patient Information:  The patient is a 57-year old Caucasian female presenting with persistent calf pain in her left lower limb for over a week. She has a known history of type II diabetes and hypertension for which she has been taking medication including gliclazide and amlodipine  respectively. She is a non-smoker and is reported to be moderate alcohol consumer. Her body mass index (BMI) measures at 29kg/m^2 signifying overweight status  and her family history is significant for venous thromboembolism  with her mother having suffered recurrent deep vein thrombosis. The patient has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient's left leg appeared swollen and was tender to touch  predominantly in the calf muscle. Physical examination also revealed a slightly elevated temperature of 37.8°C  while blood pressure and heart rate readings were consistent with her hypertensive history. Through the use of Wells Criteria for DVT  she scored 3 which marks her as high probability.    Diagnostic Assessment:  A D-dimer test ordered was found to be highly positive  a key marker suggestive of a hypercoagulable state. Doppler ultrasonography confirmed the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis demonstrating an incompressible segment in the left popliteal vein. No superficial venous thrombosis was recorded.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately anticoagulated under the guidance of the local thrombosed protocol using low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) at a therapeutic dose as initial treatment. Whilst in hospital  she was educated on the importance of leg elevation and wearing compression stockings to improve pain and swelling. The patient was transitioned onto oral anticoagulant  rivaroxaban. She was recommended to follow up with a hematologist for further evaluation of the hypercoagulable state identified and the potential need for long-term anticoagulation. The patient was also referred to a dietician considering her overweight status.   Follow-Up and Outcomes:  She attended a 4-week post-discharge appointment where she reported a significant reduction in pain and improvement in her movements. Her repeat doppler ultrasound also showed significant resolution of the clot. She continues to be under the care of the hematologist and is tolerating rivaroxaban well. Being content with her weight loss following dietary intervention  she is more enthusiastic about managing her health conditions.
