This case underscores the importance of considering venous thromboembolism even in subtle clinical presentations  particularly in patients with prominent risk factors  such as family history of DVT  obesity  and current treatment with medications which could pose a risk for DVT. Early detection and appropriate anticoagulant treatment remain key in managing this condition.

Title: A Case Report of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Female Patient with a History of Prolonged Immobility  Case Report:  Patient Information: Ms. X is a 52-year-old Caucasian female who presented to the emergency room with a two-day history of pain and swelling in her left lower limb. She is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic with no history of illicit drug usage. Her body mass index (BMI) is 25.4  indicating she falls within the overweight range.  Clinical Findings: The patient reported increasing pain and difficulty in walking due to the swelling in her lower leg. The limb had become noticeably redder and warmer to touch. She denied any associated chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or fevers.   History: She had undergone a total hip replacement surgery six weeks prior due to severe osteoarthritis  following which she had been primarily bedridden  with limited movement. Her family history is significant for ischemic heart disease and hypertension  but no genetic or acquired thrombophilic conditions were reported.  Physical Examination: On inspection  the left leg was visibly swollen and hyperemic compared to the right. Palpation revealed that the swelling was warm and tender to touch. There were no visible varicose veins. The patient's vital signs were stable  with a blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg  heart rate of 88 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air.  Diagnosis: The clinical presentation and patient's history of prolonged immobilization raised suspicion for deep vein thrombosis. It was confirmed through a Doppler ultrasound that demonstrated a deep vein thrombosis in the left popliteal vein.   Therapeutic Intervention & Follow-up: The patient was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) as a bridge to oral anticoagulant therapy  which was initiated the following day. Physiotherapy was also initiated to improve mobility. The patient was educated on the importance of mobility and using compression stockings to prevent recurrence.   On follow up after four weeks  the patient reported a marked improvement in the symptoms  and repeat Doppler ultrasound demonstrated a reduction in the size of the clot. She is due for another follow-up appointment in two months.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis in patients with prolonged immobility  such as post-operative patients  to prevent potentially life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism. Furthermore  it illustrates the crucial role of early recognition  appropriate treatment  and patient education in managing DVT.

Patient Information: Ms. AB  a Caucasian female  aged 64  presented to the clinic. She is retired and lives independently. No history of tobacco use or alcohol abuse. Medical history revealed that she had been diagnosed with hypertension two years ago and is on treatment with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors. She also had a subsequent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus a year ago  controlled with Metformin.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient reported progressive  painful swelling in her left lower limb for the past week. She had not experienced any recent trauma or injury. She also reported warmth over the swollen area  redness  and mild fever but no shortness of breath or chest pain.  Physical Examination and Investigations: The examination revealed a pitting edema on her left leg with skin discoloration. The left calf was tender. No superficial varicosities were seen. Homans sign was positive in the left leg. There is no superficial vein dilation or streaking. Laboratory investigations showed an elevated D-dimer test. A doppler ultrasound confirmed a non-compressible left common femoral vein suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Treatment: She was immediately started on anticoagulants  low-molecular-weight-Heparin (LMWH) and advised to elevate the limb and apply warm compresses. After five days of Heparin therapy  she was placed on an oral anticoagulant  Warfarin  with the plan to maintain INR between 2 and 3. The patient was counseled on the importance of medication compliance  regular follow-up visits  and lifestyle adjustment.  Discussion: The patient's history of hypertension and diabetes might have escalated the likelihood of DVT as vascular disorders were more prevalent amongst these patients. Further evaluations are necessary to ascertain if there is any underlying malignancy as there was no clear predisposing risk factor for DVT in her case such as recent surgery  long travel  genetic disorder  etc. A subsequent review of the medication regimen for her hypertension and diabetes will also be required.  In this case  prompt diagnosis assisted by D-dimer and Doppler studies  followed by early anticoagulation therapy  was essential to prevent possible complications such as pulmonary embolism. This case stresses the importance of recognizing the classical symptoms of DVT  early diagnostic investigations  and appropriate management.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 65-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  I. Introduction   This case report clinical study chronicles a 65-year-old Caucasian male with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Information regarding full demographic  past medical history  current medical investigation  diagnosis  treatment  and progress are shared in this report.   II. Patient Information   A 65-year-old Caucasian male presented to our outpatient clinic with complaints of progressive swelling and discomfort in the left leg spanning approximately 5-days. The patient is a retired engineer  a current smoker (averaging 1 pack daily for about 40 years)  and drinks socially. His BMI was measured at 28.5 kg/m²  indicating overweight status.   III. Clinical Findings  On physical examination  the left lower limb was significantly swollen and warm to touch  with an evident color change to a purplish hue  especially in the calf region. While the patient reported no chest pain or shortness of breath  he experienced discomfort in the swollen leg region.  IV. Medical History   The patient has a past medical history significant with hypertension and hyperlipidemia since 2009 and was undergoing treatment with Losartan and Atorvastatin  respectively  with regular follow-ups. He had a surgical history of a hernia repair done 10 years ago.   V. Timeline  The patient’s timeline was approximately as follows: • 5 days before clinic visit: Patient started experiencing swelling in his left leg • Day of clinic visit: Patient presented to the clinic for evaluation  VI. Diagnostic Assessment  A Doppler ultrasound of the left lower limb was conducted  which identified a deep vein thrombosis in the left popliteal vein. Hematologic investigations were largely normal apart from slight elevation in D-Dimer levels.   VII. Therapeutic Intervention  Given the patient’s medical history and current condition  anticoagulant therapy was initiated using low molecular weight heparin  transitioning to oral Warfarin therapy with close INR monitoring for maintaining between 2 and 3. The patient was also advised to wear compression stockings and elevate his leg when sitting and sleeping.  VIII. Follow-Up and Outcomes  During a follow-up visit after two weeks  the patient's symptoms had significantly reduced. He reported a reduction in swelling  pain  and discomfort. INR was in range and medication regimen with Warfarin was continued.   IX. Patient Perspective  The patient was relieved that non-invasive therapy effectively managed the condition. He was glad that the early presentation prevented any possible complications like a pulmonary embolism.  X. Conclusion and Learning Points  This case highlights the importance of rapid diagnosis and management of DVT to prevent serious complications. Even in the outpatient setting  DVT should be promptly suspected when a patient presents with typical signs and symptoms  especially in high risk groups such as the elderly and those with a history of hyperlipidemia and hypertension.   Informed consent: Informed consent for this case report was obtained from the patient.

Case Report  Patient Profile  A 67-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency room with a two-day history of pain and discomfort in his left calf. The patient also reported mild swelling  redness  and warmth over the affected area. No history of recent travel  surgery  trauma  or prolonged immobility was noted. He has a 30-year history of smoking one pack per day but quit six years ago. His other past medical history includes hypertension controlled in the medication lisinopril and hyperlipidemia treated with atorvastatin. The patient denied having any known allergies. He follows a sedentary lifestyle and works as an accountant.  Clinical Examination  On physical examination  the left calf was mildly swollen with erythema  warmth  and the patient reported pain on passive dorsiflexion of the foot. No inguinal lymphadenopathy was noted. The patient was afebrile with normal heart rate  blood pressure  and respiratory rate. Pedal pulses were palpable bilaterally. No other abnormal signs were found during the rest of the systemic examination.  Investigations  Laboratory investigations were ordered  and results were as follows: Complete blood count  renal function test  liver function tests were within normal limits. Coagulation profile revealed a marginally elevated D-dimer value at 0.6 mg/L FEU (reference: <0.5mg/L FEU).  An ultrasound Doppler study was requested and revealed an intraluminal filling defect in the left posterior tibial vein  confirmative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). No evidence of pulmonary embolism was demonstrated on a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram.  Diagnosis  Based on the clinical presentation  physical examination  and investigations  the patient was diagnosed with left lower limb deep vein thrombosis.  Treatment and Follow-up  The patient was admitted  and anticoagulant therapy was initiated with low-molecular-weight heparin (Enoxaparin)  later switched to oral anticoagulant (Rivaroxaban) as per protocol. He was advised leg elevation and graduated compression stockings. Education about the importance of mobility was provided to patient and caregivers.  The patient responded positively to the treatment with the resolution of the signs and symptoms within a week. He was discharged with instructions to continue Rivaroxaban and follow-up with the Hematology clinic. Any signs of side effects  such as bleeding or bruising  were to be reported promptly.   In conclusion  this case report of a 67-year-old male with deep vein thrombosis demonstrated the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling  even without recognizable risk factors. Early recognition and prompt initiation of anticoagulative management proved successful in the treatment of this case.

Patient Information  Initials: J.W Gender: Male Age: 65-years-old Marital status: Married Occupation: Retired  previously worked as a truck driver Race/ethnicity: Caucasian Insurance status: Medicare Location: Urban   Presenting Problem  The patient complained of persistent and painful swelling in the right lower limb for the past 1 week. He noticed the swelling started and progressively got worse after a long-duration flight. The pain increased when he tried to move his leg  or when touching the swollen area. He also mentioned a slight fever and malaise.  Past Medical History  J.W has been hypertensive for the past 15 years and takes a medication regimen of amlodipine 10mg daily. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago  managed with metformin. He also has a history of a myocardial infarction 5 years ago  after which he quit smoking. He admitted drinking alcohol for recreation but denied any excessive consumption. There is a considerable lack of exercise in his routine. There is no known history of malignancy  trauma  hematologic disorders  or prior thromboembolic disease.  Physical Examination  The patient was alert and oriented. Vital signs were within normal limits except for slightly elevated blood pressure. Cardiac and respiratory examination was unremarkable. The right lower extremity was erythematous  edematous  and visibly larger than the left. There was tenderness along the course of the right posterior tibial and peroneal veins. No visible varicose veins were present.  Diagnostic Assessment  Upon clinical examination  there was a high index of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). A D-dimer test was done  which returned positive. Further confirmation was made with a venous Doppler ultrasound of the right lower extremity that confirmed a thrombus in the right popliteal vein. Full blood count  liver function  renal function  and glucose tests were within normal range.  Treatment Plan  Initial management included subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin and oral anticoagulation (warfarin). He was advised bed rest with leg elevation and compression stockings. The patient was hospitalized and monitored until international normalized ratio (INR) was therapeutic.  Long-term management includes continuing Warfarin for a minimum of 3 months  frequent monitoring of INR  and lifestyle modifications which included quit drinking  a balanced diet  regular exercise and avoiding long-duration travels without movement.  Instructed to return for any signs of excess bleeding  chest pain or difficulty breathing which could indicate possible complications such as bleeding due to anticoagulation treatment or pulmonary embolism.  Learning Points   This case exemplifies the necessity of keeping a high index of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis in patients presenting with unilateral lower limb swelling  especially with seemingly trivial precipitating factors like long-duration flights (Economy Class Syndrome). Timely management is essential to prevent complications such as pulmonary embolism  post-thrombotic syndrome  or recurrence of DVT. The role of lifestyle modifications in managing and preventing DVT should not be overlooked.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Male  Patient Profile: Demographic Information: Mr. A  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department on July 9  2022. The patient is an accountant  married with two children  and resides in Philadelphia. His reported weight and height are 85kg and 180cm respectively. Mr. A is a moderate smoker with a 15-pack year history and consumes alcohol in moderation. He does not have any recreational drug usage history. He has no known food or drug allergies.  Medical History: Mr. A has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia that has been managed with lifestyle modification and medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin) for the past ten years. He has no history of surgery or hospitalizations and no known family history of blood clotting disorders.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with three-day history of progressive swelling  pain  and warmth in the right lower extremity. He also complained of mild shortness of breath  especially on mild exertion. Mr. A denied any history of recent surgery  significant travel  or prolonged periods of immobilization.  Physical Examination: On examination  his vital signs were stable with blood pressure reading 135/80 mm of Hg  pulse rate 84 beats per minute  temperature of 98.3 degree Fahrenheit  and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. The right lower leg appeared markedly swollen and was warm compared to the contralateral leg. There was tenderness along the medial aspect of the leg and a positive Homans' sign. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Laboratory Investigations and Diagnosis:  Venous duplex ultrasonography was performed  revealing a non-compressible segment in the right popliteal vein - a clear indication of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). D-Dimer levels were also elevated at 1 200 ng/mL (normal range: 0-500ng/mL). Blood tests also showed a slightly raised white blood cell count.   Treatment and Outcome: Mr. A was promptly initiated on low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) along with oral anticoagulant  Warfarin. Graduated compression stockings were also advised to help reduce the swelling and pain. After 5 days of hospital stay with close monitoring  the symptoms substantially reduced  allowing for his discharge with advice to continue Warfarin for 3 months  regular follow-ups  and lifestyle modification education to quit smoking.  This case emphasizes the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unexplained unilateral leg swelling and pain  especially those with risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Moreover  it reiterates the need for patient education on lifestyle modification as a part of management in such cases.

Title: Recurrent Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Female: A Case Report   Abstract:  This case report discusses a 47-year-old Caucasian female who presented with recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) despite suitable anticoagulation therapy.   Case Presentation:  The patient is a 47-year-old Caucasian female  non-smoker  with a history of hypertension and obesity. She first presented a year ago with symptoms of DVT in her left lower extremity after a long car ride and was subsequently diagnosed with her first DVT episode. She was started on appropriate anticoagulation therapy and maintained good outpatient follow-up.  However  the patient presented again twelve months later to our emergency department with a two-day history of acute swelling and pain in her left leg  fearfully suggesting it might be another bout of DVT. She denied any recent travel  surgery  immobilization  or change in her medication routine. She also denied any previous exposure to oral contraceptive pills or hormone replacement therapies.   Examination revealed an obese female in distress with an edematous left lower extremity. Her vital signs were stable. The swelling extended from her thigh to her calf  and it was tender to palpation. There was no discrete lump or evidence of superficial thrombophlebitis. No varicose veins were noted.  Investigations: Her lab values including complete blood count  coagulation profile  renal and liver function tests were all within normal limits. A D-dimer test was markedly elevated. An ultrasound Doppler confirmed the presence of an acute DVT in the left popliteal vein.  Treatment: She was hospitalized and started on therapeutic low molecular weight heparin. Prior to discharge  warfarin was initiated  and she was maintained on it until her INR reached the therapeutic range.  Discussion: This case is unique because despite compliant use of anticoagulation therapy  the patient experienced a recurrence of DVT. Secondary prevention strategies were revisited with the patient including regular mobilization  hydration  weight loss  and compliance with medications.  Conclusion: Recurrent DVT poses a real challenge in clinical practice. This case highlights the need for personalized anticoagulant treatment and constant patient education to prevent recurrent thrombotic events. Encouraging weight loss and diet control in obese patients is also crucial. Further genetic testing can be considered to rule out inherited thrombophilias  especially in patients experiencing recurrent DVTs.   Awareness of this clinical scenario can help identify potential cases of recurrent DVT and lead to more effective management strategies.

Title: A Case of Idiopathic Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 55-year-old Caucasian Male  Abstract: This report describes a case of an idiopathic deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in a previously healthy 55-year-old Caucasian man. The case highlights the patient's clinical manifestations  investigations  treatment  and long-term management.  Case report:  The patient  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  attended our clinic with a one-week history of pain and swelling in his left lower limb. He denied any history of trauma  recent immobilization  travel  or surgical procedures. He is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. There was no family history of blood clots  heart diseases  or other hereditary conditions. The patient works as an office clerk and lives a sedentary lifestyle.  On examination  his vital signs were stable. The left lower limb was swollen in comparison to the right one  warm to touch  and somewhat erythematous. The patient's Physical examination noted Homan's sign as positive. The rest of the clinical examination was unremarkable. His complete blood count  renal function test  liver function test  and coagulation profile were normal.  A Doppler ultrasound of his left lower extremity revealed an acute deep venous thrombosis in the left popliteal vein extending into the left trifurcation veins. No detectable flow or compressibility was noted in these veins.  The lack of identifiable risk factors in the patient provoked a workup for thrombophilia abnormalities. Extensive laboratory investigations  including protein C and S  antithrombin III  and Factor V Leiden screen  in addition to homocysteine levels and a test for antiphospholipid syndrome  produced normal results. A chest x-ray  electrocardiogram  and echocardiogram revealed no abnormalities to suggest pulmonary embolism.  The diagnosis of idiopathic or unprovoked DVT was confirmed  and the patient was initiated on therapeutic doses of low-molecular-weight heparin (Enoxaparin)  overlapped and followed by Warfarin. His clinical condition improved significantly over a week. The patient was counseled and educated about the importance of regular monitoring of INR values  lifestyle modifications  and adherence to medication.  Conclusion:  This case underlines the importance of considering the diagnosis of idiopathic DVT even in seemingly low-risk patients who present with compatible symptoms. A holistic approach is crucial in the management and long-term treatment of DVT  as is educating the patient about monitoring  medication adherence  and lifestyle modifications.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 50-year-old Caucasian Male  Patient Information: The patient is a 50-year-old Caucasian male who works as a truck driver. He lives with his wife and two adult children in a suburban area.  Chief Complaint:  The patient came to the clinic complaining of ongoing pain and swelling in his left lower leg that started two days ago. The pain was described as a consistent dull ache with moments of sharp  cramping pain.  History of Present Illness: The patient started noticing swelling and a minor discomfort in his left lower leg two days ago while at work. He initially dismissed it as fatigue from long hours of driving but sought medical advice when the pain increased  and there was visible swelling and mild skin discoloration.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with Metformin  and hypertension  managed with Lisinopril. He underwent an appendectomy three years ago. There is no history of surgeries involving veins or arteries. He is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Family History:  Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease. His father suffered from a myocardial infarction at 55  and his older brother was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease at 57.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed notable edema of the left calf with mild erythema  warmth  and tenderness. The patient had a positive Homan's sign. There was no noticeable shortness of breath or chest discomfort. Pulse rate was slightly elevated at 95 beats per minute  blood pressure was controlled at 135/85 mmHg  and respiratory rate was normal.  Diagnosis  Intervention  and Treatment: A Duplex ultrasound was performed due to the high suspicion of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the left lower deep vein. The patient was admitted for anticoagulation therapy  initiated on intravenous heparin  and oral Warfarin was started alongside.   Outcome: The patient responded well to the treatment  showing decreased swelling after 24 hours  and a follow-up ultrasound after 5 days showed significant decrease in the size of the thrombus. The patient was discharged with oral anticoagulation (Warfarin) management and was scheduled for frequent follow-ups to monitor coagulation parameters and signs of post-thrombotic syndrome.  Conclusion: Given the patient's occupation  sedentary lifestyle  and a family history of cardiovascular diseases  he was at high risk for DVT. This case highlights the importance of recognizing the signs and symptoms of DVT early and the necessity of preventive measures in high-risk individuals.

Patient Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: Mr. S.  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  came into ABC Hospital on November 9th with chief complaints of pain  swelling  and warmth in his right lower calf area. He had also noticed increased skin discolouration in the same region. Mr. S. is a retired engineer  lives with his wife  and has a moderate lifestyle.   Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and is a smoker for the past 45 years. He also previously suffered a mild stroke three years ago  but currently has no residual disabilities. His medications include aspirin 81 mg once daily for secondary stroke prevention and Lisinopril 10 mg once a day for hypertension. He reported no known drug allergies. The patient does not have a family history of blood clots.   Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed unilateral pitting edema along with warmth and tenderness over the right calf region. His vitals are stable. Pulses were palpable bilaterally. There was no evidence of skin breakdown or ulceration. Other systemic examinations were non-contributory.   Investigations: His complete cell counts  metabolic panel  liver function tests  and coagulation profile were within normal limits. A Doppler Ultrasound of the right lower extremity was performed  revealing a non-compressible popliteal vein suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Differential Diagnosis: The symptoms and ultrasound findings excluded the possibilities of lower extremity cellulitis  ruptured Baker's cyst  venous insufficiency  or muscle strain.   Treatment: The patient was started on anticoagulants (Enoxaparin) to prevent further clotting followed by Warfarin for long-term management. He was also educated about the importance of leg elevation and wearing compression stockings to reduce swelling.  Outcome and Follow-up: The patient responded well to the treatment  and his symptoms significantly improved over the next few days. He is further advised to quit smoking and continue his blood pressure medications. A follow-up appointment has been scheduled after four weeks to reassess his condition. He was also recommended for periodic surveillance using Doppler Ultrasound to track the responsiveness of the treatment.  Learning Points:  This case exemplifies the importance of being vigilant in identifying risk factors and symptoms for DVT  given its potential for serious complications like pulmonary embolism. It underlines the significance of early recognition  prompt investigation  and proper initiation of anticoagulation therapy. It also brings forth the role of patient education in managing the disease and preventing recurrences.

Case Report - Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information:  A male Caucasian patient  aged 55  presented himself at the emergency department. He is a known case of diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the last 20 years. He's a former chronic smoker and stopped smoking five years ago. He used to work as a truck driver  which required long sedentary hours. He is a resident of Houston  Texas  living alone with limited mobility  and has no known allergies.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient came in with complaints of progressively increasing pain  swelling  and redness in his left leg. Simultaneously  he also complained of mild shortness of breath  slight chest pain  and occasional light-headedness. He denied any symptoms of cough  hemoptysis  or recent trauma to the legs.  Clinical Findings:  The left leg was visibly swollen  warm  and erythematous. The calf diameter was noticeably larger than the right side. Pedal pulses were palpable bilaterally with no visible varicosities. There was tenderness and prominent veins noted on his left leg along the venous distribution  suggesting phlebitis. Vitals on arrival were: BP 140/85mmHg  HR 105/min  RR 20/min  SpO2 96% on room air.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  A Doppler ultrasound of both lower extremities was performed  which showed evidence of acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left popliteal vein. A D-dimer test also came back raised  further supporting the diagnosis of DVT. Considering his symptoms of chest pain and light-headedness  an ECG and troponin levels were checked which came back normal  ruling out any immediate cardiac cause. However  a CT pulmonary angiogram was done based on clinical suspicion  which revealed a small pulmonary embolism in the right lower lung lobe.  Therapeutic Focus and Management:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous heparin following DVT confirmation. The bridging therapy was started with oral anticoagulants (warfarin) alongside IV heparin. Once the INR came in therapeutic range  IV heparin was discontinued and the patient was continued on warfarin. He was also provided with a graduated compression stocking.  Education about lifestyle modification emphasis on active mobilization  the importance of regular medication  routine follow-ups  and signs of complications or recurrence - were explained to him before discharge.  The patient’s progress will be monitored and will be followed up in two weeks  with specific attention to his warfarin dosage and INR check in a week. This case highlights the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion and timely intervention in the management of deep vein thrombosis to prevent complications.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in 67-Year-Old Male  Demographic Information: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male. Retired  previously worked as an office manager for over forty years. He resides in the suburban area  is married  and has two adult daughters.  Clinical Presentation: The patient had reported an onset of moderate to severe pain  warmth  and swelling in the right lower leg progressively worsening over the past four days. There was also mention of skin redness over the abdomen area.  Medical History: The patient has a medical history of hypertension and was diagnosed as pre-diabetic 10 years ago. He also has a history of smoking for 30 years but quit 15 years ago. Patient has obesity with BMI (Body Mass Index) of 32.  Clinical Findings: Upon examination  physical redness and edema were observed in the right lower limb. The patient had a positive Homan's sign. His pulse was elevated at 90 beats per minute (normal range 60-100). Blood pressure was slightly high at 145/90mmHg (normal range 120/80 mmHg).   Investigations: Complete blood test showed a slightly elevated white blood cell count of 11.3 x 10^3/uL (normal range 4.50-11.0 x 10^3/uL)  suggesting a possible mild inflammatory response. A Duplex Ultrasound test showed the presence of a clot in the right popliteal vein  revealing deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Blood tests showed D-Dimers at 700ng/mL FEU (normal 0-500ng/mL FEU)  further suggesting DVT.  Treatment: The patient was started on anticoagulant therapy (low molecular weight heparins followed by warfarin) for initial DVT management. It was advised that he elevate the affected leg when possible and use compression stockings to prevent post-thrombotic syndrome. He was also advised to continue controlling his hypertension and pre-diabetic conditions.   Follow-Up: Follow-up visits and Duplex Ultrasound are scheduled in 1  3  and 6 months to monitor the progression/resolution of the thrombus and alterations in the treatment plan  if necessary. Patient counsel on lifestyle modifications such as engaging in regular exercise and adopting a balanced diet for weight management was provided.  Summary: This case highlights the importance of considering deep vein thrombosis as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling  particularly in the presence of risk factors such as long periods of immobility  advanced age  obesity  smoking  and history of vascular pathologies. Early detection and immediate management of DVT are crucial to preventing serious complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Patient Identification: A 66-year-old female  Patient Demographics: Caucasian  retired school teacher  married with 2 adult children  Past Medical History: Non-smoker  drinks socially  has a history of hypertension being managed with medications such as Olmesartan  does not have diabetes  no known allergies.  Presenting Complaint: The patient reported to the emergency department with complaints of progressive left leg swelling and diffuse pain localized to her calf region. She mentioned she noticed these symptoms for the past 3 days  which had gradually increased. She has no similar complaint on her right leg. No other symptoms were reported.  Family History: Her father died from complications following a stroke at 72. Her mother is still alive at 88 with chronic arthritis. She has one brother with no significant health issues. No family history of clotting disorders.  Clinical Findings: On examination  her left leg was swollen compared to her right leg  with mild erythema. There was tenderness on deep palpation of the calf muscles. Her ankle and knee joints showed normal range of motion without pain. There was no evidence of peripheral arterial disease with intact peripheral pulses. Her vital signs were stable.  Diagnostic Evaluations: An emergency Doppler ultrasound of her left lower limb veins was conducted which confirmed a thrombus in her left popliteal vein  corroborating the suspicion of DVT.  Management: The patient was promptly started on low molecular-weight heparin - Enoxaparin (1 mg/kg subcutaneously every 12 hours) for immediate anticoagulation. Consultation with a hematologist was made for further management.  Prevention measures such as wearing compression stockings and elevation of the affected leg were also initiated. Education about the importance of mobility and hydration was provided.   In making a long-term plan  the patient's risk factors for DVT such as sedentary lifestyle and hypertension would needed to be addressed. Due to the family history of stroke  the possibility of an inherited coagulation disorder is also to be considered and genetic testing might be suggested. Her treatment responsiveness and side-effects would be observed carefully  with regular follow-ups planned.

Patient Presentation: Mr. E.  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented with unilateral swelling with pain and warmth of his right lower extremity that had been progressing for 4 days prior to his admission. His chief complaint was difficulty walking due to the swelling and the pain in his affected leg.   Past Medical History: Mr. E. has a significant past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  each managed appropriately on medication for the past 10 years with Lisinopril and Simvastatin respectively. The patient is a former smoker  quit 15 years ago  and is a non-alcoholic.  Family History: The patient has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; both his father and older brother had myocardial infarctions in their mid-60s.   Social History: The patient is a retired engineer living independently with his wife in their own home. He reports a sedentary lifestyle  mainly watching TV and yard work.  Physical Examination: The affected extremity was visibly swollen and erythematous with palpable localized warmth and tenderness to touch. Distal pulses present and equal bilaterally.  Lab Studies: Laboratory studies revealed a positive D-dimer  elevated blood pressure  slightly elevated cholesterol levels  and normal coagulation profile.  Imaging: A duplex ultrasound was performed showing a clot in the superficial femoral and popliteal veins consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Management: The patient was commenced on therapeutic dosing of low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH). After a few days  he was transitioned to long-term oral anticoagulation with Rivaroxaban.  Outcomes: In response to anticoagulation therapy  the patient showed significant improvement in his symptoms over the next week. He was counselled on maintaining a healthier lifestyle and encouraged to be more active  considering his sedentary habits. Additionally  given his family history and personal medical history  a need for continued careful monitoring was stressed.  Plan for follow-up: The patient will follow up in the outpatient clinic every 2 months to monitor for recurrence of DVT  treatment side effects  and adjustment of medication if required. He has been directed to reach out immediately if symptoms recur or worsen. A referral to a vascular surgeon was also made for consideration of post-thrombotic syndrome management and prophylaxis.  .    Discussion: This case underscores the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling and pain  especially in patients with a sedentary lifestyle and a history of cardiovascular diseases. Despite the lack of a direct familial history of venous thromboembolism  this patient's personal and familial history of cardiovascular disease do indicate a potential predisposition. A targeted history  physical  and diagnostic imaging are critical to the early detection and management of this potentially dangerous condition.

Patient Presentation:   Subject: A 65-year-old Caucasian female.  Chief Complaint: Patient presents with progressive right lower extremity discomfort and swelling.   Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago  which she manages using diet  exercise  and medication (Metformin and Amlodipine). She quit smoking 10 years ago after a 40 years smoking history and also has a history of obesity but underwent successful bariatric surgery 2 years ago. She has no known drug allergies.  Family History: Both parents had cardiovascular disease. Her father had an MI at age 67  and her mother had a cerebral thrombosis at age 62. She has one sister diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis three years back.   Present Illness: Since two weeks  she has been experiencing a dull ache in her right calf area which is more noticeable at night and after prolonged sitting. She also noticed some swelling  warmth and skin discolouration in the same area. Symptoms intensified  prompting her to seek medical help.   Social and Personal History: She is a retired professor  widowed  and lives alone but within close proximity to her son. She has a history of prolonged immobility due to her previous job nature  which involved prolonged sitting hours.  Physical Examination: The patient seemed anxious. Vital signs were within normal limits. The physical examination revealed a swollen and indurated calf on the right  which is tender  warm  and with some erythema compared to the left calf. No visible varicose veins observed.  Given her symptoms of unilateral leg swelling  discomfort and the risk factors including age  obesity  family history  and sedentary lifestyle  the suspicion of deep vein thrombosis was raised.  Investigations: To confirm the diagnosis  a duplex ultrasound was conducted. Laboratory tests  including a complete blood count  PT/INR  aPTT  and D-dimer testing  were ordered.  Diagnosis: The findings from the ultrasound and high D-dimer levels confirmed the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Management: Patient was initiated on anticoagulation therapy starting with LMWH transitioning to oral anticoagulants. She was advised to wear compression stockings to aid blood flow and educated on the importance of nature walks to regain venous return. Instructions to recognize signs of pulmonary embolism were emphasized. She will have follow-ups to monitor her response to therapy and reassess in 3 months.  In summary  given the patient's symptoms  family history and personal risk factors  it was crucial to diagnose her with DVT swiftly and manage the same promptly to prevent complications.

Patient Presentation  Name: Mr. Rodriguez Age: 53 Gender: Male Ethnicity: Hispanic Occupation: Store Manager  Medical History:  Mr. Rodriguez has been previously diagnosed with Type II Diabetes and Hypertension for which he takes Metformin and Amlodipine respectively. He is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago after a 20-year habit. His other medical history includes obesity with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31.   Presenting Problem: Mr. Rodriguez presented to the clinic with swelling and pain in his left lower leg  just below the knee that has progressively worsened over the past four days. He denied history of injury or trauma and also reported a feeling of warmth at the swelling site. He rated the pain as a 7 on a scale of 1-10 which escalates to a 9 during walking.  Family History: The patient's father died at the age of 59 due to a stroke. His mother is alive and suffering from Hypertension and Type II Diabetes. His 56-year-old brother recently had a heart attack.  Diagnosis: The clinical symptoms along with positive D-Dimer test led us to perform a Duplex Ultrasound of the left leg. The ultrasound confirmed the presence of an obstructive clot in the femoral vein  indicating Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Treatment: Mr. Rodriguez was admitted immediately and started on anticoagulant therapy. He was given intravenous administration of Heparin  followed by oral administration of Warfarin. Throughout his treatment  his International Normalized Ratio (INR) was checked regularly to monitor the effectiveness of the anticoagulant therapy.  Instructions were disclosed to Mr. Rodriguez emphasizing the importance of taking his medication regularly  avoiding long periods of sitting  maintaining a moderate level of physical activity  losing weight  and following a balanced diet.   Summary: In that context  DVT in Mr. Rodriguez is presumably related to his medical history of Type II Diabetes  Hypertension  obesity  family history of cardiovascular diseases  and sedentary lifestyle due to his occupation. Treatment is fully initiated and education has been provided to mitigate the risk of serious bleeding complications and potential pulmonary embolism. Regular follow-ups and strict monitoring of vitals and medication compliance are crucial to his condition.

Patient Presentation:  Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian  retired police officer. He's a heavy smoker with significant tobacco history. He lives in Albany  New York  with his wife.   Presenting Problem: He presented to the emergency department with a complaint of progressive and painful swelling in his right lower leg for the last two days. He has also reported mild breathlessness and episodic coughing over the last few days.  Past Medical History: He has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He had undergone a laparoscopic cholecystectomy 9 years ago. His medications include losartan  metformin  and simvastatin.  Family History: His mother had an ischemic stroke in her late 60s and his father died of myocardial infarction at 75. His older sister was recently diagnosed with pulmonary embolism.  Observation and Tests: His vitals are stable with a slightly elevated BP of 150/90 mmHg and increased heart rate at 97 BPM. Physical examination revealed a warm  erythematous  and swollen right calf which was tender to palpation. He's afebrile. His Wells Score for deep vein thrombosis is calculated and is suggestive of a high probability. Further  a Doppler ultrasonography was performed which confirmed the presence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his right lower limb. The D-dimer test was positive. Chest X-Ray was clear but given his shortness of breath and family history of PE  a CT Pulmonary Angiography was ordered which ruled out pulmonary embolism.   Treatment: The patient was immediately started on a therapeutic dose of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH  Enoxaparin) and later shifted to oral anticoagulant  Rivaroxaban in view of long term treatment.   Healthcare Plan: The patient will be counseled regarding lifestyle modifications — cessation of smoking  maintaining a balanced diet  muscle-strengthening exercises  and regular follow-ups. He will be educated about the signs of complications like pulmonary embolism and the importance of adhering to anticoagulant therapy. Compression stockings will be advised to relieve symptoms and prevent post-thrombotic syndrome. Close monitoring of renal function and signs of bleeding will be required due to the anticoagulant therapy.   Given the family history of thromboembolic diseases  a consultation with a hematologist for possible inherited thrombophilia was also recommended. Familiar genetic mutations  like Factor V Leiden or Prothrombin Gene mutation  can be quite common in cases with a family history of venous thromboembolism.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: Ms. Johnson is a 55-year-old Caucasian woman with a body mass index (BMI) of 33 kg/m²  indicating obesity. She is a former smoker and has been unemployed for the past 8 months. She has a family history of her father dying from a major stroke  and her mother is currently living with hypertension and diabetes.  Past Medical History: Ms. Johnson was previously diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. All of these conditions have been managed poorly due to issues with medication adherence and regular follow-up appointments. She also had a cholecystectomy performed five years ago.  Current Complaint: She was brought into the emergency department by her daughter due to a sudden  painful swelling in her right leg. The swelling was accompanied by redness  warmth  and a mild fever. She reported no recent injuries but mentioned an extended period of inactivity due to being bedridden with the flu for a week.  Clinical Examination: On examination  the right lower leg appeared swollen and erythematous. The Homans sign was present  which is indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). No signs of peripheral arterial disease were found  and the rest of the physical examination was largely unremarkable.  Investigations: Doppler ultrasonography confirmed the presence of a blood clot in the deep veins of her right lower limb. Her D-dimer levels were elevated  consistent with a DVT. Furthermore  her fasting blood glucose levels and blood pressure were also raised  reflecting poor control of her chronic conditions.   Management: She was immediately started on anticoagulant therapy with heparin and oral warfarin for the DVT. Adjustments were made to her existing medication regimen for her poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension. Efforts were also made to counsel her on the importance of medication adherence and lifestyle modifications like weight reduction  regular exercise  and a balanced diet.  Discussion: This patient's DVT can be attributed to Virchow's triad of hypercoagulability  stasis  and endothelial damage. Her obesity  sedentary lifestyle due to unemployment  recent inactivity (bedridden with the flu)  and poor control of her diabetes and hypertension put her at a higher risk of DVT development. Moreover  her family history puts additional genetic predisposition for thrombotic events. Thus  it is crucial to manage her DVT promptly and efficiently to prevent potentially fatal complications such as pulmonary embolism.   Moving forward  regular follow-up and control of her chronic conditions  maintenance of anticoagulant therapy  lifestyle changes  and ensuring medication adherence will be crucial to prevent recurrent thrombotic incidents. Educating her about the symptoms of DVT is important so that any recurrence can be detected and treated early.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 60-year-old African American male.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith came to the clinic with a complaint of swelling and tenderness in his left calf area  which he first noticed 4 days ago. The pain seems to worsen when he stands or walks. He also mentioned feeling mild warmth in the same area.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He is a two-time pulmonary embolism survivor and had undergone hip replacement surgery eight months ago.  Family History: Patients mother had a history of DVT  and father died of a stroke. His elder sister also has hypertension.  Social History: Mr. Smith lives with his wife. He was a smoker but quit 10 years ago. Drinks alcohol occasionally. He used to be a truck driver and is now retired.  Medications: Currently prescribed metformin for diabetes  Losartan for hypertension  and Lipitor for hyperlipidemia.  Examination: On examination  his vital signs were within the normal range. His left calf appeared swollen and appeared slightly red as compared to the right calf.   Investigations: Blood tests show an elevated D dimer level. Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a deep vein thrombus in the left popliteal vein.  Diagnosis: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is the diagnosis based on clinical findings and investigations.   Plan: Start immediate anticoagulation therapy with heparin and then continue with oral anticoagulants such as Warfarin. Compression stockings have been prescribed to relieve swelling and pain. Lifestyle recommendations include avoiding prolonged periods of immobility and regular physical activity to encourage blood circulation.   Follow-up: Regular monitoring is needed every 3-6 months  or as clinically indicated  to assess the effectiveness of anticoagulation therapy and to look for any signs of a recurrent DVT.    Discussion: DVT is a serious condition due to its association with potentially life-threatening complications like pulmonary embolism. Mr. Smith's case is particularly challenging because he has multiple risk factors for DVT: prior history of DVT  post-surgical period  age and comorbid conditions like diabetes and hyperlipidemia. In such cases  post-surgery prophylaxis for DVT should be considered and proper follow-up to check for any signs of DVT.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Robert Johnson is a 66-year-old Caucasian male admitted to the hospital with complaints of unexplained extensive swelling  persistent pain  and warmth over the skin in his right lower leg. At home  he lives with his wife and maintains an active lifestyle despite being retired. He has a history of smoking (20 pack-years)  but quit about a decade ago. He enjoys social drinking on weekends and has a balanced diet. Obesity is not an issue for him.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of coronary artery disease and hypertension  for which he is on medication. He also underwent a total hip replacement surgery on his right side three years ago  following which he was on prophylactic anticoagulant therapy. There is no relevant history of hematological disorders or malignancy.  Family History:  Mr. Johnson's mother had DVT at the age of 74 and his only sister suffers from varicose veins. His father passed away at the age of 62 due to an apparent myocardial infarction. There is no family history of hypercoagulable states or cancer.  Presentation:  The patient presents with a swollen  painful  and erythematous right lower extremity. Physical examination reveals a positive Homan's sign (pain on forced dorsiflexion of the foot). There are no ulcers or trophic changes in the skin suggesting chronic venous insufficiency. Peripheral pulses are intact and the neurological examination is unremarkable. No palpable cords suggestive of superficial thrombophlebitis.  Investigations:  Preliminary laboratory tests including complete blood count  renal function  and coagulation profile are largely normal  except for slightly elevated D-Dimer levels. Doppler Ultrasonography confirms the presence of non-compressible segment in the right popliteal vein suggesting the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis.   A chest X-ray was done  which appeared normal excluding any signs of a recent or previous lung embolism. Given the family history  and after obtaining informed consent  a thrombophilia screening was also performed but deemed negative.  Plan:  Mr. Johnson should be immediately started on therapeutic anticoagulation with parenteral agents like LMWH followed by oral Warfarin therapy. Lifelong anticoagulation may be required considering his risk factors and familial predisposition to venous thromboembolism. Patient education  smoking cessation  and appropriate follow-ups must be ensured. The importance of regular monitoring of INR whilst on Warfarin therapy was reiterated to the patient.

Patient Presentation:  The patient  Mr. John Smith  is a 68-year-old African American male who was admitted to the hospital complaining of pain in his right calf and difficulties walking  which started around a week ago. He has a previous medical history of Type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both of which are well-managed with medication.  He is a retired engineer  married with two adult children  and is a former smoker  having quit approximately five years ago. However  he still consumes alcohol moderately. He is obese with a BMI of 30.5  and his dietary habits are rich in high glucose and high sodium foods. He admits to being sedentary  with very minimal physical activity.  The family history reveals that both his father and grandfather had heart diseases  which presented in their mid-50s and that his mother had Type 2 diabetes.  On examination  his blood pressure was 145/90mmHg and heart rate was regular at 72 beats per minute. His respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute and his temperature was 98.6°F. An assessment of the right calf showed it to be swollen  red  and warm to touch.  Imaging investigations (ultrasound) were performed which confirmed the presence of a blood clot in his deep veins  leading to the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Blood work showed elevated D-dimer levels  which was also suggestive of DVT.  Given the patient's age  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and family history of heart disease  along with his current symptoms and test results  his doctor has suggested that this is a likely case of DVT.  The plan going forward includes immediate anticoagulant therapy  a change in diet and physical activity  and careful monitoring. A referral to a vascular specialist for further evaluation and possible intervention is also planned. A health talk on the importance of medication adherence  regular exercise  diet modification such as low sugar and salt intake  weight loss  cessation of alcohol intake  and regular clinic visits for monitoring will be delivered to the patient. The need for the usage of compression stockings will also be discussed.  The case emphasizes the importance of lifestyle modification in the management of DVT  especially in patients with a history of hypertension and diabetes. It also highlights the importance of early diagnosis and management. This is a prime opportunity for the patient to address his various health issues and to improve his overall quality of life.

Patient's Case Presentation:  Patient Demographics: A Caucasian male  aged 65  retired. He lives with his wife in the rural area  smokes occasionally  and has no known drug allergies. His educational background reveals he was a high school teacher.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  which is under control with medication (Lisinopril/Hydrochlorothiazide). He had a cholecystectomy 10 years ago but has been otherwise generally healthy until now. He is slightly overweight (BMI 29)  and his diet often contains high-fat  high-calorie meals.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presented to the outpatient clinic with a swollen  red and painful left lower limb for the past week  with no recent injury or trauma. There were no associated symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  or coughing up blood.   Family History: The patient's family history is significant for cardiovascular disease. His father had died from a stroke at the age of 70  and his mother had a myocardial infarction in her late 60s. He has two siblings  one of whom has been recently diagnosed with hypertension.  Examination: Physical examination revealed an erythematous and warm left calf  which was significantly swollen compared to the right. He was ambulatory but with some discomfort. His blood pressure and other vital signs were in the normal range.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Due to the suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  a blood test (D-dimer) was ordered  which came back with elevated levels. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of lower limb DVT in the left superficial femoral vein.   Treatment and Follow-up: The patient was initiated on anticoagulation therapy with low-molecular-weight-heparin followed by Warfarin to prevent clot development and propagation. Lifestyle advice was also given regarding diet modification  quitting smoking  regular exercise  and keeping well-hydrated. The patient was scheduled for a follow-up appointment in two weeks to assess his response to therapy.  Discussion: In this patient  multiple factors have contributed to his DVT: his age  family history of venous thrombotic events  his hypertension (though it was well-managed)  and his dietary habits. As DVT can lead to serious complications including pulmonary embolism  prompt diagnosis - via D-dimer test and Doppler ultrasound in this case - and management with anticoagulants are crucial. Future care will need to focus on primary prevention and management of risk factors. Regular follow-ups will also be important to monitor the effectiveness of the treatment and make necessary adjustments.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Valdez is a 72-year-old Hispanic male with a history of chronic smoking and hypertension  who presents with a complaint of a swollen  painful right lower leg that has been ongoing for approximately 3 days. He states the leg has grown progressively more painful  swollen  and is somewhat warm to touch.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Valdez was diagnosed with hypertension approximately 12 years ago and has been on medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily). He also has a 45-year history of smoking  consuming approximately a pack a day. He recently had a total knee replacement (TKR) on his right knee six weeks ago. He has not received any pharmacological prophylaxis for DVT post-surgery and has been somewhat ambulant due to the pain. He has no known allergies to medications.  Family History:  His family history is notable for a brother who died of myocardial infarction at the age of 55. Neither of his parents were alive when diagnosed with major illnesses; details are unknown. No known family history of genetic thrombophilic conditions  affective disorders  or suicide.  Social History:  He is a retired garage owner with three grown-up children. He lives with his wife of 45 years  in their own home  and is financially stable. He quit alcohol 10 years ago but has remained a heavy smoker.  Physical Examination:  On examination  Mr. Valdez's right leg is notably larger than his left  with redness over the calf. The leg is tender to touch. The pulses in his foot are present  but the foot appears slightly pale compared to the left.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  D-dimer test comes back positive. Ultrasound Doppler confirms presence of clot restricting venous blood flow in the right superficial femoral vein  confirming the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis.   Management and Follow-up:  Mr. Valdez was started on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin and oral warfarin with regular INR checks. He was also advised to elevate the leg and wear compression stockings for additional relief. Patient education regarding the importance of mobility  especially post-surgery  and quitting smoking were stressed. His family was educated about the signs of pulmonary embolism  and they were advised to bring him to the hospital immediately if they notice symptoms such as chest pain or sudden shortness of breath.   The patient will be followed up after a week to assess the response of the treatment and will be referred to smoking cessation counselling. A family genetic study could be considered if recurrent or familial thrombosis is suspected in context.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 45-year-old Caucasian male with a body mass index (BMI) of 32  has presented with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) symptoms. Mr. Doe is a truck driver by profession and reports spending long hours seated during his cross-country drives. He is a smoker  having smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. He does not consume alcohol or use any illicit substances.  Presenting Problem: Mr. Doe came into the clinic complaining of left leg pain and swelling that's been persistent for five days. He also reported shortness of breath  which had been gradually increasing along with the pain and swelling.  Past Medical History: His past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both managed with medications (atenolol and atorvastatin  respectively). He has no known drug allergies. His last medical check-up was six months ago  and it was unremarkable.  Family History: His father had a history of coronary artery disease and his mother has hypertension. There's no known family history of blood clotting disorders.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  his left leg was moderately swollen when compared to the right. It was tender to touch and edematous  with a circumference measurement greater when compared to the right leg. His vital signs were normal except for slightly elevated blood pressure. His respiratory sounds were slightly diminished at lung bases.  Investigations: The initially ordered Duplex ultrasound revealed presence of a blood clot in his left lower leg. D-dimer test was positive. A chest CT scan was advised  in view to his shortness of breath symptom pointing at possible pulmonary embolism.  Diagnosis: Based on the current symptoms  clinical examination  and investigational findings  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis.   Management Plan: The management plan includes starting the patient on anticoagulants like heparin followed by warfarin for long term management. Lifestyle modifications were advised  including a quit smoking plan  regular exercise  and a healthy diet to manage weight and reduce the risk of further clot formation.  Follow-up: Mr. Doe will need regular follow-ups to monitor his symptoms and blood values. His INR (International Normalized Ratio) levels will also require monitoring to ensure appropriate dosing of his warfarin therapy.  Conclusion: Mr. Doe's age  sedentary profession  smoking history  and obesity are all risk factors that likely contributed to his development of DVT. Early diagnosis and initiation of treatment are essential to prevent complications such as pulmonary embolism  post-thrombotic syndrome  and recurrence of DVT.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John White  a 67-year-old Caucasian male from New York  presented at the emergency department with complaints of progressive left leg pain  swelling  and warmness localized to the calf  which started about five days ago. Mr. White is a retired bank manager and lives with his wife. He is a nonsmoker and consumes alcohol occasionally.   Past Medical History:  Mr. White has a history of Type 2 Diabetes mellitus and Hypertension  which are well-controlled with metformin and lisinopril respectively. He underwent a total knee replacement surgery on his left knee 5 months ago. Other than the mentioned  he does not have any significant history of hospitalizations or surgeries.  Family History:  Both of John's parents had a history of cardiovascular diseases: his father died from an acute myocardial infarction at 76 years  whereas his mother passed away from a haemorrhagic stroke at 79 years. His elder sister (72 years old) was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis after a long-distance flight two years ago.   Clinical Findings:  On clinical examination  his left calf was found to be swollen with increased warmth and tenderness. Positive Homan's sign. No ulcers or ecchymosis seen. The rest of the physical examination was normal. His vitals at presentation were Blood Pressure - 138/84 mmHg  Heart Rate - 82/min  Respiratory Rate - 18/min  Temperature - 98.2 F.   Investigations:  A Doppler ultrasound of the left leg revealed a clot in the left posterior tibial vein confirming the diagnosis of left leg deep vein thrombosis. Hematology reports showed a raised D-dimer level of 800 ng/ml. His random blood glucose level was noted to be 148 mg/dl  and HbA1c was 7.1%.   Impression and Plan:  This elderly man with a personal history of surgical procedure  sedentary lifestyle and a family history of thromboembolic disease has developed deep vein thrombosis with clinical presentation and positive findings on Doppler ultrasound.   Plan includes anticoagulation therapy initiation to dissolve the clot and prevent pulmonary embolisms. Following initial Heparin therapy  consideration for oral anticoagulant like warfarin  keeping in mind it may need careful dosing because of his comorbidities. Long-term management to include weight management  physical activity  and proper diabetes control. Consult with a physiotherapist for regular leg exercises and discussion about the possible use of compression stockings. Primary care follow-up should be arranged.   Risk factor modifications including diet control for diabetes  lifestyle changes as well as patient education for signs of complications like pulmonary embolism would be part of the management. Regular follow up with monitoring of therapeutic INR levels(for warfarin) and HbA1c is also needed. Family history of DVT indicates possible hereditary components - may further require genetic counseling and testing.

Patient Presentation  Subject: A 67-year-old African-American male  John Doe  Presenting Complaint: The patient complains of prolonged swelling and persistent pain in his left leg for the past week  which has been progressively worsening.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes and Hypertension eleven years ago. He also suffered a myocardial infarction four years ago. He had a 15-year history of smoking but quit two years ago following his cardiologist's advice after the heart attack. He also has a sedentary lifestyle and has been diagnosed with obesity.  Family History: His father died from a stroke  and his mother has a history of hypertension. His older brother was recently diagnosed with peripheral artery disease.   Investigations and Findings: The patient's Doppler ultrasound reveals a clot in the left popliteal vein  suggesting a clear diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Other findings include elevated D-dimer levels. His blood pressure was 145/100 mmHg  and his body mass index was recorded as 32  revealing his obesity.  Treatment Plan: The patient has been started on Anticoagulation Therapy with low molecular weight heparin for initial fast action. For continued treatment  oral anticoagulation with warfarin will be introduced after a couple of days  with INR levels closely monitored. To control his blood pressure  he is prescribed angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. Lifestyle interventions such as increased physical activity and a balanced diet are recommended to control his diabetes and obesity. Support stockings were also suggested to alleviate the symptoms of DVT.   Follow-up: The patient will regularly monitor his blood glucose and blood pressure at home. An appointment is scheduled in one week to assess the patient's response to medication and in a month to adjust the dosage of warfarin based on the controlled INR levels.  Risk factors for DVT in this case include the patient's age  sedentary lifestyle  history of smoking  obesity  diabetes  and previous heart conditions. This case emphasizes the importance of regular checkup in patients with similar risk factors and the need for lifestyle modifications to prevent the formation of blood clots leading to DVT.

Patient Initials: S.P.  Age: 58 years  Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Presenting Issue: The patient presented with swelling and discomfort in his right leg  persisting for a few days. Ultrasound results indicated the presence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right lower leg.  Past Medical History: Mr. S.P. has a medical history of hypertension  managed by daily administration of Amlodipine (5mg/day). Being a smoker having approximately 15 cigarettes per day and moderate alcohol consumption  he leads a sedentary lifestyle with his work involving long hours of sitting. He also acknowledged a recent long transcontinental flight.   Family History: His mother suffered from pulmonary embolism at 70 years and his sister was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis in her early 50s.   Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient had an increased temperature (38.2°C)  with visible edema  erythema and warmth to the touch observed in the right leg  more prominent in the calf region. His blood pressure was 142/90 mm Hg.   Diagnosis: Based on the clinical presentation  his high-risk score on the Wells criteria for DVT  and an ultrasound demonstrating a thrombus in the deep veins of the right leg  Mr. S.P was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis.  Management: The patient was promptly initiated on low-molecular-weight heparin together with oral warfarin as initial anticoagulation. He was advised to elevate his leg  use compression stockings for reducing edema  cease smoking and given instructions for lifestyle modifications to include regular exercise. Counseling regarding the risk of long periods of immobilization and travel-related DVT was conducted.  Prognosis: Mr. S.P. will need to continue on anticoagulation therapy for at least 3 months  with clinical and coagulation monitoring. Provided he adheres to these plans  his prognosis should be quite favorable. Education about recognizing symptoms of DVT recurrence or pulmonary embolism given his high-risk family history was also emphasized. Lastly  lifestyle modifications including smoking cessation will be crucial in his long-term prognosis and prevention of future DVT events.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who was referred to the vascular clinic with a week-long history of increasing pain and progressive swelling in his left lower leg. His past medical history is remarkable for obesity  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He also reported a past brief episode of clot in his leg approximately 10 years ago. Further  he is a long-time cigarette smoker with a 40-year pack history.  Demographic Information:  The patient is an unmarried retiree  living alone in a suburban neighborhood. He reported having an active social life and enjoying gardening and woodworking activities in his spare time. He also reported having a sedentary lifestyle and diet high in fats and carbohydrates.  Family History:  His father died at age 75 from a stroke and his mother passed away at age 83 due to chronic congestive heart failure. He has one sister  aged 70  currently living with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). They have a family history of cardiovascular diseases  which could contribute to hypercoagulable states. He has two children who are both alive and well.  Presenting Issue:  Upon physical examination  the left leg was erythematous and markedly swollen as compared to the right  with a palpable cord along the line of the left femoral vein. The patient reported increased discomfort and heavy sensation in the leg. However  he had no symptoms of shortness of breath or chest pain. He also had a low-grade fever of 100.4°F.  Laboratory Information:  Preliminary laboratory investigations showed mild leukocytosis and a moderately elevated D-dimer level. His blood glucose level was also moderately elevated  consistent with his history of uncontrolled diabetes.  Working Diagnosis:  The history  clinical signs  and preliminary laboratory findings were consistent with acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Management:  Immediate management included anticoagulation therapy using low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin). His diabetes management was adjusted as well. He is planned for further diagnostic confirmation via duplex venous ultrasound and therapy adjustments if needed. The patient was educated about the symptoms of pulmonary embolism and the significance of prompt treatment. He was also advised about lifestyle modifications such as smoking cessation  adoption of a balanced diet  weight management  and engaging in regular physical exercises.  Follow-up:  The patient was scheduled for a follow-up appointment in one week to monitor his response to the therapy and make changes as necessary. Long-term warfarin therapy has been considered and will be addressed in the follow-up depending on the findings and the patient's compliance.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 56-year-old African American male  presented to the clinic with complaints of increasing pain and swelling in his left lower leg over the past three days. Mr. Doe works as a long-haul truck driver and spends most of each day seated. He has a past medical history notable for obesity  Type-2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and a transient ischemic attack (TIA) two years ago. He is a former smoker (30-pack years) and quit 10 years ago  drinks alcohol socially and doesn't engage in regular physical activity.  Family history revealed that Mr. Doe's father died at age 62 from a stroke and his mother  aged 74  is alive with a diagnosis of COPD and breast cancer. He also has a sister  aged 58  diagnosed with venous thrombosis post her knee replacement surgery two years ago.  On examination  his left lower leg appeared erythematous  warm  and edematous. His body mass index (BMI) was 32 kg/m2  indicating obesity. Blood pressure was 146/92mmHg  pulse rate 88 bpm and regular  respiratory rate 16 bpm and oxygen saturation was 97% on room air. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were palpable and equal bilaterally. However  Homan's sign was positive on left side indicating potential DVT. There were no ulcers or skin changes indicating chronic venous insufficiency.  Differential diagnosis includes deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  cellulitis  and ruptured Baker's cyst. Given his prolonged seating due to his profession  obesity  hypertension  diabetes  and family history  deep vein thrombosis remains the most likely diagnosis.   D-Dimer levels were ordered that came out to be high and an ultrasound Doppler study of the lower extremity confirmed the diagnosis of deep venous thrombosis. The ultrasound revealed a non-compressible segment in the left popliteal vein consistent with a thrombus.  The patient was immediately prescribed anticoagulants (low molecular weight heparin) along with strict advice for weight loss  increased physical activity  and regular monitoring of blood glucose and blood pressure. He was also advised to wear compression stockings to avoid post-thrombotic syndrome and to ease his current symptoms. He is to follow up in 5-7 days for reevaluation  at which point possible transition to oral anticoagulants can be made.  Given this patient's risk factors and history  collaboration with a cardiologist for risk stratification is suggested  and the patient should be counseled on symptom recognition  preventative measures for recurrent DVT and lifestyle modifications.   This case emphasises the importance of prompt evaluation of DVT symptoms and the need for preventative measures for at-risk patients. An interdisciplinary approach collaborating with cardiology and diabetic services would contribute to a comprehensive evaluation and management of Mr. Doe's complex medical needs.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Details: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. Victoria Thompson  resident of a suburban area in Boston  Massachusetts. She is a retired school teacher  mostly sedentary due to her retired status  overweight with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 30  is a non-smoker  and occasional alcohol consumer. She has a history of recurrent varicose veins and has been using compression stockings for years.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Thompson has a past medical history significant for controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes. She had undergone a knee replacement surgery two years ago  which was complicated by a lower leg DVT and was treated with warfarin for six months. Since then  she has been taking low-dose aspirin for prophylaxis against cardiovascular disease due to her risk factors. Additionally  she has been diagnosed with osteoarthritis and takes NSAIDs for pain management.  Family History: Her family history is significant for multiple venous thromboembolic disorders  with her mother having experienced a pulmonary embolism and her brother having recurrent DVTs. Furthermore  there is also a strong family history of heart disease and type 2 diabetes.  Presenting Complaint: Mrs. Thompson presented to the clinic with complaints of pain  warmth  and swelling in her left leg for the past three days  which she initially dismissed as arthritis pain but became worrisome when it started worsening. She denies any symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or recent long-distance travel.  Physical Examination: On examination  her left leg appeared swollen  erythematous  with a positive Homans' sign. She has no edema  cyanosis  or clubbing  and the peripheral pulses were normal.  Investigations: D-dimer was markedly raised  and an urgent Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremity confirmed a deep vein thrombosis in the left femoral vein. Her EKG  chest X-ray  and vital signs were normal indicating no immediate signs of pulmonary embolism.  Diagnosis & Treatment: Mrs. Thompson was diagnosed with left-lower extremity deep vein thrombosis. Given her previous DVT and current presentation  the patient was started on low molecular weight heparin and oral anticoagulation with warfarin. She has been scheduled for a follow-up appointment to monitor her response to treatment and to reassess her current prophylactic regimen considering her risk factors and family history.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. R is a 59-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with complaints of pain and tenderness in his left calf for 72 hours. He listed his pain at an 8 on a scale of 10. The patient also mentioned a feeling of warmth over the area and a slightly red to bluish skin discoloration on his calf.  Past Medical History:  Mr. R is a smoker with a 30-year history of a pack a day habit and also admits to consuming alcohol socially. His past medical history includes hypertension  high cholesterol and diabetes mellitus II  for which he takes Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Metformin respectively. He has no known drug allergies.
