Family History:  He reported that his mother had suffered from a stroke in her late 60s and his father died at age 62 due to a heart attack. He has two siblings – an older brother with a history of coronary artery disease and a younger sister who is a breast cancer survivor.  Exam and Work-Up:  On clinical examination  Mr. R had a positive Homan's sign. His vitals showed a slightly elevated blood pressure (145/90 mm Hg) and a regular pulse. Lab investigations revealed an elevated D-dimer at 1 800 ng/ml (normal range: up to 500 ng/ml). His hemoglobin was 13.2 gm/dl  white blood cell count was within normal range and his platelet count was elevated at 450 000/mm³. Fasting blood glucose was high  around 175 mg/dl (normal range: 70-100 mg/dl).  Diagnosis:  Given the patient’s symptoms  physical examination  positive Homan's sign and markedly elevated D-dimer levels  the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) was suspected. Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities confirmed a large occlusive thrombus in the left popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of DVT.  Management and Recommendations:  Mr. R was started on subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) and also an oral anticoagulant (Warfarin). He was hospitalized for observation. The patient received health education about the importance of quitting smoking  reduction of alcohol intake  regular exercise and adherence to diabetes  hypertension and hyperlipidemia medications. He was also advised to elevate the affected leg and apply warm compresses to reduce the pain and inflammation.   Mr. R was scheduled for a follow-up appointment after his discharge to reassess his condition and manage his chronic illness better. He was referred to a dietitian for better control of his diabetes and hypercholesterolemia.   This case highlights the importance of recognizing typical symptoms and signs of a potentially life-threatening condition such as DVT and the appropriate use of diagnostic modalities to confirm the diagnosis. The case also emphasises the necessity of lifestyle modification and management of underlying conditions as an integral part of the treatment.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Jane Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  presented with swelling  warmth  and redness in her left leg which began about 3 days ago. The patient described the discomfort as gradually worsening from a mild ache to a throbbing pain. She has also reported being easily fatigued recently and cannot walk for long without needing to rest.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Doe is newly diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her left leg. She is a type 2 diabetic managed with metformin for the past 10 years and has been treated for hypertension with lisinopril for the last 5 years. She had a hysterectomy 15 years ago due to fibroids but has no other surgical history. She has a history of occasional alcohol use but quit smoking 20 years ago after a 15-year habit.  Present Medical History:  Upon examination  the left leg was noticeably swollen with tenderness along the inner thigh. The leg was warm to touch  and redness was visible from the knee to mid-calf  which could indicate a superficial vein complication due to underlying DVT. Her blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/92 mmHg from her regular range of 130/80 mmHg  likely due to pain. She had an appreciable pulse in her foot  which suggested no immediate threat of vascular compromise.  Family History:  Her father died from a heart attack at the age of 70 and her mother  who is alive  has hypertension and type 2 diabetes. She has two siblings – a brother with high cholesterol and a sister with no known health issues.   Investigation & Diagnosis:  She underwent a Doppler ultrasound confirming the presence of a thrombus in her left femoral vein confirming the diagnosis of DVT. Her D-dimer levels were also significantly elevated. Upon discussing her recent activities  she disclosed a long-haul flight about 7 days ago  which may have contributed to her developing DVT.  Treatment:  She was immediately started on anticoagulant therapy (low molecular weight heparin) and later bridged to warfarin  with the plan to continue warfarin for the next 3-6 months. She is scheduled for follow-ups to gauge her response to treatment  potential complications  and the need for continued anticoagulation therapy.  Conclusion:  Considering Mrs. Doe's newly diagnosed DVT  her antihyperglycemic and antihypertensive treatment regimens should also be reassessed during follow-ups to ensure optimal disease management. Patient education concerning signs of complications like pulmonary embolism will also be crucial. This case also highlights the importance of prophylaxis for DVT  especially for high-risk individuals before long-haul flights.

Patient Profile:  Mr. John Smith is a 60-year-old Caucasian male who resides in an urban area in the northeastern United States. He is a retired naval officer and is married with three adult children. He's a former smoker having quit 10 years ago but admits to moderate alcohol consumption. He leads a sedentary lifestyle due to his sedentary job and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.  Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. These conditions have been moderately managed with a diuretic (hydrochlorothiazide) and a statin (atorvastatin) respectively. He reports no known allergies. He had been in his usual state of health until about a week ago  when he began experiencing increasing left leg pain and swelling. No history of surgery or major illness has been previously reported.  Presenting Issue:  He presents now with severe left calf pain and swelling  as well as a low-grade fever. His symptomatic leg appears red  swollen and warm to the touch. His other leg appears unaffected. His vital signs are within normal ranges. Upon physical examination  a positive Homan's sign was noted on his left calf.  Family History:  Mr. Smith reports a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and his older brother was recently diagnosed with angina. His mother carries a diagnosis of osteoporosis  and his sister has a history of type 2 diabetes. There doesn't appear to be a family history of blood clotting disorders.  Diagnosis and Management:  Based on his symptoms  risk factors  and clinical findings  Mr. Smith was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). A venous Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a blood clot in the deep veins of his left leg.   Management includes anticoagulation therapy. He was started on a parenteral anticoagulant (low molecular weight Heparin) bridging with an oral anticoagulant (Warfarin). Measures have been recommended to help control his hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which include lifestyle modifications  such as regular exercise  healthy eating habits  reducing alcohol consumption  maintaining regular follow-up appointments  and compliance with prescribed medication.   He was educated about the importance of taking his medications as directed  potential side effects  interactions  and symptoms of potential complications (such as pulmonary embolism) to monitor for. He is scheduled for a follow-up in a week  and interim phone check-ups will be performed to monitor his response to treatment and address any issues.   This dynamic  patient-centered management plan offers the best possibility of preventing further progression of DVT  associated complications  and readmission. It also addresses his co-morbidities  leading to comprehensive care.

Patient Presentation  Mr. John Doe  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the hospital due to complaints of a prolonged pain and swelling in his left leg. He is obese  a smoker  and has a desk job that requires very little mobility. He does not have any known allergies. He does not abuse alcohol or any illicit substances.   Past Medical History  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and chronic back pain for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide  atorvastatin  and occasional NSAIDs respectively. He was diagnosed with a peptic ulcer disease 5 years ago which was managed with a proton pump inhibitor  he also had a hernia repair 3 years ago. There is no known diabetes  vascular disease  or heart disease. Mr. Doe has yet to undergo a colonoscopy  despite reaching the recommended age of diagnostic testing.  Family History  There is a prominent family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  with his mother having an episode of DVT at the age of 65 and his paternal grandfather having a pulmonary embolism in his 70s. Additionally  his father has had a heart attack at the age of 67. His younger sister is diabetic and hypertensive.   Previous Consultancies  Four days prior to hospital admission  Mr. Doe visited his GP for his leg pain but was provided with analgesics and was advised to rest  keep the leg elevated  and apply hot and cold compresses interchangeably.  Current Complaint  The patient later noticed that his left leg was warm and swollen  with the skin taking on a reddish-blue color. Pain has intensified and Mr. Doe reported that it worsened when he stands or walks. He has not experienced chest pain  cough  or shortness of breath.  Clinical Findings  Upon physical examination  his left lower limb was indeed warmer  swollen  and erythematous when compared to the right. His vital signs were within the normal range. He had a high D-dimer level and an Ultrasonographic Doppler revealed a non-compressible left popliteal vein suggestive of deep vein thrombosis.  Treatment Plan   Given his clinical presentation and family history  further investigations to rule out any clotting disorder were necessary. He was started on Low-Molecular-Weight-Heparin (LMWH) and Warfarin therapy was initiated. Mr. Doe was educated on the importance of adhering to his medications  risk factors of DVT  the necessity for regular INR check-up  and leg exercises to prevent DVT in the future. He was discharged with plans for a follow-up in the outpatient department.   It is also recommended that Mr. Doe needs to quit smoking  lose weight  and prevent long periods of immobilization  in order to reduce his risk for another deep vein thrombosis incident. An avenue for discussion is Mr. Doe's overdue colonoscopy  to ensure he doesn't have any other hidden health concerns.

Patient Information:  Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old African American male who presented at the emergency department with complaints of progressively increasing swelling  pain  and warmth in his left lower extremity for the past one week. His pain is 7/10  exacerbated by movement  and partially relieved by rest and over-the-counter pain relievers. He denies any history of trauma to the affected limb  but admits to recent long-distance flight two weeks ago. He has no history of similar events in the past.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled with medications. He quit smoking 10 years ago and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Family History:  The patient has a positive family history for cardiovascular disease. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 72  and his older brother had a stroke at 68. All lean towards a strong genetic predisposition to thrombotic events.   Diagnostics:  Upon physical examination  his left leg was found to be swollen  tender and warmer than the right leg  with a positive Homan's sign. Blood pressure was found to be 145/90 mmHg and other vitals were within normal limits. Doppler ultrasound showed thrombosis in the lower segment of the left popliteal vein consistent with a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). D-Dimer levels were found to be considerably elevated.   Treatment:  He was admitted and given subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) considering his renal function. Compression stockings were recommended for symptomatic relief  and ambulation was encouraged whenever feasible to prevent extension of thrombus and post-thrombotic syndrome.   In conclusion  Mr. Smith  with his medical history of hypertension and diabetes and positive family history for cardiovascular disease  falls in a high risk category for DVT development. His recent long-distance flight is a significant risk factor leading to prolonged immobility which likely triggered the clot formation.   Future Management:  Further management will include initiation of oral anticoagulant after 5-7 days of bridging with enoxaparin and his response to treatment will be closely monitored. He will be educated on compliance with his anticoagulant therapy and signs of potential complications related to DVT like pulmonary embolism. Lifestyle modification and proper management of hypertension and diabetes were also advised.  This case emphasizes the need for considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling  especially if risk factors like recent travel  personal history of thrombotic events  family history of cardiovascular events or certain underlying medical conditions exist.

Patient's Profile: Patient's Code: P123456 Age: 55 Gender: Male Occupation: Accountant Ethnicity: Caucasian Health Status: Non-smoker  Rare alcohol intake  Physically inactive  Case Presentation:  The patient  a 55-year-old male accountant presented with progressive pain in the left lower limb extending from the calf to the thigh for the past three days. He also reported mild swelling and warmth over the left calf region and a minor increase in fatigue levels. Prior to this  he hadn't experienced similar symptoms.   Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  poorly controlled  diagnosed seven and five years ago respectively. He disclosed the occasional occurrence of exertional dyspnea. His medication regimen includes Optimum Diabetex and Lisinopril-Hydrochlorothiazide. His adherence to treatment has been inconsistent. He has a sedentary lifestyle with long hours of remaining seated due to his professional requirements. He does not engage in any regular physical workout.  History of Surgery or Hospitalization:  There is no history of any major surgeries or hospitalizations.  Family History:  Both parents are hypertensive. His father died at the age of 68 years due to myocardial infarction. The patient's mother is a patient with Breast Cancer. He has one sibling who is in good health. There is no family history of DVT  Pulmonary Embolism  or inherited blood clotting disorders.  Social History:  The patient lives with his wife and two children. He is the primary breadwinner of the family and provides health insurance. Being a non-smoker and minimal drinker  his lifestyle is void of such risk factors.  Clinical Examination:  On examination  left lower limb was mildly edematous as compared to the right. Homan’s sign was positive. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable. The patient’s blood pressure was on the higher end of normal and his body mass index fell into the obese category.  Workups & Conclusion:  Subsequent doppler Ultrasound of the left lower limb confirmed the presence of deep vein thrombosis in the left posterior tibial vein. Hypercoagulability workup was negative for inherited thrombophilias. The patient’s HbA1c and blood sugars were elevated indicating uncontrolled diabetes.  Thrombosis with the background of Sedentary lifestyle  Hypertension  Obesity  and Diabetes demands an urgent change in lifestyle  strict control of blood sugars  weight reduction  and anti-coagulant therapy.  The patient was counseled about the severity of his condition and the urgent need to make lifestyle changes. The importance of consistent medication  maintaining a healthy diet  and incorporating regular exercise into his routine was also emphasized. He was started on anticoagulant medication for the DVT and his diabetes medication was adjusted. He was scheduled for a follow-up appointment in one week.  This case  thus  highlights the clinical presentation and management of DVT in the context of multiple comorbidities and a sedentary lifestyle.+

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 63-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department complaining of pain and swelling in his left leg which has been increasing over the last few days with no relation to any specific injury or activity. Mr. Doe lives alone  smokes one pack of cigarettes daily  is widowed  and retired. He does occasional business trips  which involve lengthy plane flights.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a known history of hypertension  for which he has been prescribed Enalapril. He also has a history of gout and takes allopurinol. He has a sedentary lifestyle  with minimal exercise due to being retired. His diet is varied  but he does admit to frequent consumption of fast food.   Family History:  There is a significant family history of cardiac disease. His father died from a heart attack at the age of 74  and his mother had congestive heart failure. His younger sister  aged 58  recently had a stroke.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  his blood pressure was moderately elevated  and the skin of the affected leg appeared reddish and warm to touch. There was noticeable puffiness around the calf  more so when compared to the other leg. He denied any chest pain or shortness of breath  however reported calf tightness and discomfort when walking.  Investigations:  A Doppler Ultrasound was performed which confirmed the presence of blood clots in the deep veins of his left calf  leading to the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Management:  Mr. Doe was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin and warfarin. Compression stockings were also recommended  and he was advised to keep his leg elevated when resting. He was counseled on the importance of quitting smoking and adopting a healthier lifestyle to reduce his risk of developing more serious complications such as a pulmonary embolism.  Conclusion:  Given Mr. Doe’s personal and family history of cardiovascular diseases  he is at risk of developing venous thromboembolism conditions like DVT. Primary prevention strategies  such as lifestyle changes and compression stockings for long trips  should be implemented in terms of risk factor modification. He will need careful monitoring and strong consideration regarding his ongoing management.

Patient Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: Mr. A is a 68-year-old Caucasian male. Resides in a semi-urban area and is retired from his job as an accountant. He lives with his wife  and they have three grown-up children. He is a former smoker (quit 10 years ago) and occasionally drinks alcohol socially.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. A presented at the hospital with a 3-day history of unexplained pain and swelling on his left calf  with no visible injury or trauma.   Past Medical History: Mr. A has a history of hypertension and is under medication (atenolol). Last year he underwent a hip replacement surgery due to osteoarthritis and was bed-bound for several weeks post-procedure. He is moderately obese and has a sedentary lifestyle. He does not have a history of cancer  surgery  or prolonged travel in the recent past.  Family History: His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60 and died at 78 due to congestive heart failure. His mother died of a stroke at 72. His elder brother was recently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis.   Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  his left calf is noticeably swollen and warmer than the other leg. The patient's pulse  blood pressure  and other basic parameters are within the normal range.  Investigations: Amounting to the patient’s history of recent hip surgery  prolonged inactivity  family history of deep vein thrombosis  and the physical findings; a deep vein thrombosis was suspected. His D-dimer was high and thus an ultrasound Doppler of his leg was conducted  which confirmed the presence of a clot in the left calf vein.  Management: Considering the risk of pulmonary embolism  Mr. A was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy (initially with low molecular weight heparin  transitioning to oral warfarin). His leg was elevated  and he was advised to wear graduated compression stockings to help reduce the swelling and pain. He was educated about the importance of regular movement and advised to gradually increase physical activity to improve circulation.  Follow-Up: Mr. A will be closely monitored  with regular blood tests to ensure correct medication dosage  and he will have regular follow-ups with his primary care doctor for assessment and any necessary adjustments to his treatment plan. Educational advice was emphasized in his continued compliance with medication and lifestyle modification.  In conclusion  Mr. A’s case underscores the importance of considering deep vein thrombosis in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling  especially with risk factors such as recent surgery  immobility  and positive family history.

Patient Presentation  Patient: Mr. Johnson  a 67-year-old Caucasian male   Presenting Complaint: Complains of unexplained swelling and pain in his left leg for the past two weeks  Past Medical History:   Mr. Johnson has a documented history of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) for which he is on bronchodilators. He had a myocardial infarction five years ago and consequently underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). He has been taking aspirin and statins since. Mr. Johnson is also a former smoker  with a history of 40 pack-years.  Family History:   His father died from coronary artery disease at the age of 72  and his mother died from stroke at 76. His older brother has been recently diagnosed with type II diabetes.  Presenting Symptoms:  On examination  the left calf was noticeably swollen compared with the right  with increased warmth and tenderness on palpation. He also indicated a moderate degree of discomfort upon dorsiflexion of the foot (positive Homan’s sign). No superficial veins are visible.  Investigation:  Mr. Johnson underwent a Doppler ultrasound which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the left deep femoral vein  therefore diagnosing him with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Plan:   Management commenced immediately with the administration of low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) for rapid anticoagulation. Plans to switch to oral anticoagulants  like warfarin  for long term site specific home therapy were initiated along with discussions on likely complications  like pulmonary embolism. Lifestyle modifications were suggested with an emphasis on regular leg exercises  wearing compression stockings  and elevating the leg while sitting or resting.   Notes:  Due to Mr. Johnson's age and history of cardiac conditions  he falls into a higher-risk category for DVT. His previous immobilization due to the myocardial infarction  and the presence of COPD  could have predisposed him to his current thrombus formation. His family history suggests a genetic predisposition to vascular and possibly thrombotic conditions. Careful planning of his management is required considering his chronic COPD  and previous history of myocardial infarction. The aim is to prevent the expansion or migration of the clot which might lead to life-threatening complications like a pulmonary embolism. Regular follow-up with echo-Doppler is considered to monitor the resolution of DVT.

Patient Profile  Mr. John Ryan is a 60-year-old Caucasian male who works as a truck driver and lives in New York City. He is 5'10"" tall  weighs 240 pounds  and has been classified as obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 34.5. He is a former smoker  with a 30-pack year history but successfully quit five years ago. He does not consume alcohol and is a non-drug user.   Chief Complaint   Mr. Ryan presented with a complaint of painful left calf swelling for three days that progressively worsened. The pain is constant  with no radiating nature. It is associated with slight redness and warmth but not with fever or chills.  Past Medical History   Mr. Ryan has a controlled hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  for which he takes Hydrochlorothiazide and Metformin respectively. He was diagnosed with these conditions ten years ago during a routine health check. He has no prior history of venous thromboembolism  cancer  recent surgery  or trauma.  Family History   The family history reveals that his father had deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at a similar age and his mother is healthy. He has one brother who is younger and has recently been diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes.   Physical Examination   Upon examination  Mr. Ryan's left calf is visibly swollen and is warm to touch when compared to his right. There is slight erythema but no palpable cord  ulceration  or discharge. His vitals are stable with blood pressure 130/85 mmHg  pulse 80 beats/min  respirations 18 breaths/min  and temperature 98.6°F.  Investigations  Lab findings revealed a positive D-dimer with a slightly elevated blood sugar level. An Ultrasound Doppler Study of the left lower extremity was ordered  which confirmed a non-compressible distal left popliteal vein suggestive of DVT.   Plan  Mr. Ryan was admitted for inpatient care. Anticoagulation therapy was initiated with low-molecular-weight Heparin and transition to long-term Warfarin. The patient will also be counseled on lifestyle modification strategies  including weight loss  increased physical activity and maintaining better control of his diabetes. He was also advised to avoid prolonged periods of immobility.   Follow Up   A follow-up appointment was scheduled for two weeks to reassess his condition  adjust warfarin dosages if needed  and check his INR levels. Future considerations include wearing compression stockings to prevent post-thrombotic syndrome and referral to a dietitian to gain better control of his diabetes and obesity.   This case presentation has highlighted the importance of considering DVT in patients with swelling  redness and increased warmth of a limb  especially if they possess multiple risk factors such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  and a familial predisposition.

Patient Information: The patient is a 72-year-old  Caucasian male who weighs 85 kg. His BMI is 27. He is a retired mechanic. He is a former smoker with a 45-pack-year history. He quit smoking 15 years ago but has been exposed to second-hand smoke. He resides in a suburban area and lives alone but has close contact with his daughter and grandchildren who visit him frequently. He has Medicare insurance.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with a three-day history of unilateral swelling and pain in his left calf that worsened with walking. He also reports a mild shortness of breath.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a documented history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes  all of which are controlled with metformin  an ACE inhibitor  and statins respectively.   Medications: The patient is on daily metformin 500mg twice daily  lisinopril 10mg  and Atorvastatin 40mg nightly. He has no known drug allergies.  Family History: The patient’s father had coronary artery disease and died from an MI at 75. His mother died at the age of 82 from a cerebrovascular accident. He has two brothers  one of whom was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer.   Physical Examination: At present  the patient appears to be in moderate distress due to pain. His vitals are blood pressure at 135/85 mmHg  pulse rate of 85 bpm  respiratory rate at 18 breaths per minute  and body temperature at 98.2 Fahrenheit. On examination  there is significant edema and erythema on the left lower leg. The left calf circumference is 2.5 cm greater than the right. There are no signs of trauma or injury observed in the affected leg. Auscultatory findings of the lungs reveal normal vesicular breath sounds  and cardiovascular examination findings are within normal limits.  Lab & Imaging:  The complete blood count and chemistry panel are within normal limits. On Doppler ultrasound  a non-compressible segment of the left popliteal vein suggestive of a Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) was found. No abnormalities were detected in the chest X-ray.  Diagnosis and Management: Based on these findings  the patient was diagnosed with left lower extremity DVT. The patient was started on therapeutic low molecular weight heparin and was scheduled for a repeat ultrasound in 24 hours. Warfarin therapy was initiated and overlapped with heparin. The patient was educated on the importance of regular INR monitoring  possible bleeding risks  and drug interactions with warfarin. He was advised to avoid prolonged periods of immobility and to seek immediate medical attention if symptoms such as chest pain or difficulties in breathing occur.  This case illustrates the risk factors of DVT such as advanced age  obesity  known history of vascular diseases  and previous smoking habits. Successful management of such patients lies in proactive monitoring  patient education  and appropriate anticoagulation.

Case Presentation: The patient is Mrs. Jennifer White  a 57-year-old Caucasian female from Chicago  Illinois. She works as a software engineer and maintains a mostly sedentary lifestyle. She is married  with two adult children. Her chief complaint is swelling and moderate  persistent pain in her left lower limb over the past days.  Past Medical History: Mrs. White was previously diagnosed with hypertension and hypercholesterolemia around four years ago. She is on Lisinopril for her blood pressure and Atorvastatin for the hypercholesterolemia. She is also overweight with a BMI of 28.5. Due to the nature of her work  she does not exercise frequently. She also revealed she had experienced a spontaneous miscarriage nearly twenty years ago.  Family History: Her father had suffered from a stroke and her mother died of a heart attack. There is a known history of cardiovascular disease in her family.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Initial physical examination showed swelling and warmth over her left calf muscle suggesting signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Given her symptoms and risk factors  a Doppler ultrasound was organized which confirmed the presence of a deep vein thrombus in the popliteal and femoral vein. D-dimer levels were also found to be elevated  which is consistent with DVT diagnosis.  Management and Discussion: Mrs. White was started on apixaban  a type of anticoagulant therapy to treat and prevent further thrombus formation. Lifestyle modifications  including diet adjustments and physical activities were also advised to manage her weight  hypertension  and cholesterol levels. Patient education was provided about the importance of movement  staying hydrated and the effects of a sedentary lifestyle on DVT development and overall health.  Possible outcome: The prognosis depends on her adherence to the treatment plan and lifestyle changes. Regular follow-ups and continued anticoagulation treatment are crucial to prevent a pulmonary embolism  a life-threatening complication of DVT. Furthermore  management of her other comorbidities like hypertension and hypercholesterolemia are also paramount in ensuring the DVT does not reoccur.  In conclusion  Mrs. White's case is a classic presentation of DVT  especially given her risk factors which include a sedentary lifestyle  obesity  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a significant family history of cardiovascular disease. It's important to continue monitoring her condition  promoting lifestyle changes  and ensuring medication adherence to manage this diagnosis effectively.

Patient Presentation   Mr. Davis  a 57-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to our outpatient department with complaints of persisting pain and swelling in the right calf that had worsened over the past few days. The pain was described as a deep ache  exacerbated during walking  with the calf warm to the touch and appearing distinctly edematous.  The patient’s past medical history revealed a condition of type II diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years  well-controlled with Metformin. He was also diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago  managed by Lisinopril. He suffered a myocardial infarction 2 years ago  and has been on a regimen of daily low-dose Aspirin since.   He has had a history of smoking a pack a day for about 25 years but quit after his myocardial infarction. He drinks socially and has no known alcohol addiction. His activity level has been below average post his heart condition and spends a majority of his day seated because of his desk job. There is no known history of any bleeding disorders  trauma  recent surgery or prolonged immobilization in his case.  His family history revealed that his father had a stroke at the age of 70 and his mother suffered from rheumatoid arthritis. His older brother was recently diagnosed with Pulmonary Embolism.   The patient’s BMI was recorded at 30  confirming obesity. His vitals upon examination were normal except for a slightly elevated blood pressure (145/95 mmHg). Given his signs and symptoms coupled with his obesity  lifestyle  and family history  a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) seemed likely.  Lab findings showed an increased D-dimer level of 500 ng/mL (normal range: less than 250 ng/mL). A Doppler ultrasound further revealed a thrombus in the femoral vein  confirming the DVT diagnosis.   An interdisciplinary team involving a cardiologist  radiologist  and primary physician is formed to discuss the best approach concerning his management. Anticoagulation therapy was initiated promptly with heparin  transitioning to warfarin  with a target INR range of 2-3. The patient has been advised to maintain an active lifestyle with controlled diet and regular follow-ups for monitoring of warfarin therapy. The need for psychological therapy has also been discussed with the patient to help him cope with the lifestyle modifications.

Patient Profile:  S. M is a 53-year-old Caucasian male who is employed as a traveling salesman.  Presenting Issue:  The patient presents with a complaint of swelling  redness  and discomfort in his right lower leg which has been persisting for the past three days.  Medical History: Notably  he has a past medical history of hypertension  which is being managed through medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily) and lifestyle modifications. He reports being a former smoker but has remained tobacco-free for 15 years. Recently  he acquired a sedentary job which requires him to travel over long periods in a vehicle. His last trip took 10 hours with short breaks. The patient denies any history of surgeries  blood transfusion  or liver or kidney diseases. His medications include only antihypertensive drugs.  Family History: Upon inquiry  he reveals a family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). His mother was diagnosed with the condition in her late 50s. His father has a history of coronary artery disease.  Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  his vitals were within normal limits. Leg examination revealed unilateral  painful swelling  and mild erythema of the right calf and ankle. Homans' sign was found positive in the right leg.  Investigations: A Doppler ultrasound was requested that confirmed the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis in the right calf veins. He was also advised to get a D-dimer test  which was observed to be significantly raised 1200 ng/mL  further supporting the diagnosis.   Case Summary: Our patient S.M.  a 53 years old hypertensive male with a notable family history of DVT  presented with symptoms suggestive of a possible DVT. Long hours of immobility due to his occupational requirement and a family history of the condition may have predisposed him to developing DVT. Symptoms  along with supportive investigations like Doppler ultrasound and D-dimer tests  confirmed the diagnosis. The patient is advised anticoagulant therapy under the guidance of a hematologist  lifestyle modification  compression stockings  and closely monitored follow-ups.

Patient Information: Ms. Jane Doe  a 45-year-old African American female  Presenting Concern: The patient came to the hospital with complaints of growing pain and swelling in the right lower extremity for the past couple of days. She also mentions a generalized feeling of discomfort and fatigue.  Past Medical History: She is moderately obese (BMI 30 kg/m2)  non-smoker  and has a history of Protective Service work that requires prolonged periods of inactivity or sitting. She has no history of major illness. However  she was diagnosed with hypothyroidism 5 years ago and is regularly using levothyroxine.   Family history: The patient reports that her father had a stroke at the age of 65. Her mother is currently healthy at age 74 but her maternal grandfather had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Physical examination: A thorough physical examination of the patient revealed a warm  swollen right calf  which was tender to touch. The circumference of the right calf was found to be 3 cm greater than the left calf (measured 10 cm below the tibial tuberosity). No chest symptoms  palpitation  or shortness of breath were reported.  Laboratory Evaluation: Lab evaluations show increases in D-dimer levels. Her thyroid function tests are within normal limits. Other routine blood tests  including complete blood count  liver function test  and kidney function test  were within normal ranges.  Diagnosis: Based on the Wells criteria for DVT and clinical findings  the probability of DVT was high. An ultrasound was recommended  which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the popliteal vein  leading to a diagnosis of right lower extremity DVT.  Treatment Plan: The patient was put on an anticoagulant regimen  starting with low molecular weight heparin and transitioning to oral warfarin. She was educated about the need for regular follow-ups to monitor her INR and was advised on lifestyle modification such as weight loss and regular exercise. The importance of compression stockings to reduce swelling and relieve pain was emphasized.  Discussion: This case notes the prevalence of DVT among individuals with poor lifestyle habits such as prolonged periods of inactivity or sitting. This combined with a familial history of DVT raised Ms. Doe’s risk. As such  preventative measures should be taken for those with similar lifestyle habits or genetic pre-dispositions.  Plan for Follow-up: Follow-up after four weeks to monitor the alleviation of symptoms and then regular follow-ups to monitor her INR if the patient remains on warfarin longer term.

Patient Presentation: Ms. Fowler  a 67-year-old African-American female  presented to the emergency department complaining of increasing pain  tenderness  and swelling in her left lower extremity over the past three days. She describes the pain as a continuous dull ache  non-radiating  6/10 intensity  worsening with prolonged sitting and improves slightly with leg elevation. Ms. Fowler is a retired elementary school teacher  lives alone  nonsmoker  and has a history of moderate alcohol intake. She denies recent travels  surgeries  or changes in medication.  Past Medical History: She has a history of hypertension (well-controlled on amlodipine) and type 2 diabetes (controlled with metformin). She had a hysterectomy 20-years-ago for uterine fibroids without any perioperative complications. No history of thromboembolic events.  Family History: Her father had a stroke at the age of 75  and her mother died at the age of 79 from complications related to Alzheimer's disease. She had an older brother who suffered from coronary heart disease and had a myocardial infarction at 60. No known family history of clotting disorders.  Physical Examination: Patient is alert  oriented  in mild distress secondary to pain. Vital signs were stable. Lungs clear on auscultation. Cardiac auscultation normal with regular rate and rhythm. Abdomen soft  non-tender with normal bowel sounds. The left lower extremity showed redness  warmth  and swelling  primarily in the calf region  but no signs of any skin breakdown  ulceration or infection. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were 2+ and equal bilaterally. Neurological exam showed no abnormalities; intact sensation and motor strength were noted in both lower extremities.  Diagnostic Assessment: Given the presentation and exam findings  a clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was considered. Ms. Fowler was sent for a Doppler ultrasound of the left leg  which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the femoral vein. Her D-dimer level was elevated  consistent with the diagnosis.  Treatment Outline: Ms. Fowler was advised to continue with her current medication for hypertension and diabetes. She was started on anticoagulation (low molecular weight heparin initially followed by oral rivaroxaban) for the DVT. She was educated about the symptoms of pulmonary embolism  a severe complication of DVT and was advised to return to the hospital if those symptoms occur.  Ms. Fowler is scheduled for a follow-up in the primary care clinic in a week's time to monitor her symptoms and plan long-term anticoagulation therapy. Discussions were also made to investigate for any possible underlying malignancies or clotting disorders due to the unprovoked nature of the event.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 57-year-old Caucasian male  is presented to our facility with complaints of swelling  redness  and warmth in his left leg  which he reported started about a week ago. The discomfort increased steadily over the past few days. Mr. Doe is an accountant and has a sedentary lifestyle which involves long sitting hours.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe is a known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years  for which he has been prescribed oral hypoglycemic agents. He has been diagnosed with hypertension for the last 5 years  and he takes antihypertensive medication regularly. Mr. Doe is also classified as obese according to his BMI.  Family History:  Mr. Doe’s mother had a stroke at age 68 and his father suffered from coronary artery disease. Both parents had hypertension. His younger sister  who is 55 years old  was recently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis(DVT).   Recent History:  Mr. Doe recently had an overseas work trip that involved a long flight (over 10 hours).   Examination and Investigations:  On examination  the left leg was swollen and erythematous  and the patient exhibited extreme discomfort upon physical assessment. Comparatively  the right leg appeared normal. The post-examination findings raised a strong suspicion of DVT. A Doppler ultrasonography was performed  which indeed confirmed the presence of DVT in the left lower limb.  Management:  Mr. Doe was immediately put on anticoagulants in the form of injections  and later  oral anticoagulants were added to his treatment regimen. Weight loss and daily exercises were strongly recommended to manage his obesity and improve his overall health. He was advised to avoid long periods of immobility and to take frequent breaks while working to ensure movement.  Follow-up and Patient Counseling:  A follow-up visit is scheduled for Mr. Doe in 2 weeks to assess his response to the therapy and any potential side effects from medications. Health education about the management of DVT and the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle to reduce risks has been emphasized.  Mr. Doe’s case highlights the importance of considering DVT in patients who present with unilateral leg swelling  particularly those with risk factors such as prolonged immobilization (long flight)  obesity  and a positive family history. The need for prompt diagnosis and appropriate management to prevent serious complications such as pulmonary embolism cannot be overemphasized.

Case Presentation:  Patient Information:   Mr. Daniels is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who has recently been diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  History of Present Illness:   Mr. Daniels presented to the emergency department with complaints of progressive pain and swelling in his left lower leg that's been present for five days. He denies any trauma or injury to the affected leg. He has also reported feeling mild general fatigue  however  denies experiencing chest pain or shortness of breath. He stated no history of similar symptoms.  Relevant Medical History:   His past medical history includes hypertension controlled with Lisinopril  type II diabetes managed with Metformin and occasional gout flare-ups treated with Colchicine. He does not have any known drug allergies.  Demographics:  Mr. Daniels is a retired mechanical engineer. He smokes about 1 pack of cigarettes a day  and has been doing so for the past 40 years. He drinks alcohol socially  mostly on weekends. He is divorced  lives alone  and is sedentary for much of his time.   Family History:  His father had type II diabetes and died from a myocardial infarction in his early 70s. His mother had hypertension and passed away from stroke.  Physical Examination:  On exam  left lower leg is swollen  erythematous  warm with tenderness to palpation. Pedal pulses are present in both feet. The reminder of examination  including cardiovascular and pulmonary systems are normal.  Diagnostic Tests:  A venous Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the left deep femoral vein. Blood work showed slightly elevated D-dimer levels. His INR is normal  and other lab work including renal  and liver function tests are within normal limits.  Impression and Plan:  The patient was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis based on clinical assessment and ultrasonographic findings. Anticoagulation therapy with a low molecular weight heparin  Enoxaparin  was initiated immediately  with plan to transition to a direct oral anticoagulant  such as Apixaban. Mr. Daniels has been advised regarding the importance of lifestyle modification  tobacco cessation and maintaining good glycemic control. A follow-up appointment for re-evaluation and therapeutic monitoring has been scheduled.  Apart from the DVT management  further risk stratification for potential cardio-vascular events being a smoker and having a family history of CAD will be needed. Also  he has been referred to a dietitian considering his diabetes and sedentary lifestyle.

Presenting a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Details: Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Issue: The patient complains of a persistent  dull aching pain in his left leg accompanied by swelling in the calf area. There’s also noticeable redness and warmth over the swollen area. He denies any recent injuries or trauma.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a significant history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and high cholesterol levels. These conditions are well managed with medication - Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for cholesterol control. He had mild COVID-19 infection four months ago and fully recovered.   Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 72  and his mother died of stroke at the age of 68. His elder brother  currently 68 years old  has a history of peripheral arterial disease.  Social History: The patient is a former smoker (quit 20 years ago after smoking one pack per day for 30 years). He occasionally drinks alcohol. He is retired and maintains an inactive lifestyle  spending most of the day sitting or lying down.  Examination: On examination  he has a higher temperature in the left leg compared to the right. There are signs of a palpable cord in the left calf and unilateral pitting edema.   Investigations and Outcome: His D-dimer tests came back positive. A follow-up Duplex ultrasound confirmed the presence of a blood clot in his left calf  leading to the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). This was likely prompted by his age  sedentary lifestyle  and his personal and family medical history.  Management Plan: Mr. Smith was promptly started on anticoagulation therapeutics  specifically low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin)  followed by a transition to longer-term anticoagulants. He has been counseled on the necessity of regular exercise and mobilization  adherence to medication  and follow-up appointments for the prevention of DVT complications like pulmonary embolism.  The patient and his family were also educated about the symptoms of pulmonary embolism  such as sudden shortness of breath  chest pain  or coughing up blood  in order for them to recognize these potential complications early. A follow-up consultation has been scheduled for 7 days from discharge to evaluate the patient's response to the treatment.   Prognosis: DVT is a treatable condition  but it requires careful management and monitoring due to the risk of serious complications. Given his prompt treatment and management plan  Mr. Smith’s prognosis seems favorable provided he adheres strictly to the prescribed medication regimen and lifestyle adjustments.

Patient Presentation  Demographics: A 65-year-old Caucasian female  retired teacher  currently residing in San Francisco. She lives alone and is independently mobile.   Presenting Complaint: Immobile and severe pain in the left lower leg accompanied by localized warmth  swelling  and tenderness for the last 3 days.   Past Medical History: She has a history of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) along with hypothyroidism controlled by levothyroxine treatment. She fractured her hip last year and had to remain immobile for a significant period. No known allergies or drug intolerances.  Social History: No history of smoking  occasional alcohol consumption  moderate physical activity mainly involving walking. She has not traveled recently.  Family History: Mother had a stroke aged 70  and father died of myocardial infarction aged 72. One brother has high blood pressure. No family history of clotting disorders.  Examination: She has a slightly raised temperature at 99.2°F and blood pressure is slightly raised at 140/85mmHg. Heart rhythm is regular without murmur. Chest clear to auscultation and percussion. Abdomen is soft  non-tender without masses. Extensive left lower leg edema present with local erythema. Dorsalis pedis pulse palpable on the right foot but diminished on the left. She demonstrated pain on passive dorsiflexion of the left foot.  Probable Diagnosis: These symptoms and signs lead towards a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).   Plan: A D-dimer test in order to assess the possibility of DVT. If positive  she would be referred to get an ultrasound scan to confirm the diagnosis. Consider beginning her on low molecular weight heparin  pending diagnostic confirmation.  Long Term Considerations: Discuss anticoagulation therapy and its implications. Consider potential risk factor modification including the cessation of HRT. Regular follow-ups to monitor anticoagulant treatment and her overall health. Lifestyle modifications encouraged to reduce DVT's future risk. Her family history of cardiovascular diseases needs attention and requires preventative strategies. Referral may be considered to a hematology specialist for thrombophilia screening due to her history of unprovoked DVT.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Brown  a 70-year-old African-American male  presented to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of right leg swelling  tenderness and warmth. He also complained of dull ache in his calf muscle. He denied any recent travels  hospitalizations  or injuries that might have contributed to the condition.  Patient’s Medical History:   Mr. Brown has a long-standing history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He suffered from a myocardial infarction two years ago which was treated with a stent placement. His current medications include Metformin  Amlodipine and Aspirin as a secondary prophylaxis. He is also on Lipitor for his hypercholesterolemia.  Family History:  There is a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father suffering from a stroke at age 66 and his mother dying of a myocardial infarction at age 75. He has two siblings  one of them diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease.   Social History:  Mr. Brown is a retired mechanic. He is a former smoker (30-pack years) and admits to drinking alcohol socially. He lives with his wife and admits to a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity.   On Physical examination and investigations:  Physical examination revealed a markedly swollen right leg with tenderness on deep palpation. Pitting edema was noted  and there was a palpable cord along the course of right popliteal vein. His vitals were stable with blood pressure at 130/80mmHg and heart rate at 85bpm.   Venous Doppler Ultrasound of his right leg confirmed the presence of a clot in right femoral vein suggestive of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Blood investigations showed elevated D-dimer levels. His other laboratory findings including complete blood count  liver and kidney function tests  and coagulation studies were within normal limits.  Management:  Mr. Brown was administered with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and admitted for further monitoring. A consult to Hematology was made to discuss the possibility of underlying conditions that could predispose this patient to thrombosis. A comprehensive plan incorporating lifestyle modifications and exercise was discussed  and he was also informed of the importance of compliance with anticoagulation therapy to prevent the possible complication of pulmonary embolism.   Conclusion:  Early recognition and prompt treatment is crucial in deep vein thrombosis. This case featured the typical presentation of DVT in a patient with multiple cardiovascular risk factors and underlying comorbid conditions. Proper management including lifestyle modifications and strict medication adherence is key to preventing complications.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: Our patient – Mr. Charles Smith  is a 68-year-old caucasian male weighing 190 lbs and standing at 5'10"" tall. He lives with his wife in the suburbs of Florida  is a retired civil engineer and has a history of sedentary behavior with occasional recreational fishing.  Past Medical History: Upon reviewing patient’s past medical history  Mr. Smith's portfolio includes Hypertension (HTN) for 10 years  Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 8 years  and Hyperlipidemia  all currently being managed with medication. He had a surgical history of left total knee arthroplasty 6 weeks ago. Smith quit smoking 15 years ago after a 30-year pack history  and drinks alcohol socially. He denies any illicit drug use.  Family History: Charles' father passed away at the age of 74 from a stroke  and his mother at 78 from breast cancer. His older brother of 70 has Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). There are no other significant illnesses recorded in the immediate family.  Presenting Problem: He presents today with a 3-day history of progressive swelling  pain  and warmth in his left calf which is not relieved by over the counter pain medications. He states that he first noticed the discomfort after a long drive from visiting his son in Nashville. There is no history of chest pain  shortness of breath  or physical trauma to the leg.   Examination: On examination  his left calf is significantly swollen with visible varicosities  warm  and tender on deep palpation of the calf muscles compared to the right side. Homan's sign is positive. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.   Diagnosis and Management Plan: Based on the clinical presentation and history  a preliminary diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) was made. Lab tests including a D-Dimer and subsequent Doppler Ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis. Given the hypertension  diabetes  recent surgery  and sedentary lifestyle  the patient is a high risk for DVT.  Anticoagulant therapy has been initiated with low molecular weight heparin and planned to be bridged to oral warfarin. The patient is counseled about the importance of compliance with this life-long treatment. Furthermore  he has been advised to increase mobility  maintain hydration  exercise regularly  and wear compression stockings to prevent recurrence. Regular follow-ups have been scheduled to monitor treatment effectiveness and possible complications.   This case emphasizes how the lack of mobility and previous surgical intervention can predispose an individual to deep vein thrombosis  highlighting the need for preventive measures in similar cases.

Patient Information: Mrs. Jane Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian female.  Presenting Symptoms: Mrs. Smith presented to the emergency department with about a week of increased swelling  redness  and pain in her left lower leg.  Past Medical History: Hypertension  Type II Diabetes  Hyperlipidemia. Mrs. Smith is a former smoker and quit 5 years ago. Her medications include Metformin  Lipitor  and Lisinopril.  Family History: Both parents had Type II Diabetes. Her mother had a stroke at 76 and her father had a myocardial infarction at 69. She has one brother who has hypertension.  Social History: Mrs. Smith is a retired teacher  widow with two adult children. She does not smoke or use recreational drugs. She drinks occasionally  maybe a glass of wine per week.  Investigations: Doppler ultrasound of the left leg shows a thrombus in the popliteal vein  clinching the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Treatment History: Mrs. Smith has been compliant with her medications historically  and her diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia are well controlled.  Plan: Mrs. Smith is admitted for anticoagulation treatment  specifically low molecular weight heparin. She is to continue taking her other medications as prescribed.   Risk Factors: Elderly  sedentary lifestyle  history of smoking  obesity  and her genetic predisposition due to family history.  Monitoring: Mrs. Smith will need to be monitored for improvements in her symptoms. Her INR and kidney function will also need to be watched closely due to her treatment with anticoagulants.  Patient Education: Importance of mobility and exercises  adequate hydration  adhering to anticoagulant therapy  monitoring for signs of embolic events  and maintaining regular follow-up appointments have been emphasized.  Disposition: The multidisciplinary team  including social work and occupational therapy  will assess her to ensure she is safe to return home. The plan is for her to be discharged once stable on anticoagulation.  Follow-Up: Mrs. Smith is scheduled to meet with the thrombosis clinic and her primary care provider in one week for follow-up post-discharge. She has contact information for the thrombosis clinic if her symptoms worsen or if any new symptoms emerge.

Subject: 62-Year-Old Female  Diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Case Presentation:   Patient Introduction: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. A  who hails from a suburban neighborhood of Chicago. She is a retired school teacher  and her past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Mrs. A is on regular antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications  as per her primary care physician's advice.  Presenting Issue: Mrs. A presented at the outpatient clinic with persistent pains and swelling in her left lower leg over the past four days  accompanied by warmth and redness. She initially dismissed the discomfort  associating them with her usual arthritis. However  with escalating symptoms  she decided to seek medical attention.  Family History: Her family history reveals that her father had a stroke at the age of 67  her mother has type II diabetes  and her older brother died of myocardial infarction at 60. Her only child  a daughter aged 35  is presently healthy.  Diagnostics and Tests: Complete Blood Count (CBC)  D-dimer test and a Compression Ultrasound of the left lower leg were conducted. CBC was within normal range. The D-Dimer test result was significantly elevated  indicating possible presence of an abnormal level of fibrin degradation fragments  typically seen in DVT or Pulmonary Embolism. The ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  revealing a non-compressible segment in the left posterior tibial vein.  Management: Mrs. A was immediately started on a course of anticoagulation therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin (Enoxaparin)  followed by oral warfarin for long term management. She was also educated on lifestyle modifications such as regular walking  leg elevation and use of elastic compression stockings.  Follow-Up: She was advised to follow up in the clinic in one week for monitoring her response to the therapy  and to adjust the warfarin dose based on her International Normalized Ratio (INR) levels. In addition  she was informed about the symptoms of pulmonary embolism- a potential complication of DVT  and advised to immediately report any such signs.  Summary: Timely identification and management of DVT in this patient is essential given her previous history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and her family history of cardiovascular disease  making her more susceptible to severe complications. Regular follow-ups and monitoring are critical to ensure effective treatment. Integration of DVT prophylaxis strategies in patients similar to Mrs. A would be beneficial in preventing such incidences in the future.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male presenting with complaints of swelling and pain in his left calf for the past week. He is a retiree and lives with his wife. His past medical history includes well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. The patient also had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago  requiring PCI with a drug-eluting stent. He is currently on Metformin  Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Aspirin.  Family medical history is significant for cardiovascular disease; his father died of myocardial infarction at age 62  his mother had a stroke at age 70. He has two brothers  one whom had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at age 57. The patient is a former pack-a-day smoker for 25 years but quit 10 years ago after the heart attack. He admits to occasional alcohol consumption but denies any illicit drug use.  Physical Examination & Clinical Findings:  On examination  his left calf is swollen and tender on palpation with increased warmth compared to the right. Positive Homan's sign on the left. His vital signs are within normal range: BP 135/85 mmHg  Pulse 75 bpm  Temp 98.2 °F  Oxygen Saturation 95% at room air.  Investigations:  Given the high clinical suspicion based on history  findings  and risk factors  an emergency Doppler Ultrasound was ordered. This revealed a presence of a clot in the left posterior tibial and peroneal veins  confirming a diagnosis of Left Lower Extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Treatment and Management:  The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) in hospital. After a few days of LMWH overlap  his regimen was switched to Apixaban  a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC)  for long-term management. The patient was educated about the signs of pulmonary embolism  a potential complication of DVT.  The patient was discharged with a scheduled follow-up in outpatient clinic  and a note was sent to his primary care physician regarding the new diagnosis and anticoagulation treatment. Follow-up protocols including repeat scanning and blood tests were advised.  In light of the family history  the patient was also advised to have his first-degree relatives tested for inherited clotting disorders. The lifestyle modifications including regular exercise  a balanced diet  and compression stockings were emphasized to aid in symptom management and prevent post-thrombotic syndrome.  Given his past medical history  the patient’s other medications - Metformin  Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Aspirin were continued unchanged. His blood pressure and Diabetes were well managed with these medications and he was advised to continue taking these consistently. He was also reminded about the importance of regular check-ups to monitor his overall health status related to his underlying conditions.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jones  a 58-year-old Caucasian male truck driver  reported to the emergency department with a 2-day history of increasing pain and swelling in his left leg. The patient is nonsmoker and maintains a moderate consumption of alcohol.  Patient history:  The patient has a history of obesity  with a body mass index (BMI) of 32.4. He has no known allergies. His medical history includes hypertension  which has been controlled with Lisinopril for the past 5 years. Mr. Jones has a sedentary job - spending up to 10-12 hours per day sitting behind the wheel. He also noted that his father died of a pulmonary embolism at the age of 60.  Clinical findings:  Physical examination of the left leg showed warmth  erythema  tenderness  and a palpable cord. Homan’s sign was positive. Peripheral pulses were intact  but distension of the superficial veins was observed. No ulcers or signs of chronic venous insufficiency were present. The right leg was normal.  Diagnostic assessment:  A venous Doppler ultrasound revealed thrombosis in the left popliteal vein extending up to the superficial femoral vein. D-dimer testing result was elevated. Complete blood counts (CBC)  serum chemistries  and coagulation profiles were in the normal range except for mildly elevated blood pressure.   Therapeutic intervention:  The patient was hospitalized and started on therapeutic low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) enoxaparin along with oral anticoagulant  apixaban  in view of long term management of DVT. Compression stockings were added to reduce his symptoms of swelling and pain.  Conclusion/Plan: Mr. Jones was educated on the importance of lifestyle changes  including diet  weight loss  stopping alcohol  and the importance of regular breaks during long drives to avoid prolonged immobility. Given his family history  genetic testing for hypercoagulability disorders was discussed. He will also be on close outpatient follow-up with the Hematology and Vascular medicine department.  This case emphasizes the importance of assessing lifestyle factors and a thorough family history in patients presenting with deep vein thrombosis. Obesity  prolonged immobility  and family history significantly increased the patient's risk.

Patient Presentation: Mr. James Chambers  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented with complaints of increased swelling and pain in his left lower leg  which have been ongoing for about three days. He denied any recent trauma or injury to the area. He rated his pain as 8/10 and describes it as constant  dull  and non-radiating.  Demographics: Mr. Chambers is a retired engineer living with his wife in the suburban area. He is a former smoker but quit 20 years ago. He currently consumes alcohol moderately  about two to three times a week. He denies any illicit drug use.  Past Medical History: He has a known history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus which are managed with Lisinopril and Metformin respectively. He also takes aspirin daily for cardioprotection. He underwent hip replacement surgery on his left side two years ago.   Family History:  His father had a myocardial infarction in his late 60's and his mother suffers from Rheumatoid arthritis. His younger sister was recently diagnosed with breast cancer.  Physical Examination:  On examination  his left leg appeared visibly swollen with noticeable tenderness. Leg was warm to touch. Distal pulses were palpable. No rashes or signs of injury were seen. There was a positive Homan's sign (pain upon forced dorsiflexion of foot) which might suggest deep vein thrombosis.  Clinical Impressions & Plan: A Doppler ultrasound was ordered immediately due to high suspicion of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Possible causes could be his recent period of immobility due to COVID lockdown  sedentary lifestyle  prolonged travel or even the hip replacement he underwent two years ago could be factors. A multidisciplinary approach with the involvement of a vascular surgeon will be necessary based on ultrasound findings. If the results are positive for DVT  therapeutic anticoagulation with Heparin will be initiated immediately  later transitioned to oral anticoagulants such as Warfarin or Rivaroxaban for long-term management. Patient education will be provided about the risk of possible complications.  In addition  lifestyle modifications will be discussed  including improving mobility  incorporating exercise  reducing alcohol consumption  and monitoring his diet to better manage his diabetes and hypertension. His family history suggests a possible risk for cardio and oncological diseases; therefore  regular follow-ups and preventive check-ups should be considered.

Patient Information: Mr. Carter  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  came complaining about persistent aching pain in his right leg  palpable swelling  and redness which began around 4 days ago. He works as a truck driver  which requires him to sit for long periods with no movement. He lives with his wife and has two adult children who do not live nearby. Mr. Carter is a smoker and has a history of heavy alcohol consumption but quit drinking 10 years ago.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of high blood pressure and elevated cholesterol levels. He was diagnosed with these conditions about six years ago and has been on hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin since then. He is overweight with a Body Mass Index of 30 kg/m2  dichotomous for obesity in males. He has no prior history of surgeries or hospitalizations. There is no known allergy.  Family History: He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases (his father died of a MI at 78  a brother had a stroke at 68).  Presentation: On examination  localized warmth  erythema  and tenderness are present over the calf muscle of his right lower leg. His resting pulse is slightly elevated at 90 beats per minute. His vital signs were within the normal parameters.  Diagnoses: The initial clinical concern is of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) based on the patient's symptoms of calf pain  swelling  and erythema. His sedentary lifestyle  obesity  family history  and hypertension raise the suspicion for DVT. An ultrasound was ordered to confirm the diagnosis. Lab work reveals an elevated D-dimer.  Plan: Mr. Carter was diagnosed with DVT and started on low-molecular-weight heparin (Enoxaparin) injection and later transitioned to oral anticoagulants (Rivaroxaban). Patient education included warning signs of DVT or pulmonary embolism  compliance with anticoagulant therapy  and lifestyle modification to assist weight loss and increase activity levels. The importance of smoking cessation was also stressed.  Follow up: The patient was advised to follow up in the clinic in two weeks to check his progress and any adverse effects of medication. Home health was arranged for initial injections and monitoring.

Patient Information: James O’Connor  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  is a long-distance truck driver by profession. He was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) recently. He has had a history of high blood pressure for the past 10 years that is well controlled with medication. He is obese with a BMI of 32 and also has a 20-pack-year history of tobacco use. He is not known to have any allergies. His daily diet is high in fats and cholesterol and very low in fiber.  Family History: Mr. O’Connor has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  notably DVT. His father had DVT at the age of 50 and later passed away from a heart attack at the age of 60. His mother  currently 80  has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He also has one older sibling who has type 2 diabetes and hypertension.   Presenting Complaints: The patient recently noticed that his right leg was swollen  red  and more painful than usual  especially after his long drives. The swelling extended from the lower leg to just above the knee. He also reported feeling a slight warmth over the area of complaint.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  the right leg was significantly larger than the left. There was notable redness and a palpable cord was felt in the right popliteal fossa. Upon further questioning  he reported a mild shortness of breath  but denied any associated chest pain or recent trauma to the legs.   Diagnosis: Based on clinical examination and family history  a venous Doppler ultrasound was ordered to confirm the suspected diagnosis of DVT. The ultrasound revealed evidence of a non-compressible popliteal vein  confirming a blood clot in the deep vein system of the right lower leg.  Treatment: Patient was admitted for initiation of anticoagulation therapy. He was started on intravenous heparin and transitioned to oral warfarin. Patient education was provided regarding lifestyle modification and medication adherence.  Follow-up & Prognosis: He is due for a follow-up in two weeks and will be referred to a hematologist for further workup given his familial predisposition to thrombotic diseases.   Preventive Measures: During his hospital stay  he was educated on the necessity of regular exercise  healthy diet  frequent leg movement during his long drives  quit smoking  and maintain regular follow-ups with his physician. The importance of adherence to his prescribed medication was stressed to lower the risk of pulmonary embolism. Weight loss due to his obesity was also recommended.   General Comments: The patient’s truck driving profession was labeled as a risk factor due to long periods of immobility while driving. The situation was further complicated by his family history and personal lifestyle choices like poor diet and smoking. Future management will focus on risk factor modulation to prevent recurrence.

Patient Presentation:  Identification and Demographics: The patient  Mr. A.B  is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  residing in Seattle  Washington. He is a retired engineer  married for 40 years  with two children and five grandchildren.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. A.B presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset right leg pain and swelling that has persisted for the past two days. He noted that the discomfort increased with walking and standing. He also reported occasional shortness of breath.  Relevant Past Medical History: Mr. A.B has a history of hypertension controlled with medication (Amlovas 5mg daily)  and he underwent an appendectomy at 22. Over the last six months  he had noticed progressive breathlessness when climbing stairs. His BMI is 29 and he is an occasional smoker.  Family History: Mr. A.B's father had late-onset diabetes and died of a heart attack at 80. His mother passed away at 90 from complications of a cerebrovascular accident. His sister has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  posing a genetic predisposition to the condition in the family.  Clinical Investigations: A physical examination resulted in the discovery of elevated temperature (38.3C)  calf tenderness  and swelling in the right lower limb. A D-dimer test indicated higher than normal levels  suggesting potential clot presence. An ultrasound Doppler study was performed  confirming the presence of a thrombus in the right lower limb's deep veins. He was started on therapeutic  weight-based low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)  and oral anticoagulation therapy with a target INR of 2-3 commenced the following day after consultation with a hematologist.  Impression and Plan: Based on the clinical presentation  physical examination  his sister's medical history specifically  and the diagnostic tests  Mr. A.B. has been diagnosed with right lower limb deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He was admitted for further observation and management. His treatment regimen includes anticoagulation therapy and compression stockings to alleviate symptoms and prevent clot propagation.  Education and lifestyle modifications  such as gradual increase physical activity  maintaining a healthy diet  weight loss  and smoking cessation  were advised for the long-term treatment. He will be scheduled for follow-up visits in the outpatient clinic once discharged. His family was also educated about the symptoms of DVT since the family history may increase their risk.   This case also suggests the possibility of venous thromboembolism (VTE) with the occasional shortness of breath  requiring further investigations in the form of a CT pulmonary angiogram.   Clearly  Mr. A.B's case should be treated with vigilant care given his age  underlying hypertension  and positive family history for DVT. Such cases highlight the importance of early diagnosis and treatment of DVT to avoid life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Patient Background: The patient  Mr. Alan Murphy  is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with complaints of persistent pain and swelling in his right leg. His past medical history includes Type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Mr. Murphy is a retired truck driver who regularly smokes and admits to consuming alcohol in moderate amounts. He lives alone following the death of his wife three years ago. There is no definitive family history of Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) or thrombotic episodes.  Clinical Presentation: Over the past few days  Mr. Murphy had noted a growing discomfort in his right lower leg described as a dull ache  which later progressed to moderate pain. An associated swelling appeared that is warm and tender to touch. He also complained of mild shortness of breath. There is no history of recent prolonged immobilization  surgery  or trauma.  Physical Examination and Diagnosis: Upon clinical physical examination  his right leg was swollen compared to the left. Homan's sign was positive (calf pain on dorsiflexion of his foot). His pulse rate was slightly elevated  and the rest of the vital signs were within normal range. The preliminary diagnosis was Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Diagnostic Results and Further Management: Lab results revealed slightly elevated D-dimer levels. An Ultrasound Doppler study showed evidence of clotting in the right popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of DVT. He was immediately started on low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)  an anticoagulant.   Mr. Murphy was hospitalized during the acute management and for close monitoring of his condition owing to his comorbidities and risk factors. The patient was counseled about quitting smoking and advised to control his alcohol intake. He was educated about the importance of regular physical activity and measures for DVT prevention such as leg exercises  taking breaks during prolonged periods of sitting/standing  and maintaining hydration.  Patient Follow-Up: After stabilization  Mr. Murphy was discharged with oral anticoagulants (Warfarin) with strict instructions for regular INR monitoring and a schedule for follow-up visits with a Hematologist and his primary health care provider. Physical therapy was also arranged to help him with persistent leg pain and swelling. He was also referred to an endocrinologist for better regulation of his diabetes and to a pulmonologist to rule out possible Pulmonary Embolism sequelae. Given the patient's solitude  local community support was involved to provide assistance at home and ensure he adheres to the plan.  By presenting this case  it is essential to highlight that DVT can present in any individual with prolonged immobilization  certain comorbidities  and lifestyle habits such as smoking and alcohol.
