Patient Information:  The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian male named John  who is a retired construction worker.   Chief Complaint:  John was brought to the hospital with complaints of acute onset severe pain in her right calf  which was associated with redness and swelling.  History of Present Illness:  The pain started suddenly while at home and gradually increased. It prevents him from walking and is aggravated by movement. As per John  he recently had a long haul flight of 16 hours from Australia to the US about 3 days ago. He recalls his right leg being immobile and constricted for most of the flight which could be a potential risk factor for his current state.  Past Medical History:  John has a history of hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril. His blood pressure is controlled adequately. He has no history of diabetes  cardiac ailments  or any cancer.  Social History:  John has a history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for the last 30 years but quit 5 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and does not use illegal drugs.  Family History:  No family history of clotting disorders  malignancy  or genetic disorders. His mother died in her 80s due to Alzheimer's and his father died of a heart attack in his late 70s.  Physical Examination:  John is in obvious pain during the examination. His vital signs are stable. His right leg is red and swollen in comparison to the left leg and is tender in the calf region. No ulcers or cyanosis were noted.  Investigations:  Blood tests  including complete blood count  coagulation profile  D-dimer level are recommended along with Doppler ultrasound of the leg.  Diagnosis:  John has been diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) on the basis of physical examination. This diagnosis needs to be confirmed or refuted by the laboratory and radiology investigations.  Management plan:  If DVT is confirmed  John is likely to begin anticoagulation therapy to prevent the clot from getting bigger and to stop it from breaking off and causing a Pulmonary Embolism (PE). Patient education about the importance of medication compliance and lifestyle modifications (proper hydration  regular exercise  avoiding long periods of immobility) forms an integral part of the management.  Follow-up:  Regular follow-ups to monitor anticoagulant therapy and relief from symptoms will be scheduled.  This brief case presentation highlights the potential risk factors  clinical presentation  and diagnosis and management of DVT in an elderly patient with a significant risk factor of immobilization during a long flight.

Patient Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: Patient X is a 60-year-old Caucasian male weighing approximately 86 kg and standing 5 feet  10 inches tall.  Chief Complaint:  Patient X presented with minor pain and swelling in the left leg  specifically the calf region  that has gradually increased over 4 days.   History of Present Illness: Patient reported a lack of mobility due to a recent left hip replacement surgery one month ago  following a fall from a ladder while doing some home repairs. He notes feeling unwell and experiencing warmth in his left calf  describing the pain as a 'muscle pull.' He also reported mild shortness of breath when he walks a short distance.   Past Medical History:  Patient has a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  hip osteoarthritis  and a myocardial infarction eight years ago. Medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and daily aspirin. No known allergies to medications were reported. Patient is an ex-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally.  Family History:  Father had heart disease and died at age 78  while mother  now 82  is managing osteoporosis and type 2 diabetes. The patient has one older brother who is currently undergoing treatment for prostate cancer.   Physical Examination:  On physical examination  his vital signs were stable. Lower extremity exam showed swelling (2+ edema) in the left leg  calf tenderness  and warm skin. The right leg was normal. There was no chest pain  but the patient appeared mildly anxious. Cardiovascular and abdominal exams were normal.   Considerations and Impression: The patient's symptoms and recent history of hip surgery indicate a high likelihood of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). He is considered high risk  given his age  recent surgery  limited mobility  and history of cardiovascular disease.   Plan: A Doppler Ultrasound was ordered to confirm the diagnosis and to rule out other causes of his symptoms. The patient has been started on prophylactic anticoagulation therapy (low molecular weight heparin) until further investigations. Patient has been instructed to elevate his leg and perform simple exercises. If DVT is confirmed  long-term anticoagulation therapy is warranted  given the size and location of the thrombus.    (Note: All information provided is fictional and for the sake of the case presentation).

Patient Profile: Ms. Susan  a 52-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department complaining of left lower leg pain and swelling. She works as an office assistant and leads a sedentary lifestyle  mostly sitting on her desk for prolonged periods. She is a smoker with a 20-pack year history. She denies illicit drug use and alcohol.   Medical History: She has a history of hypertension  diagnosed two years ago and is on Lisinopril 10 mg daily. She has no history of diabetes mellitus or hyperlipidemia. She is normotensive and her blood glucose levels are within normal range during recent medical interventions.  Presenting Complaints: She reported increased leg pain over a period of the last 5 days which has gradually worsened. The pain was associated with swelling and tenderness. There was no reported trauma.   Family History: Her father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 60 and the mother died of breast cancer at 75 years. She has a family history of thrombotic events  her younger brother suffering from a pulmonary embolism at the age of 46.  Diagnosis: On physical examination  there was left calf tenderness and swelling  positive Homan's sign. No skin discoloration or ulceration was observed. D-dimer was found to be elevated at 700 ng/ml. She was then referred for an ultrasound scan of her left lower leg  which confirmed the presence of a clot in the popliteal vein. The diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was established.  Management and Recommendations: She was started on anticoagulation with Heparin  followed by transition to oral anticoagulant  Warfarin  for a period of at least three months. She has been counseled about the signs and symptoms of Pulmonary Embolism. Risk factor modification was discussed  involving cessation of smoking and initiation of regular physical activity.   Follow Up: The patient is recommended to have periodic follow-ups for monitoring the INR (international normalized ratio) and for dose adjustment of Warfarin. She is also advised to seek immediate medical attention if she experiences symptoms like chest pain or shortness of breath  that could indicate a possible Pulmonary Embolism. Screening for occult malignancy is also suggested given her age and unprovoked DVT.   This case highlights the importance of considering DVT in patients who present with unexplained pain and swelling in the lower limbs  particularly in those with risk factors such as sedentary lifestyle  smoking  and a family history of thrombotic events.

Presentation  Patient Profile: Ms. Robbins is a 72-year-old Caucasian female with a recent diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She resides in a nursing home and has a personal aide that assists with ambulation. She was admitted for right calf swelling and pain.   Past Medical History: Her past medical history is significant for hypertension  obesity  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for which she is on a regimen of amlodipine  metformin  and tiotropium respectively. There's no history of previous DVT or pulmonary embolism.    Family History: Her family history is notable for her father dying of a stroke at age 75. She has one brother currently managing diabetes and hypertension.   Presentation: Over the last week  Ms. Robbins complained of a progressive swelling and constant  non-radiating pain in her right calf. No history of trauma or prolonged immobilization exists. She has no past experiences of similar episodes  dyspnea  chest pain  or hemoptysis.  Examinations: Upon physical examination  the patient's vital signs were stable. Her right calf was tender  edematous  and warm compared with her left calf. There was no superficial venous distention or skin discoloration present. The remainder of the physical examination was normal.   Investigations: Deep vein thrombosis was suspected based on clinical presentation. A full blood count  coagulation profile  and D-dimer were ordered. Results showed D-dimer of 900 ng/mL (Normal <500 ng/mL). An ultrasound Doppler study of the right lower extremity subsequently confirmed the presence of DVT.  Management: After diagnosis  she was started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)  transitioning to oral anticoagulants for long-term therapy. The patient  family members  and the nursing home staff were educated about the usage of compression stockings and the importance of mobilization to minimize the risk of recurrence.  Conclusion: Although Ms. Robbins is at risk due to her age  obesity  and probable lack of mobility  she had no prior family history of DVT. This case highlights the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for DVT in high-risk patients with lower limb swelling and pain. Regular monitoring and management of the patient's comorbidities  along with proper care  would be necessary to avoid recurrent episodes or further complications.

Patient Information:  The patient  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old male  was presented to the hospital with complaints of severe pain and swelling in the right lower leg. He is a Caucasian  married  and a retired bank officer  currently living with his wife.  Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension for the last 10 years  diabetes mellitus for the past 8 years  and has been smoking a pack of cigarettes a day for about 40 years. He is currently on anti-hypertensives (Lisinopril)  anti-diabetics (Metformin)  and statins for hyperlipidemia diagnosed 7 years ago. He has no known drug allergies. He also underwent surgery for a hernia around a year ago  after which he had a brief bed-bound recovery period.  Family History:  The patient's father died at the age of 72 due to a myocardial infarction  and his mother  aged 80  is living with Alzheimer's disease. His elder brother underwent aortic valve replacement  and his sister has type 2 diabetes.  Current Clinical Presentation:  Upon examination  his right calf appeared to be swollen  warm  and tender compared to the left calf  indicating possible deep vein thrombosis (DVT). On a pain scale of 0 to 10  with 10 being the highest pain  Mr. Doe described his pain as a 7. His vital signs were stable: BP- 140/90 mm Hg (under medicines)  pulse- 78 beats/min  respiratory rate-18 breaths/min  and body temp- 98.6°F. Lab results showed an elevated D-dimer level.  Imaging:  A Doppler Ultrasound confirmed a non-compressible segment in the right lower leg popliteal vein  which was consistent with a diagnosis of DVT.  Plan:  A diagnosis of acute DVT was made  and Mr. Doe was immediately started on anticoagulants (heparin) to prevent further thrombus formation. His concurrent medications for hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia were continued. Patient education about the importance of smoking cessation  weight control  regular exercise  and a healthy diet was emphasized. The treatment progress is being closely monitored and adjusted as necessary.   Teaching points for medical students include identifying risk factors for venous thromboembolism (such as postoperative state  malignancy  immobilization)  recognizing the typical clinical signs of DVT (such as unilateral leg pain  swelling)  familiarity with diagnostic work-up like D-dimer assay  and Doppler ultrasound  and understanding the principles of management with anticoagulation.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information and Demographics:  Mr. John Doe is a 65-year-old male patient of Caucasian descent  currently residing in Seattle  WA. He is a retired high school teacher  married with two adult children. He has rarely been on any medication  maintained a balanced diet  and occasional exercises  with a history of moderate alcohol consumption. His BMI measurement is 26  which falls into the overweight category.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe's past medical history is significant for hypertension and high cholesterol levels treated with lisinopril and atorvastatin  respectively  for the past 5 years. He quit smoking ten years ago  after a 25-year smoking history. He has no known allergies. He was hospitalized once for appendectomy in his early 20s.   Presentation:  Mr. Doe presented to his primary care physician with a one-week history of swelling and progressive and unusual pain in his left calf. The symptom was persistent  becoming worse when standing or walking for long periods with no history of trauma or injury to his leg. On examination  the left calf was noticeably swollen and tender on palpation compared to the right one. The overlying skin was warm  and there was a noticeable color change. No palpable lymph nodes were noticed.  Family History:  In terms of his family history  Mr. Doe's parents both had cardiovascular disease. His father had suffered a stroke and later passed on due to a heart failure in his seventies. His mother is 89-years-old  living with hypertension and type 2 diabetes. One blood sibling with no significant health issues.  Diagnostic Evaluation  The primary physician referred Mr. Doe for an urgent Doppler ultrasound  which revealed a thrombus in the left popliteal vein extending to superficial femoral vein  indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Blood tests showed an elevated D-dimer level.  Clinical Course:  Mr. Doe was immediately started on anticoagulants (rivaroxaban)  a non-Vitamin K oral anticoagulant (NOAC)  for initial and long-term treatment of DVT. In addition to managing his DVT  the healthcare team educated him on the needs to increase physical activity  blood pressure and cholesterol control  diet modifications  primarily focusing on reducing salt and fat intake.  In Summary:  Mr. Doe  a 65-year-old male with DVT  has multiple risk factors for his condition  including his hypertensive and hyperlipidemic status  age  family history of cardiovascular disease  and sedentary lifestyle. His condition is currently being managed with rivaroxaban  and lifestyle modifications are also recommended in controlling contributing risk factors. He needs regular monitoring of his symptoms and treatment response and alertness for any symptoms of complications. The patient and his family were educated about the condition  its risk factors  management  and need for follow-up.

Patient Presentation:   Patient is Mr. T  a 45-year-old Caucasian male  a known case of Hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. T presented to the emergency department with ongoing severe pain and swelling in his left leg for the past couple of days. He also reports decreased mobility and a warmth sensation in the same leg.   Past Medical History:  Apart from Hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  Mr. T has also been known to have hypercholesterolemia. His blood pressure  glucose  and cholesterol have been well controlled with medication. There were no previous incidences of any thrombotic diseases or cardiovascular events. He also tells us he is a former smoker  having quit 5 years ago. There are no known drug allergies  and he's been on Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin for his current medical conditions.  Family History:  Mr. T's father died of a heart attack at 60  and his mother has Type II Diabetes. His elder brother also has established coronary artery disease. There's no recorded history of any hematological disorders or thrombotic diseases in the family.  Social History:  He works as a software engineer  leading a predominantly sedentary lifestyle  with minimal to no regular exercise. He quit smoking 5 years ago  but admits to occasional drinking.  Clinical Findings and Diagnosis:  On examination  the patient's left leg was swollen with erythema and tenderness along the line of the left popliteal vein. Systemic examination was normal. An ultrasound confirmed a clot in the left popliteal vein. D-dimer levels were also high. Subsequently  Mr. T was diagnosed with DVT.  Current Management:  He was admitted to the hospital and started on anticoagulant therapy (low molecular weight Heparin) immediately. His current medications for hypertension  diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia are also being continued. He'll regularly undergo INR monitoring and the treatment will be adjusted accordingly.  Health Education and Prevention:  Mr. T was educated about the importance of lifestyle modifications. He agreed to incorporate more physical activity into his daily routine and maintain a balanced diet. He was also asked to be compliant with his prescribed medications and regular follow-up visits.   Future Plan:  A follow-up duplex ultrasound is planned after the completion of the initial therapeutic course. Depending upon the patient's response  the management plan may be revised. A preventive plan including regular exercise  diet regulation  and stress management has been discussed with Mr. T.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile:  Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old African American male resident of New York City presenting to the emergency room with complaints of pain and swelling in his left lower limb.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a ten-year history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  all of which are well-controlled with medication. He has also been previously diagnosed with obesity  with a current BMI of 32. He had a cholecystectomy in his forties. He does not have any known allergies.   Presenting Issue: The patient reports that he started feeling discomfort in his left leg about a week ago  which slowly progressed to acute pain. The leg also appears swollen and slightly warmer to the touch. The pain is intermittent and increases on walking or standing. Mr. Smith denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough but admits to recent limited mobility due to a minor foot injury. This introduced a sedentary lifestyle over the past month.  Social History: Mr. Smith is a retired schoolteacher who lives with his wife. He gave up smoking approximately 15 years ago  but admits to moderately consuming alcohol. His diet is not balanced and primarily consists of high-fat foods.  Family History:  Mr. Smith's father and grandfather both had heart disease and his mother had a stroke in her sixties. His elder sister was diagnosed with peripheral vascular disease.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  Mr. Smith's left lower extremity is significantly swollen with a slightly cyanotic appearance. The left calf muscle is tender to touch and the leg circumference is larger when compared with the right.  Investigations: Ultrasound Doppler of the left lower limb revealed a thrombus in the left popliteal vein and D-Dimer levels were elevated than normal.  Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical history  physical examination  and results of the ultrasound Doppler and D-dimer levels  Mr. Smith was diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis.  This case showcases the need for early detection and intervention of DVT  especially in patients with predisposing factors such as a sedentary lifestyle  advanced age  obesity  diabetes  and a family history of vascular diseases. Since this condition may lead to severe complications such as pulmonary embolism  immediate treatment is crucial.  As a physician and a healthcare provider  it is necessary to educate patients about the risk factors and complications of DVT and the importance of lifestyle modifications to prevent the occurrence or recurrence of such conditions.

Patient Case Presentation  Patient Details: Ms. Jeanette Nichols is a 56-year-old Caucasian female residing in Austin  Texas. She has a known history of hypertension (HTN) and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM). Ms. Nichols works as a senior software engineer  predominantly desk-based work with long hours of sitting. She is a non-smoker and admits occasional alcohol intake.  History of Present Illness: Ms. Nichols presented to the clinic with a three-day history of progressive pain and mild swelling in her left lower leg. She noticed an increase in discomfort during ambulation. There was no history of trauma  fever  or recent travel.  Past Medical History: Besides HTN and Type 2 DM  Ms. Nichols has no history of pulmonary or cardiovascular diseases. Her DM is well-controlled with metformin  and she has been regularly compliant with antihypertensive medication.  Family History: Family history reveals that Ms. Nichols' paternal grandfather died in his late fifties from a cerebrovascular accident. Her mother had deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her early sixties. Ms. Nichols does not have any siblings.  Physical Examination & Investigations: On examination  the left lower limb appeared slightly swollen  and tenderness was observed along the line of the deep veins  with mild erythema and increased warmth. Her vital signs were stable with a BP of 130/85mmHg  heart rate of 78/min  and BMI of 28. Doppler Ultrasound revealed a thrombus in the left popliteal vein  confirming a diagnosis of DVT.   Treatment Management & Outcome: Anticoagulation treatment was initiated with Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) followed by Warfarin with INR monitoring. A repeat Doppler after five days showed that the thrombus size had decreased. She was educated on the importance of ambulation  exercises  calf muscle pumping  and avoidance of prolonged sitting. The patient was advised to continue anticoagulant therapy and metformin and scheduled for a follow-up after two weeks.  Conclusion: For Ms. Nichols  the sedentary nature of her occupation combined with personal history of HTN  DM  and a familial history of vascular events may have contributed to the development of DVT. It is crucial to assess her response to treatment and monitor closely for signs of possible pulmonary embolism. Lifestyle modifications and regular follow-up sessions are recommended to prevent recurrence.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson is a 68-year-old African American woman who presented to the emergency department complaining of a 4-day history of right lower leg pain and swelling. She describes the pain as constant  dull ache that increases when she walks. Ms. Johnson's vitals upon arrival were stable with a blood pressure of 130/75 mm Hg  heart rate of 73 beats per min  oxygen saturation of 98% on room air  and temperature of 98.2°F. She has slight edema and erythema on her right lower limb but no signs of ulceration or ecchymosis.  Past Medical History: Ms. Johnson has a significant past medical history of hypertension  controlled with lisinopril  and type 2 diabetes  controlled with metformin. She had a total knee arthroplasty on her right knee eight weeks ago. Additionally  she is a former smoker  having stopped ten years ago  but has no significant history of alcohol or drug use.  Family History: Her family history is relevant for cardiovascular diseases. Her father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and her mother suffered from recurrent DVTs in her later life.  Social History: Ms. Johnson is a retired teacher living alone. She has two adult children who live out of state but visit intermittently. She is quite sedentary in her lifestyle and admits to a diet high in processed and fast foods.  On examination  there were no noticeable signs of pulmonary embolism  such as shortness of breath or unsustainable tachycardia. An ultrasound of the lower extremities revealed a non-compressible right popliteal vein  consistent with a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Blood tests  including d-dimer  were ordered.  Significant Findings: Given her recent orthopedic surgery  sedentary lifestyle  and family history of recurrent DVTs  Ms. Johnson is at high risk for DVT. It is crucial to start anticoagulation therapy promptly and educate Ms. Johnson on lifestyle modifications required to manage her condition and prevent recurrence.  Plan: Ms. Johnson was commenced on low-molecular-weight heparin as a bridging therapy and warfarin for long-term anticoagulation. She was admitted to the hospital for treatment  and the plan is to discharge her home with warfarin therapy once her INR levels are in the therapeutic range. Regular outpatient follow-ups with her primary care provider and a cardiologist are planned to monitor her progress.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information:   Ms. Paula is a 67-year-old Caucasian female  currently residing in Seattle  Washington. She lives by herself since she is a widow with two adult sons residing in different states. Ms. Paula is a retired schoolteacher and is relatively active in her community  participating in book clubs and volunteer activities.  Presenting Symptoms:  She arrived at the ER complaining about acute onset of right lower limb swelling and pain. The pain was constant and exacerbated on standing and walking. Additionally  her affected leg felt warm to touch and the skin over it looked reddish-blue.   Past Medical History:  She had a hip replacement surgery two months ago and since then has been majorly bedridden. She has hypertension controlled with medication  and a family history of cardiovascular disease; her father died of a heart attack and her older brother has coronary artery disease. Ms. Paula was a smoker but quit 20 years ago. No history of stroke  diabetes  or any malignancy was reported. Her medications include Lisinopril for hypertension and a multivitamin daily.   Evaluation and Diagnosis:  Based on her symptoms  clinical history  recent surgery followed by prolonged bed rest  and positive family history of cardiovascular disease  deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was suspected. An Ultrasound Doppler study of the right leg confirmed the presence of a blood clot in the femoral vein  leading to the diagnosis of DVT. D-Dimer tests were also high  further supporting the diagnosis.  Management:  Ms. Paula has been admitted for appropriate treatment and monitoring. A combination of low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) and oral anticoagulation (Warfarin) has been initiated. The plan is to continue the enoxaparin for at least five days until the INR achieves a favorable therapeutic range  followed by Warfarin for at least three months. She has been advised to raise her legs while lying down and to avoid sitting or standing for prolonged periods of time. Compression stockings are recommended to help prevent swelling associated with DVT.   Healthcare professionals will educate her about the signs and symptoms of a potential pulmonary embolism  a life-threatening complication of DVT. She will be informed about the importance of medication adherence and scheduled follow-up appointments for monitoring. The patient's sons will also be advised about the situation to ensure appropriate home support post-discharge. An evaluation for gaining mobility and physical therapy consult post-discharge for regaining muscle strength and mobility is also planned.   Future consideration will also be given to the need for prophylactic anticoagulation therapy during high-risk periods such as surgeries or prolonged immobilization. A detailed discussion of the risks and benefits with Ms. Paula and her family will be a necessary part of the future management plan.

Subject: 65-year-old Male Patient Diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis  I. Demographic Information The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Doe. He is retired and lives with his wife in a suburban community.   II. Presenting Problem Mr. Doe complained of a persistent and gradually worsening pain in his left leg for the past week. The leg is swollen  warm to touch  and displaying a noticeable reddish color. He has no recent history of trauma or injury.  III. Past Medical History Mr. Doe has a clinical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia for which he is under constant medication. He also underwent a total knee replacement surgery on the same leg 10 years ago. He is a nonsmoker but has been dealing with obesity (BMI 32.3) for the past few years.  IV. Family History His family history revealed that his father had congestive heart failure and died of a stroke. Moreover  his maternal grandmother had peripheral artery disease  suggesting a genetic predisposition to cardiovascular diseases.  V. Current Clinical Findings Clinical examination verified significant swelling (edema) in his left leg particularly around the calf region. A duplex ultrasound was used to diagnose the presence of Deep Vein Thrombosis in his left leg. Blood tests showed an elevated D-dimer level  further confirming the diagnosis.   VI. Course of Treatment Mr. Doe was promptly put on anticoagulation therapy to dissolve the clot and prevent the formation of new ones  including medication like heparin and warfarin. Compression stockings were also recommended to reduce swelling. He was provided instructions to elevate his leg as much as possible. His condition is stable  though he continues to show moderate signs of discomfort due to pain.  VII. Future Recommendations Implementing lifestyle changes including a better diet and light exercise  such as walking  will be essential to manage his obesity and associated complications. The patient is referred to a dietitian or nutritionist for a proper dietary plan and a physical therapist for a light exercise regimen. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor his condition and the efficacy of the treatment plan.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Allen  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presented with complaints of significant swelling  warmth  and tenderness over the right calf region  consistent with the signs and symptoms of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).   Past Medical History:  Mr. Allen is diagnosed with hypertension from the age of 50  and Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the last seven years. He has been on oral anti-diabetic and anti-hypertensive medications  showing inconsistent control over his blood sugar and blood pressure levels. He had a minor MI (myocardial infarction) 5 years ago  which was managed with medication therapy  and is currently on low-dose Aspirin. Mr. Allen has a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years  although he has reduced it to half a pack in the last year.  Demographics:  Mr. Allen is a retired engineer  married with two children  living in the urban population of Texas. He leads a sedentary lifestyle  mostly staying at home  reading  or watching television. His diet is predominantly high in cholesterol and fats.  Family History:  He has a notable family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having died from a stroke at 65  his older brother experiencing a heart attack at the age of 58  and his mother diagnosed with hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Allen has been experiencing a sudden onset of pain  swelling  and warmness in his right calf started a couple of days ago. There is no history of trauma  injury  or prolonged immobilization. There is no marked fever  no chest pain  or shortness of breath. He does express feeling a bit drained and fatigued though.  Relevant Laboratory Investigations:  A complete blood count  differential analysis  and coagulation profile were ordered. The results indicated a normal blood count with slightly elevated platelets  and prolonged PT and APTT. D-Dimer concentration was significantly raised indicating the possibility of any thrombus formation. His fasting glucose and HbA1C levels were high  confirming poor control over diabetes.  Imaging:  A Doppler ultrasound imaging was performed which confirms the presence of DVT in the right popliteal vein.  Coupled with the patient’s medical history  symptoms  and laboratory results  he was diagnosed with DVT likely caused by hypercoagulability state in the backdrop of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  and a sedentary lifestyle.  Mr. Allen was started immediately on anticoagulant therapy using low molecular weight heparin  and will likely be switched to oral anticoagulants like warfarin. He was also counseled on smoking cessation  lifestyle modifications  maintaining proper foot hygiene  and regular exercise. Regular monitoring of his blood sugar levels and hypertension has also been recommended.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: A 72-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Walters  retired school teacher  non-smoker  residing in Seattle  Washington.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Walters presented himself at the emergency department with complaints of pain and swelling in his right calf that had been persisting for five days. He also observed a mild discoloration and warmth over the same area.   Past Medical History: Mr. Walters has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. He was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation approximately eight months ago  for which he was prescribed a daily dose of aspirin. He also reported a sedentary lifestyle post-retirement.  Medications: He is currently taking Lisinopril for hypertension  Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  Metformin for diabetes  and Aspirin for atrial fibrillation. He confirmed that he was adhering to his medications regularly.  Family History: His father had suffered a stroke at the age of 70 and his mother struggled with coronary artery disease. Both his parents had hypertension. There is no known family history of blood clotting disorders.   Examination: On examination  the right calf was notably swollen and tender with a bluish hue. There was local warmth but no evident skin breaks or signs of infection. His vitals remained stable but his heart rhythm was irregular  in line with his history of atrial fibrillation.  Investigations: An urgent venous Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right lower limb. D-dimer levels were elevated  supporting the diagnosis. A blood panel indicated poor glycemic control and raised LDL-cholesterol despite treatment.  Diagnosis: Based on the history  clinical examination  and results of the diagnostic tests  a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) was made.   Management: Mr. Walters was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) to prevent clot propagation and to protect against the risk of a pulmonary embolism. His aspirin was stopped due to the new anticoagulant. The current regime for his pre-existing comorbidities was reevaluated. Education around diabetes and cholesterol control was provided along with advice on the importance of mobilization and physical exercise.  Community/Discharge Plan: A referral was made to a community anticoagulant service for ongoing monitoring and transition to an oral anticoagulant. If his condition stabilizes  he will be considered for direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs). Regular follow-ups with his primary care physician were scheduled with the focus on better control of diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and atrial fibrillation.    Patient education was emphasized  including the need for weight loss  lifestyle modifications  ankle and calf exercises  staying hydrated  and recognizing symptoms of complications such as pulmonary embolism. Family members were also educated about his condition and its associated potential risks.   Risk Factor Reduction: Lifestyle changes were strongly suggested including daily walks  resisting the urge to cross his legs often  and limiting his intake of foods high in vitamin K.   On a final note  this case serves as a reminder of the increased risk of DVT in elderly patients with multiple comorbidities and underlines the importance of a comprehensive approach to managing these patients  incorporating both pharmacological treatments and lifestyle-modification strategies.

Patient Profile: Mr. S is a 64-year-old Caucasian male  working as a long-distance truck driver  married with two adult children  and residing in Omaha. His complaint was constant aching pain and swelling in his left leg  especially in the calf area that had been disturbing him for about a week. He also mentioned that he noticed the skin over his calf area turning a shade of blue.  Past Medical History:  Mr. S has a history of uncontrolled hypertension and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes four years ago. His most recent blood pressure stood at 160/100 mmHg. He has previously been non-compliant with his medication  but has shown improvement in the last two years. His other significant past history includes a sedentary lifestyle with obesity (BMI: 32)  alcohol consumption with occasional tobacco use  and he acknowledges his diet is high in salt and processed foods.  Family History: His father died of a stroke at age 70  while his mother is alive and receives treatment for chronic heart disease. His older brother underwent a double bypass surgery at age 60.  Presenting Condition: On examination  Mr. S's left lower limb was noticeably swollen compared to his right  warmer  and a homogeneous red-blue discoloration was seen over his calf. He also showed positive results on Homan's Sign. After performing a D-dimer test  which was positive  an ultrasound confirmed a blood clot in the deep vein of his left calf  thereby diagnosing him with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  The working diagnosis identified some notable risk factors  such as his prolonged sitting during long driving hours  obesity  hypertension  diabetes  a family history of cardiovascular disease  and his age.  Plan: Mr. S was started on anticoagulant therapy with a recommendation to continue for at least three months. Measures to reduce his blood pressure including dietary and lifestyle changes were also advised. Patient education about the signs of Pulmonary Embolism (PE) was stressed  considering the potential for DVT to progress to PE. To address his diabetes  adjustments to his current medication regimen were considered. Regular follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor his DVT  along with his other chronic conditions.  In conclusion  Mr. S’s condition results from a combination of hereditary and lifestyle factors that need to be strictly managed for a successful treatment outcome and prevention of complications.

Patient Information:   The patient  Mr. Smith  is a 61-year-old Caucasian male  retired and living with his wife. His occupation earlier was a desk job requiring long hours of sitting. His current BMI is 28  indicating overweight. He is also a smoker with 40 pack-year history and has a moderate alcohol consumption pattern which is about 2 times a week on an average. His regular diet is high in fats and red meat. He does not currently follow any exercise or physical activity regimen.   Presenting Problem:  Mr. Smith presented to the hospital with progressive left calf pain and swelling that began suddenly  four days prior to his hospital visit. His wife noticed that the leg was not only swollen  but also warm to touch and slightly discolored  appearing reddish-blue. He reports no history of trauma or recent travel. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations and also denies any history of fever  cough  or urinary symptoms.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has been previously diagnosed with hypertension  but it is controlled through medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily). Raised cholesterol levels were reported in his past routine health check-up. His medications include the antihypertensive drug lisinopril and a baby aspirin for the primary prevention of cardiovascular events.  Family History:  His mother passed away from a stroke at the age of 68 and his father from a myocardial infarction at 70. On further probing  it was revealed that his father had a previous history of DVT as well (deep vein thrombosis).  Clinical Findings:  On examination  his left calf was visibly swollen and erythematous  measured 3 cm larger in diameter compared to the right. He had a palpable cord along the line of the left posterior tibial vein. There was pain on dorsiflexion of the foot - a positive Homan's sign. Peripheral pulses were intact and symmetrical. There were no varicose veins and no signs of chronic venous insufficiency. The rest of the examination was relatively unremarkable.  Impression:  Given the clinical presentation  the patient was suspected to have deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left lower limb.  Investigations:  A Doppler Ultrasound was ordered which confirmed the presence of thrombosis in the left posterior tibial vein extending up to the popliteal vein. D-dimer levels were significantly elevated. Complete blood count  renal function tests  and PT-INR were otherwise within normal limits.  Treatment and Follow-up:  The patient was initiated on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight Heparin in the hospital  bridged to Warfarin for long-term therapy. Strict advice regarding lifestyle modifications including quitting tobacco and alcohol  a healthier balanced diet  and adequate physical activity was given. He was referred for further intervention and assessment by a vascular surgery specialist and also a cardiologist to manage underlying cardiovascular risk factors. His overall prognosis is guarded given the severity of the thrombotic episode and the presence of multiple cardiovascular risk factors.

Patient Presentation  Subject: A 67-year-old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and Type II diabetes managed with medications. He is a former smoker for 30 years  having quit about a decade ago  no history of alcohol or drug abuse.   Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Symptom Onset: The patient presented with a 4-day history of progressive left leg swelling and pain  noticeable tenderness along distribution of left popliteal and calf veins  without redness or skin changes.  Recent History: The patient had recently undergone hip replacement surgery two weeks ago and reportedly was on bed rest most of the period due to limited mobility.  Family History: His mother experienced a similar incident  i.e.  deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  post her knee replacement surgery. His father passed away due to myocardial infarction in his seventies.  Medications: He has been taking Metformin 500mg daily for his diabetes and Lisinopril 10mg daily for his hypertension  along with an occasional over-the-counter pain reliever since his surgery.  Physical Examination: The patient’s blood pressure was 135/85  the pulse was 78 per minute  the respiratory rate was 16 per minute  and oxygen saturation was 98% on room air. His BMI was 30.2  suggesting obesity.   Investigations: A Duplex ultrasound was conducted revealing a clot in the left calf and thigh vein  confirming DVT. Laboratory tests revealed a slightly elevated D-Dimer level. The blood sugar level was also marginally on the higher end.  Treatment: The patient was initiated on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for 5 days and Warfarin with a target INR of 2.0-3.0. Compression stockings are advised to reduce swelling.  Teaching: The patient was educated about the signs of pulmonary embolism and was advised to immediately seek medical help if any of the symptoms such as chest pain or shortness of breath develop. He was also instructed on the importance of correct adminstration of Warfarin and was advised to keep up with physician appointments to monitor INR levels.   Plan: Aim is to ensure optimal management of his hypertension  diabetes alongside his DVT treatment. Lifestyle modification strategies targeting obesity were recommended. Regular follow-ups every month have been planned to monitor his condition and adjust treatment as necessary.  Summary: This presentation describes a 67-years-old male admitted with the chief complaint of left leg pain and swelling. With a recent history of hip replacement surgery  a physical examination and Duplex Ultrasound confirmed a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis. He commenced anticoagulant therapy and has since been advised for regular follow-ups. The plan includes careful monitoring of his condition and educating about the importance of lifestyle modifications.

Patient Case Presentation  I. Patient Background Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Builder Ethnicity: Caucasian Smoking Status: Non-Smoker BMI: 32.5 (classed as obese)  II. Chief Complaint Mr. Smith approached the clinic with complaints of progressive swelling and pain in his left leg for one week  particularly in the calf. He denied any trauma or injury to the site. He also reported mild shortness of breath on exertion.  III. Past Medical History John has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  controlled by medication. No history of any surgeries. No known allergies.  IV. Family History There is a history of coronary artery disease in his family; his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 59  and his elder brother had a coronary angioplasty at the age of 62.  V. Social History He lives with his wife in a two-story house. He has a sedentary lifestyle  with little to no exercise. Does not intake alcohol or illicit drugs. He's been on a high-salt and high-fat diet for years.  VI. Medications He is on amlodipine and rosuvastatin.  VII. Clinical Examination & Investigations Upon examining  his left calf was swollen  tender  and warmer to touch than the other leg  with a circumference 3cm more than the right calf. His vital signs were stable but physical examination revealed a slightly raised jugular venous pressure. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left popliteal vein extending into the calf veins.  VIII. Diagnosis Based on the patient's age  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  family history of cardiovascular disease  clinical symptoms  and Doppler ultrasound findings  he was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis.  IX. Treatment & Follow-Up Mr. Smith was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin and then planned for long-term warfarin therapy. Leg elevation and compression stockings were advised to reduce edema and pain. He was also advised to increase physical activity and was referred to a dietitian to help with weight reduction and dietary management. Transthoracic echocardiogram was also ordered to rule out any associated cardiac abnormalities like a clot in the heart or pulmonary embolism. He was given a follow-up appointment in two weeks to assess the effect of therapy and adjust the warfarin dose if necessary.   This case highlights the importance of taking a complete medical  family  and social history. It reminds us to evaluate non-modifiable (age  family history) and modifiable risk factors (obesity  diet  sedentary lifestyle) to guide the treatment approach in patients.

Patient Information:   Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old male accountant with a BMI of 30  has come to the hospital with swelling  pain  and redness in his right lower limb. He has a ten-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and a recent history of prolonged bed rest following a knee replacement surgery conducted six weeks ago. His only medications are metformin and low-dose aspirin. His only noted allergy is penicillin.  Family History:  Mr. Smith's family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. His father died at 70 from a myocardial infarction and his older brother  aged 68  currently living  has a history of stroke. His mother passed away from breast cancer at the age of 72. There are no known genetic disorders in the family.  Smoking and Alcohol:  Mr. Smith admits a smoking history of 25 years with a quadruple pack-year history but stopped about 15 years ago. He admitted that he consumes alcohol socially  no more than twice a month.  Presentation:  Upon initial assessment  Mr. Smith presented with unilateral swelling  warmth  and pain in the right calf region that was exacerbated by flexion of the foot. Preliminary examination showed a palpable cord along the line of the right popliteal and femoral veins. No systemic symptoms  such as fever or hemodynamic instability  were reported.   Investigations:  A Doppler ultrasound scan confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the deep veins of his right calf  consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). His D-dimer level was also high  further confirming the diagnosis.  Plan:  Mr. Smith was started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for immediate anticoagulation while the oral anticoagulant  warfarin  was introduced concurrently. His INR will be monitored to ensure apt anticoagulation. The plan will involve overlapping warfarin with LMWH for at least five days until his INR is therapeutic for two consecutive days.   The consideration for assessment of thrombophilias after completion of anticoagulation therapy was also made  as his prolonged immobilization and recent surgery  along with his age  may have contributed to his predisposition to DVT.  Risks and benefits  involving potential bleeding complications  of anticoagulation therapy were explained  with the patient displaying an understanding of the treatment. Follow-up appointments were scheduled to ensure therapeutic compliance  continuity of appropriate care  and reduce the chances of post-thrombotic syndrome.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old male  Caucasian  who resides in an urban center in the United States. He is a retired military personnel living with his wife. He is non-smoker and occasionally drinks alcohol.  Chief Complaint: He visited the Outpatient Department with a chief complaint of progressive pain and swelling on his left lower leg for the past 3-4 days.  Past Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 10 years ago which are well-controlled on medication. He underwent a total knee replacement surgery on the right knee one year back. No history of DVT or PE.   Family Medical History: The patient’s father suffered from coronary artery disease and his mother had a history of stroke. There is no family history of blood clot disorders or malignancies.   Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  the left lower limb appeared swollen with warmth and redness compared to the right side. A positive Homan’s sign was reported.  Investigations: Lab examination revealed an elevated D-dimer level. The Doppler ultrasound and venograph of the left lower limb revealed a thrombus in the left posterior tibial vein  confirming the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.  Medications: The patient is taking Lisinopril for hypertension and Rosuvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  Discussion: The patient's age and surgery history might have contributed to the development of DVT along with his non-mobile lifestyle post-retirement. Also  his hyperlipidemia increases his risk of atheroma development  which can further contribute to thrombosis.   Treatment: Anticoagulant therapy was initiated with Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) administered by subcutaneous injection. After a few days  he was transitioned into a long-term anticoagulant therapy  specifically the oral medication Warfarin. The introduction of a regular light exercise program was encouraged and the importance of taking his medication as prescribed was stressed.  Follow-up: Arrangements were made for regular INR monitoring and a follow-up appointment in the vascular surgery clinic was scheduled in two weeks to monitor his therapeutic response.  The patient was educated about the importance of maintaining a balanced diet avoiding vitamin K rich food  as this can affect the efficiency of warfarin. Also  the vital information regarding the early signs of pulmonary embolism and when to seek medical help was provided.   This case highlights the importance of identifying risk factors for DVT and keeping a high suspicion for early detection  leading to the prompt and appropriate management and potentially preventing serious complications.

Patient Profile:  Mr. A is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  recently retired from his job as an engineer  who lives in urban Texas with his wife. Mr. A was a smoker for 25 years  quit 15 years ago  and has a moderate history of alcohol consumption. He has been diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both being managed for the past decade. The patient is overweight with a BMI of 33 and leads a largely sedentary life. His father died of a heart attack at 70  and his maternal aunt was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her 50s.    Current Health Concern:  Mr. A visited the clinic complaining of pain and swelling in the left lower leg  which he first noticed three days ago. The swelling has progressively worsened  and the skin appears warm and reddish. He also reports a mild fever but denies any history of recent trauma or injury to the area. His symptoms indicate the possibility of DVT.  Clinical Assessment:  Blood workup revealed elevated D-dimer levels. An ultrasound was performed for definitive diagnosis  which confirmed the presence of a clot in the deep vein of his left calf  confirming a diagnosis of DVT. Additional testing  such as ECG and chest x-ray  was performed to rule out the presence of pulmonary embolism.  Risk Factors:  Mr. A's sedentary lifestyle  obesity  and history of smoking are likely contributors to his DVT. His history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes are also related factors. His maternal family history of DVT and his age may further have increased his risk.  Management Plan:  Current appearances suggest an uncomplicated DVT. Mr. A is recommended to start on anticoagulation therapy to prevent the clot from growing. He is prescribed low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) to be used initially  to be overlapped and followed by an oral anticoagulant. In addition  he is advised to elevate his limb  use compression stockings  and take analgesics for pain relief.  Discussion:  Given the patient's chronic conditions  it is imperative to ensure appropriate management of the hypertension and diabetes. Patient education on lifestyle modifications is crucial  including the importance of regular physical activity and a balanced diet to manage weight. Cessation of alcohol is recommended. Regular follow-ups will be necessary to monitor his condition and make adjustments to his treatment as needed.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thomas White  a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history most noteworthy for obesity  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He is a retired software engineer and a nonsmoker. He is known to have a sedentary lifestyle and has a family history of venous thromboembolism (his father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 57). He had a cholecystectomy 25 years ago and has been on antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications for the past decade.  Recently  Mr. White presented to the clinic with complaints of growing pain  warmth  and swelling in his right lower leg  particularly in the calf region  which has persisted for the past 10 days. Following a positive Homan’s sign during the physical examination  further investigations were conducted.  Laboratory results revealed a rise in D-dimer levels. The Doppler ultrasound of the right lower extremity depicted the existence of a deep vein thrombosis in the distal femoral vein. His blood pressure was 145/95 mmHg; BMI around 30 kg/m2 and other vitals were stable.  Further history-taking revealed that Mr. White had undergone a total knee replacement surgery 2 weeks prior due to severe osteoarthritis. He had been non-compliant with post-operative mobilization instructions and prophylactic anticoagulant therapy  as he neglected the importance of them and stopped taking the medication out of fear of bleeding side effects.  He currently lives with his wife who is a retired nurse and has been supportive throughout his episodes of illness.   Keeping his age  lifestyle  hypertension  recent immobility from post-surgical recovery  and the family history of venous thromboembolism in view  Mr. White is at high risk for deep vein thrombosis. His treatment plan would involve reinstating anticoagulant therapy  structured physical activity  and follow-up scans with a possibility of thrombolysis if the DVT does not resolve or symptoms get worse.  In conclusion  Mr. White's situation emphasizes the importance of proper health education and the necessity of adherence to post-operative instructions. Trust-building and proper communication are crucial aspects to prevent such avoidable complications.

Patient Presentation  Patient: Mr. John Doe   Age: 67 years  Occupation: Retired teacher  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Sex: Male  Demographics: Lives with his wife in a suburban area. He is a nonsmoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.  Presenting complaint: Complaint of swelling in his right leg for the past two weeks.  PastMedical History: - Co-morbidity of hypertension for 20 years that is well controlled with Lisinopril. - History of pulmonary embolism 5 years ago. - Recent surgery (hip replacement surgery) two months back.   Family history: - Father died from a stroke at age 75. - Mother has hypertension and is a diabetes patient.    Examination: He presented with a swollen right leg  which was also warm to the touch. Homan's sign was positive. No signs of ulceration or infection were evident. His vital signs are stable  and cardiovascular and respiratory examinations are normal.  Investigation: A Doppler ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis of DVT in the right lower extremity. The D-dimer test was also high. His complete blood count  kidney function test  liver function test  and coagulation profile were normal. His EKG and Chest X-ray were also normal.  Diagnosis: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) of the right lower extremity.  Treatment Management: He was started on anticoagulation therapy with low-molecular-weight Heparin (LMWH) followed by oral Warfarin. He was also advised to wear compression stockings. Advice was given for adequate hydration and leg elevation when sitting or lying down.  Plan: He was advised to continue his anticoagulation treatment. A complete review after two weeks was advised. He is encouraged to gradually increase physical activity and keep a healthy diet.  Follow Up: To manage his DVT  regular follow-ups every three months are advised.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information:  Mr. X  a 65-year-old African American male  presented to the Emergency Department on January 10th.  Presenting Complaint:  He came in complaining of sudden  persistent swelling and pain in his right leg over the past three days.  Past Medical History:  He has a ten-year history of well-controlled hypertension and was diagnosed with type II diabetes five years ago. He was also diagnosed with obesity and has a BMI of 33. He underwent a hernia operation 20 years ago and a hip replacement surgery in the same leg six months ago. He takes antihypertensive drugs  oral hypoglycemics  and daily aspirin.  Family History:  His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his mother suffered a stroke in her late sixties. His older brother was diagnosed with DVT at the age of 58.   Social History:  He is a retired civil engineer  married with two kids. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history but quit 8 years ago. He denies any alcohol or recreational drug use.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the right leg was found to be erythematous  warm  and visibly swollen compared to the left  with a positive Homan’s sign. Vital signs were stable; however  his pain score was 7/10.  Investigations:  A Doppler ultrasound scan confirmed the presence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right popliteal vein. His blood works showed an elevated D-dimer level of 3.0 mg/L. Fasting glucose  HbA1C  lipid profile  renal  and liver function tests were ordered and found to be within the normal range except for slightly increased levels of triglycerides.  Treatment & Progress:  He was immediately started on unfractionated heparin intravenously  and warfarin was introduced alongside after a day when his INR was found to be 1.1. He will be continued on warfarin for the long term once the therapeutic INR range is reached  considering his risk factors like personal and family history. Instructions were given to elevate his leg  wear compression stockings  monitor his symptoms  and to present at the earliest if any symptoms of pulmonary embolism like chest pain  breathlessness develops.   The patient continues to be monitored and educated on lifestyle modifications  including dietary changes  exercise to maintain a healthy weight  regular follow-ups  blood pressure control  and sugar level checks.  Discussion:  The patient's advanced age  obesity  recent surgery  and family history of DVT  along with a sedentary lifestyle  put him at higher risk for DVT. His DVT was most likely prompted by the stasis induced by his hip surgery combined with his other risk factors. An anticoagulation regimen was initiated and the patient was educated on the warning signs of life-threatening complications  including pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mr. Johnson Age: 58 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Truck driver  Presenting complaint: Mr. Johnson presented to the ER with complaints of swelling and discomfort in his left leg  which started approximately 3 days ago. He also reported a mild shortness of breath.   Past Medical History: The patient has a 15-year history of uncontrolled Type 2 diabetes mellitus and is also hypertensive. He was diagnosed and treated for prostate cancer at age 54  presently in remission. He is a former smoker  quitting 10 years ago  and drinks alcohol socially. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a poor diet.  Family History: His father died of a myocardial infarction at age 70  and his mother has hypertension and dementia. His older brother underwent angioplasty at age 60.   Review of Systems: Apart from the symptoms above  Mr. Johnson reports feeling increasingly fatigued over the last week but did not think much of it  attributing it to his work.  Physical Examination: His vital signs are BP 145/90mmHg  pulse 85 bpm  temperature 98.6F  and respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  SPO2-95% on room air. His left leg appears swollen and a bit redder than his right leg. The circumference of the left calf is 2cm greater than the right calf. His chest is clear on auscultation.  Lab investigations: D-Dimer test was ordered  which came back elevated  and an ultrasound confirmed a clot in the left deep vein of his lower leg.   Diagnosis: Based on the ultrasound findings  past medical history  and current symptoms  Mr. Johnson was consequently diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Plans: He was admitted to the hospital  and anticoagulant therapy was started immediately. We also recommended lifestyle changes including a healthier diet  regular exercise  better diabetes management  and continued abstinence from smoking to reduce his risk of recurrent DVT. The patient was educated about signs of complications like pulmonary embolism and was advised to seek immediate help if they occur. Further treatment and follow-up plans will be based on future reassessments and his responses to the prescribed treatment.    Overall  he needs a multi-disciplinary approach to manage his DVT  his diabetes  and his overall risk of cardiovascular and thromboembolic events. His high risk is based on his individual history and family history of cardiovascular disease.

Case Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. X  who resides in Montreal  Quebec. He has a job that requires frequent air travel. He is overweight  with a BMI of 30 kg/m^2  and is a non-smoker. However  he has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Chief Compliant: The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden  progressive pain and swelling in his right lower leg  which started a few days ago.  Past Medical History: Mr. X has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been well controlled with medication (lisinopril and metformin  respectively). There is no history of any heart disease or respiratory illness.  Family History:  There is a significant family history of thromboembolic diseases; his father developed a Pulmonary Embolism at the age of 62  and a cousin has a history of recurrent Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  there was warmth  pain and a notable swelling over his right calf muscle. Client experienced tenderness on deep palpation of the calf area concerning for DVT. Vital signs showed BP: 142/95 mmHg  HR: 105 bpm with no evidence of respiratory distress.  Investigations: A Duplex Ultrasound was performed  which confirmed the presence of a Deep Vein Thrombosis in the right calf vein. D-dimer tests were elevated.   Diagnosis: Based on the clinical presentation  supporting history of prolonged immobility due to frequent flights  family history of thromboembolic diseases  and above-mentioned clinical and radiologic findings  a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis was made.  Treatment: The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy with Low Molecular Weight Heparin (enoxaparin). Consultation with a hematologist was also arranged for further management.   Follow up: The patient will have frequent follow-ups in the clinic to monitor his symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. He has also been informed about the importance of regular physical activity and weight loss.   This presentation provides a detailed overview of the case at hand. It is also important to understand that while this presentation is detailed  every patient is different  and treatment plans should be personalized for each unique situation.

Patient Profile: Patient X  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents with symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He is a retired teacher and married with two adult children.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 20 years  which is managed through medication and dietary control. He has taken oral antihypertensives and metformin to manage these conditions. Additionally  he is overweight  and has a BMI of 32. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. Other than this  his past medical history is unremarkable.  Presentation: Patient X presented to the clinic complaining of pain  swelling  and redness in his right leg  which has lasted for about one week. He mentions that the pain started mild and has progressively gotten worse. The patient denies any history of trauma or injury  and reports no associated symptoms such as shortness of breath  chest pain  or fever.  Family History: Family history is significant  as his father experienced a non-fatal Pulmonary Embolism at the age of 67. His mother has a history of stroke at the age of 72. His two siblings are alive and well  with no significant medical conditions.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  signs of pitting edema  erythema  and a palpable cord along the medial aspect of the right leg were noticed.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Given the history and physical examination  a preliminary diagnosis of DVT was suspected. Duplex ultrasound was performed  showing the presence of blood clot in his right lower extremity. D-dimer test was done which came back positive favoring the diagnosis of DVT.  Management: The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)  followed by oral anticoagulants  as well as a graded compression stocking for his leg pain and swelling.  Discussion: Being an older patient with comorbidities such as obesity  diabetes  and hypertension  the risk of DVT in this patient escalated. Moreover  his family history of thromboembolic disorders raised concerns. The mainstay of therapy involves anticoagulation to prevent further clot propagation and reduce the risk of Pulmonary Embolism.   The patient should continue with lifestyle changes to manage his risk factors  which include following a balanced diet  regular exercise  and weight loss.  This case represents the classic presentation of proximal lower limb DVT. Early diagnosis and immediate management of these cases is essential to prevent life-threatening complications.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 63 years old  Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Engineer  Marital Status: Married  Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe visited his local GP clinic reporting a progressive painful swelling in his left lower leg since last one week. He also mentioned noticing skin redness and warmth. Mr. Doe reports difficulty in walking due to the intense discomfort. On further questioning  he also noticed mild shortness of breath that started two days ago. He has not experienced any chest pain  hemoptysis or syncope.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe is known to have hypertension and type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  for which he has been receiving treatment for last 8 years. His glucose levels and blood pressure are usually well-controlled with medication. He had a MI 5 years ago  for which he was hospitalised and managed medically. He's been a smoker for over 40 years but quit 5 years ago following his MI. He's also obese with a BMI of 31.  Family History: His father died at 66 due to heart disease  and his mother at 72 from lung cancer  she was a lifelong smoker. His older brother is alive and has hypertension. No notable genetic disorder or hereditary disease in the family.  Clinical Findings: On examination  his vitals were largely within normal limits with his BP at 132/86 mmHg and pulse 78 bpm. Abdomen was soft and non-tender  his cardiovascular examination was unremarkable with no abnormal heart sounds. However  his left lower leg was erythematous  swollen and warm to touch with positive Homan's sign. Respiratory examination revealed mild tachypnea without any adventitious sounds.   Diagnostic Assessment: Based on clinical findings of the patient a provisional diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was made. An urgent D-Dimer test was ordered  which came back elevated. Doppler ultrasound was subsequently performed confirming the presence of DVT in the left lower leg. An ECG was performed showing sinus rhythm  no acute ischemic changes. A chest CT was advised to rule out pulmonary embolism due to the suspicion raised by the shortness of breath and tachypnea.  Plan of Care: Anticoagulation was initiated promptly to prevent clot expansion and pulmonary embolism. Since this is John's first DVT  the decision was made to start on Apixaban  a direct oral anticoagulant  for a minimum duration of 3 months. Consultation with the vascular surgery team was made. Patient and family education about disease  compliance with treatment and follow up appointments was carried out. The need for lifestyle modifications involving dietary habits and regular exercise was also stressed upon to manage obesity  hypertension  and diabetes.   Conclusion: Mr. Doe’s case underscores the risk of DVT in patients with multiple risk factors like advanced age  history of smoking  hypertension  obesity and heart disease. It emphasizes the need for a high level of suspicion in at risk patients presenting with suggestive symptoms and the importance of swift management to prevent severe complications like pulmonary embolism.   This short case presentation also sheds light on the importance of long term management of co-morbidities and lifestyle modification  emphasizing holistic care of a patient.

Patient Profile: Mr. Brown  a 67-year-old African American male  has been diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). His previous history includes hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  obesity (BMI 33)  and Type 2 diabetes  all of which are well-managed with medication. Mr. Brown is a retired construction worker and is a non-smoker. However  he has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. His vaccination history is up to date. The patient lives with his wife in a suburb and has excellent familial support.  Family Medical History:  His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 68. His mother lived to age 82 and had a history of hypertension. He has one brother who is 61 years old and diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Brown presented with swelling  tenderness  and redness in his right lower leg. The pain in his leg started a couple of days ago without any apparent cause and progressively worsened. The patient also noticed that the skin on his leg was warmer than usual.  Examination: Upon examination  Mr. Brown's vital signs were stable  but his right lower leg was notably swollen  warm  and tender on palpation. The consultation included Duplex Ultrasound  which confirmed the diagnosis of DVT. There were no other significant examination findings.  Management Plan: He was hospitalized and started on a regimen of anticoagulants immediately  specifically a direct oral anticoagulant. His regular medications  including antihypertensives  statins  and antidiabetic medications  continued as per usual. Lifestyle changes such as regular leg exercises  elevation of the affected leg  drinking plenty of fluids  and weight management  were also emphasized to prevent recurrence.  Prognosis:  With early intervention and appropriate treatment  Mr. Brown's prognosis looks good. His symptoms have already started to improve  however  the risk of developing post-thrombotic syndrome  a long-term problem with pain and swelling in the leg  and the risk of another DVT will need to be monitored continually.   His lifestyle interventions will also need to be re-evaluated from time to time and optimally managed to keep contributing risk factors (e.g.  obesity  diet) at bay. Monthly follow-ups with vein scans are scheduled for the upcoming year to ensure the clot is resolving and to prevent the occurrence of possible complications. There is also a plan to involve a dietitian and a physiotherapist in Mr. Brown's management.    In conclusion  Mr. Brown's case is a classic example of how lifestyle diseases can pile up to increase the risk of other  potentially serious conditions such as DVT. It emphasizes the need for patient education and public awareness about preventive measures and early consultations in case of symptoms.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mr. Smith Age: 67 Sex: Male Occupation: Retired accountant Location: San Francisco  CA Race: Caucasian  Chief Complaint: Mr. Smith presents with complaints of left leg swelling and discomfort lasting for the past week. He further admits to some instances of mild shortness of breath but no chest pain or cough.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with lisinopril and high-dose atorvastatin respectively. No previous history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy 15 years ago  and no surgical complications were reported.   Family History: Mr. Smith's father had coronary artery disease and passed at the age of 75. His mother died of an unknown cause at the age of 89. His older brother had a stroke at the age of 70  and a younger sister is healthy. No family history of coagulation disorders or unexpected clotting events.     Social History: Mr. Smith is a widower living independently. He is a former smoker  has quit 20 years ago. He admits to occasional alcohol use. He maintains a sedentary lifestyle  most of his activities are chair-bound owing to his hobbies  such as reading and chess playing.  Recent Events: Mr. Smith had a long-haul flight (12-hour trip) three weeks ago to visit his daughter in Spain. After returning  he started noticing the symptoms  initially faint but gradually worsening over time.  Physical Exam: On physical examination  the left lower extremity was warm and noticeably swollen than the right. No pitting edema or visible erythema was observed. Pulses were palpable and equal in both lower extremities.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Considering his recent air travel and clinical presentation  a clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis was made. A venous Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a non-compressible left popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of DVT. Pulmonary embolism was ruled out using a D-dimer test and chest imaging due to his mild breathlessness.  Treatment and Follow-Up: Mr. Smith was started on low molecular weight heparin followed by a planned transition to warfarin. He was educated on the importance of mobilization and wearing compression stockings during long-haul flights. He will be closely monitored with regular blood checks to ensure therapeutic anticoagulation.  This case shows the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling  especially in the context of recent long-haul travel or prolonged immobilization. His hypertension and hyperlipidemia also pose a higher risk of vascular complications.

Patient Presentation:  Patient's Information: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Miller  living in Idaho  USA. He is a recently retired engineer with a BMI of 29.5  putting him on the overweight range. He is a long-term smoker - having smoked for 40 years  averaging 20 cigarettes a day. He lives with his wife  is financially stable  and both of his children are independent adults.  Past Medical History: Mr. Miller has a history of hypertension which is well-controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily). In the past  he had an appendectomy at the age of 15  and a hernia repair at 42. He has no known allergies. He consumes alcohol but only socially  he intakes around 8 units weekly  mainly on weekends. He does not use any recreational drugs.  Recent Medical Issue: He recently undertook a 12-hour transatlantic flight to visit grandchildren. Post-flight  he noted increasing pain and swelling in his left calf. After 2 days of discomfort  his wife urged him to seek medical help.  Clinical Examination: Physical examination revealed an erythematous  swollen and painful left calf. No chest pain or difficulty in breathing has been reported.  Diagnostic Tests: D-dimer test came back with high levels  ultrasound Doppler showed deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his left calf. Chest CT scan didn't show any evidence of pulmonary embolism.  Family History:  His father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at age 60 and his mother at 68 due to breast cancer. His elder brother  presently 65  has type-2 diabetes and his younger sister (58) is healthy. There's no known family history of DVT  thrombophilia  or bleeding disorders.  Management: Considering his recent flight  current smoking habit  and symptoms  the diagnosis of DVT is the most likely consideration. He has been prescribed anticoagulation therapy (apixaban 10mg twice daily for 7 days  then 5 mg twice daily). He has also been advised to elevate the affected leg  use hot or cold packs for pain relief  and been provided with graduated compression stockings. He has been given advice to quit smoking and increase his physical activity levels. And has been referred to a local smoking cessation group and a community exercise program.
