Follow-up: Mr. Miller will be scheduled for a 1-week follow-up to evaluate his therapeutic response to the prescribed treatment and fortnightly monitoring thereafter.  This case highlights the importance of awareness of DVT risk factors and early intervention for a better prognosis. It further emphasizes the significance of lifestyle modifications in comprehensive DVT management.

Patient Presentation  Patient Identification: Mr. X  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with a complaint of pain and swelling in his right lower extremity.  Chief Complaint: Mr. X has been experiencing discomfort in his right leg  which is warm to touch and visibly swollen. He reports that the pain has been progressive over the past week.  Past Medical History: Mr. X has a significant past medical history including hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He had a myocardial infarction two years ago. He underwent a knee replacement surgery on the right side 1 month ago.  Family History: His father died of a stroke  and his mother has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. His older sister has a history of pulmonary embolism.  Social History: Mr. X is a retired construction engineer  currently living alone. He is a non-smoker and only drinks alcohol occasionally.   Medications: His current home medications include Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for his hyperlipidemia. He also takes daily aspirin for his cardiovascular disease.  Assessment: Based on his recent surgery  symptoms  and older age  his Wells score for the DVT is 3  indicating moderate risk. Duplex ultrasound examination confirmed the presence of deep vein thrombosis in the right popliteal vein.  Plan: Mr. X was admitted to the hospital for management and monitoring. We have initiated anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin in the hospital  transitioned to Rivaroxaban for continued outpatient management. We are advising him to wear compression stockings to help decrease the swelling and pain.  Education: He has been educated on the importance of medication compliance  potential medication side effects  and to report any worsening symptoms immediately like chest pain or shortness of breath which could indicate a pulmonary embolism.  Prognosis: Prognosis is good with adequate compliance with anticoagulation therapy. Follow-up: Follow-up is scheduled in a week for reassessment.  This case emphasizes the importance of thorough evaluation in patients with risk factors for DVT.

Patient Identification: Mr. R is a 65-year-old white male.  Presenting Issue: He reported edema  pain and tenderness in the right calf.  Medical History: Mr. R has a history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He was also previously diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD) for which he underwent a bypass surgery about 10 years ago. He is currently on medications for diabetes  hypertension  and a statin for cholesterol control.  Lifestyle and Social History: Mr. R is a retired engineer. He is a former smoker who quit five years ago and is a moderate alcohol drinker. His diet is high in saturated fats and he has a sedentary lifestyle.  Family History: His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his grandmother had deep vein thrombosis (DVT). His 68-year-old brother was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Recent Developments: Two weeks ago  he took a 12-hour flight from Australia to the United States and has been complaining of calf discomfort since then. Symptoms were initially mild but have since progressed.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  he demonstrated significant calf swelling  warmth  and erythema  but no palpable cords.  Vital Signs: Blood pressure- 145/90mmHg  Pulse- 85 bpm Respiratory rate- 16 breaths per minute BMI- 30 kg/m2 (Obese)  Investigations: Mr. R’s lab values indicated elevated D-dimer levels. A compression ultrasonography confirmed the presence of a clot in the deep vein of the right calf  and he was diagnosed with DVT.   Diagnosis and Management: Mr. R was started on anticoagulant therapy- low molecular weight heparin followed by an oral anticoagulant. He was also advised to wear compression stockings and was counseled about the importance of regular physical activity  balanced diet  and weight loss.  Plan for Follow-up: Mr. R has a follow-up scheduled in one week to assess his response to the treatment. Depending on his progress  the treatment plan might be adjusted. Considering his risk factors and family history  he will also be counseled on DVT prevention.  Given his history and presentation  it is essential for Mr. R to understand the necessity of adhering to medication  maintaining a healthy lifestyle  and avoiding long periods of immobility to minimize the risk of recurrent DVT or any other potential comorbid conditions such as pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. X  a 45-year-old Caucasian male  presented himself at the clinic with complaints of swelling  redness  and pain in his left lower leg. He has been working as a financial analyst  mostly desk-based  for fifteen years. Mr. X is a non-smoker and reports occasional alcohol use.  Past Medical History:   In the past  Mr. X underwent minor surgery for an abdominal hernia five years ago without any complications. He has been recently diagnosed with hypertension and was started on antihypertensive medications two months ago. Furthermore  Mr. X has moderately well-controlled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past six years and is on Metformin.  Family History:   His family history reveals essential hypertension in his mother and both maternal and paternal grandparents. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 63 and passed away due to a stroke at age 70. One of his paternal uncles was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis at an age similar to Mr. X's current age.  Examination:  Upon physical evaluation  his left calf appears swollen and erythematous compared to his right. The left calf circumference is approximately 3 cm larger than the right. On palpation  the calf is warm and tender. His blood pressure is slightly high at 145/90 mmHg  and his BMI is 28  indicating overweight status.  Investigation and Diagnosis:  Considering moderate risk for DVT based on the Wells Score  a D-dimer test was ordered  which came back elevated. A subsequent Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a clot in the left popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of left lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Disease Management:  Mr. X was started on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin followed by oral anticoagulant Rivaroxaban. He was also referred to a dietician for weight management and a diabetic educator to improve glycemic control.   Follow up:  A follow-up in three days was scheduled for reassessing his symptoms and blood pressure  and a plan was made for regular monitoring of his anticoagulation levels.  Progress:  The patient is responding well to the initial treatment  with reduced swelling and pain in his left lower leg. Further management and regular follow-ups are planned to treat and monitor his DVT  hypertension  and diabetes. He is also counseled about the importance of regular exercise including walking  maintaining a healthy diet  and quitting alcohol.   Conclusion:  This case is an example of lower extremity DVT  which is not uncommon in a sedentary worker  overweight  hypertensive  diabetic individual with a strong family history of DVT and cardiovascular diseases. Early recognition and prompt treatment can prevent serious complications  including a potentially fatal pulmonary embolism. It also highlights the need for managing lifestyle factors.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Jane Doe is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who resides in a nursing home and was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Relevant Medical History:  Ms. Doe’s medical history is notable for Type 2 Diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. She underwent a right hip replacement surgery three weeks ago  after which she was still largely immobile due to post-operative pain. She is a former smoker with no moderate alcohol intake.  Demographics:  Ms. Doe is retired  widowed  and has two adult children who live out of state. She is financially stable but has limited social interaction due to her physical impairment and less frequent visits from family.  Current Clinical Status:  She presents with a 3 day history of increased redness  swelling  and tenderness of her left lower leg. On examination  there were warmth and palpable cord over her left popliteal region  indicating the possibility of DVT.   Relevant Family History:  Ms. Doe’s father had fatal pulmonary embolism in his late 70s. There's also a heavy prevalence of heart disease in her family. Her mother had diabetes and hypertension. Her younger brother is fighting chronic kidney disease due to uncontrolled hypertension. Her older sister is a breast cancer survivor.  Risk Factors and Pathophysiology:  Considering her recent surgery  prolonged immobility  age  family history of venous thromboembolism  personal history of hypertension and diabetes  Ms. Doe had high risk for developing DVT. During her limited mobility and post-surgery  blood stasis could have a significant contribution to the DVT development according to the Virchow's Triad.  Diagnostic Tests:  Ms. Doe was sent for a D-dimer test  which came back highly positive. For further confirmation  an ultrasound of her left leg was done which clearly demonstrated DVT.  Treatment Plan:  Ms. Doe was started on a low molecular weight heparin  Enoxaparin subcutaneously  for rapid anticoagulation and arranged for a follow-up with a Hematologist for consideration of long-term oral anticoagulation. She was also referred to Physical Therapy for mobilization and recommendations on the use of graduated compression stockings to expedite her mobility. Education about the need for leg movement  even when bed-bound  was provided.   Follow-up:  Regular follow-up care will be arranged to monitor her anticoagulation status and assess the progress of her DVT. Family members will be encouraged to visit more often to improve her social interaction and consequently her overall health.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian female arrived at the clinic citing pain and substantial swelling in her left leg.  Presenting Issue: She complained about a persistent ache in her left calf that didn't seem to subside with rest  unlike typical muscle strains. She also noted the area felt warm to touch and that she had noticed a slight reddish discoloration. The patient has a sedentary job that requires long periods of sitting and just returned from a long-haul flight three days prior to the visit. She smokes 10 cigarettes a day and her Body Mass Index (BMI) indicates mild obesity.  Past Medical History: She was previously diagnosed with stage two hypertension and is on therapy. No known allergies. She had cholecystectomy 8 years ago. She has not previously been diagnosed with any clotting disorders.  Family History: Her mother suffered a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at roughly the same age. Her father had myocardial infarction. There is a history of hereditary thrombophilia running in her family.  Clinical Examination: On physical examination  her right leg appeared normal. The left leg was noticeably swollen with a circumference 3 cm greater than the right. There were no ulcerations or varicose veins visible  nor were there signs of injury or trauma.  Diagnostic Tests: Lab tests were conducted and ultrasound was performed which revealed a vein in her leg with restricted blood flow  confirming a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis.  Treatment Plan:  She has been started on anticoagulant medication to prevent the clot from getting bigger and to stop new clots from forming. She was advised to wear compression stockings to prevent swelling and was educated on the importance of regular movement to promote blood circulation. The patient was also recommended for smoking cessation counseling to reduce her risk factors. Follow-up appointments have been scheduled to monitor her progress and adjust her treatment plan as necessary. Patient education was also done about the increased risk of pulmonary embolism and what symptoms to watch out for.   Overall Prognosis:  Prognosis depends completely on the patient's adherence to the medication and her willingness to modify her lifestyle and quit smoking. Her family history of thrombophilia necessitates that she continues follow-up screens and exams.

Patient Information:   Mr. Louis King  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  residing in Brooklyn  New York  presented at our clinic complaining of swelling  pain  and warmth in his right calf. He reported noticing these symptoms approximately one week prior to the visit.   Medical history:   Mr. King was diagnosed with early-stage prostate cancer 6 years ago  treated with radiation therapy  and has remained cancer-free since then. He also suffers from controlled hypertension for the past 10 years with daily doses of Amlodipine 5mg and Losartan 50mg. He had an appendectomy at age 12 and a hernia repair 15 years ago.   Family history:  Mr. King's father passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 75  and his mother had a history of varicose veins and died of stroke at 80. He has one brother who is living and healthy.  Social history:  Mr. King is a retired engineer  a non-smoker  and consumes alcohol socially. He lives with his wife. He reports a sedentary lifestyle since retiring 3 years ago and admits to increased time sitting reading and watching television.  Examination and Diagnostic Testing:  Upon physical examination  his right calf displayed erythema  edema  and tenderness to touch  with a slight increase in temperature compared to the left calf. A Doppler Ultrasound confirmed the presence of a non-compressible venous segment consistent with DVT in the right lower extremity.  Diagnosis:  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Treatment and Follow-up:  Considering his examination findings and ultrasound results  the risk factors (sedentary lifestyle  age  and family history)  the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis was made. He was started on Anticoagulation therapy with Rivaroxaban. He was also educated about the importance of mobilization to prevent clot propagation. He is scheduled for follow-up visits and monitoring of therapeutic response and potential side effects.   Patient instructions:  Mr. King was instructed to take his medications regularly  avoid prolonged periods of inactivity  keep hydrated  wear compression stockings as suggested  and follow up regularly with the health care provider. He was also advised about the symptoms of pulmonary embolism  a possible complication of DVT  and directed to seek immediate medical attention if he develops shortness of breath  chest pain  or palpitations.

Patient Presentation:  The patient  Mr. John Doe  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  presented with symptoms of unresolved leg pain and swelling in the left calf for the past seven days. He also reported intermittent shortness of breath in the past three days. In assessing lifestyle  he is a long-haul truck driver  sedentary most of the time. He is a non-smoker  but drinks occasionally.  The past medical history reveals that Mr. Doe suffers from Type 2 diabetes  controlled with Metformin  and has a BMI of 32  indicating he falls within the obesity range. He has a history of hypertension  well-managed through medication (Lisinopril). There is no record of surgeries or previous hospitalizations.  Family history shows a trend of heart disease and stroke in multiple first degree relatives including his father  a maternal uncle  and older sister. His father had a myocardial infarction at 63  and older sister had a cerebrovascular accident at 58.  Upon physical examination  his left calf is markedly swollen  erythematous and warm to touch  measures 3 cm larger than right calf. Positive Homans’ sign was noted. Pulse rate was slightly elevated at 88  blood pressure was 125/80  respiratory rate was regular at 16 per minute  and oxygen saturation measured 95% on room air.   Investigations:  Doppler ultrasound performed confirmed the diagnosis of acute Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in the left lower extremity. Further investigations like D-dimer tests were positive which support the diagnosis.   Treatment:  Treatment was initiated with heparin drip for immediate anticoagulation and warfarin started concurrently. His diabetes and hypertension were managed with ongoing prescriptions of Metformin and Lisinopril respectively.   Discussion:  Mr. Doe's sedentary lifestyle  diabetes  obesity  and hypertensive status  along with familial predisposition makes him more prone to DVT and PE. Early recognition was key to preventing disease progression and potential fatal complications  warranting an urgent measure of initiating anticoagulation therapy. Continuous patient education regarding medication compliance and lifestyle modifications will be pivotal in managing his conditions and preventing further thromboembolic episodes.  Plan:  Mr. Doe was advised to stay hospitalized until his INR reaches a therapeutic range of 2-3. His medication regimen will be assessed and adjusted accordingly. Once discharged  he will be monitored continuously with regular INR checks. He will also be referred to a dietitian for weight management counseling and a metabolic specialist to ensure optimal control of his diabetes. An exercise regimen under the guidance of a Physical therapist is also planned. He would be properly educated on the need to take breaks to facilitate leg movement and prevent DVT during his long-haul drives.

Case Presentation:  Patient Information: Miss L  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presented with complaints of acute onset swelling and tenderness in her left lower limb. She is retired  living alone in an urban apartment.  Chief Complaint: Left leg swelling and pain for 3 days.  History of Chief Complaint:  The pain is constant and is described as a dull ache; the patient also reports mild shortness of breath. No associated fever  cough  or weight loss is reported.  Past Medical History:  She has Type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) that was diagnosed 10 years ago managed with Metformin  and hypertension (HTN) managed with Lisinopril for the past 7 years. She had total left hip replacement surgery two months prior due to severe osteoarthritis.  Family History:  Her mother was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at the age of 65. Her father died of myocardial infarction at age 73.  Social History:  Miss L is a retired teacher  non-smoker  non-alcoholic. She leads a sedentary lifestyle and travel history includes a recent road trip lasting long hours pre-surgery.  Physical Examination: She appeared generally well and her vitals were stable. The left lower limb was swollen  with warmth and redness over the calf. Homan's sign was positive. Rest of systemic examination was unremarkable.  Investigations: Her blood investigation showed elevated D-dimer. Coagulation profile also showed prolonged PT and APTT. Ultrasound-Doppler of the affected leg confirmed the presence of DVT.  Diagnosis:  Based on the history  physical findings and investigations  Miss L was diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis in the left lower limb.  Treatment:  She was started on anticoagulants with close monitoring of her coagulation profile.  Discussion: This case underlines the importance of taking into account multiple risk factors for DVT  such as age  prolonged immobility  diabetes  hypertension  and major surgery. Family history of DVT further increases the risk. Early diagnosis and management can prevent potential complications  including pulmonary embolism.  Note: This case is generated for the purpose of learning and discussion.

Patient Profile: Gender: Male Age: 65 years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Present Illness:  The patient reports chronic dull pain and swelling in his right lower leg that has worsened over the past week. On examination  the calf was found to be red  warm  and slightly swollen. A Venous Doppler ultrasound of the right calf was performed and confirmed a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the popliteal vein.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  for which he takes Ventolin (albuterol) regularly. He had surgery for total knee replacement two years ago on the right knee  after which he was briefly on an anticoagulant. He is non-diabetic and has no history of cardiac ailments  liver or kidney diseases  or any other significant health issues.  Family History: There is a history of cardiovascular diseases in his family. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 68 and his mother had stroke at the age of 72. He has one brother who is currently being treated for hypertension.  Lifestyle and Habits: The patient is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago. He does drink alcohol  but only socially. He leads a sedentary lifestyle since retirement and is moderately overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 27. He does not exercise regularly.  Other Pertinent Information: Patient lives with his wife in a suburban setting. He has two adult children who live in different states. He is up-to-date with his vaccinations  including an annual flu vaccine and has no known drug allergies.   Differential Diagnosis: Given the patient's clinical presentation  medical history  previous knee surgery  and sedentary lifestyle  he was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis. Other possible diagnoses such as cellulitis  superficial thrombophlebitis  and Baker's cyst were considered but ruled out based on symptoms and confirmed by the ultrasound results.  Management: The patient was admitted for the management of the DVT and was started on oral anticoagulation therapy with apixaban. He received patient education about his condition  importance of medication compliance  need for regular follow ups and lifestyle changes including incorporating more physical activity into his daily routine  weight management and calf-strengthening exercises.    Prognosis: With proper treatment  follow-up and lifestyle modifications  the patient can expect a good prognosis  though he is at an increased risk for recurrent DVT due to his previous knee surgery and family history of cardiovascular illness. Regular follow-up and appropriate interventions can help manage these risks.

Patient Presentation  Profile:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  non-smoker  from a middle socio-economic background who presents with a 1-week history of a swollen  painful left lower leg. He denies any recent trauma or injury to the leg. He does have a known history of hypertension for the last ten years  which is managed effectively with medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily).  Past Medical History: Aside from hypertension  his past medical and surgical history is significant for a gastric ulcer and a cholecystectomy 15 years ago. The patient has had no previous incidents of thromboses or pulmonary embolism. No known allergies are reported. He is physically active  enjoys regular walks and does minor chores in his backyard. He consumes alcohol socially  averaging about 1-2 glasses of wine per week.  Family History: His father died at the age of 70 due to a myocardial infarction  and his mother suffered from type 2 diabetes and passed away at 78 years old. His only sibling  a sister  is alive and well with no significant medical conditions. As per the known family history  there's no record of venous thromboembolism or any known hereditary coagulopathy.  Recent History:  Three months ago  he had a short trip overseas involving 8 hours of flight. However  he reported no issues during that time. There has been no recent hospital admissions or surgeries. For the past few days  the patient has been complaining of gradual onset  worsening pain  redness  and swelling in his left calf. He hasn’t taken any medication for the same.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient's left calf is indurated  erythematous  and mildly edematous. There's 2cm of more circumference on the left calf compared to the right  with a positive Homan's sign. His vital signs show no abnormality and the rest of the physical examination is normal.  Clinical Impression: A presumptive clinical diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis was made. The patient was referred for Doppler ultrasound examination of the lower limb veins  D-dimer assay  and other relevant blood investigation for confirmation. He's currently being managed on low molecular weight heparin pending the results.  Management: The patient's condition will be managed accordingly once the test results are reviewed. This may include anticoagulants  compression stockings  and lifestyle changes. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor his condition and review his medication plan.  Considerations: Given his age  recent long-distance travel  and presentation  the possibility of venous thrombosis was raised. The patient doesn't seem to have obvious risk factors like cancer  familial clotting disorder  or obesity; therefore  this might be an unprovoked episode of DVT. If confirmed  further search for undiagnosed malignancy will be contemplated as per guidelines. There's also a need to consider the possibility of post-thrombotic syndrome as he's presenting after a week. His hypertension also needs to be managed regularly as it may contribute to the progression and recurrence of DVT.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. X  from Albany  New York  who presented to the emergency department with swelling and severe pain in the left lower leg. Mr. X is a former social worker  retired  married  and lives with his wife. He is a non-smoker but has a reported history of moderate alcohol use.   Past Medical History: Mr. X has a known history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and Hyperlipidemia. He is on Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He underwent a total hip replacement two months ago  which was complicated by prolonged immobility.  Family History: The patient reports a paternal history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. His father  who passed away at age 70  had multiple episodes of DVT and PE which were attributed to genetic thrombophilia. His mother  deceased at age 80 suffered from arthritis. He has no siblings. His two children are alive and well.  Current Presentation: Mr. X complained of a progressively worsening painful swelling over his left leg for the past two days. He denied experiencing any chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or fever. Upon examination  the left lower leg was visibly swollen and warm to touch  compared to the right leg. Pulses in the left leg were palpable  but the leg was tender  especially in the calf area.  Relevant Investigations: A Doppler ultrasound of the bilateral lower extremities was performed which showed an acute deep vein thrombosis in the left popliteal vein and the distal portion of the left superficial femoral vein. Other routine laboratory tests  including kidney function  were within normal limits. His coagulation profile showed increased D-dimer levels.  Impression and Plans: Given the clinical presentation  ultrasound findings  and history of recent immobility following hip surgery  a diagnosis of deep venous thrombosis was made. Considering his history of DVT in his family  it suggests a likely inherited thrombophilia.  Management: The patient was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin for anticoagulation. His other medications were continued as before. He was also advised to ambulate with assistance to promote blood flow.  Considering that this could be a recurrent condition  genetic testing for inherited thrombophilia will be done. Long-term management will include anticoagulation therapy while balancing the risks of bleeding. His family members would also be advised to get tested for inherited thrombophilia  given the strong family history.  Outcome: The patient's symptoms were relieved after initiation of treatment  and he was discharged with a follow-up appointment in the hematology clinic to discuss the implications of his potential thrombophilia. His family members were also referred for testing  given the strong family history. His alcohol use would also be addressed  as it might have an effect on his overall health in the long term.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Gordon  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the ER complaining of pain and swelling in his left lower limb. As an ex-smoker and retired truck driver who often engaged in a sedentary lifestyle  he presented with a substantial risk for developing DVT. His height is 5’9” and weighs about 85 kgs.   Past medical history:  Mr. Gordon was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia ten years back  well managed with atenolol and simvastatin. He has a ten-year history of Type II diabetes mellitus which is currently managed with metformin. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago with successful angioplasty. He was also aware of mild prostatic hypertrophy but has not undergone any specific treatment.  Family History:  His mother and maternal aunt had suffered from a stroke in their later years  but there was no known history of blood clotting disorders or venous thromboembolism in the family.   Presenting complaint: He noticed pain and swelling in his left lower leg one week ago  which gradually worsened over time with increased tenderness  warmth  and discoloration around the calf area. There were no symptoms of chest pain or shortness of breath. No recent travel history or signs of an apparent infection or injury.  Physical examination:  On physical examination  his vital stats include a blood pressure of 138/85 mm Hg  a pulse of 78 beats per minute  a temperature of 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit  and a respiratory rate of 16 beats per minute. Upon palpation  the left calf is noticeably swollen and appears redder than the right calf.   Diagnostic impressions:  With physical examination and patient history  a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis was suspected. He was sent for a D-Dimer test and lower extremity venous duplex ultrasonography which confirmed the diagnosis of DVT.   Treatment plan:  The primary care includes anticoagulation  to prevent propagation of the clot. He was put on a regimen of Heparin and then switched to warfarin for long term management. As an adjunct to medication management  he is advised for incentive spirometry and venous foot pump for ensuring smooth blood flow. He was advised a healthier diet and light exercises were also suggested to shed some weight and to keep his other conditions in control.  Risk of DVT recurrence:  Given the patient’s conditions and lifestyle  he is at a considerable risk of DVT recurrence  hence necessary changes in lifestyle and strict compliance to management plans are recommended.

Patient Information:   The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. B  hailing from the suburban region of Colorado. He lives with his wife in a comfortable middle-class neighborhood. He is a retired software engineer and spends most of his time doing indoor activities like reading  computer programming  and watching television.   Presenting Issue:   Mr. B has been experiencing persistent pain  swelling  and warmth in his left lower leg since the past one-and-a-half weeks. Initially  he dismissed them as symptoms of aged-induced fatigue. However  when the pain started getting intense  he decided to seek help.   Medical History:   Mr. B has a history of type-2 diabetes and hypertension; both conditions are being managed with oral medication. He also had an open cholecystectomy about five years back due to gallstones. Apart from these  he is also known to have hypercholesterolemia and he's on statin therapy. Mr. B does not smoke or use alcohol.  Family History:   His father had coronary artery disease and suffered from a myocardial infarction in his early 60s  while his mother has osteoporosis. There is no family history of any coagulopathy or DVT.   Examination & Diagnosis:  On examination  the left calf was found to be noticeably swollen  with an increased temperature than the surrounding skin and a slightly erythematous overlying area. The Homans' sign was positive. Mr. B was subsequently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his left leg after a Doppler ultrasound report confirmed the presence of a non-compressible segment in the left popliteal vein  suggestive of a thrombus.   Treatment & Recommendations:  Management is centered on an immediate start of anticoagulation therapy to prevent the clot from enlarging  leading to a pulmonary embolism. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) such as Enoxaparin is initiated  and after a few days overlap  Warfarin therapy is added.  Simultaneously  patient education has been provided on the importance of regular leg exercises  wearing compression stockings in the affected leg to reduce swelling  and maintaining a healthy lifestyle that includes having a balanced diet and a regular physical activity regimen.  Follow-Up:  A follow-up appointment has been scheduled next week to monitor Mr. B's progress and make any necessary therapeutic adjustments.  In conclusion  while Mr. B's Sedentary lifestyle and medical conditions increase his likelihood of developing DVT  with prompt diagnosis and effective treatment  he is expected to have a fairly good prognosis. However  he will need to make lifestyle changes to prevent a reoccurrence in the future.

Patient Identification: Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presented with a two-day history of increasing pain and swelling in the right lower extremity.   Presenting Symptoms: He stated that he noticed a dull pain in his right calf  followed by progressive swelling  redness  and warmth over that area. This was associated with mild shortness of breath. He denied chest pain  cough  and hemoptysis.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes  both well-controlled with medication. He also had a cholecystectomy approximately 10 years ago. He had no prior history of thromboembolic disease.  Current Medications: Metformin  Lisinopril  and Metoprolol.  Family History: His mother had a stroke in her late 70s and his father died from a heart attack in his early 60s.  Lifestyle and Social History: He recently retired from an office job and has been leading a largely sedentary lifestyle. He is an ex-smoker and quit 20 years ago. He has a moderate intake of alcohol (1-2 glasses of wine in the evening). His diet is usually balanced but not specifically tailored to his diabetes. He lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver.   Physical Examination: On examination  there was noticeable swelling of the right calf compared to the left  with warmth and redness over the calf muscle. The right calf was tender to touch. His vital signs remained stable. There were no signs suggestive of a pulmonary embolism.   Investigations: A duplex ultrasound of the right lower extremity showed a clot in the deep vein behind the knee  suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). His D-dimer levels were also significantly elevated. EKG and chest X-ray were performed to rule out any signs of pulmonary embolism  both of which were unremarkable.  Management: Mr. Smith was started on anticoagulation therapy as per the standard guidelines for the treatment of deep vein thrombosis.  Summary: 65-year-old Mr. Smith with a history of hypertension  diabetes and sedentary lifestyle developed an acute onset of right lower limb deep vein thrombosis likely secondary to his prolonged periods of immobility after retirement. His shortness of breath and raised D-dimer level signify a threat of subsequent pulmonary embolism  for which he was started on anticoagulation therapy and monitored closely.  Further Plan: Apart from anticoagulation  Mr. Smith and his family members were educated about leg exercises  keeping hydrated  and the benefits of regular movement. He will also need strict sugar level monitoring to keep his diabetes under control. He and his wife were also educated about the symptoms of pulmonary embolism to seek immediate medical help if required. A follow-up appointment is scheduled to reassess his response to the treatment.

Case Presentation:  Patient Identification: Mr. Smith  54-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a significant leg pain and swelling. He is married with two children and works as a software engineer.   Chief Complaint: ""The severity of pain and swelling in my left leg has increased significantly over the past few days.""  History of Present Illness: Patient has been experiencing progressively worsening pain and swelling in his left leg for the past week. No recent trauma or injury to the leg reported. He does have a recent history of prolonged plane travel (vacation trip to Europe  approx. 8-hour flights each way) 10 days ago. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or other systemic symptoms.   Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension two years ago and hypercholesterolemia one year ago. His current regimen includes amlodipine 5mg daily for hypertension and rosuvastatin 10mg daily for hypercholesterolemia. No allergies are documented. He is a former smoker having quit around eight years ago (16 pack-year history) and admits to moderate alcohol use.  Family History: He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  his father suffered from a myocardial infarction at age 70 and his paternal grandmother passed away from stroke at age 77. No history of venous thromboembolism in the family.   Physical Assessment: On examination  there are no visible signs of trauma or infection. There is evident left calf swelling  warmth and erythema  compared to the right. The patient's calf circumference is 3 cm greater on the left than the right.   Investigations: A Doppler Ultrasound of the lower limbs confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the left popliteal vein  consistent with DVT. His D-dimer level was elevated and complete blood count  electrolytes  and creatinine were found to be within normal limits. ECG and chest X-ray were also normal.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical assessment and diagnostic results  a diagnosis of acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the left lower limb was confirmed.  Treatment: Patient was prescribed parenteral anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) and planning for transition onto oral direct oral anticoagulant (Rivaroxaban)  as soon as possible.  Follow Up: The patient will be monitored routinely. He has been adequately counseled regarding the risk factors  importance of medication compliance  and lifestyle modification required. He will be scheduled for follow-up in a week to assess therapeutic response and side effects  if any.  [Note: Diagnosis and management might vary based on individual patient characteristics and clinical context. Please consult a healthcare provider for appropriate diagnosis and treatment.]

Patient Presentation:   Patient Initials: J.S. Age: 60 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Corporate Employee  J.S.  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presented at the clinic complaining of increasing pain  swelling  and redness of his right lower extremity for the past five days. He denied any recent injuries but admitted to sitting long hours for his job  as a corporate professional that requires frequent long-haul flights.   Past Medical History: He has a history of hyperlipidemia and non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus. J.S. indicated he is a smoker and occasional drinker  and his BMI was calculated as 30  which qualifies him as obese.  Family History: He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases: his father underwent a coronary artery bypass grafting at the age of 65  his mother died of a stroke at the age of 67  and a paternal uncle had a deep vein thrombosis at a similar age.  Examination: On physical examination  J.S.'s right lower leg appeared erythematous and edematous with increased warmth. A Homans' sign was noted on the right side. He had a regular pulse  blood pressure was within normal limits  and oxygen saturation was 97%.  Investigations: Based on the symptoms  a possible diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis was suspected. Therefore  D-dimer testing was done  which showed an elevated level. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a clot in the right popliteal vein  supporting the diagnosis of DVT.  Management Plan: J.S. was admitted for initiation of anticoagulant treatment. He was given a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) and instructed about the importance of medication adherence. Lifestyle modification  such as regular physical activity and smoking cessation  were emphasized. Also  he was advised to use compression stockings and avoidance of long periods of immobility  particularly during flights.  Summary: A 60-year-old man with a sedentary lifestyle and significant family history of cardiovascular disease presented with deep vein thrombosis confirmed by Doppler ultrasound. He was subsequently treated with an anticoagulant and advised to modify his lifestyle. The case highlights the importance of considering deep vein thrombosis in individuals who have prolonged immobility  family history of VTE  and other risk factors such as obesity  smoking  and comorbid conditions.   Ongoing management will involve monitoring for potential bleeding complications related to anticoagulant therapy as well as consideration for withdrawal of anticoagulant after an appropriate period  based on ongoing assessment of J.S.'s risk factors.

Patient Profile: Our patient is a 72-year-old African American male  previously a high school basketball coach  presenting with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient is married and lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. He is retired and his primary role is taking care of his grandchildren. He is a non-smoker and only drinks socially. His Body Mass Index (BMI) measures 27  indicating that he is overweight.  Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes. He is on medication for both conditions - Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. He had an episode of left-sided DVT two years ago which was treated with standard anticoagulation therapy. He was compliant with the treatment regimen but was taken off anticoagulants a year ago. He also has had a total hip replacement surgeries 3 years ago.  Family History:  His family history is significant with his father dying in his mid-70s due to a myocardial infarction and his mother died from a stroke in her late 70s. His older brother has coronary artery disease and had a stent placed a few years ago.   Presenting Problem:  The patient was brought to the emergency department with severe pain in his right leg  which he describes as 'as heavy as a brick'  with redness and swelling. The symptoms began two days ago  and he initially attributed them to his arthritis. However  due to the progressive increase in pain and swelling  he sought medical attention.   Clinical Examination and Diagnosis: Upon examination  Homan’s sign was positive  and Doppler ultrasonographic evaluation confirmed the presence of DVT in his right lower extremity. His laboratory results indicated a slight elevation in his D-dimer levels. Given his age  medical history (particularly his prior episode of DVT  hypertension  diabetes type II  and previous hip surgery)  clinical presentation  and confirmatory Doppler study  he was diagnosed with right-sided DVT.   This case illustrates the typical presentation of DVT and indicates the necessity to consider this condition in patients who present with unilateral leg pain and swelling  particularly in those with risk factors such as advanced age  previous history of DVT  hypertension  diabetes  and recent surgery.

Patient Presentation:   - Name: John Doe  - Age: 65 years  - Gender: Male  - Occupation: Retired Army Veteran  - Ethnicity: White American   Presenting Complaint:   Mr. Doe presented with unilateral swelling and pain in his right lower leg which had started progressively within a week. He reported no trauma or injury to the leg.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  but had a cumulative smoking history of 30-pack years prior. He has a known history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus which is controlled by oral hypoglycemic agents  and Hypertension  controlled by beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors. He previously had a minor myocardial infarction ten years ago and completed cardiac rehab. There were no other significant diseases in his medical history.  Personal and Social History:  He lives alone since his wife's demise 5 years ago  and has two adult children living out of town. As a retired army veteran  he leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle which has been more pronounced since the COVID-19 lockdown began. He quit smoking following his previous heart incident and restricts his alcohol consumption to occasional social gatherings.  Family History:  Both of his parents deceased  mother died due to a myocardial infarction in her late 60s  and his father had a history of stroke in his early 70s.  Physical Exam:  Upon examination  his right lower leg was edematous and the skin was slightly warm compared to the unaffected side. His vital signs were stable. Cardiac and lung exams were unremarkable.  Investigations:  He was immediately sent for a Doppler ultrasound and D-Dimer test  which confirmed the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Management/Treatment Plan:  The patient was prescribed anticoagulants to dissolve the clot and prevent further clot formation. Compression stockings were advised along with lifestyle modification - increased physical activity  nutrition guidance  and medication compliance.   Summary:  Mr. Doe is a 65-year-old male with a history of Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and previous Myocardial Infarction. He presented with a week-long history of unilateral pain and swelling suggestive of DVT. Doppler ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis. His DVT is likely related to his circulatory diseases and sedentary lifestyle  both of which are risk factors for thrombus formation. The management should address his acute symptoms along with improved control of his chronic disease and lifestyle modification. Regular follow-ups advised to monitor the patient's progress.

Patient Presentation --- **Patient Demographics:** Mrs. M  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  presented herself at the clinic. She is living with her husband in the suburbs of Ohio and is a retired school teacher. The patient is a non-smoker and takes occasional alcohol. She reports to regularly walk her dog and is overall physically active for her age.  **Chief Complaint:** The patient was seen in the clinic with her chief complaint being swelling and discomfort in her lower right leg  particularly the calf region  which had been persistent for the past seven days. The pain increases with walking and standing.  **Past Medical History:** Mrs. M has been treated for hypertension and type 2 diabetes for past ten years. She is regular on antihypertensive and oral hypoglycemic agents. She had a hysterectomy 30 years ago due to severe endometriosis. No reported allergies.  **Family History:** Parents are deceased. Mother had cardiovascular disease  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes. Father had lung cancer. No siblings. One son  healthy.  **Investigations and Diagnosis:** On examination  her right calf was found to be swollen with tenderness and redness  warm to the touch compared to the left one. Pulses were palpable in both lower extremities. Considering her symptoms  a d-dimer test was done that turned out to be positive. In order to verify the diagnosis  an Ultrasound Doppler study of the lower limb veins was done  which confirmed the presence of a clot in the right leg deep vein confirming a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  **Treatment Plan:** Mrs. M was immediately put on anticoagulation therapy. Therapeutic dosing of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) was started. Recommendations of a consultation with a Hematologist for further evaluation and management decisions.  **Follow Up:** The patient was advised bed rest with limb elevation when possible and asked to wear compression stockings. Counseled about the risks of pulmonary embolism. Regular follow-ups were arranged to monitor her condition and response to therapy.  **Prevention and Education:** Considering her two risk factors for DVT – age and hypertension  patient was educated about the importance of regular exercise  the maintenance of a balanced diet  and on regular medication compliance. She was also explained about signs and symptoms of pulmonary embolism like chest pain  shortness of breath  rapid heart rate  or fainting  and to seek immediate care if such symptoms arise in future.   The patient was also counselled to monitor her weight and keep her blood glucose under control to avoid any future complications associated with her diabetes. Her eldest daughter was also educated regarding the condition  its implications and prevention measures for future.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 75-years-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with edema and discomfort in his left lower leg  which become worse over the last week. Mr. Doe reports that he's been living a sedentary lifestyle after he retired five years ago which has become progressively worse due to the COVID-19 pandemic. He has a 20-year history of hypertension controlled by lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. He is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history having quit 15 years ago and is an occasional alcohol consumer.  In addition to his leg symptoms  he reports recent unexplained weight loss  fatigue  and feelings of weakness. Prior to presenting to the emergency department  the patient reported initial mild swelling and a discomfort sensation in his left lower extremity. However  the symptoms persistently worsened leading to significant during movement  and he noticed increased swelling and warmth over the area.  His family history indicates that his father died of a stroke at 67  and his mother had a myocardial infarction at 70. His older brother died at 59 due to lung cancer while his 72-year-old sister is alive and well with no significant medical history.   Physical examination reveals left calf mildly tender to palpation with a notable difference in calf circumference between the two legs. He also has mild pitting edema in the left leg. His vitals were stable except for a mildly elevated blood pressure of 148/93.  Doppler ultrasound showed a non-compressible segment in the left popliteal vein  indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He was subsequently started on anticoagulation with enoxaparin in the hospital and was transitioned to apixaban for long-term management.  The patient's DVT  on the grounds of his sedentary lifestyle and hypertension  classifies him as having provoked DVT. Finding out the cause of the patient's unexplained weight loss and weakness might be critical  as it could suggest an underlying malignancy which is a risk factor for DVT. Management with anticoagulants has been started  and further investigations for underlying causes are ongoing.  The patient has been educated about the importance of regular movement  maintaining a healthy lifestyle  and the need for medical compliance. He has been scheduled for a follow-up in two weeks for the therapy evaluation and further assessment.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. Ronald Jeffery  Age: 65 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Residential address: Orlando  Florida  USA  Past Medical History:  Mr. Ronald is known to have hypertension  for which he takes a Beta-blocker medication  and Type II Diabetes Mellitus managed with insulin and diet. He has an established history of hyperlipidemia and had a myocardial infarction 8 years ago for which he underwent angioplasty. He has been a smoker for the past 30 years and recently decided to quit.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Ronald arrived at the ER complaining of a progressively worsening pain and swelling in his right lower leg over the past 4 days. He denies any recent trauma or injury to the leg. He describes the pain as a deep ache  non-radiating and aggravated on walking. Associated symptoms include mild shortness of breath and palpitations.   On further interrogation  he divulged that he recently underwent orthopedic surgery (hip replacement) 2 weeks ago and has been relatively immobile since then. He also has an upcoming long-haul flight for a vacation. He denies any history of fever  chest pain  cough or hemoptysis. He has not noticed any change in color of urine or stools. He has no known allergies.  Physical Examination:  General Aspect: Conscious  Oriented  appears anxious. Vital signs: BP- 140/85 mmHg  Pulse- 85 beats/min  Respiratory rate- 20 breaths/min  Temperature- 98.6 F  Oxygen saturation- 98% on room air Lower Limbs: Right lower leg is visibly swollen than the left. The skin over the right lower leg is warm and red.  This case focuses on a high-risk patient presenting classic symptoms of deep vein thrombosis. Factors such as his medical history of cardiovascular disease  recent orthopedic surgery and prolonged immobility  as well as the impending long flight  put him at elevated risk for DVT. The scenario encourages students to consider diagnostic tests (such as D-dimer or ultrasound) and management plans for DVT  teaching them about the condition's risk factors  symptoms  and treatment.

Patient Profile: Name: John Doe Age: 65 years Sex: Male Occupation: Retired engineer  leads a mostly sedentary lifestyle Ethnicity: Caucasian Location: Urban area  Past Medical History: 1. Ex-smoker  quit 5 years ago after a 30-year smoking history. 2. Diagnosed with hypertension and Type 2 diabetes 7 years ago. 3. Underwent a knee replacement surgery two weeks ago. 4. On regular medication for his chronic conditions  including Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. 5. No prior history of blood coagulation disorders or thromboembolic diseases. 6. No familial history of coagulation disorders. 7. Prior to his knee surgery  his mobility was moderate but reduced significantly post-surgery due to pain and recovery.  Key Current Complaints: 1. Acute onset  unilateral  and non-traumatic swelling in the lower right leg that began three days ago. 2. Swelling is associated with pain that is severe upon extending the leg or when standing. 3. Mild redness over the affected thigh area. 4. No recent history of direct trauma or injury to the leg. 5. Denies experiencing chest pain or shortness of breath. 6. No symptoms suggestive of systemic infection such as fever or chills.  This case scenario suggests a high probability of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  common in patients with reduced mobility  post-surgical recovery  obesity  and existing chronic conditions. This case allows medical students to understand the risk factors  clinical presentation  diagnostic procedures  management  and complication prevention regarding DVT. It also aims to underscore the importance of prophylaxis in patients with risk factors.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics: Name: Mrs. Jane Doe Age: 65-year-old  Sex: Female Occupation: Retired School Teacher Smoke: No Alcohol: Social Drinker Physical Activity: Low  mostly sedentary Ethnicity: Asian-Indian Living Situation: Lives with her husband  Past Medical History: Mrs. Doe is known to have Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  managed with medication for the past 10 years. She underwent a right total knee replacement surgery three months ago. Her post-surgical recovery at home was uneventful. There is no previous history of DVT or Pulmonary Embolism (PE)  or any genetic clotting disorders in her family.  Key Complaints: Mrs. Doe presents to the clinic complaining of gradual onset pain  swelling  and warmth over the right calf area that has worsened over the past 48 hours. She had also noticed pain becoming more severe when the foot is flexed upward. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or recent long-haul travel.   On examination  her vital signs are stable. Her right leg appears swollen and is tender to touch  especially in the calf area. There is no current history of trauma or rash. Her skin color appears normal but feels warmer in the affected leg as compared to the left. There's pitting edema present in her right lower limb.  Please note  this training case is designed to demonstrate essential skills in identifying  diagnosing  and managing DVT. Teaching focuses should include patient history taking  understanding risk factors (such as major surgeries and immobility)  physical examination  use of clinical decision rules  and interpretating diagnostic tests. Understanding how to counsel patient on treatment options along with prophylaxis of DVT is quintessential as well.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: Mr. John Doe is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  smoker  and regular red wine drinker. He is married with two adult children and five grandchildren. His body mass index (BMI) is 32  indicating obesity.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  both of which have been fairly well managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively for about 10 years. He also had an appendectomy at the age of 23. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus three years ago  managed through Metformin. He has been compliant with his medications. There is no history of illicit drug use  but he admits to smoking a pack of cigarettes a day for about 30 years  and drinks a glass of red wine each night. He has no known drug allergies.   Key Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with a 3-day history of progressively worsening pain and swelling in his left calf. He denies any history of trauma or excessive use of the leg but does mention a recent long 14-hour car trip he took a week back to visit his grandchildren. He describes the pain as constant  intensifying with movement and slightly alleviated with rest. He also reported a sense of tightness in the same leg. No chest pain  shortness of breath  palpitations  or syncopal episodes were reported. On a scale from 0 to 10  he rated his pain as 7.  This case report provides students a chance to discuss and investigate the possible occurrence of deep vein thrombosis in the context of several risk factors  including age  prolonged immobility  smoking  obesity  and hypertension. The absence of respiratory symptoms can also be utilized to explore the clinical variations between lower extremity DVT and pulmonary embolism.

Patient Demographics: Patient Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 70 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired engineer Ethnicity: Caucasian Residence: Suburban community  Past Medical History: John has a history of hypertension controlled with medication. He had a hip replacement surgery around six weeks ago. He also has a previous history of smoking for 30 years but quit 15 years ago. There's no history of any hemorrhagic disorders or malignancy. He does not have any known allergies.  Presenting Complaints: John has presented to the emergency department with complaints of acute onset  severe pain and swelling in his right leg. He noticed the pain after waking up in the morning  and it has steadily worsened throughout the day. He mentions that the pain increases when he tries to stand or walk. He also reports slight shortness of breath and mild chest discomfort. He denies any symptoms of high fever  disorientation  or recent travel history.  This training case calls for the learners to identify the signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  and the connection between his recent surgery and the risk of developing DVT. The presentation also includes minor signs of possible pulmonary embolism (shortness of breath and chest discomfort)  an arising complication of DVT. Students should consider these factors  prioritize patient safety  and find the best approach for diagnosis and treatment of this condition.

Case Report  Patient Details:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68  Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Corporate Employee Ethnicity: African American Location: Urban  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus  both of which are managed with medication. Around five years ago  he underwent a total hip replacement surgery due to osteoarthritis. He is also diagnosed with obesity with a BMI of 34. He is a former smoker and quit smoking 10 years ago. There is no history of previous thrombotic events known or bleeding disorders in the family. He has a sedentary living style and lacks physical activity.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe visited the emergency department reporting severe unilateral pain and swelling in his right calf of two days duration. The pain is constant and has progressively worsened. He reports no history of injury or trauma to his leg. The patient also complained of mild breathlessness on exertion. No complaint of chest pain or palpitations.  Risk Assessment:  His obesity  recent immobility  past hip surgery  age  and comorbidities like hypertension and Type II diabetes suggest a high risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  The above case is designed as an exercise for medical students to explore a typical presentation of DVT. Students should be encouraged to discuss differential diagnoses  appropriate diagnostic tests  and potential treatment options. Each student's understanding of the pathophysiology of DVT and its risk factors should be assessed.   In this case discussion  they should recognize the importance of patient education for preventing DVT  especially in high-risk patients and the settings where they might encounter similar cases in their practice.

Patient Profile: Name: John Smith Age: 60 Sex: Male Occupation: Long-haul truck driver Race: Caucasian Marital status: Married  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of smoking for 30 years but quit 5 years ago. He is diagnosed with hypertension and cholesterol which is controlled by medication. He has a BMI of 30  indicating obesity. He has no known allergies. Mr. Smith has no previous surgeries or hospitalizations. His parents suffered from heart disease.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith presented at the clinic with complaints of left leg pain and swelling that had been progressing over the past week. He mentioned that he noticed a gradual increase in the pain  especially after completing long hauls in his truck. He also remarked about mild shortness of breath after climbing stairs  which he had not experienced before.  Clinical Summary: Mr. Smith is a 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking  and prolonged sedentary activity due to his job as a long-haul trucker  who presents with a week's history of worsening left leg swelling and pain  showing the classical symptoms of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).   This case is felt to be an appropriate scenario to teach medical students about the risk factors  classical symptoms  differential diagnosis  management  and potential complications of DVT.

Patient Case Report:  Gender: Female Age: 50 years old Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Office worker  Residential area: Urban  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of level II obesity (BMI: 35)  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. She also has a sedentary lifestyle and a 10-year history of pack-a-day smoking. There is no known history of any major operation or past concerning health issues like deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Her family history is significant for her father having ischemic heart disease  and her paternal aunt passed away due to a stroke at the age of 57.  Key Complaints: The patient presents with a chief complaint of experiencing progressively worsening and persistent left lower limb pain and swelling for the past week. She reports that the swelling and pain is generalized throughout her left lower leg  enhanced after prolonged sitting at work  and not relieved by rest or over-the-counter pain medications. She denies any recent trauma to the area  chest pain  or difficulty in breathing. However  she mentions feeling intermittently dizzy over the past few days.   This case presentation should raise the clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Given the patient's age  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  smoking history  and hypertension  she is at a higher risk for venous thromboembolism. Primary attention should be given to her limb symptoms  while her intermittent dizziness may also point towards possible concurrent pulmonary embolism.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: The patient  Mr. Joseph  is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired military officer  currently working part time as a security consultant. He's a nonsmoker and drinks alcohol moderately. Mr. Joseph lives in suburban Philadelphia with his wife of 42 years and their golden retriever.   Past Medical History: Mr. Joseph has been diagnosed with hypertension for which he takes lisinopril  and mild osteoarthritis which he manages with over-the-counter NSAIDs. He was diagnosed with non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus five years ago  controlled with diet and metformin. He also has a history of hypercholesterolemia and takes atorvastatin. He has no known allergies.  He has had one previous hospitalization for an appendectomy 25 years ago. Family history is notable for father's death following myocardial infarction at the age of 73 and brother's stroke at the age of 69.    Key Complaints: Mr. Joseph reports experiencing severe pain and swelling in his left calf for the past two days. He notes that the area feels warm to touch and the skin appears somewhat reddened. He denies trauma to the area but admits that he recently had a long  trans-Atlantic flight (10 hours) returning from a business trip. He notes that he remained seated for most of the journey.   He also mentioned being short of breath occasionally during moderate exertion over the last week. He has no known exposure to viruses and no cough or fever. He denies chest pain or palpitations.  This case emphasizes the importance of recognizing the risk factors and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  particularly in patients with history of prolonged immobilization (long flights)  advanced age  and other comorbidities including hypertension  diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: Mr. Alan Rogers  a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a BMI of 30  retired engineer  a non-smoker  living in the rural Midwest.  Past Medical History:   The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension being managed on Lisinopril for the last 10 years. He had a right hip replacement surgery four months ago for osteoarthritis. He had laparoscopic cholecystectomy 15 years ago. No known drug allergies. Family history indicates that his mother died at the age of 78 due to stroke and his father died at the age of 82 due to cardiac arrest. No family history of any clotting disorders.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Rogers visited the clinic with a chief complaint of swelling and mild pain in his right leg  specifically the calf area. He indicates that he's not been very mobile for the past few days due to his hip pathology. His pain worsens when he stands or walks. He denied any trauma to the leg  fever  or recent illness.  Physical Examination:   The right lower leg was edematous  erythematous with mild tenderness on palpation. The pain score on VAS scale was 4/10. Pulse in the limb felt normal  Capillary refill time was less than 2 seconds. No superficial veins were visible. There was a noticeable difference in circumference when compared to the non-swollen left leg.   A differential diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) could be drawn out from these symptoms along with his recent surgery and immobilization. Further tests including a D-dimer and an ultrasound scan of the right lower limb should be conducted to confirm the diagnosis. If confirmed  treatment and management with anticoagulants and measures to prevent an embolic incident should be the primary focus.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information: Name: Ms. Lorraine Stevenson Age: 67 years Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher  Chief Complaints: Ms. Stevenson came into the clinic complaining of acute swelling and pain in her right calf that started three days prior. She reported that the pain was throbbing  non-radiating  and somewhat relieved by elevating her leg. She also noted that her right calf appeared slightly red and warmer than the left calf.  Past Medical History: Ms. Stevenson is a breast cancer survivor  having completed chemotherapy and radiation therapy three years ago. She is currently under hormonal treatment - Tamoxifen. She had undergone a hysterectomy in her early 50s following a diagnosis of uterine fibroids. She has a history of obesity and a sedentary lifestyle  with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32. Her family history reveals her father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 75.   Additional Health Information: She had taken a long-haul flight (over 7 hours) to visit her son 2 weeks prior  where she had limited mobility. She reported no trauma  bug bite  scratch  or any skin damage. She also has no known allergies and does not smoke or drink alcohol.  This provided case should be used to train students on risk factors (e.g.  cancer  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  long travel hours) and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis  as well as the need for prompt evaluation and treatment to prevent potentially serious complications such as pulmonary embolism. Additionally  the case may illuminate discussions around the intersection of a patient’s medical and personal history on their current health status.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Mr. Richard Mathews  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired college professor living in rural Ohio. He has been married for 36 years  lives with his wife and their two labradors.   Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of intermittent claudication and was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease 10 years ago. He underwent angioplasty three years ago and was put on antiplatelet therapy. He also has controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Mr. Mathews is a former 30 pack-year smoker but quit five years ago. He has not been diagnosed with any hematologic disorders  and no known drug allergies exist.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Mathews visited the local emergency department with complaints of increasing pain and swelling in the right lower leg  more pronounced over the calf  for the past 2-3 days. He described the pain as constant  dull  and rated it 8/10 in severity. Furthermore  he reported a feeling of warmth over the area but denied any fever  chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough.   The patient noticed that the swelling and pain seemed to progress during the day  especially during prolonged sitting. He also mentioned that he recently returned from a long-haul road trip  during which he was in the car for several hours without getting up or walking. He admitted of compliance with his medications but reported non-adherence to exercise advised for his peripheral arterial disease. Mr. Mathews reported no recent trauma  injury  or surgical procedures.   This case is designed to familiarize students with the standard investigation approach  risk factors  clinical presentation  and management principles for deep vein thrombosis.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Accountant Race: Caucasian Lifestyle: Sedentary Location: Urban  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 10 years ago  for which he is currently taking antihypertensives and statins respectively. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago after smoking a pack a day for 30 years. He is overweight with a BMI of 28 and has a family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe visited his general practitioner complaining of a non-traumatic  increasingly painful and swollen right lower leg over the past 5 days. He recently had a long overseas flight about a week ago and had been sedentary for most of the time since then. Upon further questioning  he reported a mild discomfort in his chest  but described it as ""not quite like heartburn "" and a slight shortness of breath when climbing stairs.  Objective Clinical Information: Physical examination revealed a noticeably swollen and reddened right calf. There were no signs of injury or inflammation around the area. The circumference of the right calf was greater than that of the left. On auscultation  breath sounds were clear bilaterally  heart sounds regular  no murmur. Palpation was painful on the right calf. No distinct mass or bulge felt. The rest of the systemic examination was within normal limits. The patient's blood pressure was slightly elevated  and his pulse was regular.  Possible Diagnosis: Considering his recent prolonged travel  sedentary behaviour  and clinical presentation  Mr. Doe is at high risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with a potential pulmonary embolism (PE). However  other differential diagnoses that may need to be ruled out could include Baker’s cyst  cellulitis  or muscle strain.  Plan: Order duplex ultrasonography test to confirm DVT and D-dimer blood test. Based on Mr. Doe's complaints of slight dyspnea and chest discomfort  an immediate chest CT angiography would be essential to rule out PE. Consultation with a hematologist for anticoagulation management will be the course of action upon confirmation of DVT. Suggesting lifestyle modifications and assessing his need for weight management and exercise regimen will be part of long-term management.   This case highlights the importance of proactively looking at risk factors for DVT  understanding the complications  and recognizing the need for immediate action when PE is suspected. It also emphasizes the importance of education about prevention of DVT  especially in high-risk situations like long-haul travel.   This case is designed to guide medical students through the comprehensive management of a potential DVT case  including diagnosis  immediate clinical management  and long-term preventive strategies.

Training Case: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male who works as an airline pilot. He is a moderate smoker and maintains a moderately sedentary lifestyle. He reports the frequent consumption of alcohol and is substantially overweight. Patient is non-diabetic and has no known drug allergies.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a previous history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a sedentary lifestyle  for which he is currently on Amlodipine and Atorvastatin. He was diagnosed with polycythemia a year ago. He experienced a myocardial infarction three years ago  which was managed with angioplasty. He has been recently started on hormonal therapy (testosterone) for late-onset hypogonadism.  Key Complaints:  The key complaint presented by the patient is a severe and sudden onset of pain  warmth  and swelling in his left calf that progressed over a day. He reports a feeling of heaviness in the same leg with red or discolored skin. He is also experiencing breathing difficulties  palpitations  and mild chest pain which intensifies on deep inhalation. This has resulted in a functional limitation in his daily activities. Upon further questioning  he also reported recent long-haul flights as part of his profession. He denied any recent surgeries or immobilization.   This case highlights risk factors such as age  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  long duration travel  malignancy  hormonal therapy (Hypercoagulable state)  and advanced vascular disease. The symptoms are suggestive of a DVT with a possible pulmonary embolism  given his chest symptoms. It perfectly underscores the importance of careful history-taking and recognizing risk factors for DVT.  Follow this brief report with diagnostic methods like blood tests  Doppler ultrasound  D-dimer tests  and treatment approaches including pharmacologic management (anticoagulants  thrombolytics)  mechanical treatment options  and prophylaxis information. Structured discussions must also include understanding differential diagnoses  risks  benefits  decision-making process  follow-up criteria  and multidisciplinary approach to manage complications. This case can serve as a comprehensive teaching tool and useful resource for trainees.

Patient Information: • 68-year-old Caucasian female • Lives alone in suburban home • Non-smoker with moderate alcohol consumption • Occupation: Retired schoolteacher  Past Medical History: • Hypertension  controlled with medication • High cholesterol (hypercholesterolemia)  controlled with statins • No history of clotting disorders • History of intermittent atrial fibrillation – takes warfarin regularly • No previous surgeries • Noticed mild varicose veins two years ago • No known allergies  Key Complaints: • Feeling a sensation of tightness and heaviness in the left leg for the past two days • Describes the pain as dull aching  7/10 on pain scale at worst • Lying down or keeping the leg elevated helps slightly reduce the pain • Symptoms escalated today with noticing warmth over the affected area and the leg becoming visibly swollen • Colour and temperature of the right leg are normal  This case has been designed for medical students to help illustrate the typical presentation of a patient suffering from deep vein thrombosis. It involves a patient who presents with classic symptoms  such as pain  swelling  and warmth over the affected area  along with known risk factors for the condition. The students would be encouraged to propose and analyze differential diagnosis based on the symptoms provided before considering deep vein thrombosis.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Information:  - Gender: Male - Age: 55 years - Occupation: Long-haul truck driver - Marital Status: Married - Racial Background: Caucasian  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril)  type 2 diabetes mellitus well controlled with Metformin  and hyperlipidemia managed with Atorvastatin. He has been smoking a pack of cigarettes a day for the last 25 years. He also suffers from obesity with a body mass index (BMI) of 35. His father had a history of stroke at the age of 60.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset progressive swelling  heaviness  warmth  and pain in his left leg for the past 2 days. The patient also stated there has been a slight increase in his heart rate  but he has no chest pain  lightheadedness  syncope  dyspnea  or cough. He affirmed he recently had a long  non-stop driving stint of 10 hours from the Midwest to the East Coast.  This case provides a good starting point in discussing deep vein thrombosis  its risk factors  presentation  diagnosis  and management. In this case  risk factors that can be highlighted includes the patient's occupation requiring long periods of immobility  smoking habits  hypertension  obesity  and a family history of thromboembolic disease.
