The case also alludes to the potentially life-threatening complication of pulmonary embolism. Key aspects of the management of DVT including lifestyle changes  anticoagulation therapy  thrombolysis  and the use of compression stockings can also be discussed.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics: Name: John Doe Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Location: Urban suburban area  Midwest US  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension (Controlled with atenolol) 2. Type 2 diabetes mellitus (Controlled with metformin) 3. Hyperlipidaemia (Controlled with atorvastatin) 4. Ex-smoker (quit 5 years ago) 5. Recent right total knee arthroplasty 4 weeks ago 6. No known allergies  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the clinic with complaints of a progressively swollen right leg with a moderate degree of pain worsening since last 2 days. He noticed a mild redness  warmth and tenderness over the calf muscles of his right leg. He also reported difficulty in walking due to these symptoms. He denied any recent trauma to the leg  fa fever  chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness or fainting episodes. He also denied any family history of blood clotting disorders.   This case scenario introduces a patient with multiple risk factors for deep vein thrombosis: advanced age  recent orthopedic surgery (total knee arthroplasty)  and a sedentary lifestyle due to the recent surgery. The key complaints of leg swelling  redness  pain and warmth are classic signs of deep vein thrombosis. The absence of more systemic symptoms like shortness of breath or chest pain (indicative of pulmonary embolism) allows learners to focus on the local presentation and diagnosis of DVT. It also emphasizes the importanc of risk assessment and prophylaxis for DVT in patients undergoing major orthopedic surgeries. The case can be further developed to discuss differential diagnosis  diagnostic approach (like the use of D-dimer testing  Duplex ultrasound etc.)  and treatment modalities for DVT  including the use of anticoagulation therapy.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics:  Patient is a 65-year-old African American male  retired truck driver who recently had a long transatlantic flight two weeks ago. Lives in a suburban neighborhood with his wife of 40 years. He's a past smoker but quit 1 year ago and occasionally drinks alcohol. No known drug allergies.   Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago and Hypertension 7 years ago. He is currently managing his conditions with a combination of Metformin (500mg twice daily) for his diabetes and Lisinopril (20 mg daily) for high blood pressure. His most recent A1C level was 7.1%. The patient's hypertension has been well-controlled with his current medication  although he admits he sometimes forget to take his medication. His BMI is 32  indicating obesity.   There is a known history of Cardiovascular Disease in his family; his father died at the age of 65 from a heart attack  while his older sister  68 years old  recently underwent surgery for peripheral vascular disease.   Primary Complaints: The patient visited the emergency department with a 3-day history of worsening pain in his left leg. The pain was started suddenly  is constant  and importantly  is not relieved by Ibuprofen or rest. His leg appears swollen and slightly red compared to the right leg. He also reported feelings of warmth over the region of pain. The patient also complained of shortness of breath  especially when climbing stairs. He denies chest pain or any other associated symptoms. His pain is rated as 7 on a scale of 1-10.   Objective Data: On examination  his left calf was warm  swollen  with a positive Homan’s Sign. His vitals at entrance were as follows: BP- 140/90 mmHg  HR- 97 bpm  Temp- 98.6°F  RR- 20 breaths/min  O2 level 94%.  In the light of these reports and given the patient’s past medical and family history  the suspicion for Deep Vein Thrombosis is high. The next step would be to confirm the diagnosis through Doppler ultrasonography or a D-dimer test  and subsequently manage the patient condition appropriately.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics  Name: John Doe Sex: Male Age: 67 years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe presented with a two-day history of progressive left leg swelling and discomfort. The patient also reported mild  intermittent shortness of breath. He denied any recent long-distance traveling  surgery  or traumatic injuries.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of type II diabetes mellitus  for which he takes Metformin. He also has been treated for hypertension with Losartan for 10 years. He quit smoking 15 years ago but had a 30-pack-year smoking history before he quit. He does not consume alcohol nor has any known drug allergies.   Family History: Mr. Doe's mother had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 72  and his elder brother recently was diagnosed with DVT. His father and grandfather both died from myocardial infarction.  Physical Examination Findings: Upon examination  his left lower leg appeared swollen and red compared to the right  with calf circumference notably larger on the left. His vitals were stable  and cardiovascular  respiratory  and abdominal examination was essentially normal.   The clinical scenario above illustrates a straightforward case of DVT  paying attention to risk factors such as age  family history  and history of systemic illnesses such as diabetes and hypertension. The leg swelling and discomfort in the context of these risk factors are suggestive of a deep vein thrombosis. Further investigations should include Doppler Ultrasound  D-Dimer test  and potentially a CT scan to rule out a potential pulmonary embolism given his mild shortness of breath.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information and Demographics: Mr. George Lucas is a 65-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired high school teacher and has been living alone since his wife passed away two years ago. Mr. Lucas is a smoker  with a 40-pack per year smoking history  and he enjoys a sedentary lifestyle since retirement due to which he has gradually gained weight. He consumes alcohol moderately.   Past Medical History: Mr. Lucas has a history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus. He has been under medication for hypertension (Lisinopril 10 mg daily) and Diabetes (Metformin 1000 mg twice daily). His diabetes is moderately controlled. He was hospitalized 6 months back for right hip replacement surgery post a fall at home.   Key Complaints: Mr. Lucas visited the outpatient department with complaints of swelling and slight pain in his left lower leg  which he noticed two days back. He mentioned that the swelling appeared suddenly without any noticeable injury and has been increasing gradually. He reported that the pain escalates on stretching his foot. On further questioning  he noticed mild tenderness and warmth over the swelling area. He also reported mild shortness of breath that started a day ago. There is no reported chest pain or dizziness.   This information initiates the beginning of the case study for medical students. Students should be guided to probe further into the presenting complaints  consider the relevant past medical history  and determine the necessary physical examination  diagnostic procedures  and potential management options for Deep Vein Thrombosis.

Patient Information: Mr. George Thompson  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  travelling businessman with limited physical activity  non-smoker and social drinker.  Past Medical History: Patient has hypertension for which he takes medication. Has a history of myocardial infarction three years prior  was stabilized and is routinely followed up. He has also been diagnosed with obesity (BMI: 32) and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  which is controlled through diet and metformin. Family history indicates a mother having a stroke at age 65 and a father with a coronary artery disease diagnosed in his early 60s.  Key Complaints: Mr. Thompson presents in the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of pain and swelling in his left leg  particularly the calf that started a day before. Describes the pain as dull and constant  rating it at 7 on a 10-point pain scale. The pain is somewhat relieved with elevation and worsens with walking and standing. He denies trauma to the leg. Patient also reports feeling slightly short of breath for the past few hours  no chest pain  cough  or fever. He additionally remarks he just came back from a cross-country business trip that required long hours of sitting.  Case Summary: This case presents a middle-aged  obese male with multiple risk factors for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) including hypertension  history of myocardial infarction  and recent prolonged immobility due to travel. His complaint of sudden unilateral leg pain and swelling with associated shortness of breath is highly suggestive of DVT. The shortness of breath could possibly indicate a pulmonary embolism  which can be a life-threatening complication of DVT. Immediate further diagnostics including a Doppler ultrasound of the leg and D-dimer blood test should be considered. Additionally  computed tomography (CT) of the chest may also be required to exclude pulmonary embolism in context of his symptoms.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics: Name: Jane Doe Age: 65 Sex: Female  Race: African American  Occupation: Retiree  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type II  and chronic kidney disease stage III. Her medications include Metformin and Ramipril. Neither she nor her family has a history of blood clotting disorders. She is an ex-smoker and does not drink alcohol. She is overweight  with a BMI of 30.  Key Complaints: Miss Doe was admitted to the emergency room presenting with unilateral swelling of the right calf  which has been worsening for the past 5 days. She describes it as a “heavy” feeling with an ache. However  no overt pain is experienced. She has noted the area to be warm to touch.  She reported recently returning from a long international flight 7 days prior to the onset of symptoms. She was mostly immobilized during the flight. She has not undergone any recent surgical procedures. She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. There is also no history of trauma to the affected leg.  The patient is scared as she has read online about the severe complications that could arise from a blood clot in the leg. She wished to get professional help  and hence  she came to the hospital.  Teaching Objectives: The purpose of this case is for medical students to identify and manage Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Key learning objectives would include:  1. Understanding the pathophysiology of DVT. 2. Recognizing the risk factors for DVT. 3. Being familiar with the signs and symptoms of DVT. 4. Being able to order and interpret appropriate diagnostic tests for DVT. 5. Knowing how to manage and treat DVT  and when to refer the patient urgently for specialist opinion. 6. Understanding the appropriate prophylactic measures for DVT. 7. Being aware of the possible complications and prognosis of DVT.  8. Appreciating the importance of patient education about DVT.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Roberts is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  a retired construction worker  who hails from West Virginia. He was a smoker for 40 years and quit two years ago.  Past Medical History: Mr. Roberts has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past ten years  managed with lisinopril and rosuvastatin. He has no history of diabetes  stroke or heart disease. His body mass index (BMI) is 27. He has a surgical history of right hip replacement done four years ago due to severe osteoarthritis. He is allergic to penicillin  which causes him to break out in hives.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Roberts presents to the outpatient clinic complaining of undue pain  swelling  and slight redness in his right leg. The pain started approximately a week ago  gradually escalating in severity  and it is now difficult for him to walk. He mentions that the leg feels warm and appears swollen. He also mentions he's felt slightly short of breath recently  but he has no associated chest pain  palpitations  fainting  recent illnesses or injuries. He denies ever having experienced similar symptoms in the past. He also denies having traveled long distances or being immobile for extended periods recently. Mr. Roberts appears anxious about his symptoms but maintains coherence and cooperativeness.   Plan: Given Mr. Roberts’ symptoms and past medical history  it is crucial to consider deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the differential diagnosis. Urgent diagnostic tests such as a Doppler ultrasound of his right leg and  if necessary  D-dimer levels are planned. He would need a referral to a hematologist for further investigation and management. It's also necessary to emphasize the risks associated with DVT including pulmonary embolism. Low molecular weight heparin may be considered for initial treatment once the diagnosis is confirmed. The importance of seeking immediate medical help should worsening symptoms occur like acute chest pain or difficulty in breathing will be emphasized.

Patient Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics:  Age: 68 years  Sex: Male  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired professor (used to lead a sedentary lifestyle)  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension - On medication for the last 10 years (Lisinopril 5mg daily). 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - Diagnosed 15 years ago  controlled with Metformin 1000mg twice daily. 3. Ex-smoker - Quit smoking 5 years ago but has a smoking history of 1 pack/day for 35 years. 4. No known allergies.  Recent Event: The patient recently underwent a total knee replacement surgery (left side) due to severe osteoarthritis.  Presenting Complaints: 1. Patient reports swelling (edema) in his left calf since the day before  which seems to be worsening. 2. He is feeling tenderness and pain in the same area  which is increasing while standing. 3. He also reports a mild fever and describes the left calf area as slightly warm to touch.  The patients' symptoms point towards the suspicion of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The sedentary lifestyle  age  recent surgery  and medical history of the patient are the risk factors associated with his current complaint. Therefore  further investigations including D-dimer testing  compression ultrasound  and possibly contrast venography need to be planned to confirm the diagnosis and initiate the therapy.  Learning Goals: The case gives medical students a comprehensive understanding about the pathophysiology of deep vein thrombosis  its risk factors  symptoms and diagnostic tools available. The students should also learn about the importance of prophylaxis and treatment options for DVT. This case further emphasizes the necessity for patient education about lifestyle modification and weight management.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired accountant  non-smoker  with moderate alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History: 1. History of hypertension controlled with an ACE-inhibitor 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  well-managed with metformin 3. Overweight with BMI of 28.5 kg/m2 4. Atrial fibrillation diagnosed six months ago  currently on baby aspirin 5. History of left total hip replacement 5 years ago due to osteoarthritis with no post-operative complications  Presenting Complaints: 1. The patient presents to the emergency department with a two-day history of left calf pain and swelling. 2. The pain is described as a constant  dull ache  grading 6/10 in intensity  not radiating  with minimal relief from over-the-counter paracetamol. 3. He also mentions that the calf feels warm to touch  but he has not noticed any redness or change in color. 4. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  palpitations  abdominal pain  recent trauma  or any other symptom. 5. He mentions that his general practitioner recently asked him to switch to a sedentary lifestyle due to his age and existing medical conditions. 6. The patient has no known allergies.  This brief case report showcases a typical high-risk patient for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  presenting with typical symptoms. Medical students should investigate the possibility of DVT with such presentations and align the patient's history  especially features like hypertension  diabetes  obesity  hip replacement surgery  sedentary lifestyle  atrial fibrillation  etc.  which are risk factors for DVT.

Patient Information:   The patient is a 65-year-old obese Caucasian male named Mr. Brown.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Brown has a medical history of hypertension  type II diabetes  hyperlipidemia for which he is on medications. He used to smoke for around 40 years  but he quit ten years ago. He did not have any history of surgeries or hospital admissions until now.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Brown came to the emergency department complaining of sudden swelling and pain in his right lower limb  specifically around the calf muscle  that started a day ago without any preceding injury or trauma. He also reported a slight fever  fatigue  and some shortness of breath. On further questioning  he mentioned that he had recently taken a 12-hour long-haul flight after attending his daughter's wedding  during which he remained seated most of the time. Since his return 5 days ago  he had been taking rest and had minimal physical activity. He denied any chest pain  dizziness  or loss of consciousness.   Remarks:   Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) should be suspected in Mr.Brown  considering his clinical symptoms of unilateral leg swelling  pain  warmth  and redness over the calf muscle. Other risk factors that make his case more suspicious for DVT include advanced age  obesity  long-term immobility due to the recent long-haul flight  hypertension  and history of smoking. As he has similar symptoms for Pulmonary Embolism  such as shortness of breath and fatigue  he should be appropriately evaluated and managed accordingly. For diagnosis  D-dimer tests  ultrasound of the leg  CT scan  or MRI might be conducted. If diagnosed  anticoagulants would likely be a part of the initial treatment strategy. Since Mr. Brown would be at an increased risk for DVT recurrence  long-term maintenance therapy may be needed.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:  - Age: 52-year-old - Sex: Female - Race: African American - Occupation: Senior Staff Accountant (mostly sedentary work) - Social History: Non-smoker  rarely consumes alcohol  no drug use  Past Medical History: - Chronic obesity (BMI: 32.8) - Hypertension controlled with medication  - Hyperlipidemia - No history of surgeries  - No known family history of clotting disorders - Patient has taken several long international business flights in the past month  Chief Complaint: - Unilateral calf pain: Patient complains of severe pain in the left lower leg that started 2 days ago. She describes the pain as a dull ache  constantly present but varying in intensity. The pain seems to intensify when she stands up or walks. She also notes some slight swelling and redness in the area. - Difficulty in walking due to pain  - Mild shortness of breath when exerting herself more than usual but no chest pain.  Physical Examination:  - Normal vital signs - Trace edema in the left lower leg - Mild Tenderness in the left calf - Skin over the left calf warm and slightly erythematous - No signs of ulceration/ skin changes - Other systems: WNL  Given the patient's presenting symptoms  recent long-haul travel  sedentary work lifestyle  and a history of obesity  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  there is a high index of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis. Proceed with further diagnostic investigations to confirm the presumptive diagnosis.   Note to the educator: Weight management and exercise should be a part of the patient education for this case. Emphasize that medical students should not only focus on the presenting symptoms in a patient with DVT but also evaluate their risk factors which include obesity  prolonged immobility or sedentary lifestyle  and hyperlipidemia in this case. Teaching points could include clinical presentation of DVT  importance of early diagnosis  risk factors  differential diagnoses  and appropriate diagnostic investigations and management strategies for DVT.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:   - Name: Mr. James Jonathan  - Age: 69 years - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired college professor - Race: Caucasian - Marital Status: Widowed - Smoking History: Non-Smoker - Alcohol History: Social Drinker   Past Medical History:   - Hypertension – Diagnosed 10 years ago  taking Amlodipine 5mg once daily. - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus – Diagnosed 15 years ago  managed by Metformin 500mg twice daily. - Had a total knee replacement surgery 2 weeks ago and was relatively immobile during recovery. - No history of any known allergies. - No previous history of any vascular or haematological disorders.  Chief Complaint:  Mr. Jonathan presented to the emergency department with a swollen  warm  reddened left calf  which he noticed since 2 days. He mentioned the swelling is usually milder in the morning but worsens as the day progresses  accompanied by a dull  consistent pain in his lower leg. He denies any recent trauma or injuries to the leg. He also complained of shortness of breath which he attributed to his age and overweight status  but noted that it has become more pronounced recently  especially on lying down. He has had no chest pain but a feeling of mild discomfort around his lower chest region.  Other Complaints/ Symptoms:  On further questioning  he admitted that he has been feeling fatigued and weak over the last week or so  but thought it was due to his recovery from surgery. He denies any fever  chills  cough  haemoptysis or night sweats. There has been no alteration in his bowel or urinary habits.  Please ensure to use this as a base to develop further diagnostic steps and treatment options. It would be crucial to demonstrate the process of diagnosing a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) using Doppler ultrasound and D-dimer tests and then a detailed approach to managing it  discussing both pharmacological (anticoagulants) and non-pharmacological measures (compression stockings  lifestyle modification). Also take the discussion towards the complications of DVT such as pulmonary embolism  which the patient might be developing  given the increased shortness of breath.  Remember  a key learning from this case should be the understanding of Virchow's Triad – stasis of blood flow  endothelial injury and a hypercoagulable state – all three factors of which are present in this case.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe  Age: 67 years old  Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired school teacher  Location: Suburban area  East Coast USA  Lifestyle: Sedentary  lives alone  Past Medical History: - Hypertension controlled with medication - Type 2 Diabetes  managed with oral hypoglycemic agents - Double bypass surgery  10 years ago - Smoking (30 pack-years  cessation 8 years ago)  Presenting Complaints: Patient presented with a 3-day history of swelling  tenderness  and warm sensation in his left calf. There was no trauma or injury reported. John indicates that he recently underwent a long-haul flight (12 hours) around one week ago and has a general feeling of malaise. He has noticed a progressive increase in calf circumference and discomfort when moving. He also complains of mild shortness of breath  which is unusual for him.  Objective Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  the left calf was significantly swollen and warmer than the right one. His vitals were stable but his respiratory rate was slightly elevated. A D-dimer blood test was ordered given the high index of suspicion for DVT.  Objective of Case Study: This case study is designed to provide medical students an understanding of the risk factors  pathological mechanisms  symptom presentations  and appropriate diagnostic procedures related to Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). The management and prevention measures of DVT and its complication  Pulmonary Embolism  are also discussed.

Patient Information:   Mr. Paul Richardson  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  non-smoker  lives in rural Idaho with his wife. Height 6 feet  weight 220 pounds.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Richardson was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes about 10 years ago which is well-controlled on metformin and lifestyle modifications. He also has mild hypertension treated with losartan  and a history of chronic low back pain managed mainly with physiotherapy. He underwent hip replacement surgery 4 weeks ago due to osteoarthritis  after which he was immobilized for about two weeks. His only additional operative complication was a superficial postoperative wound infection which was managed successfully with oral antibiotics.  Key Patient Complaints:   Mr. Richardson presented to the clinic with a 3-day history of left calf pain and swelling more significant than on the right side. Pain is exacerbated when walking or extending his foot  persistent throughout the day and unrelieved by over-the-counter pain medications. He denied any symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or any other systemic symptoms. Reports some warmth over the site but no notable skin color change. He denies any recent trauma  prolonged travel  or family history of blood clotting disorders.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: Gender: Female Age: 60 years Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Office worker   Past Medical History: The patient is an active smoker with a 45-pack-year smoking history. She was diagnosed with obesity (BMI: 32) and has an inactive lifestyle. Other medical history includes hypertension  managed with ACE inhibitors  and a family history of PE (Pulmonary Embolism).   Key Complaints: The patient entered the clinic with complaints of a swollen  red  warm  and painful right leg that had been persisting for 5 days. Upon specifically asked  she affirmed experiencing a generalized limb ache with heaviness and cramping. She also admitted to mild breathlessness on exertion and chest discomfort but had not been paying much attention to those symptoms until specifically asked.   Additional information: She recently took a long-haul flight (12 hours) 2 weeks ago for a business trip and has been working sedentary hours ever since. The patient denies any trauma or injury to the painful leg and has not undergone any recent surgery. She also denied any allergies and current medications apart from her anti-hypertensives.   This case study is designed to get medical students to think about deep vein thrombosis  its risk factors  symptoms  complications  and appropriate interventions.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics: - Gender: Female - Age: 59 years old - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Secretary – spends most of the day sitting - Body Mass Index: 28 - Smoking status: Ex-smoker  smoked a packet a day for 20 years  quit 5 years ago - Alcohol consumption: Occasional  Past Medical History: - Hypertension for the past 10 years  maintenance treatment with Amlodipine - Hormone replacement therapy for the past 5 years due to menopause - Broke left leg  femur in a car accident 1 year ago  healed with no complications - No known allergies - Her mother had a history of stroke in her 60s.  Presenting Complaints: The patient reports a dull ache in her right calf for over two days. She describes the pain as constant  not associated with any over-exertion or unusual activity. It worsens when she walks. She has noticed some mild swelling in the right calf area and slight discoloration  stating it looks a bit red. She denies fever  chest pain  shortness of breath  or coughing.   Other non-specific symptoms she reports include fatigue over the past week and occasional night sweats. She has not noticed any weight loss or loss of appetite. She denies having any recent injuries  surgeries  prolonged periods of immobility  or recent travels.  This case is designed to encompass several risk factors and typical clinical features of deep vein thrombosis  such as previous fracture  longer periods of immobility due to her work  higher BMI  Hypertension  and hormone replacement therapy. The symptoms are typical but non-specific  necessitating careful consideration and investigation by the medical students.

Patient Information:  Name: John Doe Age: 63 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Long-haul truck driver  Presenting Complaints:  John presents with a 2-day history of pain  swelling and redness in his left calf which he initially thought to be a muscle strain from his recent gardening. He also mentions experiencing shortness of breath during his daily walks  which he has never experienced before. These symptoms have made him uncomfortable and worried  leading to his visit.  Past Medical History:  John has a past history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM2) and hypertension. There is no known history of surgeries or allergies. He is a former smoker  quit 3 years ago. His medications include metformin for DM2 and losartan for hypertension. He has no family history of thrombotic disorders but his mother passed away due to a stroke.  Physical Status:  Immobility due to John's sedentary job as a truck driver is noted  possibly contributing to venous stasis.  This case will ideally illustrate the common risk factors for the formation of deep vein thrombosis  including advanced age  immobility  hypercoagulable state (possibly due to DM2)  and vascular endothelial injury (as a result of hypertension). The uncharacteristic symptoms of shortness of breath might suggest a potential pulmonary embolism  a severe complication of DVT  necessitating immediate further investigations. It will allow the students to understand patient evaluation methods  diagnostic measures and the importance of early detection and treatment of DVT.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics Name: Mr. James Gallagher Age: 67 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Accountant Location: Melbourne  Australia  Past Medical History: • Patient has a documented history of diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years which is under control. • Hypertension diagnosed 8 years ago  managed with medications. • Had a right hip replacement surgery two years ago. • Non-smoker  moderate alcohol intake.  Key Complaints: Mr. Gallagher presents to the emergency department complaining of increasing pain and swelling in his left lower leg particularly the calf area that started about two days ago. He describes the pain as a ""deep ache"" that worsens when he stands or walks. He noted a mild warmth sensation and redness around the affected leg.   He denied any recent trauma  fever  chest pain or shortness of breath  and has not travelled recently. He mentioned that he has spent the past week mostly sedentary  reading books due to the lockdown in his state.  The students should then investigate the signs  symptoms  and risk factors related to DVT  and discuss potential diagnosis  differential diagnoses  management  and prevention of the condition.

Patient Information:   Patient Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 62 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith  a 62-year-old Caucasian man  came to the hospital reporting a pain in his left calf for the last three days. The pain seems more with walking and it feels warm to touch. He also noticed some redness and slight swelling in the same area. He reported no trauma to the area.  Medical History:   Mr. Smith's past medical history revealed that he has been recently diagnosed with Stage II colon cancer and currently on chemotherapy. He had a heart attack 5 years ago and is on a regular dose of aspirin. No known drug allergies reported. Additional medical history included a desk job with long hours of sitting and a recent flight trip of six hours. He is an ex-smoker and quit smoking about 2 years ago. His family history revealed that his mother had a pulmonary embolism in her early seventies.  Assessment:  Combining symptoms of calf pain  warmth  redness  and swelling  along with a recent history of prolonged immobilization and cancer  the clinician should consider a high index of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Further investigations are required for confirming the diagnosis.  (Note: The aim of this case is for students to understand the risk factors  presentation  diagnosis  and management of deep vein thrombosis. The risk factors present in this case  such as malignancy  prolonged immobilization/sedentary behavior  and a family history of venous thromboembolism  make the patient highly susceptible to DVT.)

Case Report:  Patient Information: Name: Mr. John Thompson Age: 62 years Sex: Male Occupation: Office worker  sedentary job Ethnicity: Caucasian Location: Urban dwelling  Past Medical History: Smoker for last 40 years which totals to around 20 cigarettes per day. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Had a right hip arthroplasty two years ago due to osteoarthritis. He is not physically active and is considered obese with a BMI of 31.   Key complaints: The patient reported to the ED with complaints of right leg pain and moderate swelling for the past 3 days. The pain is persistent  deep  and becomes pronounced upon walking. He also described a sense of warmth in that area. The patient further reported intermittent shortness of breath  but he assumed it was due to his smoking habit. No incidents of chest pain or discomfort were reported. No recent travel history  bed rest  or immobilization was noted. No previous history of clotting issues or familial clotting disorders reported.   On general examination  his right calf was swollen and tender on palpation. The circumference of the right calf was greater than the left. No significant changes in skin color were noted.  The brief case above describes a patient who could potentially be suffering from deep vein thrombosis and may have associated symptoms suggestive of pulmonary embolism. This scenario allows medical students to learn and discuss the risk factors  symptoms  diagnostic workup (like D-dimer test  ultrasonography  venography  etc.)  and management (including anticoagulants  thrombolytics  etc.) of deep vein thrombosis  and its complications like pulmonary embolism.  They can also discuss the role of prophylaxis in high-risk groups. Learning from this case  students should also understand the importance of lifestyle modifications and the risks associated with unhealthy habits like smoking  sedentary lifestyle  etc.

Case Report - Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:  Name: John Doe   Age: 65-year-old   Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired computer programmer  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension  diagnosed 8 years ago  currently managed with Lisinopril 20 mg daily. 2. High cholesterol  diagnosed 10 years ago  currently managed with Atorvastatin 40 mg daily. 3. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  diagnosed 5 years ago  currently managed with Metformin 1000 mg twice daily. 4. Ex-smoker  quit 15 years ago (1 pack/day for 30 years).  Presenting Complaint:  The patient reports a 4-day history of increasing left lower leg pain and swelling. He describes the pain as a heavy  dull ache that gets worse when standing or walking  but improves slightly with leg elevation. He also reports instances of slight unexplained breathlessness over the same period.  Additional findings:  No recent history of immobility  trauma  or surgery. He flew cross-country (6-hour flight) for a family visit 1 week ago. He denies chest pain  dizziness  or other symptoms.  Possible Case Discussion Points:   This case presents a good opportunity to discuss the risk factors  clinical presentation  diagnosis  and management of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Specifically  it would be valuable to dive into how the patient’s past medical history (hypertension  high cholesterol  Type 2 diabetes  and smoking history) and recent long-haul flight increase his risk for DVT. Furthermore  the symptoms reported by the patient align with those typically seen in DVT  especially the progressive leg pain and swelling  and unexplained shortness of breath  which might indicate a pulmonary embolism as a complication. This case allows medical students to understand the application of the Wells Score and the use of D-dimer testing and duplex ultrasonography in the diagnostic pathway. The importance of prophylactic measures in patients at risk of DVT could be another point of discussion.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Jane Doe  Female  65 years old  Caucasian  Retired High School Teacher  Non-smoker  exercises moderately  drinks alcohol occasionally.  Past Medical History: Mild Hypertension managed with medication for the past 5 years  type-2 diabetes mellitus controlled with diet and medication for the past two years. No history of surgeries. There is a significant family history of Cardiovascular Diseases (CVD)  her father underwent a bypass surgery at the age of 70 due to Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).   Key Complaints: The patient came for a routine check-up when she reported a progressive swelling and pain in her right lower limb which she has noticed over the past week. She dismissed it as a possible strain due to her daily walks. However  the swelling did not subside and the pain has progressively increased in intensity. Upon further questioning  she also mentioned recent unexplained fatigability  and frequent breathlessness. She denied any chest pain  palpitations  or dizziness.   Based on the reported symptoms such as swelling  pain in the right calf muscle  breathlessness  and history of hypertension and diabetes  I suspect the patient might be developing a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). These symptoms and risk factors provide an important opportunity for medical students to learn about differential diagnosis and the importance of investigating such symptoms early to prevent serious complications.   This case study could be a starting point for discussions about the importance of venous anatomy and physiology  risk factors for DVT  diagnostic methods - including D-dimer tests  ultrasounds  and venography  as well as treatment options such as anticoagulants  thrombolytics  and preventative measures against post-thrombotic syndrome and pulmonary embolism.

Patient Profile:  Demographics: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 57 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Computer Software Engineer Ethnicity: Caucasian Location: Detroit  Michigan  Past Medical History: - Hypertension (controlled with medication) - Occasional smoker (5 cigarettes/day) - Sedentary lifestyle due to nature of job - No known allergies - Never had surgery - First degree relative (father) had a history of deep vein thrombosis  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe presents to the emergency department complaining of acute  unilateral leg swelling  pain  and discomfort in his left lower leg for the past 3 days. The pain is described as a constant  dull ache  exacerbated on walking. He also complains of mild shortness of breath  especially during moderate physical exertion  which he typically would manage without noticeable distress. He denies any chest pain  cough  palpitations  recent injuries  long-distance traveling  or immobilization. His appetite remains the same  but notes that he has had anxiety recently because of his worrisome symptoms.

Case Study - Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Information: Mary Connors  Demographics: 63-year-old Caucasian female  Occupation: Retired school teacher  Location: Suburban Midwest  USA  Past Medical History:  1. Chronic obesity with a Body Mass Index of 35 2. History of hypertension maintained by medication  3. Ex-smoker  quit smoking 10 years ago  4. Lacks consistent exercise 5. No previous history of cardiovascular diseases  6. No familial history of blood clots   Present Illness: Mary arrived at the clinic complaining about an acute onset of left leg pain that has been worsening over the past five days. She describes the pain as a constant ache but exacerbated by stick and twist movements. The pain is localized to her lower leg and is associated with swelling  warmth  and erythema.   She denies any recent trauma  long travels  surgery  or prolonged immobilizations. She also denies fever  chest pain  shortness of breath  or similar symptoms in the right leg. She has no history of miscarriages.  Observations: 1. Mary appears to be in mild to moderate pain 2. Height: 5'4""  Weight: 230 lbs 3. Blood Pressure: 138/85 mmHg   This patient presentation is characteristic of potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT). In the following sessions  students will be invited to discuss possible investigations  diagnosis  and management of Mary’s condition based on the information provided. The case will highlight the importance of recognizing the signs and symptoms of DVT  understanding its risk factors and complications  and finally  the implementation of necessary interventions for patient management.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  who lives with his wife in their two-story home. He is a former smoker but quit 10 years ago. He has mild alcohol consumption (1-2 glasses of wine per week) and does not participate in regular physical activities. His BMI records at 28.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  and occasional tachycardia which is currently managed by his primary care physician through medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily). He suffered an MI three years ago and has been on Aspirin 81mg since then. His cholesterol levels have been high but acceptable (LDL-140  HDL-40  TG-150)   Key Complaints: The patient has approached the service today  complaining of sudden onset left calf pain and swelling that began two days ago. He stated the pain increased during walking and eases at rest. He reported a noticeable increase in size compared to the right leg  along with warm sensation and mild redness. He expressed increased anxiety related to his symptoms. The patient denies any recent trauma  surgeries  or long periods of travel. His wife  who accompanied him  mentioned his decreased mobility for the past few weeks  primarily due to his online chess tournament  where he would sit at his computer for prolonged hours. The man also reported shortness of breath which began a night ago. He rated the pain as 6 out of 10 and reports no other symptoms. He states that he has not missed any doses of his medication and follows a balanced diet plan.  Given the patient's complaints  the possibility of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) should be within differential diagnosis. Further diagnostic procedure such as doppler ultrasonography  d-dimer testing may be warranted. In addition  medication review and possibly adjustments might be needed to properly manage his cardiovascular health. Patient education regarding regular physical activity  leg exercises  and avoiding prolonged sitting would also be beneficial.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics:  Mr. James Bennett  aged 62  is an African-American male. He works as an accountant and resides in Austin  Texas. He's a non-smoker but is slightly overweight (BMI: 28).  Past Medical History:  Mr. Bennett has a known history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Both conditions have been generally well controlled through medication and dietary management. He underwent a knee replacement surgery two years ago due to osteoarthritis. His mother suffered from a stroke in her late sixties  and his father has a history of varicose veins.  Key Complaints: Mr. Bennett presents with complaints of a swollen  warm-to-touch  reddish left leg  which started roughly 4 days ago. He describes more discomfort when standing or walking  and the pain is primarily in the calf region. He denies experiencing any shortness of breath  chest pain  or dizziness. He notes having sat for extended periods without breaks during a recent deadline at work.   His vitals upon admission are as follows: BP of 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 92 bpm  respiratory rate of 18 cycles per minute  temperature of 37.4°C. Physical examination reveals pitting edema and tenderness in the left calf with a mild increase in local temperature. Further study and appropriate management are recommended based on presumptive diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).

Case Report - Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 62 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Financial Analyst  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has been relatively healthy throughout his life. However  he has a history of high blood pressure which he manages with diet and medication. He was diagnosed with Type II diabetes six months ago and currently on oral hypoglycaemic medications. As for family history  his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65 and his mother had a stroke at age 70. Mr. Doe is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago and occasionally drinks alcohol during social events. He does not engage in regular exercise and has a sedentary lifestyle due to his work nature.   Presenting complaints:  Mr. Doe has come to the Emergency Department with complaints of progressive swelling  warmth  and redness in his left lower leg over the past few days. He describes the pain as a constant  dull ache which increases when standing and decreases while lying down. He denies any trauma  recent surgeries  or recent travels. He noted increased fatigue but refutes any chest pain  shortness of breath  coughing  or breathing difficulties.   As the educator  you should prompt medical students to consider the risk factors for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in this patient. Age  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  hypertension and Type II diabetes all play a role in predisposing Mr. Doe to a DVT. His presenting complaints of a swollen  red  warm leg are typical symptoms of DVT  highlighting the significance of clinical examination and suspicion in diagnosis. Differential diagnoses might include cellulitis  a Baker's cyst  or simple leg strain. Discuss why each of these would be less likely given Mr. Doe's symptoms and history.   This case should stimulate conversation about DVT  its risk factors  diagnosis  and management  as well as complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Adult   Patient Demographics:  The patient  Mr. Harrison  is a 50-year-old Caucasian male who resides in a suburban area. He is employed as a corporate lawyer and therefore leads a primarily sedentary lifestyle. He's non-smoker  occasional alcohol drinker with a well-balanced diet according to him. He is married with three children and has a history of being overweight with a BMI of 30.   Past Medical History: Mr. Harrison's medical history is significant for Hypertension managed through medication (Atenolol  50mg daily)  and Hypercholesterolemia  managed with Rosuvastatin (20mg). His surgical history is non-significant. His family history reveals that his father died from a heart attack at the age of 70  and his mother is living with Type 2 Diabetes.  Key Complaints: Mr. Harrison presented to the emergency department complaining of progressive left leg pain and swelling of four days duration. He stated it started mildly but has been escalating in intensity. He denied any recent trauma to the leg but admitted to multiple long-haul flights over the past month for work purposes. There are no symptoms of fever  shortness of breath or chest pain. He has not noticed similar swelling in the other leg.   Upon physical examination  the left calf appeared swollen and warm to touch with a mild erythematous discoloration. He winced during passive dorsiflexion of the foot (Homan’s sign).   Such a case scenario setting should encourage students to consider DVT in the differential diagnosis related to work  lifestyle habits  and the reported clinical features. In the following lessons  they should be guided through the process of definitive diagnosis  management  and potential complications like pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome. These teachings should also emphasize primary prevention strategies for DVT.

Patient Information:   Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African American male presented to the hospital.   Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has been a type II diabetic for fifteen years  managed with metformin. He also has hypertension  which is treated with atenolol and a history of cerebrovascular accident about five years ago  with mild residual dysarthria. He is a former smoker and quit 15 years ago. Family history reveals a sister who had a pulmonary embolism.  Chief Complaint:  He has arrived complaining of acute onset  painful swelling in his left calf that developed over the day. He noticed it was warm to touch and slightly red. He denies any trauma  recent injury  or latest strenuous activity. He has not recently traveled for long distances.   Additional information:  On examination  his left calf is indeed swollen  erythematous and is tender to palpation but without crepitus. Distal pulses are palpable. His vitals are slightly elevated with blood pressure of 145/95mmHg  pulse rate of 87 beats per minute  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and temperature of 37.5 degrees Celsius (99.5 F). His routine blood work shows slightly elevated D-dimer levels.   This case provides an opportunity to discuss the diagnosis  differential diagnosis  risk factors  management  and complications of deep vein thrombosis in medical students.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. Robert Davis Age: 65 years Sex: Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  Address: Seattle  Washington  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: On medication for the past 5 years 2. Smoker: Quit smoking 3 years back  but a heavy smoker for 25 years. 3. Bilateral total knee replacement surgery two weeks ago. 4. Obesity: BMI of 30.8 - considered obese according to standards set by the World Health Organization.  Presenting Complaints:  1. Swelling in the left leg: The patient complains of noticing an unexplained swelling in his left lower leg over the past 3 days.   2. Increasing pain and tenderness: Intense pain is experienced especially when standing or moving the leg. The pain has been gradually increasing over the past two days.  3. Skin discoloration: The patient's left leg has turned warm and is red in color.  Presenting Illness:   Post his bilateral total knee replacement  Mr. Davis reports moderate adherence to his prescribed physiotherapy routine. He admits to limited movement mainly due to obesity and pain. With the onset of the complaints  he stopped moving around altogether. Of note  he has been using compression devices as prescribed  but has faced difficulty in ensuring correct usage  more so in his left leg.   Given the patient's constellation of complaints  we're considering a possible case of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  potentially arising from prolonged immobilization post-surgery  compounded by the risk factors such as advanced age  obesity  and history of smoking.  This case report is aimed at the understanding of the clinical presentation and differential diagnosis of DVT  highlighting its common risk factors  clinical sequelae  and emphasizing the importance of prophylaxis  early intervention  and management strategies.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 67 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Bank Manager Location: Residential  in a suburban area  Social History: Smoker for 45 years  occasional alcohol use  sedentary lifestyle  Past Medical History:  John has been treated for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 12 years  both of which are mostly well-controlled with medication. He also has a history of varicose veins. Six months ago  John suffered a minor stroke with full recovery. Since then  his mobility has decreased considerably.   Presenting Complaints:  For the past week  John is reporting a persistent pain in his left lower leg. He describes the pain as 'throbbing'. He also reports his left calf is noticeably swollen and warmer to touch compared to his right calf. Walking exacerbates the pain and lately has led to him becoming largely immobile. He mentioned that he's also observed that his left leg appears slightly reddish-blue. He denies any trauma to his legs. John also states he recently flew back from a 12-hour long-haul flight a couple of weeks ago post which he noticed these symptoms gradually appearing.  Case Objective:  The primary learning objective of this case is to teach medical students how to identify  diagnose  and manage deep vein thrombosis (DVT). This includes understanding risk factors (advancing age  history of stroke  immobilization  long-distance travel  previous varicose veins  etc.)  recognizing classic symptoms (unilateral leg pain  edema  warmth  discoloration)  and acknowledging the importance of rapid evaluation and treatment to prevent complications  such as pulmonary embolism. This case also encourages discussions on preventative strategies for individuals at risk for DVT.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)   Patient Information: Name: Mr. John Reyes Age: 56 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Accountant  Demographics:  Mr. Reyes lives in a suburban neighbourhood in Chicago  Illinois. He's a smoker with a history of 20-pack years and leads a sedentary lifestyle. He has no known family history of genetic disorders or any hereditary diseases. He was recently on a 15-hour-long international flight.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Reyes has a history of hypertension and is obese  with a body mass index (BMI) of 30. In the past  he had an episode of pulmonary embolism for which he was on blood thinners. He has been off blood thinners for over two years now.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Reyes presented to the Emergency Department with complaints of a swollen  red  and painful left leg that began gradually and increased over three days. He denied chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or fainting episodes. He also mentioned experiencing mild tenderness in the calf muscle when he forced his foot upward.  Specifically  he complained of significant discomfort while walking and noticed increased warmth around the affected region. He has no history of recent trauma or injury to the region.  As observed  Mr. Reyes's case is typical for deep vein thrombosis. Still  medical students should focus on differentiating it from other conditions that may present similarly  such as a Baker's cyst  cellulitis  superficial thrombophlebitis  or muscle strain. Also  his previous medical history and risk factors should be used to explain the pathophysiology of DVT to students.

Patient Information:  Mr. Aiden  a 65-year-old Caucasian retired welder from Wisconsin  presented himself in the emergency department.  Primary Complaint: Patient complains of sudden onset swelling  warmth  and pain on the left side below the knee that has been progressively worsening over three days. He also complains of mild shortness of breath.  Medical History: Mr. Aiden has been a smoker for approximately 30 years and he quit five years ago. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension fifteen years ago  which has been managed with Metformin and Lisinopril respectively. Also  he underwent radical prostatectomy due to prostate cancer three years ago. His mother died of a stroke and his father had a stent placed due to heart disease.  Lifestyle: He enjoys reading and gardening and is not involved in regular physical exercise. Limited travel history with the recent trip being a cross-country car ride four months ago. He admits to moderate alcohol intake.  Review of Systems: Upon enquiry  he reported no chest pain  dizziness  nausea  or vomiting. Reports no history of similar episodes in the past.  Physical Examination: Physical examination revealed a mildly distressed individual. Vital signs: BP 138/85  Pulse rate 90  Temp 98.2F  SpO2 97% on room air. His left lower leg was swollen  warmer compared to the right  and tender along with the line of veins  indicative of superficial venous inflammation. No palpable cords were observed.  Provisional Assessment: Given the patient’s history of hypercoagulable state (prostatic cancer  diabetes  and hypertension)  prolonged sedentary status  and current symptomatology  a possibility of Deep Vein Thrombosis is considered. Differential diagnosis should rule out cellulitis  muscular strain  and Baker’s cyst.  The next steps would be Diagnostic Testing (D-Dimer assay  Doppler ultrasound) and management based on results.

Case Report:  Patient Information: A 67-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith reports to the clinic with complaints of significant leg swelling and unrelenting pain in his right leg that has progressively worsened over the past two weeks.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension  varicose veins and had undergone hip replacement surgery two months ago. He is a retired truck driver  a non-smoker and has a moderate alcohol intake. Patient's father had a history of stroke in his late seventies. He is currently on antihypertensive medications and low-dose aspirin.  Chief Complaints: The patient primarily complains about increasing leg pain on the right side and noticeable swelling. He also mentions a feeling of warmth in the swollen area and somewhat limited mobility  likely due to discomfort and pain. He has also noticed light red or blue skin discoloration on the swollen leg.  Objective: The primary objective of this case is to sensitize the medical students to the process of suspecting  diagnosing  and managing a case of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  particularly in patients who have undergone recent surgery  have a sedentary lifestyle or present with comorbidities that heighten their risk.  Rationale: The patient's history of recent hip surgery  physical inactivity due to his previous job  and symptoms of leg swelling  pain  warmth and discoloration  in combination with a history of varicose veins  position him as a potential candidate for DVT. As such  his case provides an excellent resource for students to learn about the risk factors  clinical suspicion  diagnostic approach  and management of DVT. It is crucial for students to understand the importance of prompt and accurate diagnosis in preventing fatal complications such as pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome. At the same time  this case can also educate them about the preventive measures and lifestyle changes required for DVT patients.

Case Report - Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Thompson  Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired School Teacher Ethnicity: African American Residence: Urban setting  Past Medical History: - Smoking history of 30 years  quit 5 years ago - Obese (BMI 32) - Hypertension controlled with medication for the past 10 years - Family history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism - Sedentary lifestyle  - Previous hip replacement surgery 2 years ago  Presenting Complaints: - Unilateral leg swelling (right) - Mild to moderate pain in the right leg  increase with standing or walking - Redness and warmth over the affected area - The skin around the affected area has turned slightly bluish - Occasional mild chest pain last 1-2 weeks  Additional Information: Mr. Thompson came in with his daughter who reported that lately  he had been less active  complaining of fatigue  breathlessness on exertion  night sweats  and a lack of appetite. He also mentioned discomfort in his right leg and occasional chest pain over the last two weeks. His daughter was concerned about the unusual swelling and slight color change in his right leg. She also pointed out that he does most of his activities sitting in his armchair and rarely moves around since his hip replacement surgery.  Note to students: This case was selected as it provides an excellent basis for the discussion of risk factors  signs  and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis. It is crucial to understand the combination of clinical findings  patient history  and appropriate investigations  in this case  to manage this condition effectively and prevent serious complications like pulmonary embolism.

Patient Information:  Mrs. Abigail Thompson  68-year-old  Caucasian  retired school teacher Address: 275 Fairhaven Avenue  Worcester  MA 01604  Presenting Symptoms: Mrs. Thompson presents with progressive swelling and pain in her right lower limb over the last two days. She also mentions an increasing fatigue and slight breathlessness.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Thompson has a history of long-standing hypertension which is under control with hydrochlorothiazide. She is also diagnosed with type II diabetes and is currently under metformin treatment. In terms of surgeries  she had a total knee replacement surgery (right knee) for severe osteoarthritis about 3 weeks ago. Family history reveals her father suffered a stroke in his early 70s.  Physical Examination: Vital signs: Blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg  pulse rate 92 beats per minute  respiration rate 18 breaths per minute  and body temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F). The oxygen saturation is 97%.   On inspection  her right lower leg appears swollen  with visible distention of the veins. On palpation  there is tenderness in the calf muscle  and it feels warm to touch. There is a positive Homan's sign. Her respirations are clear and rhythmical. Both cardiovascular and abdominal examinations are unremarkable.  Further Investigation: Given her recent surgery and the clinical presentation  the suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is high. An ultrasound Doppler of the lower limb is suggested for further confirmation.   Educational objectives with this case: - Recognize the signs and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis. - Understand the risk factors contributing to the development of DVT  including recent surgeries  especially orthopedic procedures  like total knee replacements. - Highlighting the relevance of inherited or acquired blood clotting disorders in such presentations. - Practice making a differential diagnosis with other conditions that might present similarly  like cellulitis or Baker's cyst. - Decide an appropriate course of action  including diagnostics and treatment options for suspected DVT cases.

Patient Case: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics: Name: Joseph Clark  Age: 64 years  Gender: Male  Race: White  Occupation: Retired construction engineer Insurance Status: Medicare  Past Medical History: - Hypertension (10 years)  controlled with medication - Obesity (BMI: 32) - History of smoking (quit 5 years ago) - No known allergies - Previous right leg fracture (age 42) - No history of surgeries or blood disorders - Father died of a stroke at age 70 - Mother had varicose veins and passed away at 82 due to pneumonia  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Clark arrived at the emergency department with complaints of the sudden onset of swelling in his left lower leg. He reports a feeling of ""deep-seated"" pain that has escalated over the past 3 days. The pain appears to be localized  does not radiate  and intensifies upon standing or walking. He has noticed that the skin over the calf is warmer compared to the other leg.   He also complained of increased shortness of breath and a dry cough that started 1 day ago. He denies chest pain  fever  or other systemic symptoms. He hasn't traveled long distances recently  and his activity level is generally low.  Additionally  he reports no injuries to the leg  no recent surgeries  and no history of similar symptoms. The patient takes a daily antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril) and has no known drug allergies. He has not been using any over-the-counter or herbal medications.   This case of sudden unilateral lower limb swelling and aching pain  combined with the patient's age  past medical history  and low activity level  warrants a thorough examination  keeping in mind the possible diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The new onset of shortness of breath and cough could be signs of a potential complication of DVT - a pulmonary embolism. It is therefore essential to approach this case with careful evaluation and timely management.  As a next step  a thorough physical examination  appropriate laboratory tests  and imaging like a Doppler Ultrasound for his leg/pelvis and possibly a CT of the chest should be ordered. If his symptoms are due to DVT and/or pulmonary embolism  treatment should commence immediately  with education given to the patient on the potential risks and preventative measures for future instances.

Case Report:  Patient's Information:  - Age: 69 - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Office Worker  Patient's Past Medical History:  The patient had a significant past medical history  including the following conditions:  - Type II Diabetes Mellitus - Hypertension - History of malignancy; prostate cancer treated with radiation therapy 3 years prior - Hyperlipidemia - Sedentary lifestyle  Patient's Key Complaints:  The patient presented to the outpatient department  complaining of a sudden onset of a painful  swelling  and redness in the left lower leg that had progressively worsened over the past 2-3 days. The pain intensified when walking or standing. He also reported mild shortness of breath but denied any other associated symptoms such as chest pain  fever  or recent injuries to the leg.  He mentioned that he had recently undertaken a long-haul flight (12 hours) about 1 week ago  during which he did not move from his seat often. He also disclosed that he had stopped taking his regular aspirin  as prescribed for his heart condition  around the same time.  The patient was further getting worried due to a mild increase in the intensity of pain and any strain or movement making it worse. He also reported slight difficulty in walking due to the same reason.  [The case is helpful for teaching deep vein thrombosis  focusing on risk factors (long immobility  sedentary lifestyle  recent surgery or cancer  advanced age  and discontinuation of anticoagulant therapy)  symptoms (unilateral leg pain  swelling  redness)  and potential serious complication of pulmonary embolism (shortness of breath).]

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient information: Mr. Joseph Adams  a 67-year-old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Adams has a history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with metformin. The patient also has had a history of intermittent claudication in the left lower calf related to peripheral arterial disease for the past three years. He is a former smoker (quit 10 years ago)  and has been treated for moderate hypertension over the past five years. Mr. Adams underwent a total hip replacement surgery 5 weeks ago.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Adams presents to the office complaining of a progressively worsening pain and swelling in his left calf over the past week. He denies chest pain or shortness of breath. He also explains that he has not been very mobile since his hip replacement surgery and has been spending most of his time seated on his living room couch.   Objective Findings: Upon physical examination  the left leg was observed to be swollen (edematous) and warmer than the right one. The left calf circumference was 3 cm larger than the right one. Homans' sign was positive. No ulceration or rash was visible on his legs and pedal pulses were symmetric. The patient grimaced upon palpation of his left calf muscle.  Case Design: This case is designed to equip medical students with the knowledge and skills for diagnosing  managing  and preventing deep vein thrombosis. The case focuses on a common risk factor for DVT: prolonged immobilization  in this case due to recent hip replacement surgery. By studying this case  students will learn how to recognize the signs and symptoms of DVT  how to interpret key findings and understand the important role of patient history in diagnosing DVT. They will also discuss appropriate treatment and preventive measures for DVT in post-operative patients.

Case Report  Patient Profile: - Name: HB (initials used to maintain anonymity) - Age: 65 - Profession: Computer Programmer - Gender: Male - Race: African American - Smoking: Yes - Alcohol consumption: Social drinker - Marital Status: Married with two daughters  Past Medical History: - Underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy one month ago - History of obesity - Type 2 diabetes mellitus being managed with oral diabetic medications - Hypertension treated with a diuretic and ACE inhibitor - Dyslipidaemia managed by statins - Mother had atrial fibrillation and Father passed away from myocardial infarction at 66 years old  Key Complaints: - Presented with a 48-hour history of increasing discomfort and swelling in the left calf - Difficulty walking  and admitted to falling twice in the past week - Symptoms were not relieved by over-the-counter painkillers - Mild shortness of breath on exertion for the past three days - No chest pain  cough  or fever  Physical Examination: - Increased calf circumference on the left side - Mild tenderness to touch in the left calf - Left lower limb is warm with redness - Mildly elevated heart rate at 95 beats per minute - No signs of deep ulcers or cyanosis in extremities - No evident chest abnormalities  Notes:  This case intends to teach medical students the presentation  diagnosis  treatment  and possible complications of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). The patient's medical history puts him at increased risk for thrombosis. Moreover  his symptoms  particularly unilateral calf pain and swelling  are highly suggestive of DVT. This case can help shape the differential diagnosis and emphasize the importance of further investigations like D-Dimer levels and ultrasound of the affected region.

Case Report - Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years  Sex: Male Occupation: Retired accountant  lifestyle mainly sedentary Residence: Rural  lives alone Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: - Hypertension  under control with Amlodipine 10 mg daily for the past ten years. - Type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with diet control and Metformin. - Smoking history: 30 pack-years  quit five years ago. - No known drug allergies. - No family history of clotting disorders. - Underwent right total hip arthroplasty two years ago.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of unilateral swelling in the left leg  which he noticed gradually increasing over a week. The leg has become red and mildly tender  but he denies any injuries or bug bites. He also reports mild pain which increases during walking and a feeling of warmth over the swelling region. No associated symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  recent trauma  or prolonged bed rest.  This is a concise but comprehensive case about a patient with DVT. The discussed medical history and symptoms like swelling  redness  and pain can guide medical students to suspect deep vein thrombosis  which can further be confirmed by investigations. They should also be made aware that patients like Mr. Doe with risk factors such as a Sedentary lifestyle  past major surgery  older age  obesity  and high-risk ailments like hypertension and diabetes are more susceptible to develop DVT. Additionally  absence of symptoms like shortness of breath or chest pain yet  may exclude pulmonary embolism  a dangerous complication of DVT. Students should though remember that sometimes DVT may be asymptomatic.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics:  John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  has presented to the clinic today. He is a non-smoker with a moderate alcohol intake. He is overweight with a BMI of 28.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has controlled hypertension  diagnosed at age 60  for which he is on Amlodipine 5mg once daily. Additionally  he was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago  currently managed on Metformin 750mg twice daily. He underwent a total knee replacement of his left knee 7 days ago following a fall at home where he fractured his patella. He is currently on prophylactic low molecular weight Heparin which started post-operatively.  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe complains that for the past 24 hours  he has an increasing pain and swelling in his right lower calf  which is the non-operated limb. He states that the leg has turned 'slightly red' and that it feels 'warm to touch'. He denied chest pain  shortness of breath  or hemoptysis. He has no history of DVT in the past and no familial clotting disorders that he is aware of.  Upon physical examination  there is tenderness on deep palpation of the right calf  with noticeable unilateral swelling of the calf and an increase in its circumference in comparison to the left calf. The right lower limb is observed to be slightly warmer with a faint red discoloration. Signs of superficial vein distension are apparent.   Clinical Suspicion:  Given the patient’s recent surgery  which was a significant risk factor  as well as his symptoms  there is a high suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right lower limb.

Case Report:  Title: An interesting Case of Deep Vein Thrombosis in an otherwise Healthy Male  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Smith  a Caucasian male  aged 54  married with one child  employed as an accountant  non-smoker  and consumes alcohol only on social occasions. He has no known allergies or genetic history of significant diseases.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith is relatively healthy with no history of any major illnesses. His immunizations are up-to-date  and he doesn't consume any chronic medications. He reports engaging in moderate exercise 3 times per week  and his BMI is within the normal range. He did  however  mention that he recently returned from a long-haul flight (12 hours) and experienced minor leg discomfort towards the end of the flight  which he attributed to the lack of movement.  Key Complaints: Mr. Smith has presented at the clinic complaining of a localized 'hot  red patch' on his left lower leg accompanied by intermittent sharp pains  without any recent trauma or injury. Upon inquiry  he reported experiencing a general feeling of fatigue and malaise over the past two days and had been taking over-the-counter pain-relief medication to manage the leg pain. He denied any cough  chest pain  or difficulty breathing. Mr. Smith expressed concern as the leg symptoms persisted despite rest and medication.  The plan will be to carry out a comprehensive physical examination followed by appropriate diagnostic tests  bearing in mind the possibility of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). This case can be used to teach students the importance of considering risk factors (such as prolonged immobilization during the recent long-haul flight) and identifying key symptoms for the prompt diagnosis and effective treatment of DVT.

Case Report:   Patient Identification: Mr. John Smithson Age: 67 Gender: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired  Living Situation: Lives with wife  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smithson is a moderately obese individual with a past medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (diagnosed 10 years ago) and Hypertension (for the past 7 years). He is a non-smoker but used to smoke a pack a day until 6 years ago when he quit smoking due to health concerns. His father had a history of Myocardial Infarction at an early age of 50. Mr. Smithson has been on medications for his medical conditions and is compliant about them.   Key Complaints:  Patient came to the ER with reports of increasing discomfort  redness  warmth and swelling in his left calf for the past 24 hours. The pain appears to worsen when he stands or walks  and slightly alleviates once he lays down. He recalls a long 12-hour car ride last week due to a family emergency  where he mostly remained seated. Besides this  he also mentions occasional dyspnea on exertion over the last few days  but no chest pain or discomfort. His wife reports him looking a bit more pale than usual.   All these indicators point towards a possible case of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). The next steps will involve conducting a detailed history  doing a complete physical examination  and proposing different investigations based on the info. The objective will be to confirm if it is indeed DVT  identify its extent  and evaluate the risk of potential Pulmonary Embolism.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics:   Mr. Thompson is a 65-year-old Caucasian male. He previously worked as a truck driver  involving prolonged periods of immobility  but has been retired for the past five years. He is a current smoker with a 45 pack-year history. His body mass index indicates mild obesity (BMI of 31). He has no allergies and lives alone.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Thompson has a history of hypertension  controlled with medication  and had undergone a right knee replacement surgery approximately six weeks prior to presentation. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease: his father passed away from myocardial infarction at 68 and his older brother suffered a stroke.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Thompson presents to the clinic with a 48-hour history of increasing pain and swelling in his right calf. He denies any recent trauma  fever  chest pain  or difficulty breathing. Initial assessment shows the right calf is visibly swollen  warm and tender on palpation  but with good distal pulses.  Further questions indicate that he has been less mobile than usual due to his knee surgery  but he hasn't been diligent with the prophylactic anticoagulation regime prescribed post-operation. He also reports occasionally forgetting to take his blood pressure medication.  Initial examination and vague symptoms might suggest a musculoskeletal etiology  such as a strained muscle from post-operative exercises. However  given his recent orthopedic surgery  prolonged immobility  history of smoking  and family history of cardiovascular disease  there is a high clinical suspicion of Deep Vein Thrombosis.   The case proceeds from here to further investigations  discussion of the Wells Criteria and potential implications of neglecting postoperative prophylactic care.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe is a retired construction worker with a medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  with no known allergies. He is a non-smoker and has moderate alcohol consumption. He has no family history of hematologic disorders.   Current Medications:   1. Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes 2. Lisinopril 20mg once daily for hypertension   Chief Complaint:  Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with complaints of increasing left leg swelling and discomfort for about 72 hours. He has early signs of a raised temperature and he has described the pain as a constant dull ache  rating it 6/10. He noticed it initially after a 3-hour road trip  during which he was driving. He has no previous history of similar symptoms.  Mr. Doe denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  or feelings of lightheadedness or weakness.
