He also denied any recent trauma  surgery  or prolonged periods of bed rest.  Key Signs and Symptoms:  1. Swelling and pain in the left calf area. 2. Slightly raised temperature (low grade fever). 3. No indication of erythema or calf tenderness on examination  but leg is noticeably edematous. 4. No palpable cords or Homan's sign.  This case report is created with an aim to highlight the typical presentation of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). It allows students to explore concepts such as risk factors  clinical presentations  differential diagnoses  as well as potential investigations and management for DVT.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:   Ms. Maria Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic female  retired teacher  currently living with her daughter and grandchildren. She is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol consumption until she stopped drinking about 10 years ago.  Past Medical History:   Ms. Rodriguez has a known history of Hypertension on antihypertensive medication (Amlodipine 5mg daily) and Type II Diabetes Mellitus on oral hypoglycemic agents (Metformin 500mg twice daily). She was diagnosed with these conditions about 15 years ago but has managed to control them fairly well with medications and lifestyle modifications. She does not have any known allergies. She has a surgical history of hysterectomy 20 years ago due to fibroids. Her family history is significant for a sister who had suffered from Pulmonary Embolism.  Presenting Complaints:   Ms. Rodriguez presents with complaints of a dull ache in her left calf  which she first noticed 48 hours ago. She states that the pain seems to increase with walking and eases slightly when she elevates the leg. She denies any recent trauma  fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath. On questioning further  she admits that her mobility has been decreased for the past week due to a common cold  and she tended to stay in bed most of the time.   Physical Examination:  On examination  her left calf is tender to touch  warm and slightly swollen compared to the right. Her vitals are stable  but her left calf circumference is 3 cm greater than her right. Pulses are palpable bilaterally.  Upon examination findings and her recent immobility  there is a high index of suspicion for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). An urgent Doppler Ultrasound of the left lower limb will be advised for confirmation of DVT  and appropriate therapeutic measures will be started based upon the results. The patient will be educated about the condition  symptoms of possible complications like Pulmonary Embolism  and methods to prevent recurrence such as leg exercises  losing weight  and avoiding long periods of immobility.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  A 72-year-old African-American male veteran is brought to the emergency room by his middle-aged daughter. The patient lives in a retirement home and is retired from active military duty. He has a history of smoking  though he quit 10 years ago.  Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus (DM)  and hyperlipidemia. All conditions are being managed with medications including hydrochlorothiazide  metformin  and atorvastatin respectively. He underwent a right total hip replacement surgery two weeks ago due to osteoarthritis  and after a week's stay in the hospital  was discharged in a stable condition. On day 10 after the surgery  the patient sought help for a urinary tract infection (UTI)  for which he was given a course of antibiotics.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient's daughter reports that he has been complaining of increasing pain and swelling in his right calf over the last two days despite keeping his leg elevated. She also reports that he seems more fatigued than usual and has experienced shortness of breath earlier today.  Possible Diagnosis:  Based on the patient's presenting signs and symptoms  recent hip surgery  and his risk factors (including his age  history of prolonged immobilization following surgery  and history of hypertension and DM)  there is a high level of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  This case study is a potential opportunity for medical students to understand the clinical presentation  risk factors  and possible complications of DVT. Discussing this case can provide insight into how various medical histories are interlinked and may contribute to new problems due to immobility  infections or other complications. It prompts for timely intervention and treatment to prevent potentially severe sequelae  including pulmonary embolism.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Mr. John White  a 71-year-old Caucasian male  retired  who lives alone  non-smoker and only occasional drinker. He is 5’10” in height and weighs 210 lbs.  Past Medical History:   He has a known history of Type 2 Diabetes and Hypertension for the past ten years. His medications include Metformin 1000 mg twice a day and Losartan 50 mg once daily. He had an open cholecystectomy 20 years ago. Mr. White has no known allergies. He underwent hip replacement surgery 3 weeks ago due to severe osteoarthritis.   Key Complaints:  Mr. White presents to the emergency department with complaints of a sudden onset of warmth  redness  swelling  and pain in his left calf since the last two days. He reports not having sustained any injury to the area. He also notes a certain degree of breathlessness on exertion which was absent before. He also reports intolerance to physical activities which he used to participate in with relative ease.   Observations on physical examination reveal a swollen  reddened left calf which is tender to touch. His vital signs are recorded as temperature: 98.8°F  pulse: 96 beats/min  blood pressure: 140/90 mmHg  and respiratory rate: 22 breaths/min. On auscultation  no abnormalities found in the heart and lung sounds.  The primary objective for the students would be to utilize this case by discussing the risk factors  signs  and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis and formulating a differential diagnosis that includes Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). They also need to describe the subsequent steps in diagnosing DVT  which may include D-dimer test  Doppler ultrasonography  and venography  and outline appropriate treatment options by considering the patient’s history and complaints.

Patient Profile: Name: John Doe Age: 63 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Past Medical History: 1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 10 years 2. Hypertension since the last 5 years 3. Ex-smoker  quit smoking 3 years ago but has a 30 pack-year smoking history 4. History of sedentary lifestyle  Key Complaints: 1. Unilateral leg swelling: Patient came in with complaints of severe and sudden swelling in the right leg which started a week ago. He denies any trauma or injury in the past. 2. Pain in the right leg: He correlated the pain to a muscle pull effect  describing it as a cramping sensation. 3. Changes in skin color: Reports observing a reddish discoloration of the skin in the swollen area. 4. Foot and ankle edema: Patient also complains of pitting edema around the foot and swelling near the ankle region of the right leg. 5. Mild shortness of breath: Mr. Doe also reported experiencing mild difficulty in breathing for the past 2 days.  This case should be presented with an emphasis on recognizing the common signs and symptoms of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  including swelling  pain  discoloration  and edema in a single limb  besides unexplained shortness of breath which could possibly represent pulmonary embolism  a serious complication. The importance of relevant past medical history  such as chronic diseases and lifestyle factors in the context of thrombotic events  should also be highlighted in the discussion. Management should cover both immediate treatment and long-term strategies to prevent recurrence and complications.

Patient Information: John Doe  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  is a non-smoker who consumes alcohol moderately. He weighs about 220 lbs and is about 5'8"" tall.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 8 years ago and is currently well-controlled on Metformin. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and hypertension  both of which are controlled with medication (Lisinopril and atorvastatin). The patient underwent left knee replacement surgery about 2 years ago.   Key Complaints: Mr. Doe came to the emergency department complaining of gradually increasing left leg pain  warmth  and swelling that started three days ago. He had just returned from a cross-country road trip last week where he spent extended periods sitting. He does not recall any recent injury to his leg and has not presented any chest pain or shortness of breath. He also complained about mild tenderness around the area of pain.  Summary: This case presents a 67-year-old male with past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and knee surgery. Recent prolonged travel with long periods of inactivity coupled with the symptoms of leg pain  swelling  and warmth makes deep vein thrombosis (DVT) a critical part of the differential diagnosis. Further clinical assessment and diagnostic tests  like doppler ultrasound  are needed to confirm the diagnosis. This scenario is appropriate for teaching medical students about DVT risk factors  clinical presentation  diagnosis  and management.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics:   - Name: Patient X - Age: 65 years - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired office worker - Race: Caucasian  Past Medical History:  1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - diagnosed 10 years ago  currently on metformin 2. Hypertension - under control with lisinopril for the last 8 years 3. A 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit 12 years ago 4. Underwent orthopedic surgery for a hip fracture 3 months ago after a fall at home 5. History of sedentary lifestyle; travels extensively  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presents with a two-day history of increasing pain and swelling in the left lower leg. The pain is dull and constant  non-radiating  worsening with standing or walking. He also complained of moderate redness along with the area. He denies any history of recent trauma or injury to the leg. He also reports feeling a bit short of breath when climbing stairs  which was unusual for him.  Physical examination revealed warmth  tenderness  and mild erythema over the left calf on palpation. The left calf circumference was found to be larger than his right calf. There was no palpable cord. His vitals were stable  but his oxygen saturation dropped to 94% on exertion.  These findings were suggestive of deep vein thrombosis. The additional shortness of breath indicated the possibility of a pulmonary embolism. A D-dimer test was ordered  which came back with elevated levels. Subsequently  a duplex ultrasound revealed a noncompressible segment in the left posterior tibial and the peroneal vein confirming  the suspected DVT.   A CT pulmonary angiogram was done to rule out a PE due to the patient's shortness of breath  which fortunately did not show any emboli in the lungs. A referral was made to the hematology team for further management and anticoagulant therapy was initiated.  This case is designed to train medical students to recognize the signs and symptoms of DVT  understand its risk factors  and learn to manage this condition. It highlights the importance of being suspicious about the possibility of DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg pain and swelling  especially in the context of recent surgery  immobilization  or personal history of thrombotic events. It also underscores the clinical implications and risk of Pulmonary Embolism in patients with DVT  emphasizing the need for urgent medical management.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Name: Robert Simpson Age: 66 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired School Principal Marital Status: Married Lifestyle: Sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity.  Smoking History: Yes  smokes half a pack per day  Presenting Complaints: Robert presented with complaints of gradual  increasing pain and swelling in his left calf for one week. He mentions his leg appears reddish-purple and feels warm to touch. He has recently been on a long transatlantic flight a week ago for a family occasion.  Past Medical History: Robert was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago  and hypertension three years ago. He also suffers from mild osteoarthritis  likely a result of obesity (BMI 30.5).   Medication History: He has been on metformin for his diabetes  amlodipine for his hypertension  and paracetamol for managing his osteoarthritic pain. He remembers to take his medication regularly  though admits to indulging in unhealthy food which has not helped manage his diabetes.  Family History: Father deceased from a myocardial infarction at 72  and mother deceased due to breast cancer at 76. His elder brother underwent angioplasty at 64.  Social History:  Robert had an active social life before COVID-19. He is a member of the local golf club and used to participate in tournaments before movement restrictions. Currently  he spends most of his time watching TV or reading.  This is a simulated case designed for medical students to understand the mechanism  identification  and management of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). The goal is for students to understand risk factors such as recent immobility  age  smoking  obesity  and pre-existing conditions  to identify symptoms such as leg pain and swelling  and to diagnose DVT using tools such as a D-dimer test  venography or ultrasound  and to initiate appropriate management.

Patient Profile:  1. **Demographics:**     * Name: Mr. Rex Jameson    * Age: 62 years old    * Gender: Male    * Employment: Retired corporate manager; sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity    * Ethnicity: Caucasian    * Residence: Baltimore  Maryland  2. **Medical History:**    * Obesity with a BMI of 34    * Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus managed with Metformin for the last eight years    * Hypertension treated with olmesartan for the past five years    * History of smoking for 30 years with cessation ten years ago    * No known drug allergies    * Unremarkable family history; parents died of old age with no genetic diseases    * No history of previous venous thrombosis  3. **Key Complaints:**    * The patient reports persistent pain and swelling in the right calf for one week    * The pain is described as a 'cramp-like' ache that intensifies upon standing or walking    * Noticed skin over the area to be warmer than usual    * The patient denies trauma  recent injury  or long travels    * Denies shortness of breath or chest pain.  Review this case as a potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Consider the patient's risk factors such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  diabetes  and age. Teach about the clinical presentation and significance of ruling out DVT in similar patients. Also  focus on the importance of interventions like lifestyle modifications  weight management  and good glycemic control in preventing DVT.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Sarah Thompson is a 68-year-old Caucasian woman who resides in a suburban assisted living facility. She is a retired school teacher  a non-smoker  and does not drink alcohol. She has 2 adult children and 5 grandchildren that she loves spending time with but has problems in movement due to her condition.   Past Medical History: Sarah has a known history of hypertension and a 5-year history of treated breast cancer. She has been on Tamoxifen therapy for the past 3 years. She also had a cholecystectomy in her late 50s and suffers from occasional irritable bowel syndrome. She is also overweight (BMI: 30) which she has struggled with for many years. Her family history includes a mother who died at 79 YO from myocardial infarction and father at 71 YO from stroke.  Key Complaints: Sarah came to the clinic with complaints of swelling in her left lower leg  which has been present for about 4 days.  She initially assumed the swelling was due to her inactivity  as she spends most of her days sitting alone reading books. However  she started noticing progressive enlargement of the left lower leg along with a mild  dull ache. The leg is also notably warm to touch. The skin has also turned a slight shade of red. She denies any shortness of breath  chest pain  lightheadedness  or syncope.  The pain is non-radiating and gets worse while standing and walking. She reports she has no fever  recent trauma  surgery or history of such swelling before. This condition has kept her from visiting her grandchildren  which added to her concern.      This case could be designed to focus on deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and could emphasize the need to examine the high-risk factors such as old age  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  long term use of Tamoxifen (which is known to increase the risk of clot formation) and the presentation of unilateral limb pain  swelling and erythema. The case can also address the differential diagnosis ruling out congestive heart failure  lymphedema  and cellulitis. The medical students can be encouraged to discuss the underlying pathophysiology  clinical manifestation  and potential complications like pulmonary embolism.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Richard Green Age: 54 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Truck Driver  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and obesity. He has been a smoker for 30 years and follows a sedentary lifestyle. His father had deep vein thrombosis. Tiered medication includes Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and atorvastatin for dyslipidemia. Allergies include shellfish and penicillin. Immunizations are up-to-date.  Key Complaints: Mr. Green visited the emergency room complaining of a sudden onset  progressive pain and swelling in his left leg  particularly in the calf region. He described the pain as a ""throbbing"" or ""cramping"" sensation. He denied any history of trauma  but mentioned he recently had a cross-country driving assignment  which required prolonged sitting for approximately 12 hours a day over the past week.  He also noted a moderate level of breathlessness on exertion over the last two days  which he initially attributed to his sedentary lifestyle and obesity. He denied chest pain  cough  hemoptysis  fever  or recent surgery. He had no symptoms in the right leg.  On examination  his left calf was swollen and warm to touch  with a positive Homan's sign. His vital signs included blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 92 beats per minute (bpm)  a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  with an oxygen saturation of 94%.  Instruct students to consider his background while contemplating potential causes and treatment plans for the clinical presentation. They should be tasked with formulating relevant investigative protocols and management plans while discussing the importance of early recognition and implications of untreated deep vein thrombosis.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Gender: Male Age: 65 Occupation: Retired software engineer Ethnicity: Caucasian Location: Rural Iowa  USA  Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of sedentary lifestyle and was diagnosed with Type II diabetes 15 years ago. He has been managing the condition with Metformin. His other past medical history includes hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril  and hyperlipidemia  treated with Atorvastatin. He has a 40-pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He also has a history of occasional alcohol use and obesity  with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 30.   Key Complaints:  The patient presented with complaints of increasing pain in the right calf that began approximately four days ago. He describes the pain as a dull ache that becomes sharp with walking or standing. The pain is non-radiating and not associated with any other leg symptoms. It  unfortunately  has worsened over the last two days. He denies any injury  fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath.   The patient also reports noticing that his right calf seemed slightly swollen and warmer to the touch compared to his left calf. He lives alone so no one witnessed if there was any change in skin color. However  there's no reduction in the range of movement.  His family history is significant for deep vein thrombosis  with his father having suffered a DVT event in his late 60s.  Upon initial examination  there was noticeable edema in his right calf  with a mild increase in local warmth. His vital signs  including blood oxygen level  were normal. Conscious of the patient's risk factors and clinical presentation  you consider deep vein thrombosis as a probable differential diagnosis. The next step is to confirm this with a Duplex Ultrasound and D-dimer testing.

Patient Details:  John Doe  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  from Indiana  presents to the clinic. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He lives with his wife and maintains an active lifestyle.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia managed with amlodipine 5mg daily and atorvastatin 20mg daily respectively. No history of surgeries or hospitalizations. No allergies reported. No family history of clotting disorders. He is up-to-date on his preventive health care  including annual check-ups and appropriate cancer screening.  Key Complaints:  The patient complains of a sudden onset of left lower leg pain and swelling that has been worsening over the last two days. He reports that the pain increases on walking and eases on resting with the leg elevated. No chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or other systemic symptoms reported. No recent travel  immobilization  trauma  or surgery. He does not notice any change in color of the leg but reports a mild warmth over the swollen area.  Summary:  A 70-year-old male with a history of hypercholesterolemia and hypertension presents with two-day history of left lower leg pain  swelling  and warmth around the area. His lifestyle is generally active  with his literal complaint having a sudden existence with no prior relevant incidents. His current symptoms and other factors have led to the suspicion of deep vein thrombosis  yet further investigation is required to confirm.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics: Name: John Doe Age: 65 Years Old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired corporate worker Race: African American  Past Medical History: The patient has had a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for the past ten years and is a former smoker. He is also hyperlipidemia and has type II diabetes that is well-controlled with Metformin. He had an elective knee replacement surgery 2 weeks ago. The patient resides in a nursing care facility due to his limited mobility post-surgery. Family history includes a brother who had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 72.  Key Complaints: John reports experiencing increased pain  swelling and warmth in the calf of his right leg  which has been progressively worsening over the past several days. He also mentions a moderate ache  which is unusual as his post-operative pain had been otherwise steadily improving. He has no complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath or recent changes in health status apart from the leg symptoms.  Presenting Symptoms: Upon examination  he was noted to have increased calf circumference on the right when compared to the left. The right calf appeared erythematous. The rest of the examination was within normal limits. He was hemodynamically stable with no signs of respiratory distress. Furthermore  he is alert  oriented  and communicative  providing connotation to the symptoms at hand.  Physical Examination: Temp: 98.7°F Pulse: 75 bpm Resp: 20/m BP: 130/85 mmHg O2 Sat: 97% on room air. Calf circumference: Right 17.3 inches  Left 15.2 inches.   Conclusion: Given the patient’s recent surgery  immobility  and current symptoms  there is a significant clinical suspicion of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Discussion topics could include: Pathophysiology  Risk factors  Clinical manifestations  Diagnostic criteria and tests (such as D-dimer  compression ultrasonography)  Initial treatment options  Long term management  and Prevention of DVT.  NB: This case is intended for educational purposes and does not establish a standard of care  nor should it be considered suggestive of any specific treatment plan for a similar patient.

Patient Profile  Patient Details: Mrs. Savita Singh  a 63-year-old female   Occupation: Retired school teacher  Ethnicity: Indian  Location: Lives in New Delhi  India  Medical History: Mrs. Singh has a history of type II diabetes mellitus  controlled with Metformin. She is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago. She has a history of obesity and has undergone a hysterectomy about 10 years ago due to fibroids. She is diligent with her medications and medical appointments.  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Singh visited her local clinic with complaints of noticeable swelling  pain  and warmth in the calf muscle of her right leg which she had first observed three days ago. Additionally  she reported progressive difficulty in walking due to the discomfort. She also noted an episode of breathlessness and light-headedness  which she dismissed as an aftermath of her walk.  Relevant Information: She acknowledged prolonged periods of inactivity during her recent trip that involved long-haul flights. On further evaluation  it was ascertained that she had not been using her prescribed pressure stockings during the flight. She took 325 mg of Aspirin as prophylaxis pre-flight  a habit she had developed through her years of travel.  This scenario is designed to simulate dealing with a case of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) - a condition where a blood clot is formed in the deep veins  commonly in the leg. The students should be instructed to assess Mrs. Singh’s risk factors  her symptoms and to make a plan for diagnostic testing and management. The case should highlight the importance of considering DVT in the differential diagnosis in any patient with unilateral leg swelling. It will also help emphasize the significance of prompt identification and management of DVT to prevent potential life-threatening complications like pulmonary embolisms.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:   Mr. Thomas Smith  67 years old  Caucasian male  retired supermarket manager  married with two grown-up children. Non-smoker  occasional drinker  has a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity. Mr. Smith is on regular medications for his chronic conditions. Patient lives in the city with his wife  who is his primary carer.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a significant past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease five years ago. He underwent a hip replacement operation six months ago due to severe osteoarthritis. His medication regimen includes metformin  lisinopril  and low-dose aspirin. There is no known drug allergy.  Key Complaints:   Mr. Smith is primarily presenting with a 5-day history of unilateral calf pain and swelling in his left leg. The pain has been progressively worsening and is not relieved by over-the-counter analgesics. He describes the pain as constant and rates it as 7 out of 10 on the pain scale. He also reports a feeling of warmth over the swollen area  with mild erythema but no open wounds or skin changes.  He denies any recent trauma  fever  cough  chest pain or shortness of breath. His wife also reports noticing Mr. Smith is not his usual self lately  appearing slightly grumpy and anxious. His appetite and sleep have also slightly decreased over the past few days.   Upon gathering this information  given Mr. Smith's age  sedentary lifestyle  history of recent major surgery  and other comorbidities  there's a strong suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Immediate diagnostic testing and management is imperative to prevent potential serious complications such as pulmonary embolism (PE). This case provides an opportunity for medical students to learn about risk stratification  clinical features  diagnosis  and management of DVT in a medically complex patient.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. Robert Smith Age: 62-year-old Gender: Male Residence: Rural area Occupation: Retired banker (had a mostly sedentary lifestyle)  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a medical history of minor heart illness (atrial fibrillation) with occasional anticoagulant use and hypertension controlled with medication. He also has a history of an active smoking usual of 15 cigarettes per day  heavy alcohol consumption  and sedentary lifestyle. His Body Mass Index is 29 (slightly overweight). Robert had a major surgery (right hip replacement surgery) around eight weeks ago. He also has a familial history of thromboembolism.  Present Complaints:  Mr. Smith presents to the clinic with complaints of swelling  redness  warmth  and pain in his right lower leg that began suddenly few days ago. He also reported experiencing a low-grade fever and slight shortness of breath. These symptoms have forced him to limit his normal activities. Robert also reported palpitations and complained of increasing fatigue. Pain gets worse when standing or walking  and mildly relieves when leg is raised. He denies any chest pain  headache  or fainting episode.  Given these complaints and medical history  focus should be on evaluating him for a potential case of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). The key complaints  medical history  and demographics of the patient hint towards a high probability of DVT. The teaching goal in this case will be understanding how to diagnose DVT  the importance of rapid diagnosis and initiating therapy  and recognizing potential complications like pulmonary embolism.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. John Peterson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  presented to the outpatient department. He is a lifelong non-smoker and has moderate alcohol consumption. He lives with his wife  has two adult children  and maintains an active lifestyle  including regular exercise.  Past Medical History: Mr. Peterson has a history of hypertension  adequately managed with lisinopril (10mg daily)  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  well-controlled with metformin (500mg twice daily). He had a laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair two months ago.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Peterson presented with complaints of new-onset left calf pain and swelling that had been progressively worsening for the past three days. He rated the pain as 6/10 on the pain scale. He denied any fever  chest pain  shortness of breath  or hemoptysis. He also reported that he noticed a slight warmth and redness of the affected leg.  On physical examination  his left calf was visibly swollen  warm  and erythematous compared to the right calf. His vital signs were within normal limits except for a slightly accelerated heart rate of 100/min. Homan's sign was positive.  Given his recent surgery  symptoms  and positive physical examination findings  a preliminary diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was entertained. Further diagnostic investigations were ordered to affirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the condition.  The hypothetical educational case is oriented to facilitate detailed discussion and understanding of risk factors  pathophysiology  diagnosis  and treatment plan for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) among the medical students.

Patient Information:   Robert Graves  a 58-year-old Caucasian male who works as a long-haul truck driver.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Graves is a smoker for nearly 40 years and has a BMI of 28. He has a family history of thromboembolic disorders  with both his mother and grandmother having a history of blood clots. He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 7 years ago  which is managed with diet and Metformin. Graves has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both are currently managed with atorvastatin and Lisinopril. He is non-compliant with medications and frequently misses his doctor appointments.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Graves presented to the emergency department complaining of acute onset of redness  warmth  and intense pain in his left calf that developed over the past day. He denied fever  trauma  or recent surgeries  but admitted sitting behind the wheel for extended periods without breaks. Hemodynamically stable but exhibited marked anxiety.  Physical Examination:  Physical examination revealed that his left calf was significantly swollen  erythematous  and tender to palpation. He had a positive Homan’s sign. His blood pressure was slightly elevated (140/90 mmHg) and other vital signs were within normal limits.  Course of the case:  This case study should illustrate the investigation (e.g.  D-dimer studies  ultrasound)  treatment (anticoagulation)  management (e.g.  compression stockings  lifestyle modification)  and potential complications (e.g.  pulmonary embolism) of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in Mr. Graves.  Learning Objectives:  1. Understanding the risk factors and common symptoms of DVT. 2. Stemming importance of obtaining a thorough medical history and physical examination. 3. Recognizing the importance of DVT diagnosis and management. 4. Integrating clinical findings with diagnostic tests to confirm diagnosis and guide management. 5. Understanding the importance of patient education in the management and prevention of DVT recurrence. 6. Understanding the significance of medication and lifestyle management in chronic disease such as type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian female named Ms. Smith. She is a retired school teacher and lives alone in her single-story home.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which are well-controlled with medication. Ms. Smith is also a former smoker  having quit 12 years ago. She reports a family history of cardiovascular disease  with both her father and a brother experiencing myocardial infarctions in their 60s. She has no known allergies and is currently taking hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension and metformin for diabetes.  Key Complaints: Ms. Smith presented to the emergency department with a complaint of swelling in her left lower leg  which she first noticed the day prior. By morning  the swelling had increased and was associated with a dull aching discomfort. She also reports a mild general feeling of malaise  but denies any headache  chest pain  dyspnea  or abdominal discomfort.   Upon further questioning  Ms. Smith revealed that she recently came back from a transatlantic flight a week ago and was immobile for most of the flight due to some mild travel anxiety. Over the past week  she also noticed progressive fatigue  but did not seek immediate medical attention considering it to be due to jet lag. She has not sustained any injuries  does not remember being bitten by any insects  and reports no recent illnesses or surgeries.  Note: This case is designed to help students consider the possibility of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  given this patient's risk factors such as advanced age  immobility  and long-distance travel as well as her symptoms of unilateral leg swelling and discomfort. The non-specific symptom of fatigue may also be a consequence of DVT and it is important for students to recognize the broad presentations of this condition.

Patient Case:  Patient Information: - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 50 years - Gender: male - Occupation: Accountant (mostly sedentary) - Race: Caucasian - Smoker: No - Alcohol: Occasional  Past Medical History: - Known hypertensive for the past 10 years  controlled with medications (Lisinopril 10mg  once daily) - Known case of obesity  BMI: 32 - Recent history of immobilization due to a fractured tibia 10 weeks ago   Presenting Complaints: - The patient came in complaining of increasing swelling and pain in his left leg. These symptoms have been present for the last 3 days.  - The pain intensifies on movement and is somewhat eased with rest. He describes the pain as a deep  constant ache. - He also reports mild shortness of breath  especially when climbing stairs.   Weight: 100 kg Height: 5’8''  On physical examination: - Significant pitting edema of the left lower extremity but no visible changes in skin color or temperature. - Reduced left pedal pulses - Positive Homan's sign (pain in calf on forced dorsiflexion of the foot) - No signs of superficial phlebitis on inspection - Shortness of breath on exertion  - No chest pain - BMI 34  - Blood pressure: 140/90 mmHg  Note to Educator: This case is designed to introduce medical students to the clinical presentation of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Risk factors like hypertension  obesity  and recent immobilization are illustrated in this case. The symptoms of limb swelling  pain  shortness of breath  and positive Homan’s sign are classic for DVT and should prompt diagnostic confirmation through appropriate investigations such as D-Dimer test and Doppler ultrasound. The extension of teaching can include discussions on the pulmonary embolism and their critical relationship with DVT.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  -James Cornell -65-year-old Caucasian Male -Occupation: Retired lawyer -Resided in Boston  Massachusetts  Past Medical History:  -Ex-smoker (Stopped 10 years ago) -Hypertension (Managed with medication for 15 years) -Recently treated for a right femur fracture following a fall  immobilized for the past 6 weeks -No allergies reported -No known drug intake except for his antihypertensive medication -Family history notable for stroke in his father  Key Presenting Complaints:  -James arrived at the Emergency department complaining of gradually increasing pains in his right leg that started a couple of days ago -Swelling in the right lower leg over the last day -When asked to characterize the pain  he labeled it as constant  “aching”  non-radiating  and 7 out of 10 in the severity. -He denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  or headaches  but mentioned that the pain was making it difficult for him to walk. -Denies any recent long flights or car rides.  Initial physical examination showed a mildly distressed man due to pain  with an elevated blood pressure. The right lower limb was noticeably swollen when compared to the left  and warm to touch. Overlying skin was normal  with no discoloration or signs of a wound. James winced when his right calf was palpated. Differential Diagnosis to be considered:  Deep vein thrombosis  Cellulitis  Baker’s cyst  -Muscular strain.  [This case is designed to emphasize the key features of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  necessitate further investigations like D-Dimer test  duplex ultrasonography  or more advanced imaging techniques like CT or MR venography if required  and discuss appropriate treatment options.]

Case Report  Subject: Mrs. Rita L.  a 70-year-old Caucasian woman  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Rita L. comes to the emergency department with complaints of newly persistent pain and swelling in her left lower limb for the past 3-5 days. She describes a throbbing type of pain that is worse when she is standing for a long period. Additionally  she mentions noticing a slightly warmer feeling in this area compared to her other leg and slight changes in skin color (light redness or discoloration).  Patient Demographics: The patient is a retired librarian  a widow with two grown-up children living independently. She lives alone and is a non-smoker. She denies any recent injuries  trauma  or surgery to the legs.  Past Medical History: Mrs. L has had a long-standing history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  which are well-controlled with oral medications. She has a BMI of 31 and falls under the category of obesity. She also has a history of varicose veins for which she has been using compression stockings.  She reports no known allergies or any previous episodes or family history of venous thromboembolism. She has never been prescribed or used oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy.  This Training Case Objective: Medical students should consider her symptoms and past history  especially her sedentary lifestyle  obesity  varicosis  and age which are risk factors for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). They should be able to suggest appropriate investigations (such as a D-dimer test or ultrasound)  understand the importance of this condition due to its life-threatening complication - pulmonary embolism  and propose potential treatment options including anticoagulants  thrombolytics and preventative measures.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. James Robinson Sex: Male Age: 67 years old Occupation: Retired banker Ethnic background: Caucasian  Residence: Urbanna  Virginia Smoker: No Drinker: Occasional  Past Medical History: Mr. Robinson is a known case of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus which have been under control with medication for over 10 years. No known drugs allergies. No previous surgical history. He has had a sedentary lifestyle and follows a high-fat diet. His family history is significant for a paternal uncle who died due to pulmonary embolism.   Key Complaints: Mr. Robinson presented with swelling and aching in his left lower limb (calf region) for last 5 days. The pain was described as a dull ache  exacerbated on walking and relieved by rest. There is no history of any acute trauma or injury to the leg  no fever. He also mentioned recent airline travel from California four days ago  during which he was seated for most of the 5-hour flight.   The symptoms are indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  which can manifest as unilateral leg pain and swelling. The patient's disposition towards a sedentary lifestyle  long uninterrupted travel (known as an economy-class syndrome)  and family history of vascular diseases signify a potential higher risk for developing DVT. His hypertension and diabetes can also contribute as secondary risk factors.   Upon examination  the doctor should note any erythema  signs of calf tenderness  palpable veins  or differences in the circumferences of the two calves. These details will be a critical part of the clinical evaluation. A D-dimer test should be done to screen for a thrombus  but its absence cannot definitively rule out DVT.   An ultrasound scan is expected to follow to confirm the diagnosis of DVT. Treatment would then follow with anticoagulation therapy.   The students should understand the potential severity of DVT  risk factors  symptoms  and possible complications  including the deadly pulmonary embolism. Furthermore  the case highlights the critical value of the patient's clinical history in evaluating DVT and other cardiovascular conditions.

Patient Profile: - Name: James Stuart - Age: 45 years - Gender: Male - Occupation: IT Analyst - Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: 1. No prior hospitalizations or surgeries 2. Mild hypertension diagnosed at 39 and controlled with lifestyle modifications 3. Non-smoker  drinks socially 4. No known allergies  5. Mother had venous thromboembolism  Presenting Complaints: James Stuart  a 45-year-old male  presented to the outpatient department complaining of increasing pain  redness and swelling in the left leg for the past four days. He mentioned that the pain was a bit intense with movement but reduced with rest. He also described mild palpitations and reported no chest pain or breathing difficulties.    On further questioning  James reported having traveled on an international flight (12 hours long) around six days ago for a business meeting. He denied sustaining an injury  recent sick contacts  or history of malignancy. He had been mostly sedentary at his work and during his travel  and had not recently participated in strenuous physical activities.   James expressed worry due to a family history of blood clot disorders  as his mother developed a clot in the thigh many years ago.    This case report aims at focusing on deep vein thrombosis. Key points to discuss with medical students can be the risk factors of DVT  (such as prolonged travel  sedentary work  family history)  signs and symptoms of DVT and the available diagnostic tests and management.

Patient Information:   Mr. John Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  is a retired teacher and a former chain smoker who quit 15 years ago. He lives alone and has previously been fairly independent.  Past medical history:  Mr. Smith has a known history of type II diabetes and hypertension  both managed on medications for the past 8 years. He had a myocardial infarction 9 years ago and underwent angioplasty. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and COPD  with mild intermittent asthma.   Key complaints:  Patient has been having a persisting  dull ache and discomfort in his right calf for the past week. He reports the pain worsening at the end of the day and seems to subside with rest. The patient reports no trauma to the area and no penetrating foreign bodies. He does not report any knee pain  stiffness  or swelling in any of the joints. He denies fever  chest pain.  The pain and discomfort has prompted the patient to limit his physical activities. He has noted some minor ankle edema in the evening  that relieved by morning. Loss of appetite  but no significant weight loss. He also felt shortness of breath at day 5 when he tried to do some physical tasks but blamed it on his smoking history.   Unrelated to this  he reports an unrelated incidence of sudden discomfort with brief visual abnormalities experienced 2 days prior  but felt resolved within a few minutes  and did not seek medical attention considering it a random event.  Today  he's reporting increased calf pain  swollen ankle and unusual warmth over the calf area. He has also noted a mild  infrequent cough for a day. These new symptoms finally prompted him to seek medical help. With his array of symptoms  deep vein thrombosis is high on the differential.   Social History: The patient was a heavy cigarette smoker  a pack a day starting age 17 and stopped at 53. He drinks alcohol socially and denies illicit drug use. He enjoys a moderate activity level that includes daily walking for approximately half an hour. The patient has never been on long-duration flights  hospitalized  or immobilized for extended periods in the past recent years. He has no known drug allergies.  With his history and presenting symptoms  deep vein thrombosis (DVT) should be highly considered  and students should also consider the differential diagnoses and discuss potential investigations  treatment  and management. Future focus should also be inclined toward the prevention of potentially dangerous complications like pulmonary embolism (PE).

Case Report:  Patient Profile: - Name: Mr. Thomas - Age: 65 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired school teacher - Resides: Suburban lifestyle.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thomas has a medical history of hypertension  which is well handled with medication  mild hypercholesterolemia  and type-2 diabetes under control with oral medications. He had a surgical history of a total right hip replacement performed five years ago. He has a known history of smoking  consuming a half pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years  but he quit a decade ago.  Presenting Complaint: Over the past week  Mr. Thomas has been experiencing moderate unrelenting pain in his left calf aggravated by walking  a slight swelling  and increased warmth in the area. He denies any trauma to his lower limbs  any shortness of breath  chest pain  or dizziness. Mr. Thomas states that he had been quite active at his home over the last week and did not travel recently. He has no known allergies.  Key Screenings: Considering Mr. Thomas's symptoms  his past medical history  and the potential risk factors for DVT such as age  history of orthopedic surgery  and hypomobility  the students should promptly evaluate him for the likelihood of deep vein thrombosis. Initial evaluation should include an assessment of vitals  a thorough lower extremity examination  and organized consideration for DVT using a validated clinical decision rule such as the Wells Score for DVT.  Key Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the risk factors  and recognize the signs and symptoms of DVT. 2. To appreciate the importance of an organized approach to the assessment of DVT. 3. To interpret the result of a DVT risk assessment tool such as the Wells Score. 4. To understand the importance of prompt diagnosis and treatment of DVT to prevent thromboembolic complications such as a pulmonary embolism.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mrs. Bianca Turner Age: 62 Sex: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension: Diagnosed 7 years ago  on regular medication (Lisinopril). 2. Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 5 years ago  well-controlled with Metformin. 3. Mild Obesity: BMI- 32  with diet controlled management plan. 4. No known allergies. 5. No history of surgeries. 6. Non-smoker  occasional alcohol consumption.  Presenting Complaints: 1. Mrs. Turner reported severe pain in her left leg that started about 2 days prior. 2. Her pain was primarily located in the calf muscle  severe in intensity and constant. 3. She noticed sudden swelling and tenderness in her left leg without any trauma. 4. She also reported a mild increase in the warmth of the affected area compared to the right leg. 5. Mrs. Turner had been feeling slightly short of breath for last 1 day. 6. No change in her urination and bowel movements.  7. No palpitations  chest pain  or dizziness. 8. She reports to not have any recent history of prolonged immobilization  recent surgery or malignancy.  In this case  the chief complaints and clinical presentations are indicative of a possible deep vein thrombosis (DVT) condition  and the associated risk factors include hypertension  type-2 diabetes  and obesity. However  this is a training case  and a more definitive diagnosis should be made based on the results of clinical assessment  lab tests  and imaging studies.

Patient Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: - Name: Mr. Samuel Rodriguez - Age: 72 - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired Librarian - Ethnicity: Hispanic - Current Medications: Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia - Smoker: No - Alcohol consumption: Occasionally  Past Medical History: - Chronic Hypertension - Mild Hyperlipidemia - Left-sided Ischemic Stroke 5 years ago - No history of diabetes  asthma  or any significant surgical history.  Family History: - Father passed away from myocardial infarction at age: 68 - Mother with Alzheimer's disease - No known genetic disorders/conditions in the family  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Rodriguez presented to the clinic with a 5-day history of increasing pain  warmth  and swelling in his right calf. He reports that he recently returned from a 10-hour flight about a week ago and noticed leg discomfort started a couple of days after that. He denied fever  chest pain  cough  shortness of breath  or hemoptysis. He also denied history of similar symptoms in the past.  Clinical Examination: - Positive Homans' sign in right leg - Unilateral calf swelling measuring approximately 3cm larger in diameter than the left calf - Warmth and erythema over the right calf - Vital Signs: Blood Pressure – 160/90 mmHg  Pulse – 80 bpm regularly  Temperature – 98.2 F  Respiratory rate - 18 breaths per minute - Neurological exam within normal limits.  Given the patient's recent travel history  clinical symptoms  and physical findings  Mr. Rodriguez's case should raise immediate suspicion for deep vein thrombosis. This scenario serves to teach medical students not only about the diagnosis and management of deep vein thrombosis  but also the importance of considering patient's risk factors  like prolonged immobilization (long flight) in a patient with underlying hypercoagulable state (Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia) and its potential complications.

Patient Information:   A 62-year-old Caucasian male  6"" tall  weighing 220 lbs. He has a history of chronic cigarette smoking (30 years  1 pack per day)  uncontrolled hypertension  and sedentary lifestyle.   Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes 10 years ago. He has also been diagnosed and treated for hypertension over the last 5 years. Both his mother and paternal uncle had deep vein thrombosis.   Chief Complaint:  The patient came to the Emergency Department complaining of a 3-day history of worsening pain  heaviness  warmth  and progressive swelling in his left lower leg. He denies any recent surgery  long distance travel  or prolonged periods of immobilization. He has not noticed any chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or hemoptysis.  Key Facts:  Given the patient's long-term smoking habit  sedentary lifestyle  uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  and family history of DVT  the patient is at a high risk for developing a thromboembolism. The presence of unilateral lower extremity pain and swelling in combination with warmth may indicate the possibility of DVT. The absence of chest symptoms do not completely exclude the possibility of a pulmonary embolism.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Allen Nixon Age: 66 years Gender: Male Occupation: Retired civil engineer Race: Caucasian Insurance: Medicare   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is an ex-smoker and quit 10 years ago. He reports moderate alcohol usage. His father underwent a bypass surgery for coronary artery disease at the age of 58 and his older brother died of a heart attack at 60 years of age. He hasn't had any major surgeries in the past. He is currently on enalapril  metformin  and atorvastatin for his chronic conditions. He is ambulatory and lives with his wife.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Nixon presents to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden  sharp pain and swelling in his left lower leg that has intensified over the past 24 hours. Simultaneously  he also expresses an increased level of discomfort while walking. He denies any recent trauma  fever or a change in the color of the skin over the affected region. He recalls a recent 8-hour flight he took for a family event  after which he noticed his left leg feeling slightly heavier than usual.   The focused case report is centered around the possibility of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) for this patient  considering his sudden leg pain and swelling  history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  smoking  and recent long-distance air travel. The medical students should be trained to verify the diagnosis through a detailed examination  considering other probable differentials  and also plan an appropriate treatment and prevention strategy.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Mr. Smith is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  a lawyer by profession. He is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. He reports no recreational drug use. He is married with two children and lives in the suburb.   Past Medical History: Patient has a known case of hypertension and is maintained on hydrochlorothiazide. No known allergy to any drug. He has been generally healthy except for occasional flu-like symptoms. He does not engage in regular exercise  confessing that his job often makes him sit for long hours.  Key Complaints: Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department with the chief complaint of sudden onset of pain and swelling in his left leg. He characterizes the pain as a dull ache that increases on standing and walking. Additionally  there is a feeling of tightness and fullness in the affected leg. He also reports occasional shortness of breath over the last two days.  On physical examination  the left leg appeared swollen and was warmer to touch as compared to the right leg. The calf was tender on deep palpation. There were no visible varicose veins and no signs of superficial vein thrombosis. His cardiovascular and respiratory examination within normal limits. Lab values awaited.  In Mr. Smith's case  a sedentary lifestyle and a history of hypertension are risk factors for DVT. The primary complaints of unilateral leg swelling  pain  and recent onset of shortness of breath warrant a high index of suspicion for DVT. The next step would be to perform a D-Dimer test and  if positive  followed by Duplex ultrasonography or Venography to confirm diagnosis.  This case aims to highlight the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with the common complaints of sudden onset leg pain and swelling  especially in the context of the patient's lifestyle and any relevant medical history. It also emphasizes getting appropriate diagnostic testing when clinically suspicious for DVT.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Details: Name: John Doe Age: 67 years old Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired office worker  Location: Urban  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe had been previously diagnosed with hypertension five years ago. He also had a myocardial infarction three years previously. He's currently on medication for both conditions. His BMI shows obesity. He had total hip replacement surgery two weeks ago and has been mostly bedridden during recovery. He has no known allergies  is a non-smoker  and only occasionally consumes alcohol.  Family History: Cardiovascular diseases are prevalent in his family  his father succumbed to stroke at the age of 75. His elder sister is diagnosed with hypertension.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Doe complains of pain and swelling in the right lower leg  which is worsened when standing or walking. He also mentioned a heavy ache and warmth in the same area. No complaints of chest pain or breathing difficulties.  Key Examination Findings: Physical examination reveals a swollen  erythematous  and tender right calf  significantly warmer than the left. There's a slight fever of 100.2 Fahrenheit. Vital signs are stable.  Conclusion: This case is designed to emulate a clinical scenario of deep vein thrombosis  typically characterized by unilateral leg pain and swelling  which students should be able to identify based on the given history (post-surgery and prolonged immobilization) and clinical presentation of the patient. A further investigation like doppler ultrasound will confirm the diagnosis.  Clinical Goals: The training case serves to help medical students comprehend the risk factors  classical symptoms  and management of deep vein thrombosis.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Demographics: Name: Miss Jane Doe Age: 65 years Sex: Female Occupation: Retired school teacher Ethnicity: Caucasian  Address: New Jersey  United States.  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history that includes hypertension (managed with lisinopril 10 mg once daily) and hyperlipidemia (managed with statin therapy). She also mentioned in passing about former smoking habits almost 20 years back. Her maternal grandmother has a history of pulmonary embolism. Miss Doe is also overweight but is not diabetic and doesn't have any known cardiovascular disease. She underwent a total hip replacement surgery on the left side six weeks ago. Post-operative period was uneventful.  Key Complaints: Upon presentation  the patient complained of swelling in her left calf and an increasing level of discomfort over the past week. The pain intensified when she stands or moves  which she describes as a ""deep aching."" She also mentions recent episodes of shortness of breath on climbing stairs  a new symptom for her. She denied any cough or upper respiratory symptoms. She had not suffered any falls or injuries.   This case of Miss Doe will aid in teaching students in recognizing and diagnosing deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Key points to be emphasized during lessons include major risk factors for DVT like her recent hip surgery  age-associated risks and potential complications of leaving such conditions untreated. Detailed discussion on management and prevention tactics also to be included in the curriculum.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John D.  Age: 60  Gender: Male  Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Computer-programmer    Medical History:  - Smoker for 20 years   - Previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) 3 years ago with good recovery   - Type II diabetes for 10 years (controlled with oral hypoglycemic medications)  - Dyslipidemia   - Hypertension on medications  - Had a right knee replacement surgery 1 week ago due to osteoarthritis.  Presenting Complaints:  - Gradual onset swelling of right leg which has progressively worsened over the last two days.  - The swelling is associated with a mild  dull pain which is non-radiating and increased on standing.  - The patient also complained of tenderness and warmth over the swollen area. - No symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness were reported.  Physical Examination: - Vital signs are stable. - The right leg appeared swollen and visibly reddened compared to the left. - Positive Homan's sign (calf pain at dorsiflexion of foot). - No visible varicose veins. - Peripheral pulses in the lower limb are palpable. - No signs of superficial venous thrombosis. - Cardiac and respiratory examinations were unremarkable.  This detailed case is designed to help medical students learn about Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  a condition commonly seen in patients with a prior history of major surgery  immobilization  smoking predisposing to hypercoagulable state  age  and other risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  and dyslipidemia.  Learning objectives: History taking  risk factor analysis  physical examination findings in DVT  understanding the pathophysiology of DVT  and management based on risk factors and clinical presentation.  NOTE: Please remember that it is important for students to recognize that the absence of chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness does not rule out a more proximal or severe clot such as a pulmonary embolism. After the case  it would be a good idea to ask students what they would do if this patient suddenly became hypotensive  tachycardic  short of breath  or lost consciousness.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. James Allen  a 72-year-old Caucasian male has been admitted to the hospital.   Past Medical History: Patient has a known history of Type II Diabetes  hypertension and was recently admitted for a hip replaced surgery four weeks ago. He quit smoking 10 years ago. He’s currently on Metformin  Lisinopril and low-dose Aspirin.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Allen complained of progressive swelling and tenderness in his right calf over the past two days. He denies any chest pain  cough  OR shortness of breath but admits to reduced mobility since his hip replacement surgery.  On examination  his vitals were stable. The right calf appeared swollen (compared with the left)  erythematous  and was warm to touch. Pain was elicited on manual Dorsiflexion of his right foot (Positive Homan's sign). No noticeable crepitations on lung auscultation and his cardiovascular examination was also normal.  This case focuses on potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following orthopedic surgery in an elderly patient with a few risk factors including his age  hypertension  diabetes  recent hip surgery  and reduced mobility. Students can discuss differential diagnoses  appropriate investigations (like D-Dimer Test  Doppler Ultrasonography)  possible treatments (anticoagulants  thrombolytics  filters  compression stockings) and preventive measures for DVT. This case would give them an understanding of the identification  management  and potential complications (pulmonary embolism) of DVT.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Mr. John Baker is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  who is a retired construction worker living in Brooklyn  New York. He is a widower with a son who lives out of state. His lifestyle is mostly sedentary since his retirement.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He is currently taking medication for both conditions. He also has mild obesity with a BMI of 30.5. Mr. Baker has a 30 pack-year smoking history and quit smoking ten years ago. Three years ago  he faced a hip fracture condition which required surgical intervention followed by an extended period of immobility. He has no history of allergies as far as he is aware.   Key Complaints: Mr. Baker has come in expressing complaints of persistent unilateral leg pain  increasing in severity over the past few days. There has been a noticeable swelling in his right calf  with the skin over the area appearing red and warm to touch. The patient also reports a mild shortness of breath after minor exertion  which was unusual for him. He denies any chest pain  recent trauma  fever  or recent illness. He also denies any changes in diet or medication.

Patient Information: Mrs. Joan Black  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  residing in downtown Seattle.  Past Medical History: Reported hypertension and type II diabetes  both condition are controlled with metformin and Lisinopril  respectively. Mrs. Black is a non-smoker and exercises occasionally. She mentioned discontinuation of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) about a decade ago due to risk of complications. She recently underwent a total right hip replacement surgery and was discharged a couple of weeks ago after routine follow-up.  Key Complaints: Mrs. Black visited the outpatient clinic with primary complaints of increasing discomfort  tenderness  and warmth in her right lower leg. She also noticed a slight swelling in the region. She refuses any recent injury  fall  or trauma to her leg. Her pain is moderately severe  non-radiating  and steady  and it worsens on standing. Despite her attempts to deal with it using over-the-counter analgesics  there is no relief. She also mentioned experiencing modest shortness of breath recently  which she had attributed to lack of physical activity due to her leg pain.  Objective Findings: Vital signs demonstrated a slightly raised heart rate. Examination of right lower limb revealed edema  erythema  and mild tenderness along the distribution of the calf muscles. Higher than normal warmth was noted in the affected area. A slight increase in the diameter of the involved leg was noted in comparison to the other leg.   This initial patient case can be used to guide medical students towards a preliminary diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The case provides cues like age  a recent hip replacement surgery (prolonged immobility)  HRT in past  and key complaints consistent with DVT such as swelling  warmth  pain  redness in the right lower leg  along with symptoms of possible lung involvement. It's a framework for teaching the importance of immediate assessment and intervention for critical conditions like DVT  which if left untreated  may lead to pulmonary embolism.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  non-smoker  moderate alcohol drinker  presents to the emergency room.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of Type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both controlled with medication (metformin 500mg BID and amlodipine 5mg QD). He also mentioned that he had recently been on a 12-hour long-haul flight 7 days ago where he had minimal mobility. He has a family history of Venous Thromboembolism (VTE) as his mother had a DVT at the age of 75 and his older brother had a pulmonary embolism 5 years ago.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Doe complained of a 5-day history of increasing calf pain and swelling in his right leg. He noticed the leg swelling the evening after coming from his trip  initially attributed it to jet lag and exhaustion. He reported no chest pain  hematoptysis  or shortness of breath. There was no prior history of similar symptoms and he denied any recent injury to the leg. The pain is sharper when standing and walking but it eases when he lifts up his leg. He claims that the affected leg looks redder and feels warmer than the other one.  On physical examination  his right calf was found to be larger in circumference than the left  with an increased temperature  and slight erythema. Palpable cord was noticed  and Homan's sign was positive. Other examination results were within normal range  with no chest abnormalities indicative of a Pulmonary Embolism.    Mr. Doe's D-dimer test was positive  elevating the suspicion of a DVT. Doppler ultrasonography confirmed the presence of non-compressible segment in right popliteal vein  consistent with a diagnosis of DVT.  Treatment and Follow-up: Given the patient's age  prior health conditions  recent travel history  symptoms  and diagnosis  the students should consider how to manage Mr. Doe's case in terms of immediate management  secondary prevention with long-term anticoagulant therapy  potential complications  and patient education regarding lifestyle modification  signs of potential complications  and medication compliance. Further potential scenarios could involve discussions on outpatient treatment feasibility  selection of anticoagulant therapy  and the approach to thrombophilia testing.
